game-hours: 330.2
review: If you love RPGs. This is a must have. If you hate RPGs. This is a must have.
game-hours: 843.1
review: I am perfectly comfortable in saying that The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is by far the best game that I have ever played. The combat is familiar but still keeps things fresh to differentiate itself from previous Elder Scrolls titles. By current standards, the graphics and character models may seem a bit muddy, though this can be fixed by one of Skyrim's strongest features, its amazing mod support and community. While the base game of Skyrim itself can keep most players busy for a few hundred hours, mods add hundreds more, and with DLC-worthy mods such as Falskaar and the Skywind Project, the game seems as though there is no end. Gameplay aside, the lore and quests in this game don't offer as much freedom as Morrowind or Oblivion, but don't tie you down enough to where you feel like you're being forced to make a certain decision. The game offers the player a lot of freedom, as all side quests in the game can be completed as long as the player has obtained the power of the Thu'um, and that's another great feature all together. The Thu'um, or Shouts as the game more frequently refers to it as, is a power that the player (and a few other important characters) possesses that allows him or her to use their own voice to pretty much annihilate the enemy. There are more than 20 different Shouts in the base game, with the DLCs adding even more, and each one is uniquely different than the next, so the player doesn't feel like they're just getting an alternate version of the same power each time. A few other small things to mention is the simplified Level Up menu that allows your character to distribute stat points and perks without having to find somewhere to sleep and the amazing character customization. Honestly, there isn't much that I could find wrong with this game. And I'm pushing 800 hours of gameplay. So seriously, if you don't own Skyrim and you need to blow a few bucks, buy it. Trust me, you won't regret it. On a scale from 1 to 10, I think it's quite obvious at this point that the Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim receives a strong 10/10 from me.
game-hours: 146.9

The leveling system is incredibly unique and allows one to play exactly the type of fictional character they desire by completely ruling out having to choose a class. Without a doubt, this is personally my all-time favorite game.

review: I got Skyrim a while ago for my Xbox 360 and it is probably one of the best games I have ever played, and I didn't know it could get any better until I got it for PC. I'm typically one for playing a game with no cheats and no mods, but I gave one or two mods a little try and now I have my game modded out to the point I'd much rather live in my game than real life....minus the flying, fire breathing angry dragons of course! (And those oversized spiders can go too...) Without mods the game is still great, of course. I love that you can freely roam the world and do as you please. Be good, help people out, steal from them, cut their heads off, set everything on fire, start a large battle with an entire town... Good times, good times... Some of the quest lines for the guilds I felt could have lasted a lot longer, have more missions and be a bit more in-depth with a bigger storyline and maybe some more NPCs. And I do recommend the HD dlc if your computer is able to handle it, plus it is free and does add to the feel of the game a bit. And despite the prices I also feel that the DLC Dragonborn and Dawngaurd are worth getting as well (I don't have them yet for PC but I know they are enjoyable from my XBox 360 experience). Hearthfire is good too but if you are looking for more gameplay and quests it is best to go with the other two expansions. (Though Hearthfire is enjoyable...who doesn't want to build their own home and adopt some child you randomly find? Ok I hate kids but building a house was enjoyable.)

game-hours: 134.5
review: The Elder Scrolls are a strange bunch of games. In Skyrim, like Morrowind and Oblivion that proceeded it, you wonder around a huge open world, inhabited by wooden NPCs who all seem to utter the same phrases, in a voice you've heard several times before. You engage in clunky, repetitive combat and the main questline falls short of the Tolkienesque epic it could have been. But that's not quite what Skyrim is about. Skyrim is a huge world, intricately crafted and it's the little touches that make it amazing. It's finding a chest behind a waterful overlooking a beautiful landscape; Looking up from the ruins of an ancient underground city to see a crack of sunlight filtering through the rocks, illuminating the architecture of the lost race that once thrived there. Or maybe it's watching the corpse of an undead warrior smash its way out of a burial tomb, an aura of unholy magic nestled in those souless eyes. It's not the quests that make this game, they serve as an interesting motivator to get you out there exploring, the carrot on the end of an elven stick if you will. This game is about the unscripted moments and immersion in a land imbued with a rich mythological heritage. Skyrim never ceases to wow me and coupled with the mods available in the workshop and elsewhere, you could explore the land for weeks without finding half of whats to see. It's been on sale a few times in the last months and, even if you've played it on a console, with the graphics settings maxed out and a few mods to freshen the experience, Skyrim is a fantastic game with plenty more life left in it. It gets a huge thumbs up for me and I'd suggest anyone remotely interested gives it a go and sees for themselves why Skyrim players have racked up some of the longest playtimes for any Steam game, despite the lack of a multiplayer component. Rock on! It gets a huge thumbs up from me!

You can spend hours reading every book in the world and days exploring every inch of this world. If you are looking for an escape there are few places better to escape to.

game-hours: 390.3
review: This game will bind you to your PC and wont let you go for a long long time. The Main Story-line is good, solid, and befitting of the Elder Scrolls. Some complain that it is nothing special, which might be true it is nothing totally new. But one has to consider that most things seem to have been there at one point or another. Instead of laying the focus on innovation I rather put it on how the story is delivered. The Story unfolds depending on your playstyle, you can have it unfold right into your face if you rush ahead. But you could also spend days or weeks in the game and barely scratch the surface of the Storyline. There is a lot to do in Skyrim, a seemingly endless amount of side-quests offer diversion and immersion into the Lore of TES ( The Elder Scrolls ). Besides delving deeper into the TES universe that way, one will also be rewarded with Coin, magical Weapons, Ancient armor and more. The Combat System is not overly complex but offers enough freedom for creative approaches. Especially on higher difficulties, or through mods, combat can be quite challenging and rewarding. Freedom of choice regarding Weapons and Magic add to the diversion of the combat system. Playstyle changes accordingly to ones choice of Weapon and Profession. The Visuals of the game are good and the design of the world appears Epical. Granted the basic Graphic was not spectacular but through the means of a free DLC it got much sharper. There is also the option of visually modding the game, the results are simply stunning. The Sound is bombastic, it adds to the immersion, the music is putting one in the right mood and underlines the fantasy setting. The Graphical User Interface is clearly a console Port, but it is managable. The game has a very active mod community, especially on the Nexus. One can drastically enhance or change the game there and replay it countless times. Each DLC adds greatly to the game as well, adding new content, options and storylines. The game definately has flaws, logical ones, some bugs, but they are not game breaking. The saying " perfection is made by flaws " fits, in regards of the mod community, very well here. Many a flaw inspired a modder to contribute to the game turning a semi rough diamond into a gem to behold. If you like freedom of choice, action, a nice story, immersion and exploring then you should not miss this milestone in game History.

game-hours: 138.3
review: So I bought this game in Christmas of '11 origionally as a gift for someone else (for the Xbox 360). He had already owned a copy and I didn't know it. As a result I took this game and gave him another one from my stash, which I believe was the newest Call of Duty (MW3?). Let me begin my actual review by stating this was my first Elder Scrolls game, and it got me so hooked that I own every game in the series and am beta testing ESO. I Love This Game. So when I got into it on the Xbox, the first thing i noticed was the possibilities of doing whatever you wanted. It hooked me with a narrowly avoided decapitation, and then the evasion of a dragon, going through Helegan Keep, and thats where the magic happened, both literally and figuratively. Haadvar gave me countless posibilities to get through just the first quest. Magic, Two handed weapons, Dual Weild, Shield and sword, bows, and even subcategories in between (Sword swings faster than warhammer, but sacrifices power). Then comes the choice between nice, enchanted robes, quick and light Light Armour, or slow but strong heavy armour. And that is just the first thirty minutes. Once you really get into the game with quests and what not, you have tons mre options. You can do short, sweet, and simple Miscelaneous Objectives, Side Quests which are a bit longer, but with a greater reward, or Main Quests, which are usually long, but add the most to your experience and give you the best loot. I could go on for hours about everything you could possibly do in this game, but the sad part is that I have hardly scratched the surface. On the 360, I have 1,271 hours, PS3 I have 767, and on the PC I have a good 312 hours (most are offline because I am rarely home lately, which is why I started PC gamming in the first place). The moral of the story is not that I have no life, just I choose to do what I love with my life, and Skyrim is just that thing.

game-hours: 253.7
review: The continuation of the excellent Morrowind and Oblivion, Skyrim streamlines many of the biggest complaints fans had from those games (the obtuse and painful levelling systems among them) and continues the experience of the biggest open-world fantasy RPGs ever made. Like the previous games, you're going to want to get the Unofficial Community Patches (Google it) to fix some of the more glaring issues, and the modding community is huge. Much like the previous games, Skyrim also suffers from some lack of depth; the consequences of player actions are limited in overall scope, which is unfortunate. This is similar to other bethesda games, including The Elder Scrolls and Fallout franchises. Ultimately, depth gets somewhat sacrificed for the huge scope and freedom of the game. That said, Skyrim is still an amazing experience that any fan of RPGs of any kind should strongly consider playing. The 'lack of depth' critique only holds true in comparison to other fairly linear RPGs (Deus Ex franchise, Mass Effect, Witcher, etc) and should not be taken as a negative so much as something Bethesda needs to work on going forward.
game-hours: 1355.8
review: This was my first Elder Scrolls game. I hesitated to start it because just getting involved with it seemed like a monumental task, but I felt obligated to try it out and see what all the fuss was about. I'm very glad I did. The game is very very well done. The art is beautiful, the stories are interesting, the lore is worth exploring and the gameplay is engaging. There are many ways to play this game, and before I move on, I will have tried many of them. But because of the huge mod support that it has, ranging from simple to staggeringly complex in practically any direction you wish to take it, I will have only scratched the surface of its possibilities. I very much look forward to experiencing more of this studio's fine work in the future. Here are a few suggestions to those who wish to play the game at it's best. 1. Google the skyrim nexus and download their mod installer for the game. 2. Search the site for and install all the "unoffical patches" that you need for your level of downloaded content. This kills all the meaningful bugs that are present in the game. There are a few noticable ones that while they don't completely ruin the game experience, if you are OCD at all as I am, they will irritate you. There are some broken quests and a few other glitches that the studio never fixed and are unlikely ever to at this point, but the mod community has done it for them. 3. Don't try and do everything with a single character. The game is huge and there are hours of things to do and many decisions to make that will drag you in different directions. Making some of the decisions vastly change how the rest of the game plays out. Try and stay true to what your character would do and I think you'll really be happy you did later. 4. Try not to use cheats or game breaking mods. You're really going to hurt your game experience and butcher any challenge that the game presents. This game scales with your level so there really are ways to beat whatever you're up against at almost any level. If something is too hard, go do something else and come back to that particular challenge later after you've gotten more powerful. Enjoy folks, this is a great one.

game-hours: 46.5
review: Just when you think you've had your fill of Skyrim, something incredible happens. You come back. I'm not talking about testing the waters as we've all done in Runescape or Guild Wars 2 or World of Warcraft. This is a more genuine feeling. It's not a toe dip for holiday events. Every few months I'll take a look at Skyrim and see something new to like. A new mod(or 4), DLC I haven't played, a better appreciation for playstyles or races I've shunned; and then once I'm there, I find new content or experience it in a completely new way. This time, the simplest of things. In Skyrim, a game seemingly half-constructed by the community playing it, one tiny tweak has revived the entire experience all over again - the removal of the HUD. That's it's wonderful draw, that's why Skyrim is timeless. There's enough here that it never feels bland, unless you want it to be. Skyrim is a game where, the more you want to enjoy it, the more option you have to and the more you *do* enjoy it. New mods that fulfill a Magestyle with a full complement of interesting effects, new weapons, more NPCs, in-game achievements that affect your character, redefined skill trees. If there was ever a game worthy of mods, it's Skyrim, and the community has put so much wonderful effort into it. But after you've gotten everything to your liking, it's the GAME that allows for all of this customizable enjoyment. The developers released the tools, and we've been off to the races ever since. Moreso than my sweetheart Payday 2, or really any experience you don't craft yourself, Skyrim will get YOUR fantasy. Immersive, modular, and plain out one of the most reliably enjoyable games ever made. Skyrim is a real winner and worthy of your shelf/library.

review: JUST AMAZING
game-hours: 463.8
review: This game is great for the PC gamer because of the extensive list of mods in the workshop on steam. The game itself is great, DLC or not. If you take advantage of the Steam Workshop, and use mods, you can vastly expand your player options. I love this game. I am glad I fianlly picked it up. My first impressions of the game were that it was a medeviel version of the fallout games, and that didn't appeal to me at all. So it was a long time before I finally got it. Everyone told me they had similar impressions but were very suprised to see that wasn't the case. There are several different races you can play that alter your playing experience and character interactions. You can customise you characters looks, including dirt, warpaint, complexion, etc. There are numerous armor and weapons to make your character as unique as you like. The map is extensive and every location offers you some for on quest or interation. Unlike similar games like Fallout, once you complete the main question you just keep going, it doesn't end. You can constantly improve on your skills to get better and stronger. The homes, villages, and landscaping is beautifully designed. All of the aspects of the game are great, however you can improve and expand it tenfold through the use of Steam Workshop mods. A must have for all pc RPGers.

And I played this unmodded. With the rediculous amount of mods out there, you could continue to play this game until Half-Life 3 finally comes out. Skyrim offers everything I would ever need in a game: Exploration, adventure, customization, excessive item hoarding (optional), entire weeks disappearing, replayability, and so much more. I've sunk so many hours into this game and I've enjoyed every second of it.

review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim has taken away DAYS of my life. With so many characters to interact with, and most of them giving quests, the game is hard to get bored of. The province of Skyrim is a vast land waiting for you to explore every last corner, find every last septim, and kill every last dragon. As a role playing game it is fantastic, with a major questline for each player to purchase it. For example, if you want to be a hero then join either the Companions or the College of Winterhold, but it doesn't stop there, if you want to use combat join the Companions. For magic, join the College. You also have the standard 10 Elder Scrolls races (Argonian, Altmer, Breton, Dunmer, Imperial, Khajiit, Nord, Orc, Redguard, and Bosmer) that each have different starting stats and abilities. The combat in Skyrim isn't the best. The weapons are varied and can fit different playing styles, but when you hit something it just seems like you're wacking something with a sword until it falls over and dies. You can't tell that your even hurting it without it's health bar, but it's not the worst combat. Finally, the story. For me, the story was definitely NOT the best part of the game. It was pretty simple, basically you're the "chosen one" and you go on an adventure where more people tell you that you're the chosen one, and then for some reason you need to find an Elder Scroll, and then more boring stuff. This was why I stayed away from the main questline. Overall Skyrim is fantastic and definitely is worth your time. I give it a 4.7/5

review: An epic game made all the more epic by the fact that it is so easy to mod and so well supported by the modding community. The Elder Scrolls series has a large following and often you will hear people argue over each new TES game comparing it to the last, but for me each TES game stands on its own merits, and Skyrim is no exception. The story is pretty good and there are plenty of side quests, but what makes Skyrim so great even when not modded is its large and open nature. This is a land you can just pick a direction and with no quest in mind and just explore. You will find danger and excitement on your journey ... and loot. Lots and lots of loot. But once you start modding this game, that is when you unlock the true value that is Skyrim. Potentially thousands more hours content (for free) in a game that can be improved ten thousand different ways from graphics, textures and sounds all the way to game mechanics and user interface changes. You can make the game exactly what you need it to be, and play it for so long you may still be playing when the next game in this series comes out.... and sometimes longer than even that. If you are interested in modding the PC version of the game, be sure to check out my guide for beginners:

game-hours: 92.5
review: I was stacking books on a shelf in my house in Whiterun, one of Skyrim's major cities, when I noticed a weapon rack right beside it. I set a sacrificial dagger in one slot, an Orcish mace in the other. They were on display for nobody but me and my computer-controlled housecarl, Lydia, who sat at a table patiently waiting for me to ask her to go questing. The chest upstairs was reserved for excess weapons and armor, the bedside table for smithing ingots and ores, the one next to the Alchemy table for ingredients. I'd meticulously organized my owned virtual property not because I had to, but because tending to the minutia of domestic life is a comforting break from dealing with screaming frost trolls, dragons, a civil war, and job assignments that never seem to go as planned. It's even a sensible thing to do; a seemingly natural component of every day existence in Skyrim, one of the most fully-realized, easily enjoyable, and utterly engrossing role-playing games ever made. Part of what makes it so enjoyable has to do with how legacy Elder Scrolls clutter has been condensed and in some cases eliminated. In Skyrim, there's no more moon-hopping between hilltops with a maxed out Acrobatics skill. That's gone, so is Athletics. The Elder Scrolls V pares down the amount of skills and cuts out attributes like Endurance and Intelligence altogether. There's no time wasted on the character creation screen agonizing over which skills to assign as major. You don't assign major and minor skills at all, but instead pick one of ten races, each with a specific bonus. High Elves can once a day regenerate magicka quickly, Orcs can enter a berserk rage for more effective close-range combat. These abilities are best paired with certain character builds  the High Elf regeneration is useful for a magic user  but don't represent a rigid class choice. Major decisions don't need to be made until you're already out in the world and can try out magic, sneaking and weapon combat, emphasizing first-hand experience over instruction manual study, letting you specialize only when you're ready. It contributes to the thrilling sense of freedom associated with life in Skyrim. Do a quest, kill a dragon, snatch torchbugs from the air, munch on butterfly wings or simply wander while listening to one of the best game soundtracks in recent memory. Despite the enormity of the world and the colossal amount of content contained within, little feels random and useless. Even chewing on a butterfly wing has purpose, as it reveals one of several alchemical parameters later useful in potion making at an alchemy table. Mined ore and scraps of metal from Dwemer ruins can be smelted into ingots and fashioned into armor sets, pelts lifted from slain wildlife can be turned into leather armor sets, and random books plucked from ancient ruins can trigger hidden quest lines that lead to valuable rewards. Skyrim's land mass is absolutely stuffed with content and curiosities, making every step you take, even if it's through what seems like total wilderness, an exciting one, as something unexpected often lies just over the next ridge. Many times the unexpected takes the form of a dragon. Sometimes they're purposefully placed to guard relics, sometimes they swoop over cities and attack at seemingly random times. In the middle of a fight against a camp of bandits a dragon might strike, screaming through the sky and searing foe and friendly alike with frost or flame. Momentarily all on the battlefield unite, directing arrows and magic blasts upward to knock down the creature, creating impromptu moments of camaraderie -- a surprising change from what may have been yet another by-the-numbers bandit camp sweep. Dragons show up often, their presence announced by an ominous flap of broad wings or an otherworldly scream from high above. The scale and startling detail built into each creature's appearance and animations as it circles, stops to attack, circles again and slams to the ground makes encounters thrilling, though their predictable attack patterns lessen the excitement after a few battles. In the long run they're far less irritating than the Oblivion gate equivalent from The Elder Scrolls IV, can be completed in a few minutes, and always offer a useful reward. Killing a dragon yields a soul, which powers Skyrim's new Shout system. These are magical abilities any character can use, you don't have to specialize in spell casting to slow time, throw your voice, change the weather, call in allies, blast out ice and fire, or knock back enemies with a rolling wave of pure force. Even if you favor sword, shield and heavy armor and ignore magic entirely, you'll still be able to take full advantage of these abilities provided you find the proper words  each Shout has three  hidden on Skyrim's high snowy peaks and in the depths of forgotten dungeons, serving as another reason to continue exploring long after you've exhausted the main quest story, joined with the Thieves Guild, fought alongside the Dark Brotherhood, or thrown your support behind one of the factions vying for control of Skyrim. Not only is this land under assault by dragons, long thought to be dead, it's also ripped in two by civil war. You can choose one side or the other, but so much of the allure of Skyrim is how, even outside of the confines of quest lines, the embattled state of the world is evident, and steeped in a rich fictional legacy. Lord of the Rings this is not, but with the release of every Elder Scrolls game, the fiction becomes denser, and the cross-referencing for long-time fans all the more rewarding. Skyrim's residents are all aware of current events. They'll comment on the civil war, some sympathizing with the rebels, others thinking the establishment sold its soul. The peasants complain about the Jarls who control each settlement, the Jarls complain about the rebels or foreign policy, the overprotective College librarian complains when I drop dragon scales all over his floor; many characters feel like whole, distinct personalities instead of vacuous nothings that hand out quests like a downtown greeter hands out flyers for discount jeans. Characters stereotype based on race, they double-cross at even the slightest hint it might be profitable, and they react to your evolving stature within the world. It makes a ridiculous realm, filled with computer-controlled cat people and humanoid reptiles, demon gods and dragons, feel authentic, like a world that existed long before you showed up and will continue to exist long after you leave.

review: Skyrim is not game of the year , Skyrim is game of the decade. Perhaps the single most non-linear game with a beautiful open world and dynamic settings where you can almost literally go and do anything you please, Skyrim was my first experience with The Elder scrolls series , I had got it as a Christmas gift in 2011 for the PS3 , I managed to log well over 800 hours of game play ,always starting a new game after hitting level 50ish .also got all three DLCs (Dragonborn) (Dawnguard) (Hearthfire) after they become non exclusive (still sort of pissed about that one ) and that added another 100 or so hours of game play . But even so, eventually the grind catches on , i had done the whole story , every side quest and nearly every radiant that you can think of several times over , it would be a safe guess to say that I had done the story nearly 20 times , and so after my love of skyrim died I turned to Oblivion ( and eventually getting well over 200 hours of gameplay ) . and then Steam puts Skyrim Legendary edition on sale (from what i can remember it was 25 % off ) and so after playing it on a console for the past few years, and always wanting to be able to mod it , I grabbed it on steam , and the love for it found me again, after finding a few wonderful mods here on the workshop I found myself wrapped in it again , and while the story line is pretty much the same (aside from a few mods) , the ability to add and take away elements from this game makes it all worth while again . so would I recommend Skyrim to You ?, most probably, if you like playing games that utilize critical thinking skills , and if you like open world RPGs , and if you have somewhat of an Imagination , then yes I would .

review: First there was life, then came Skyrim. It took some 500 hours of play for me to actively need to seek out new and interesting things to do, which is saying something. The main storyline is somewhat quickly over if you don't explore the world for 20+ levels before getting to it, but even after it, there's hundreds of locations to explore and small, interesting little quests to do and characters to meet. The graphics are gorgeous even with a disappointingly generic graphics card (such as mine) if you're willing to do a little research and tweak the settings. All in all, more than worth the money I put into it. (One little thing: if you're an archer at heart, I suggest you tweak the settings in the .ini file to lose the arrows that disappear into thin air instead of hitting targets at a greater distance, and also to adjust the aim.)

review: I'm not sure how mere words could possibly form a summation for my adoration and the enjoyment I've found in Skyrim. This game had provided me with a plethora of fond memories from my adventures in the snowy province. With countless quests and interactions, there's hardly a dull moment in the robust life of a dovahkiin. Now, of course there's the occasional bugs and glitches. I won't deny that I've experienced my fair share of these, all varying from amusing, annoying, and/or frustrating. But that's an incredibly meager price to pay for the vast immersion I recieved when I was dropped into the culturally rich, lore-filled world of Nirn once again. Truly, there's something in Skyrim for everyone. Even when the gameplay ceased to amuse me, the world and its' people continues to enthrall me. I'm no stranger to Tamriel, and I intend to stay here for a long, long time.

review: This game is still incredible, even 2 years after release. At the time of writing this, I have 392 hours clocked, and I do not intend to stop any time soon. Skyrim let's you be who you want to be; a heroic warrior, an evil assassin, a greedy theif, a powerful mage. With it's class-free open ended skill system there are so many different playstyles available. Another advantage of this game is the amazing and still active modding community, giving the game near unlimited replay value. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys RPG's, or just open-world games in general. It also has dragons, in case you needed any more convincing.

game-hours: 33.6
review: Wonderful modding community and pretty good story.
game-hours: 717.3
review: Skyrim is the best PC game I've played in a while. I used to have Elder Scrolls #2: Daggerfall, then #3: Morrowind, and now #5: Skyrim. Around every corner opf this game, there is a new thing to discover, whether that be an awesome new weapon, a powerful monster with some awesome loot, or even a brand new "Thu'um," or powerful shout that causes a change in the behavior of other beings, or just does damage. You are the "Dragonborn" a being who can permanently kill a dragon by devouring it's soul, whose destiny lies in the eldest dragon, Alduin, who wishes to control all of Tamriel. You were born to destroy Alduin and kill all of his resurrected dragon army. Every dungeon and cave in this game was hand-crafted by the developers. Whether you decide to strictly follow the main questline, or do whatever you want, your quest log within a few hours or even minutes of gameplay, will have dozens of side quests and miscellaneous (not sure if I spelled that right, lol) quests that are very fun to complete. My favorite part of this game though, by far is the customization options and different races that you can choose to be. Every race has different stats that could be better or worse than any other races' stats. For instance, an Imperial finds more gold in more places than a nord in the same places. An Orc has more of a blacksmithing skill than a Nord. The world is aslo very VERY organic. For example, one particular quest for a great sword is gained by reading a book, and completed by defeating "The Red Eagle," an ancient warrior who could destroy entire armies with his master blade. There is also a lot of DLC that has come out for this game, like Dawnguard, which is based off the ideal that the vampires are coming back to take control of Skyrim and you are either on their side of evil, or against them, on the side of the Dawnguard, who are vampire hunters. Another DLC, Dragonborn, revolves around the first Dragonborn who wants you dead because he does not beleive that you are truly dragonborn. Overall, this game is truly enthralling in its complex but simple gameplay mechanics and physics engine. This game on a scale of 912038098 monkey butts, this game get a full, legendary 912038098 out of 912038098.

review: The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim is one of THE best games i have ever played. It contains everything a basic human needs: Food, sleeping, and murdering. This game get's clawww's personal 10/10!
game-hours: 174.3
review: How to begin? I started playing skyrim on xbox 360 back in 2011 christmas when I was still a console peasant, and boy did I not see the sunlight ever again, massive huge world, so much to do, never bored whatsoever, the storyline is average to good, not as immersive and gripping as oblivion, but to make up for it is the multiple dialogue choices you can choose during this, compared to Oblivion with limited answers. The graphics are awesome too, they have slightly looked a little worse as time went by and advancements have been made, but with a few mods on pc, in which I got skyrim in early 2013, its very worth it, there is also so much playback value with the side quests and the character specialities, such as mage, thief and warrior, or even a hybrid of those classes. However the few downsides I have seen is its really poor engine and its LOD, and how the water on the game looks so crap in the distance, and also how it is quite badly optimized, so even the beefiest of rigs will kneel before having an ENB mod or something in that nature. Overall, my favourite ES game in the series, basically tied with Oblivion. Such an engrossing and amazing game, truly. So excited for ES6, these games never fail to make me not sleep at night with the excitement of it's release.

review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is the latest installment of the Elder Scrolls Series. It places you in the role of the legendary "dragonborn" who is the only person capable of stopping the dragons from conquering the world of Tamriel. While you could follow the main story and have a good time, the strenght of the game is in its vast land. The game features hundreds of quests and adventures which are only improved upon in the DLC's. Although some may get tired of the generally simple formula of the game, the mods available on the steam workshop and the Nexus make this game have nearly infinite replay value. I'd recommend this to both casual players and long time RPG fans

review: Skyrim one of the best Elder Scrolls games if not the best game in the series. Skyrim is an outstanding game with immersive visuals and atmosphere. The music that plays during night and day and even the music when exploring dungeons and Nordic Ruins really sets the atmosphere. Skyrim's graphics are amazing especially with the free high resolution texture pack installed. Now enough of that lets get on to the story. Skyrims story is amazing and is very immersive. it goes from slaying Dragons, to fighting the undead nords of skyrim known as Draugr. Bethesda has put an amazing back story for almost every quests and creature in the game. Skyrim will have its amazing Storyline to the occasional side quest such as visiting the college of winterhold and joining the imperial legion. One of my favourite side quests (and im sure most players will agree with me) is the companions. but in the end it has an amazing twist. but thats something you'll have to find out yourself. Overall skyrim is one of the most amazing video games i have ever had the pleasure of experiencing 10/10-Silver Reviews

review: I think myself and most of the rest of the world would recommend this game... lol. But no, seriously, I took a first look at this game, and said, "Nope... never gonna' get me to play that." Then my friend told me how good it was, and let me borrow it... and then I just HAD to buy it. If you haven't played it- you will love it. I don't think it matters if you're an RPG, FPS, RTS, or whatnot, I'm pretty sure there's something for everyone in this game, the puzzles, the small stories, the quests... and it's such a HUGE map, you can play this thing a few times, and still see different things each time. Just a tip though, make sure you install at least the HD textures before you play, the graphics are a little dated. Also, if you're a hardcore graphics person, youtube Gopher and his series on how to Mod Skyrim. If you haven't played it before, I wouldn't mod the gameplay at all- but feel free to mod the graphics systems to your hearts content! ENB makes EVERYTHING look so amazing in this game- the stars and the nightsky look so realistic, as well as the shadows and the direction lighting system.

game-hours: 150.4

game-hours: 222.7
review: One of the finest games I've ever had the privilege of playing. + Nearly infinite replayability: Since the game's release there have been countless mods to recreate and reimagine the storyline to suit all manner of playstyles and imaginations, it's one of this games greatest strengths in that you can be anyone and do anything in a world that not only feels alive but reacts to you + Beauty worthy of conversation: There are parts of Skyrim that are so undeniably beautiful that you may find yourself sight seeing equally as much as you'll find yourself slaying dragons and trolls, after my initial playthrough there were landmarks that I couldn't help but travel back to just to explore and see them once more I would struggle to name a game with more artistic beauty than Skyrim. + Variety of gameplay: Want to go cave diving? Go cave diving. Want to go exploring a set of Dwarven ruins? Go explore them. Want to hunt dragons? Hunt dragons. Want to go on a merciless killing spree slaying anything that sets foot in front of you? To each there own. There are TONS of things you can do in Skyrim far more than I can describe in this review. + Wonderful character creation: I don't know why but I've always loved character creation something about being able to customize my character to look like what I imagine them to look like, Skyrim has what is arguably one of the most robust character creation systems ever made allowing you to craft every individual proportion down to minute details. + Mods mods MODS: If you can imagine it chances are someone has made a mod for it, Skyrim probably has the largest mod community of any game ever made whether it be the Steam workshop or the Nexus mod community there are mods for everything better textures, better lighting, new weapons, new missions, new areas, new armor, new NPCs, new companions, Skyrim's modability has allowed it to become something most every other game available today could never be which is EXCACTLY what you want it to be regardless of who you are, if you don't like something just change it. + DLC that is actually worth the price: SO many games on the market today have useless DLC whether it be DLC to change the color of your character's shirt or DLC for 'horse armor' they always just end up feeling like cash-ins, Skyrim's DLC adds whole questlines, new characters, new threats, and one DLC even goes as far to add a whole island that allows you to reexplore a previous Elder Scrolls game. + INSANE amount of lore: If you like having mythology and lore in your games then Skyrim is definitely for you there are hundreds of books that help expand the universe well beyond the scope of an average playthrough. - No multiplayer: There hasn't been an Elder Scrolls game to date that has had multiplayer and while Skyrim holds it's own perfectly well without it I would be lying if I didn't say exploring the game with someone else would be even more amazing. - Do you have friends/family?: I've sank well over two hundred hours into this game when you combine my PC time with my Xbox 360 gametime and I still feel like I've barely scratched the surface Skyrim is a wonderful game but there's no denying that it's a major time sink if you're anything like me once you've played the game you won't really want to leave for a while which can't bode well for any kind of social existence. This game is great and is a shining example of what a serious, devoted, talented team of developers can come up with and it should be held as a standard of what consumers should expect of their products in the gaming industry. 10/10 Reasonable Price Point: You can purchase the game and all of it's DLC for around $50 to $60 USD these days even less if you find it on sale if I were forced to purchase it again I would gladly pay $60+.
game-hours: 224.7
review: *English Version below. Keep in mind, that I'm not that good at speaking English, but I hope it's okay for you.* Gleich vorweg einmal alle meine Kritikpunkte an Skyrim: -Das Kampfsystem ist irgendwie schon frn den , es fhlt sich einfach nicht wirklich toll und packend an, auer Bogenschieen, das ist doch recht gelungen, auch wenn ich ein "richtiges" Zielsystem hier bevorzugen wrde. -Bethesda hatte nur eine Hand voll von Synchronsprechern, weshalb sich jeder 3. irgendwie gleich anhrt. -Es gibt keine wirkliche Gegnervielfalt -Das Skillsystem ist ganz ok, aber manche Bume sind zu wichtig, selbst, wenn man gar keine solche Klasse spielt (wie vor allem Bogenschieen) -Die Ausrstung entscheidet hauptschlich, wie gut ein Charakter ist. Als schwerer Rstungstrger mit Schild und Einhandschwert ist es beispielsweise viel leichter zu Spielen auf Meister und Legendr als als Schleicher-Typ, Fernkmpfer oder Magier. -Die Mainquest ist ziemlich langweilig, berraschungen gibt es kaum. -Die tollen unendlichen Quests sind irgendwie auch immer das Selbe (hol mir das und mach den kalt, wie bei MMOs halt.) -Viele Nebenquests haben nur selten gute Storys, obwohl sie meistens echt angebracht wren. -Die Bewegungen der Figuren sind extremst hlzern! Wer nun denkt, Skyrim ist scheie: FALSCH GEDACHT! Der wichtigste Punkt zuerst: Bei einem Fantasy-Rollenspiel ist das wichtigste die Atmosphre. Die Welt muss sich einfach anfhlen, als ob sie frher schon einmal genau so oder zumindest sehr hnlich existiert hat, und das tut sie in Skyrim. Man fhlt sich wie ein paar Jahrhunderte in eine fiktive Welt zurckversetzt, und das ist eines der besten Gefhle in einem Spiel: Wenn die Atmosphre bewirkt, dass man sich fhlt, als ob man IM Spiel wre. Auerdem ist die Grafik toll und das Open-World-Feature ist auch klasse, auch wenn jede Hhle von innen irgendwie gleich aussieht. Trotzdem macht das erkunden von ihnen Spa. Mir persnlich macht Skyrim einen RIESEN Spa, auch wenn es doch einige Negativpunkte hat, die das Gesamterlebnis fr mich trben. ********** Starting with all my points of criticism: -The combat-system is not that good, it doesn't feel great or anything, except archery, which is quite good, but I'd personally prefere a real target system. -Every 3rd person in this game sounds the same! Feels like Bethesda hadn't had much voice actors... -No real variety of opponents -The skilling system is ok, but some trees are to important, even if you don't play that kind of class (especially archery) -The gear is the most important thing when it comes to good or awesomely good characters. If you play with heavy armor you're WAY harder to kill than if you play as the sneaky guy, as a ranger or as a mage, especially on the difficulties "master" and "legendary". -The main quest is very boring, there are barely any surprises. -The oh-my-god-so-great infinite quests are the same every time (get me item a or kill person b, just like it is in most MMOs.) -Most side missions have no good stories, even though they would be really reasonable. -The movement of all the characters and NPCs is extremely wooden! There are pretty sure some of you thinking now that Skyrim is not a good game, but no, THAT'S NOT THE CASE! The most important point first: The most important thing about a fantasy-rpg is the atmosphere. The world has to feel, like if it excisted a long time ago, and that's what the atmosphere in Skyrim does. You feel like if you're in a fictionary world a few centuries earlier and that's one of the best feelings a game can cause: You feel, like you're really IN the game! Additionally, the graphics are nice for a open world game, altough the caves don't differ a lot. Nevertheless, it's always fun to explore them. In my case, Skyrim is a game that I really enjoy, altough there are some negative things about it.

game-hours: 194.7
review: It's massive. Vanilla story alone will take you 100+ hours to complete, not to mention DLCs. The good: The mechanics are solid, the gameplay is smooth, the scenery is gorgeous, and mods make it even better. The bad: The magic leaves a lot to be desired, it's clunky, the menus are primitive, and you can spend more time scrolling then you do shooting. (Mods recommended to alleviate this) The ugly: It seems that a team of maybe 20 total voice actors voiced about 1500 people in the game, I'm used to some overlap, but hearing the same guy's voice (not disguised or changed in any way) on three different people in the same town of 20 people is a little annoying. Conclusion: Annoyances aside, it's an incredible game with a rich story and the mods will produce more content then you'll ever be able to play in your lifetime. This game will eat your life, and you will love it.

review: One of the greatest rpg games ever to bless the gaming community. Skyrim is full to the brim with quests, loot, murder and free will. Don't like that old woman sitting outside her house? stab her in the face, but be ready to fight the onslaught of guards coming your way! being able to make choices about anything is always great, no more are you restricted by boundaries, you can kill that character you always hated, stab that lizard man that looked at you funny on the street, its all up to you. I have too much to say about this game in one review, so i will keep it short. BUY THIS GAME! you will not regret it, full customisation of your character and what gear he/she uses, hundreds of weapons, armour, spells ECT ECT i could go on for hours. game-hours: 292.2
review: Ok so I'll get straight to the point. Everybody loves Skyrim. It can be a true sandbox game where you can literally do youre own thing. Lets say you want to play a thief but only on your off time, thewn you can go join the thieves guild and not complete any of the story missions, just take bonus jobs and complete them for a good bit of cash. The game keeps the targets and other details very random so despite being similar objectives every time, you do get a flavour of diversity. So yes well done Bethesda etc, did a good job. hundreds of hours of gameplay and plenty of things to play around with. Only two critisisms I have are that going ruin exploring is still too repetative. Go in, fight undead, unlock doors and get throuugh traps. It gets predictable. They did a great job on making most of the dungeons have something unique about them, but I would have liked to see something really different every now and then. Secondly I dont think theres enough diversity in the creatures you come across. The different types of animals were done well, no issues there, but with monsters, well theres trolls, dragons, undead, chaurus, giants, ice wraiths and the odd summoned elemental here and there. The DLC adds a few more but the encounters just arent varied enough I think. One last bit which I think they probably considered but didnt add in, is a race based skill tree. Each of the races could have had a skill tree so that playing a race becomes more varied and exciting than just start skills, a few dialogue changes and a few powers. There we go, rant over. Still love the game and keep playing it. Its damn good, if you dont own it, then go own it. Simples

review: Skyrim is arguably Bethesda's best game I've seen yet. The graphics are stunning and the storyline is far better than any of the previous Elder Scrolls or Fallout games they have made. Glitches aside, this game is definitely worth the money. You'll get to experience a vast and in depth world filled with all sorts of creatures. On top of all this, there are so many mods to make the game something new or even make the game even more beautiful. The incredible number of mods will allow you to keep playing the game in new ways for quite some time and will definitely give you your money's worth.

review: 10/10 This is the greatest game I have ever played in my life. There are endless possiblilities and you can build your character however you want. I've had about 7 full play throughs. My favorite build has been sneak assassin in conjunction with alteration spells. I have still yet to explore all the clever ways to gear your character. game-hours: 166.0
review: Well, it is an Elder Scrolls game and due to the fact that i watched my dad playing Daggerfall when i was a little cub this is something that is almost melded to my body. The Elder Scrolls games where an essential part of my life in the way that i read EVERY SINGLE BOOK INSIDE OF THE GAMES SINCE OBLIVION. Why did i do that? I really dont know it but what i know is that i know quite a lot about the Elder Scrolls Saga and so i feel like writing a review for this. Before i start i should say sorry because i will bring points up which may be a bit missleading, i really like the game in the state i have it in right now and am a complete Scrolls freak so i could counter every point of mine with the Argument that it is part of the Elder Scrolls. So where to start, maybe with the kind of game this is. This is if you would ask me a Sandbox game with RPG elements and not a fullblown RPG and this is why, the most characters in the game appear too onesided, there is almost nobody that questions his or her own actions and even if you can influence the country's politics and raise up in ranks it doesnt really matter. Well that doesnt make any sense Larker you might say now but let me describe what the difference is. If you usually proceed to a higher rank you feel proud because you accomplished something and this feeling isnt existant in Skyrim because these promotions fly in your direction and the reward almost feels casual. Skyrim is in some respectives an rpg, without any doubt but it just doesnt feel completely like it even though it fullfills one point which i will talk about in a second. The game has a good structure and the World is somewhat fascinating with many locations which are interesting enough to visit. There are some parts in it that are repetetive but its in a way that isnt annoying and that is quie an accomplishment if you consider the size of this world. The Quests are a bit more repetetive but i have to defend them because there arent that many things in a game like this that you could give as a quest. The Skill System is good and the shout system brings an interesting aspect into the game even if i have a bit of an argument with myself about it because i personally believe that a shout is entirely different from a bigger power and thus should be on an other button but well what do you wanna do. There are 2 giant problems though. 1. The writing and the story on its own is mostly just sloppy compared with games like oblivion, the characters feel dumb and the interaction is really basic, i understand that bethesda might have gone for a bigger audience and they succeeded but on the way they dumbed down the game quite hard. Interestingly enough are the facts that the books in the game hold more interesting writing than the characters speeches. It doesnt matter if you are an archmage or a Thane because for the guards those two things both are on the same level (They also are most of the times just annoying). The games tries to be a game and thats actually fine by me, if you consider that most Games that try to send a message these days only cause more problems. Though there is maybe and im really not sure about it, critique about politics in it. At the point where the two factions meet up it feels more like kindergarten than politics, but as i said im not sure if this is a critique made by the game developers that was made intentionally. 2. Some Career choices just arent viable on their own. It is unbelievably boring and hard to actually train some traits, like alchemy for example and even if you do they sometimes dont benefit you that much. I picked alchemy because it was quite recent that i made a Skyrim run with an alchemist. So you level up your alchemy but then you find out that brewing poisons and mixing potions on its own is somewhat useless, sure you could put it on your weapons and potions are always awesome but i imagine an alchemist as a mage not as a warrior. So what else could i do? Well you can obviously poison them not by weapons but by simply putting the poison in there bags, what do you need for that? Well another Trait so yay. You Basically have 5 ways to actually viably fight your fights, these are one handed, two handed, archery, destruction and conjuration. I cant completely say i didnt know that before the game came out but i really hoped that i would be able to go a path and dont have to leave it to actually be viable. Why would I hope such a thing? Well now we can talk about that point i spoke of before. Skyrim isnt a hardcore RPG because you arent forced into a character that socially develops and thus almost everything concerning your character happens in the players mind or happens not entirely. It is Roleplaying in its pure way or you arent roleplaying at all and you rather arent roleplaying because due to the few REAL decisions you are limited to the dumbed down format of the game which doesnt give you enough options to play freely, thank Meridia though that there is Mod support for the game which basically gives it an insane amount of replay value and fixes to play as you want. Pro: Beautiful and giant World, Mod Support, High Replay Value, Easy and smooth Story, (Elderscroooooooolls!!!!!!) Contra: Bad or Mediocre Writing, Bad for Roleplaying, Dumb Characters, Too small influence on the world Who should buy this game?: Well almost every person might try this gem, it is easy to start into rpg's with skyrim due to its simple format and can be lots of fun. However if this is your first RPG you might rather not buy it at a full price, if you already like rpg's and are up for a bit of 'sploring you should pick this game up at any time. Make sure that you always buy the legendary edition due to the bigger content and its cheaper to buy it like that, than all on its own. Also check out the Workshop for skyrim and maybe check out TheGreyLight, he made some amazing and useful mods. Sincerely, Lord Larker the Lurker

review: THIS GAME IS BEAST
game-hours: 184.6
review: Best RPG EVER!
game-hours: 128.5
review: Skyrim's about emergent experiences. It presents a sandbox, a MASSIVE one, and with a thousand and one things to do and places to see and tombs to plunder. They're all built around the same building blocks, so there is a strong sense of "seen this before" immediately followed by "ooh, but look how they changed it!" Best moment: In the hellish depths of a dwemer ruin, I'm plagued by the most vile Falmer. My companions are dead, these morlock-esque creatures want to eat me, and I will die in the dark with no one to mourn my little archer. I'm fighting for my life on a catwalk in an archery battle across a chasm. I dispatch all but the last of them, who's as close to death as I am, and when I reach for my quiver, I find it empty. He fires his arrow at me. I panic and Shout, forgetting entirely what spell I had equipped. The world slowed. Time stopped. The arrow crawling towards my face. Amazed, I plucked it out of the air, knocked it in my bow, and shot it right into the Falmer's face. I had no idea I could even do that.
game-hours: 337.8
review: The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim is a truly great game. This is my first Elder Scrolls game, but I really found myself immersed in this world compared to Bethesda's other titles, such as Fallout. Without mods, the game's still amazing. But if you want to improve your experience, skip to the bottom. Total: 8.2/10 (Note that this was my first review, and I'm not being biased. I mean, this IS my favorite game) Gameplay: 5/10 The controls are simple and easily understood. Has nice HUD, UI, etc. The difficulty... not so much. The dragons, were at first depicted to be "strong, deadly; only killable by the best of the best" yet, while in a town, a guard who's adventuring days were over because of a single arrow to the knee can easily kill a dragon. Once you reach level 30, you're practically unbeatable, even in the hardest difficulties. Story: 10/10 I loved the story, although I was never able to finish it. Spent 3,000 hours on it offline, but never got a chance to finish the story. You're a badass Dragonborn. The first one in centuries. Who wouldn't want that? To be able to learn the power and tongue of the dragons in a matter of seconds. Being the only person alive to be able to devour a dragon's soul. Your enemy is the son of a god. A world eater. Pretty cool eh? Well, I'll stop there. Playability: 7/10 It's just so replayable to the point where you can end up making several characters, and none of them are even past level 10. You can start out as a warrior, mastering heavy armory and weaponry. Or a Mage, using regular clothing but warding yourself in bound armor or using bound weaponry; even many different types of magic. Or a thief, sneaky and evasive. Focusing only on light armor and archery. It's very great and all, except Bethesda released the game 25% finished. It didn't have most of the things it currently has now, like fixed bugs, mounted combat, etc. The game was so broken, many players waited for patches before playing. Just like every Bethesda game: Lots of bugs. Many have been fixed by patches or the Unofficial Skyrim Patch :) Visuals: 9/10 Although not very high-end compared to most games, and the shadows are highly demanding despite the low details, it's still very appealing. ESPESCIALLY with Parallax, texture, and ENB mods. Sometimes, I'm fulled thinking I'm playing Crysis or BF3. But the lighting and shadows are noticably bad, which may break immersion. The "Ultra" Shadows are worse than BF3's low Shadows. Immersion: 10/10 Immerse yourself in the game with ease. The moddibility helps it be more and more immersive. With the right mods, you will feel as if you're truly living in the world of Skyrim... freezing in the cold regions, trying not to get drunk, etc. Wearing a hood in the rain... Things like that. Now, mods. Mods are great and all, but the more mods - The longer your startup will be. You'll need to use TES5Edit to fix incompatibilities. More mods - More conflicts. A friend took 3 days to clean his initial set up. Me? I don't care, as long as there's no CTDs or it runs well, I'll play. Mods I recommend, in order from top to bottom: Unofficial Patches. Get them accordingly, they will fix many many bugs in the game. Highly compatible with many. Requiem (Roleplay - A thousand times better, much more immersion... truly amazing mod.) Tytanis (Overhaul - Adds a lot of stuff that makes the game much better) Duel - Realist Combat (Fighting mechanics - Much better and realistic fighting.) SkyUI & iHud (Much better interface that will fit nicely into the game; more immersive HUD) ACE (Difficulty and skills overhaul. Will make the game a challenge) Tamriel Reloaded (Amazing Textures, I recommend to install Skyrim High Res DLC and Skyrim HD 2k first then installing this over it; pure parallax at its best) WATER (Much better water, truly jaw dropping with the right ENB) VFO (Stands for Vurts Flora Overhaul; better flora, will help immerse) EBT (Enhanced Blood Textures; adds wounds, cuts, etc. Makes battles look manlier.) Thunder Child (Overhauls the shout system; I've yet to try it because I'm already far ahead with several shouts (not really, just Fus) so I'm waiting until I start my female character) Warzones (NOTE: NEED A VERY POWERFUL PC. EVEN I CAN'T HANDLE IT. Okay, so. Skyrim - A land torn apart by war and usunder. Civil Unrest is everywhere, the Civil War rages through the land. -walks outside- Huh... no battle here. This mod adds the battles in dynamic locations. Even makes Civil War quests harder by adding nearby battles or patrols. Immerse yourself deeper into the world as 1,000+ NPCs are fighting each other) That's all I can do to keep this short. Enjoy your game :)

review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is a Action Adventure RPG which takes place in the fictional land of Skyrim You are the dragonborn, a human with a dragons soul destined to stop a powerful evil dragon named Alduin(the world eater) Now let's get real the plot is very weak and the game is full of bugs where any of them can destroy your safe file which can contain 100+ hours of playing. Gameplay wise it's mostly this: see something, whip out sword, run up to it, start hitting, ??? profit. The graphics looks good but if you got a powerful gaming setup i suggest downloading graphics mods which makes the game jaw dropping beautiful. Again plot wise it isn't very good, but then again a RPG is about creating a character and roaming the world with it and on that note Skyrim delivers. Exploring in this game is so much fun, you actually lose track of time a lot. I might be a bit harsh regarding the gameplay but it can be really boring at times if you choose a melee focused play style. But if you like magic the game is fun at almost all times. But what really impressed me was the soundtrack in-game. Whoever composed it is a absolutely genius. Once again Bethesda proves themselfs to be the king of soundtracks (Fallout 3/Fallout New Vegas) Presentation: 7.5 Graphics: 8.5 Sound: 10.0 Game-play: 8.0 Lasting Appeal: 9.0 Overall Rating: 9.5 While the gameplay can be rather stiff at some points the makes up for it with masive amounts of exploration and a fantastic soundtrack. Simply a must buy.

review: Time to recommend, what is probably the most hyped game I've ever played. First of all. It's good, that's all you need to really know. It is a good game. But it got some massive flaws. First time playing morrowind you will notice that it' got some of the best music you can come by, and some cool gameplay. Oblivion was so good I never stopped playing it, until I had made EVERY mission. This game, skyrim, is a bit of both. only real problem with it - it's extremly repetitive. Every mission (pretty much) is the other alike. It got some really cool graphics, finally some decent voiceacting and some good missions every now and then. The dragons that were so extremly hyped are a bust tho. They do NOT live up to their name. They are repetitive and boring. Which kinda kills the whole "dragonborn-plot" So wait for a sale, then buy it. you won't regret it. it's good, really good, just not AS good as it's precursors. game-hours: 43.5
review: Its Elder Scrolls....whats not to LOVE
game-hours: 229.7
review: Excellent RPG game. Best-in-class overworld exploration, loads of dungeons to explore and complete, and a slew of quests to go through including 5 faction questlines that you can run through (6 if you count both sides of the civil war questline). This game easily has 150 hours of content to your average player and much more to Elder Scrolls fans. While not retaining all of the RPG elements of it's predecessor, Skyrim is interesting in it's own way by characterizing all of the races individually, from the Scandinavian accents of the Nords to the Secluded Orcs, each race feels different like it actually belongs somewhere. It doesn't have the same attributes and skills system as Oblivion, but rather sets you out into the world and just lets you level up any skills that you want. While this is effective for a playthrough or two, I soon found myself running to the Steam Workshop to download some mods that give the game more of an RPG feel. While this could be found as a negative, I think that the fact that I was able to go to the workshop and essentially just fix the problem says a lot about the freedom that this game gives you. The Steam workshop gives you unlimited freedom to do whatever you could want to do to the game, from little mods that tweak the game to you liking to mini expansions with all-new locations and characters. This game isn't the best PC port, however. It doesn't let you turn off Vsync (a problem that is easily overlooked but still annoying) and you have to go into the .ini files of the game's directory to change the field of view. These are minor, nitpicky complaints but it would be nice if Bethesda put more effort into making the game a bit more playable with a mouse and keyboard on the PC. The worst offender of this is the UI, which is a dream come true for controller players but a frustrating place to go for mouse and keyboard players. Luckily, the Steam Workshop combined with SKSE (a community made script extender for the game) let you once again fix the problem with a new UI that works perfectly with a mouse and even lets you search your inventory for items by simply typing the items in. All in all, this game is incredible and will entertain your for hundreds of hours if you're willing to go to the trouble of manually fixing a few minute issues. I would recommend it to anyone.

review: Was walking along an icy river, when all of a sudden an evil rabbit with the voice of Satan walks up to me triggering the start of Danger Zone by Kenny Loggins. Luckily for me, just a swift swing of my sword sent him flying back to Oblivion, but to my surprise I was yet to leave the Danger Zone as a troll began trolling me with the trololol song playing alongside his dumb troll face. With the mix of Kenny Loggins and trolling making my ears nearly bleed, I began to run for my life jamming out to now just Danger Zone when out of nowhere I was hit with a wave of childhood memories as a thundering "choo choo" overcomes the glory of Kenny's voice. As I looked to the sky, down came Thomas the Tank as he blasted me with his fiery breathe. In the background, a faint trolling began to creep back into my ears as that damn trolling troll began to catch up to me with my new aforementioned foe. Overcome with nostalgia, fire, trolls trolling, and ungodly amounts of damage being hurled my way, I noticed my screen beginning to flicker. Faster and faster, the flickering began to overcome my screen and suddenly in a heartbeat, I was no more. All that remained as my body hit the floor was the faint sounds of Kenny reminding me that I was indeed on the highway to the Danger Zone, and the lesson of how you never pick a fight with a troll as the one I took on danced his trololol victory dance. 11/10 would recommend

review: Skyrim is a huge fantasy game with lots of options for gameplay experiance and fit for anyone looking for medieval entertainment. The world is huge and filled to the brim with life, such as deer, foxes, wolves, dragons, bandits, mages, thugs, assassins, thieves, legendary warrors, werewolves, vampires, ect. You are free to choose between ten different races and customize them to be a mage, archer, swordsmen, ect. However, this game does comes with a large number of hilarious and frustrating glitches, so do beware and save often with different files. In the end, you will find yourself easily putting 500+ hours into the game just as I have. I recommend finding some good mods at the Steam Workshop or Skyrim Nexus to make your experiance even better. This game is one of my personal favorites. My final rating: 8.5/10 The game is highly entertaining, but the amount of bugs and glitches brings it down a bit.

game-hours: 73.7
review: ----Skyrim Experience---- I have played this game on Xbox 360, (breifly on) PS3, and now PC. On Xbox I've logged over 200 hours, probably closer to 400 or 500. ----Is Skyrim Good?---- This game is immensely fun. It is very extensive in its player-chosen content, such as character creation, faction choice, and many hundreds of quests and objectives. ----PC versus Console Versions---- The PC version seems to only be better, other than the fact that it may not run as well and you have a mouse and keyboard. In my case, I'm running it on a Lenovo Flex 15, intel i5, 8GB RAM laptop. I don't know the graphics card... I can run this at a framerate of... 60-80 on the default medium-quality graphics. So if you have a lower quality system, you may be out of luck, and might just buy it on console. Which is the second point I bring up. As soon as I get what I need, I'm going to start playing it with my Xbox controller, as: - I'm familiar with the controls - Due to my playing Minecraft, every time I go to close my inventory I hit 'E', and wind up equipping or unequipping something - Lockpicking falls victim to to unfortunate fate that many Console -> PC games share: games with a button input that changes based on how much a trigger is depressed or how far a stick is pushed are somewhat ruined, as the PC keyboard isn't capable of that (if you've ever played Trials: Evolution and attempted to do some of the mini-games things you know what I mean). This leaves lockpicking with using the mouse to turn the pick, then w to turn the lock, which has one medium speed. However, the PC version allows you to install mods by the plenty. Mods that add armor, or weapons, or mods that make the dead females nude, or mods that allow you to explore other parts of Tamriel, like Sommerset Isles, Elsweyr, or even the entire Tamriel. For this reason I recommend the PC version, so long as you have a good PC and a controller. ----Why Is Skyrim so Awesome?---- - Character customization: Aside from the initial choosing of your facial features, build, and race, you are always customizing your character throughout the game. Every time you level up a skill, you become more prominent in that skill; every time you level up a character, you attain a skill point with which you can upgrade a skill of your choice. On top of skills and features, every decision you make either directly or indirectly affects you. - Massive F*ing World: Skyrim is filled to the brim with towns, cities, temples, fortresses, fields, lairs, caverns, and mountains. To this day, I have likely only seen 80-95% of Skyrim's features. Sure, a lot of hostile battlements, fortifications, and caverns look similar, but they always change what they hold. - Quests Abound: There are a lot of quests and objectives. A lot. But not enough. Sounds funny, right? Before you start the game, I recommend downloading a lot of quest mods, that way you'll be prepared for it. But when you're starting, there are so many quests, you have no clue what to do! Being a perfectionist, I can't play an open-world game without scouring the world. So I always had tons of quests in my To-Do list. But I slowly completed them, and once I got around to finishing the main quest, I started burning through my quests quickly. (This is all on my Xbox version, by the way). - Stuff: I'm sorry, I'm tired and bored of writing this review, because I only started writing it when I went to the Skyrim page to go to the Workshop to download more mods to continue playing Skyrim, and then I saw this giant empty text box. So... I guess I'll just wrap up this review? I should probably give my recommendation of the game, to play or not: PLAY THE GAME! If you're iffy on it, grab it quick on the Steam sale for $7.99.

game-hours: 460.5
review: TESV: Skyrim is the 5th installation in the Elder Scrolls series of games. Pros: -Replayability: The amount of factions you can join or oppose, questlines and the like are so vast. Different playstyles grant both advantages and disadvantages, and the random encounters in the world cause nothing to be boring or dull. -Mod compatibility: The mod community for Skyrim is a myriad of different topics, from fixing small bugs, adding followers or even remodelling the game, like Skyrim Redone by T3nd0. -Open-world adventure: With many places to go and dungeons to explore, there will always be something to do in Skyrim. Cons: -Some areas feel like they're unfinished, like Windhelm. The arena would have polished the grim city off rather well, but Bethesda didn't implement it, unfortunately, although this leaves resources for mod authors to create their own renditions of the content. -Most characters have little or no unique dialogue, leading to randoms with no real purpose. -Capital cities are very empty, and have 20-35 citizens, rather oddly. Again, there are mods to fix this. -A lot of annoying bugs, some of which CAN be fixed in the console, opened with the tilde (`) key, above the tab button. Unofficial Skyrim patch helps out with these. Overall, a beautiful game, with a lot of feeling, although can feel desolate at times. Moddability is a massive plus with me, allowing for a more customised game experience. Rating: 7.3/10

game-hours: 151.3
review: What is Skyrim? Well, some say it's a game made by Bethesda as another installment in the Elder Scrolls series, but is it really? First of, let's define aberration: An aberration is something that deviates from the normal way. So in lieu of calling this game another installment in the series, let's say this is an aberration. This aberration of a game brings us idyllic, serene landscapes( with the addition of mods) that make the game so riveting and immersive, especially with the perfect equipoise of dialogue and character development. The Elder Scrolls V offers a extensive open-world map with monumental to non-imposing cities, villages, towns, farming huts and intimidating caves, mines, crevices, dungeons and forts that offer adversity while maintaining the perfect balance of immersion and simplicity. From edifices to primitive dwellings comes a myriad of immersive characters, animals, creatures, patrols, travellers and a cult to offer the player a great deal of convivial entertainment. The story itself, can make players really engange in their decisions because of the level of entrancing dialogue, visuals, continuity and the preeminent factor of overall interaction with the full use of the open world map. Lastly, the inclusion of mods really augments the experience of Skyrim i.e, Graphical Mods, ENB's, environmental mods, texture mods, gameplay mods, immersive mods and a plethora of more categories. ENB's are graphical mods that enhance the use of lighting and shadows to add an aesthetic value to the game. Environmental mods can alter alot of things including: grass, tree's, water, establishments and a multitude of other things. Texture mods change the landscape, character models, animals and basically any texture. So, in conclusion, this game has a myriad of varied factors listed above to make this game in my top 5 favourite games of all time. A superfluity of mods can really alter the experience in a positive and negative depending on the discovering of "good" mods. Dialoge, characters, environment and immersion are really the paramount factors that made this game one of my favourites. I recommend this game to anyone and everyone, including non-rpg advocates. 9.9/10( IGN). Just kidding. 10/10.

game-hours: 51.1
review: * Visuals - One of the prettiest, if not the prettiest game I have played. I like how the environment varies from location to location. One area can be a sunny flat forest while the next can be snowy rugged mountain range. * Cities - There isn't a grand city like Vivec or Imperial City, but I do like how certain elements in the city is associated with interesting lore. Each city has a timely feel. People actually do things and follow a unique schedule. * RPG Elements - Like its processors, you level up by doing things. One of the biggest drawbacks to this game is the loss of the six attributes. Everything is combined into three attributes: health, magicka, and stamina. Those three are tied with the other missing attributes that determines how much weight you can carry, how fast you can walk, etc. * Combat - The combat is very balanced. Destruction spells + one hand weapon, restoration spells + one hand weapon, one hand weapon + shield, archery, and two handed weapons are all equally viable combined with either light, mage, or heavy armor. The combination of builds are endless. The combat itself feels more real and immersive than the previous two games. * Quests - Is a big hit or miss in Skyrim. I would avoid most Misc quests unless you like repetitive procedurally generated quests. The main quests and all of the guild quests (with the exception of the mages) are decent. Unfortunately, most of the quests will boil down to this: "go to a cave and kill someone or get something". That being said, the dungeons and caves are not nearly as boring as Oblivion or Morrowind. * Story - Still have that cheesy charm. The dialog can use a lot of work. I understand that crafting a dialog system that covers everything next to impossible, but there are a few major things that I feel can be easily fixed. Aside from the dialog, the main quest story line is very good. Dark Brotherhood and thieves guild storyline (minus the nocturnal ) is worth noting. The other two guilds on the other hand is cringeworthy. The biggest highlight, in regards to story, is the lore and history you gain by reading books, engaging in conversation, or even completing side quests. I highly recommend if you: 1. Enjoy RPGs with minimal micro management. 2. Love visually pleasing games 3. Think Lore is important to you
