game-hours: 88.3
review: It took me two years and much convincing to buy Skyrim. To give context, let me explain why I was so wary. At the insistence of both friends and online review, I picked up a copy of oblivion years ago. I played it for slightly over an hour and was completely uninterested. I've never been able to enjoy an MMOrpg, and lost my taste for FPS games about ten years ago. Basically, all my experience told me that Skyrim was going to be another huge and boring game that got a lot of acclaim but let me desiring something to get attached to. Luckily for me, it did just that. Skyrim's draw for me lay in it's polish, and the depth and extent of it's vision. I've spent 20 minutes looking at the aurora Boryalis. I spend time actually listening to the dialog instead of button mashing to get the quest, and I'm constantly blown away with where the story, and the environment of the game take me. It's gameplay is solid, yet there isn't some interesting feature that marks it as special, besides maybe the vastness of it. The three varying paths of mage, rogue and warrior offer a plethora of fighting styles and tricks that have kept me engaged while I further along the plot arcs. It's satisfying to sneak through a dungeon never being seen, only to place arrows in the backs of every foe's head. Similarly, rounding up all the baddies to be dispatched by a bombardment of fireballs is satisfying in a totally different way. But the entire time I'm doing that, I know it will get me one step closer to finding that scroll, learning that new word of power, or getting that huge chest of loot at the end of the tunnel. Skyrim is a beautiful game that has taken the beauty of storytelling and let you immerse yourself as an adventurer in a fantasical, beautiful, and fully realized world. If you are looking to get lost in a story, or tame a dragon, I think you've found the right game to do it.

review: skyrim
game-hours: 328.0

game-hours: 229.4
review: Um.... buy this...
game-hours: 220.4
review: Actions speak louder than words they say - well, at least that's what delved into the minds of bethesda's designers when skyrim was conceived. Skyrim shamelessly takes the cinematic goodies from theaters and crushes it into a mix with highly interactive gameplay and, like every good mix of elements, explodes brilliantly but leaves something valuable behind. Climb a mountain, kill a dragon, steal a sweetroll, raise zombies, everything splashes and rumbles like a great parade. Boredom is blasphemy in Skyrim. A cent for each fun popcorn greased, action filled cinematic moment would cumulate into enough wealth for buying out Microsoft just for the sake of comparison. Skyrim finally moved into her own and makes no apologies about it. Let's face it, TES is no longer in the D&D generation. Skyrim set out to the original TES ambition of a free roaming action RPG but made no compromises with her older siblings. You set out to do something and the world doesn't hold you back, right? Well, that idea doesn't only apply to the gameplay but the evolution of TES-series in general. It had it coming for sure but the foundation was already laid back in the days. So what is wrong with Skyrim? Well this question cries out a bit of precision: There is a more-or-less fine line between failure and the burden of choice. You can't pull a lever to both sides at once; you set out to erase the D&D scheme - you strip off the attributes. Well, tough. A failure, however, means not exceeding the set goal. So, for the most part, the criticism I've seen about Skyrim incline towards the former because Skyrim was great about the things it set out to accomplish and, to be fair, it set out to do a lot. Where Morrowind succeeded as a good book, Skyrim succeeded as a good movie. Movies made out of vast worlds tend to be spread thin in raw content but the experience is ever more vibrant and lively than the written counterpart. Despite that, Skyrim doesn't leave you cold in the sheer amount of awesome things to explore and experience, it's stuffed! As books are not as big part of the zeitgeist anymore, the issue people take in Skyrim is usually more about the taste of the average player rather than the match of vision and craft of the developers. It's evident that whatever category Skyrim assumed for itself, it gave one hell of a shock, not only, to the rivals in its respective field, but the ones outside of its assumed borders. Coincidently, Skyrim may have dealt the critical strike to the dragon phenomenon in videogame industry for a temporary demise. But for the time being: Get ready for the copycats.

review: If you have never heard of this game, I hate to say you live under a rock. This game may sound a bit cheesy if its your very first time, but this is the farest from it. There are thousands of hours worth of gameplay. So basically you will never ever beat this game. There is also LOADS of customization to choose from. Instead of being just human you can be loads of different other races aswell. not only that but you can choose how high your nose is, how forward your mouth is, and how big your eyes are. 100/10 The requirements are little for your pc so that is good. I have a $350 laptop and it runs extreamly smooth, although you may need to change the detail setting in the first menu you get to. But thats only if you have a bad/cheap computer. But if you do have a good/GREAT computer your in for a real treat. The graphics are amazing especially with the graphics dlc THAT YOU GET FOR FREE. On top of all this YOU GET MODS! game-hours: 1465.8
review: Skyrim is the fifth installment in the Elder Scrolls main series, and third that I have played extensively. There are some definite improvements in this game over previous Elder Scrolls titles, and there are some drawbacks. The combat system exemplifies this; while the actual use of weapons is an improvement over Morrowind, the skilling up of weapons is greatly oversimplified over even Oblivion, which itself is simplified over Morrowind. There are more weapon skill types in Morrowind than there are all skills combined in Skyrim. The stat system suffers from this simplification as well. On the plus side, Skyrim's story and graphics are on par with what one should expect from an Elder Scrolls title, even if the final battle may seem anticlimactic to some. The character animations are far superior to those from Morrowind, as well.

game-hours: 315.8
review: Very exciting game once you start off, but unfortuately you realise the simplicity and lack of depth as you play more and more. Combat is hack and slash, many quests are cloned 'fetch' or 'complete this dungeon' quests, and dungeons lack true diversity because there are so many. Paraphrasing TotalBiscuit, the game is the size of an ocean with the depth of a paddling pool. It is a shame because the game has potential. Mods can definitely improve your experience if you're willing to experiment but it can take time to compile a list and install them for your perfect experience. I've been wanting to do this for a while. Although my review appears negative, Skyrim will provide you with many hours of enjoyment before it gets repetitive even without mods, so I do recommend it.

review: Another addition to the Elder Scrolls, Skyrim had my hopes up for a great sequel to the other games. Having been fond of Morrowind and Oblivion, I had preordered Skyrim the moment I could afford too. Only to find out that Skyrim is so graphic heavy that if your computer doesn't have top of the line hardware your going to run into issues. My Radeon HD4800 can't handle Skyrim and I crash to desktop almost religiously near any town, to the point that I am no longer playing Skyrim because of the fustration. I recommend Skyrim ONLY if your computer can actually handle it. Even the minimal requirements to run the game does not guarentee that it will actually work. I'll return to playing Skyrim once I've forked over a bit of money and time to upgrade my computer to at least 'decent' standards.

game-hours: 169.5
review: Rome 2 was supposed to be the strategic game of the year. The hype was big, the game itself sold more preorder copies than any other game of the franchise. The problem is the bigger promises you make the bigger the expectations will be. They promised us mountains and delivered a little hill with a sheep on top (dont get me wrong it was a nice fluffy sheep). Rome 2 has a huge map and gives you the ability to play with several playable factions. They can be divided into the following categories: Roman, Greek, Barbaric and Eastern. Each faction has it own unit, but tribes of the same category have similar units. There are three ways to win the game: Economic, Cultural and Conquest. The problem is that winning feels like conquest no matter which way you choose. For example in order to win Economical victory with Britannia (Iceni tribe) you have to capture 60 settlements and burn down or pillage at least 30 settlements. Never mind the pillaging, but who are we kidding, it is never economical to destroy in order to prosper. Game is highly addictive (if you get hooked on the game see your local doctor). You can play for hours and it will feel like 20 minutes. Playing with Rome will give you command of the most diverse units, which are fun to use. Sparta on the other hand has probably the least distinctive units. However you wont care. Why? Because we are talking about Spartan Hoplites, born killing machines that can destroy a large war unit such as elephant with ease. Big map gives you a lot fun to conquest the ancient world. Wonders are a great new edition to the game, and give your faction a perk of sorts, to boost your economy, army or culture.

review: This is one of the buggiest, most broken, most unfinished-feeling games I have seen in a long time. review: A good game but plagued by bugs. Take note, that I'm a rogue player, so Sneak, Thievery, Backstabs, etc are all my modus operandi. People who are not using this skill set and aren't stealing all the loot may have a better time getting around these. Bugs that have annoyed me: Thievery success capped at 90% (Not actually a bug, and I fixed this by changing the cap in the editor). Thievery success going -down- at higher levels. Sneak not being sneaky enough (some enemies will -always- spot you cause plot hook) Getting stuck in floors on level change Enemies doing unrealistic amounts of damage, on Adept (Normal) difficulty (Two higher difficulties than this). Had an enemy randomly one shotting everything with a bow and arrows much worse than mine. Could only hit me for 1/20th of my health with a dagger he was also wielding. I could also one shot him. Otherwise, quests/cinematics/story all good, as much as I avoided them because I was too busy stealing everything.

review: Suddenly - ING DRAGONS
game-hours: 103.8
review: A action-rpg. The action is done terribly and the rpg-elements aren't that great either. Morrowind was a lot better, they're really starting to dumb down a lot in this series. Hell, even morrowind was a dumbed down version of daggerfall. This is ofcourse a bethesda game so it's going to be plagued with bugs which makes me question their programming skills. The combat system is terrible. All the weapons feel like wooden pads and the swords even look like pads. (there's a mod that fixes this) Magic is powerful early on but quickly starts to become worthless. (but there are mods that improve the magic) Stealth is terribly unbalanced. You can one-hit-kill everything with your weapons later on or you can make it even easier and use a bow. None of the characters are interesting or were s, so i could care less if they died. The only character i really liked was cicero, a killer jester. The story is boring and really simple compared to other elder scrolls games. A destroyer of worlds has returned and you're the chosen one so you have to kill him. The final battle was hilarious simply because the big bad destroyer of worlds is a pushover. The dragonslaying in this game is terribly anti-climactic. Bandits are more powerful enemies than the dragons. Changing the difficulty only changes the damage that enemies receive and dish out and they won't change tactics. So all the difficulty does is make the battles take a little longer. So in conclusion......the game is terribly overrated. Avoid it on console. But....... get it for pc. Why? Because of the modding community. There are some really amazing mods for this game that make this game enjoyable to play. But it's inexcusable that mods have to redeem this game. It should be a good game on it's own.
game-hours: 53.8
review: This game is very well made, Im able to run it on my laptop on highest settings with no problem. The gameplay itself is as always with The Elder Scrolls series is deep and involving and with completely new stretch of lands to discover and explore, will give many hours of excellent gameplay. You create your own destiny as a Dragonborn and as such you can speak the voice of the dragons knows as shouts and must explore the lands and slay dragons to learn more ancient dragon words to help you on your journey. There is also several new features in this installment of Eldar Scroll being that you can now create your own armour at the forge, enchanting has been improved somewhat and alchemy now has to be done at dedicated places. Overall this is a must have for the fans of Eldar Scrolls series, the RPG elements have been dumbed down since Oblivion but it is still an excellent game.

game-hours: 67.7
review: A very expansive game, Skyrim's vast map is, if not the best, one of the best virtual world ever created. The map is full of things to do, prey to be hunted, ingredients to be collected, enemies to kill. Not to mention the random creature spawn that makes the world of Skyrim feels alive, not just scripted by the development team. When you turn that corner, there maybe some random NPC giving you quest, some guy walking along the road that can train you in your way to become a Speechcraft Master, or an old Orc warrior who seeks an honorable way to die. So much things to do, so much variety, which makes pouring hours upon hours on this amazing world feels exciting every single time. The main quest is epic, but compared to the many side quests in the world feels kinda dull. The freedom to build your own character is so liberating, particularly because of many strong arguments from many types of play. Add to that many amazing mods which has already been created, makes this a truly living game which always evolve with new content. Truly a great experience.

review: Pro: This is the best of the Elder Scrolls series to date. Story line and game play provides for total character emersion. Steam community includes great expandability for those that are seeking to fine tune the game experience. Con: There are only two cons that I have after 3500 saves and 600 hours of game play. The first is one that is consistent with previous series. Game saves are linier. Playing multiple characters requires scrolling through literally thousands of game saves to find the specific save point. Character category would be helpful. The second con relates to item categories and similar to the save issue. Though improved from later titles, there is room for improvement. If Betheseda simply added one more category, Stolen I would be happy. Neither issue affects game play.

review: Highly recommendable to anyone looking to experience a fantasy world of depth, scope, and, most of all, adventure. Blends the elements of Open-world, Rpg, and Hack-and-Slash games nearly seamlessly, allowing you to play through as many times as you'd like without ever having identical play-throughs. The modding community behind this game is committed, savvy, and vast enough that you can tailor the world into a unique, breath-taking virtual reality that fits unlimited varieties of game-play preferences. Any serious fan of gaming who hasn't bothered themselves with this game is truly missing out. It offers the player more than just the opportunity to experience a beautiful story -- it lets them write it themselves. It leaves the player with the feeling that they are immersed in not just a good game (though they certainly are) but in a rich and compelling world. Top-notch, Bethesda.

game-hours: 130.0
review: There was a lot of hate for Skyrim when it came out, and having just beat the game tonight after getting it at midnight launch I can say after 2.5 years it's held up as a game for me. I wasn't a huge fan of Oblivion, which was very classical fantasy and I loved Morrowind, which was a very alien land with tons of interesting lore and culture. Skyrim is a slightly classical-deviated middle ground. It didn't come out running on the best engines but it was well appreciated by someone who can't run the best hardware for the game or so I play a year. Now that I have a nicer PC I can mod it how I please and it's been fantastic. I'm someone who appreciates the graphics in life so Skyrim was already a pleasure for it's time and I've only made it prettier to look at. I didn't like the simplification of skills and alchemy/enchanting and the loss over the last few games of things like Medium Armor, Hand-to-Hand, Unarmored, Staves, etc. but I can understand wanting to make the game more accessible to new players. It just seemed a bit hand-holdy and uncustomizable, especially having first played Morrowind where you could run around with one paldron, a different glove on each hand and a robe over your armor. Was Skyrim the most fabulous game ever forever? Absolutely not, but it was certainly enjoyable for a player who has been an ES fan for 3 game generations at the very least. Here's hoping VI will be even better for us.

In the latest update they added legendary difficulty which has made the game even better, making it feel like they need a dragonborn to protect them. This is an absolute terrific game and once you play it youre going to come back. Defiantly a ten out of ten from me.

review: An epic game made all the more epic by the fact that it is so easy to mod and so well supported by the modding community. The Elder Scrolls series has a large following and often you will hear people argue over each new TES game comparing it to the last, but for me each TES game stands on its own merits, and Skyrim is no exception. The story is pretty good and there are plenty of side quests, but what makes Skyrim so great even when not modded is its large and open nature. This is a land you can just pick a direction and with no quest in mind and just explore. You will find danger and excitement on your journey ... and loot. Lots and lots of loot. But once you start modding this game, that is when you unlock the true value that is Skyrim. Potentially thousands more hours content (for free) in a game that can be improved ten thousand different ways from graphics, textures and sounds all the way to game mechanics and user interface changes. You can make the game exactly what you need it to be, and play it for so long you may still be playing when the next game in this series comes out.... and sometimes longer than even that. If you are interested in modding the PC version of the game, be sure to check out my guide for beginners:

game-hours: 92.5
review: I was stacking books on a shelf in my house in Whiterun, one of Skyrim's major cities, when I noticed a weapon rack right beside it. I set a sacrificial dagger in one slot, an Orcish mace in the other. They were on display for nobody but me and my computer-controlled housecarl, Lydia, who sat at a table patiently waiting for me to ask her to go questing. The chest upstairs was reserved for excess weapons and armor, the bedside table for smithing ingots and ores, the one next to the Alchemy table for ingredients. I'd meticulously organized my owned virtual property not because I had to, but because tending to the minutia of domestic life is a comforting break from dealing with screaming frost trolls, dragons, a civil war, and job assignments that never seem to go as planned. It's even a sensible thing to do; a seemingly natural component of every day existence in Skyrim, one of the most fully-realized, easily enjoyable, and utterly engrossing role-playing games ever made. Part of what makes it so enjoyable has to do with how legacy Elder Scrolls clutter has been condensed and in some cases eliminated. In Skyrim, there's no more moon-hopping between hilltops with a maxed out Acrobatics skill. That's gone, so is Athletics. The Elder Scrolls V pares down the amount of skills and cuts out attributes like Endurance and Intelligence altogether. There's no time wasted on the character creation screen agonizing over which skills to assign as major. You don't assign major and minor skills at all, but instead pick one of ten races, each with a specific bonus. High Elves can once a day regenerate magicka quickly, Orcs can enter a berserk rage for more effective close-range combat. These abilities are best paired with certain character builds  the High Elf regeneration is useful for a magic user  but don't represent a rigid class choice. Major decisions don't need to be made until you're already out in the world and can try out magic, sneaking and weapon combat, emphasizing first-hand experience over instruction manual study, letting you specialize only when you're ready. It contributes to the thrilling sense of freedom associated with life in Skyrim. Do a quest, kill a dragon, snatch torchbugs from the air, munch on butterfly wings or simply wander while listening to one of the best game soundtracks in recent memory. Despite the enormity of the world and the colossal amount of content contained within, little feels random and useless. Even chewing on a butterfly wing has purpose, as it reveals one of several alchemical parameters later useful in potion making at an alchemy table. Mined ore and scraps of metal from Dwemer ruins can be smelted into ingots and fashioned into armor sets, pelts lifted from slain wildlife can be turned into leather armor sets, and random books plucked from ancient ruins can trigger hidden quest lines that lead to valuable rewards. Skyrim's land mass is absolutely stuffed with content and curiosities, making every step you take, even if it's through what seems like total wilderness, an exciting one, as something unexpected often lies just over the next ridge. Many times the unexpected takes the form of a dragon. Sometimes they're purposefully placed to guard relics, sometimes they swoop over cities and attack at seemingly random times. In the middle of a fight against a camp of bandits a dragon might strike, screaming through the sky and searing foe and friendly alike with frost or flame. Momentarily all on the battlefield unite, directing arrows and magic blasts upward to knock down the creature, creating impromptu moments of camaraderie -- a surprising change from what may have been yet another by-the-numbers bandit camp sweep. Dragons show up often, their presence announced by an ominous flap of broad wings or an otherworldly scream from high above. The scale and startling detail built into each creature's appearance and animations as it circles, stops to attack, circles again and slams to the ground makes encounters thrilling, though their predictable attack patterns lessen the excitement after a few battles. In the long run they're far less irritating than the Oblivion gate equivalent from The Elder Scrolls IV, can be completed in a few minutes, and always offer a useful reward. Killing a dragon yields a soul, which powers Skyrim's new Shout system. These are magical abilities any character can use, you don't have to specialize in spell casting to slow time, throw your voice, change the weather, call in allies, blast out ice and fire, or knock back enemies with a rolling wave of pure force. Even if you favor sword, shield and heavy armor and ignore magic entirely, you'll still be able to take full advantage of these abilities provided you find the proper words  each Shout has three  hidden on Skyrim's high snowy peaks and in the depths of forgotten dungeons, serving as another reason to continue exploring long after you've exhausted the main quest story, joined with the Thieves Guild, fought alongside the Dark Brotherhood, or thrown your support behind one of the factions vying for control of Skyrim. Not only is this land under assault by dragons, long thought to be dead, it's also ripped in two by civil war. You can choose one side or the other, but so much of the allure of Skyrim is how, even outside of the confines of quest lines, the embattled state of the world is evident, and steeped in a rich fictional legacy. Lord of the Rings this is not, but with the release of every Elder Scrolls game, the fiction becomes denser, and the cross-referencing for long-time fans all the more rewarding. Skyrim's residents are all aware of current events. They'll comment on the civil war, some sympathizing with the rebels, others thinking the establishment sold its soul. The peasants complain about the Jarls who control each settlement, the Jarls complain about the rebels or foreign policy, the overprotective College librarian complains when I drop dragon scales all over his floor; many characters feel like whole, distinct personalities instead of vacuous nothings that hand out quests like a downtown greeter hands out flyers for discount jeans. Characters stereotype based on race, they double-cross at even the slightest hint it might be profitable, and they react to your evolving stature within the world. It makes a ridiculous realm, filled with computer-controlled cat people and humanoid reptiles, demon gods and dragons, feel authentic, like a world that existed long before you showed up and will continue to exist long after you leave.

game-hours: 255.3
review: Being a player, who loved Morrowind and couldn't stand Oblivion, I was surprised how much time I actually spend playing Skyrim. What is more, the main plots (main quest and mages in my case) were actually quite uncomplicated, most of the time predictable and player choices lacked depth. Yet, enjoyed this game very much. That was due to two main factors - extremely smooth gameplay, and what is even more valuable, the amazing atmosphere of the region built by every thing you walk through - the tombs, the marshes, mountain passages, rivers, totally unique, yet still down from scale (same as Oblivion and Morrowind) cities, and the NPCs you meet. Skyrim is a harsh and unfriendly land and you often have to stick your nose out of some places and even being the legendary hero - run from dragons. I especially recommend the assasin (Dark Brotherhood) storyline and of course the Dragonborn extension, which is also surprisingly good with the recreated - known from Bloodmoon addon for Morrowind - island Soltsheim. Comparing these two you'll get much less quests to complete, but they're still worth the time with even better atmosphere which got some TES III nostalgia and really well created mage character Neloth. Just simply don't expect from Skyrim choice and roleplay depth, you won't get it. Yet the land is worth of trying out, exploring, enjoying the view, killing thousand of draugrs and meeting very well crafted NPCs.

game-hours: 91.4
review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is an open-world fantasy game with a non-linear play style (meaning that you dont have to stick to the main story). The game itself is set in the Tamrielic province of Skyrim, a harsh, wintery landscape that is absolutely stunning both in graphical terms and gameplay. You play as the Dragonborn: a warrior that has the body of a man... But the soul of a dragon! You can use special drgon shouts to defeat your oponents. Skyrim is-in my opinion-one of the BEST open world fantasy games there are. Whereas some diehard fans would always say that Oblivion was the best Elder Scrolls game, I feel that what Skyrim does brilliantly is giving the player choice, as do all of the Elder Scrolls games, but Skyrim opens up this and doubles those opportunities for choice. There are at least three seperate sub-storylines to the game (all three adds up to about 9-11 hours playing time) as well as the main story (which is around 12-13 hours) so there is a great sense of replayability with this game, not to mention the endless amounts of side quests which are both interesting and immersive. But, I think the best thing about Skyrim is the modding community. Modding does have quite a bad reputation with non-gamers as the word "modding" brings to mind the idea of unfair advantages, but because Skyrim has no multiplayer, there are no unfair advantages and Bethesda (the developers of the game) bring out the Creatin Kit to allow players to mod their games. Even here on Steam, there is the Steam Workshop which allows Skyrim players to upload their own mods for others to use. There are a wide variety of mods from awesome visual updates to adding in completely new things; the modding community keeps Skyrim fresh so that the replayability will never run out. So, should you get the game? If you like the idea of choices, fresh ideas and good the good old "Hack and Slash" element as well as spellcasting, then Skyrim is the game for you. Even if you don't think you'll like it, I highly recommend that you give this game a try (ESPECIALLY SINCE IT'S ON SALE NOW!! "HINT! HINT!" "NUDGE! NUDGE!") because a lot of my friends have said that they would absolutely hate this game, they came round mine and are now hooked! So GET THIS GAME! You may just like it!

review: This game never gets tiresome; Start out on Adept and try your hand, defeat the game - tell yourself its to easy - move yourself through the difficulties to Legendary and watch the simplest creature show you who's boss. With the largest moding community out there, there will always be something new to offer this game. The DLCs provided give you a great boost of immersion and diversity to the world of Skyrim, The mods available by those that chance and master the Creation kit give you a whole new world [or WORLDS] to explore. This is a game where you are truly only limited by your imagination. If you find something does not fit right or you would like to see done better, you have the creation kit to improve upon it! NPC's to wooden and lifeless, go into the kit - add in what you want them to do and voila! You want a new and improved dungeon experience, done! With the tutorials that come with the Creation Kit and all the modders out there to help you, there is never an excuse to not enjoy this game. Do I recommend this game - YES.

game-hours: 132.3
review: Skyrim.... What can I say about this game? Loved by people everywhere and often regarded as the best RPG of all time. Well, I disagree. Now dont get me wrong, I like the game and think its great, but the large unbalance between trying to be a mage, archer, or assassin and being a forefront heavy armored idiot with 1,000 health potions is insanely stupid. Im gonna be a badass sorcerer/archer and lurk in the shadows! says me on my first play through. Well those skilly are nothing in comparison to wielding heavy axes and gladiator amor. So it turns out that the 50 hours you spend leveling up those sneaky skills are for nothing and you can still be killed by any old peasant in the blink of an eye. The leveling system makes everything else around you level with you. So that homeless guy that you could kill with a splinter to the thumb suddenly got Jesus proof skin and it takes smashing a semi-truck on his head to take him down. And on the other side of this problem, things that should remain hard to kill, dont. For example, I found myself having a harder time killing a town guard at level 40 than trying to kill a dragon. Totally legit. I also found the world of Skyrim to be uneventful and boring in comparison to other Bethesda RPGs. I really tried to get into the story of the game and never really could. I loved the concept and kept reassuring myself that Ill get into it. But all the characters sound the same and never have anything interesting to talk about, or maybe its because the monotone villagers voice makes me wanna put in arrow through my neck to I skip through the talking parts. Ill admit, there were some epic battles here and there, nod I did really like some of the side quests, but as a whole, it bored me to tears. Now the environment is enthralling. It is a huge improvement over Oblivion for sure, the scenery and wildlife is magnificent, and while Bethesdas physics have never been. ugh. amazing the improvement on the graphical part of the game makes up for it. Overall, I did enjoy the game. Between the choices and freedoms you have as a player and the atmospheric wonder, Id say its actually a great game, just not as great as everyone else makes it out to be.
game-hours: 203.4
review: A little bit of something for everyone, and there's a lot of somethings to go around. Everything from new weapons and armor to new questlines, to difficulty tweaks making the game as easy or as challenging as you want. There's a little something here for everyone. Now if only they'd add co-op...

review: This is my favourite game of all time. I have so many great memories of this game, questing, roleplaying, killing, it was such a great experience. Environments such as the harsh cold mountains of the north, the beautiful forests and flora of Whiterun and Falkreath, the amber trees and golden grass of Riften. And the rocky, Dwemer feel to Markarth. Playing through the vanilla game was one of my favorite and greatest experience ever. And then I started modding. WOW. The modding support for this game is both ridiculous and amazing at the same time. There are mods out there for absolutely everyone. Whether your a hardcore survivalist ( Frostfall, RNAD), or roleplaying a hunter (Hunterborn, A hunting guild) or maybe your a fearless brute, a mercenary, this game is perfect. If you are not a fan of the 2011 graphics, do not worry there are several enb's out there which vastly improve the look of this game. My favorites are: Realvision enb, Seasons of skyrim enb and project enb. All look absolutely stunning. Honestly, I could write a thousand word essay on why you should buy this game or why it's my favourite game of all time. To anyone wanting one of the best gaming experiences out there, I recommend this game. It's perfect.

game-hours: 161.8
review: I used to be an adventure like you , but i took an arrow to the knee
game-hours: 572.0
review: This is a great game. Basically, you are put in the shoes of the one warrior in Skyrim who can stop the World-Eater Wyrm, Alduin. You accomplish this through your steel, your spells, your wits, and your Dragon Shouts (the power to warp reality by yelling in the dragon tongue). Along the way, you must battle the likes of vampires, bandits, frost trolls, and more. And the story does not end after you save the world once, oh no. The DLC adds two more possible armageddons, one in which you may choose to be a villain. It is extremely choice-based as a game. Combat is easy to learn, hard to master. Left clicking attacks, holding left click performs a power attack, right clicking blocks, and power attacking while moving results in a more powerful strike, which changes depending on the direction. Spells are powerful tools, but it can be difficult to cast them at first due to low Magicka. Each attack is governed by a different meter. Power attacks drain Stamina, spells drain Magicka, and getting hit will (of course) drain your hit points. The Perk system is a unique class approach that allows you to govern how you play. Want to wield heavy weapons alongside spells (my personal favorite)? Choose the right perks and you are all set. Want to sword and board, but also don't want to miss out on archery? Done. Options include Stealth, Combat, and Magic perks. The world itself is amazing. Every detail, from an underwater cavern to an aurora borealis is crafted with painstaking detail. The dungeons can start to look alike after a while (especially Nord crypts), but the world is simply compelling. Dragon battles are big enough to get their own review point here. It can be difficult to slay dragons at first, but you eventually will get the Dragonrend shout, which forces the beasts to land. Moddability is amazing for this game. I run it heavily modded (mostly it adds spells or new swords) and it is amazing. Highly suggest grabbing mods for this game when it suits you. In conclusion, great game. I'd recommend this to anyone who enjoys a Role-Playing Game.

game-hours: 840.0
review: I have clocked in so many hours of my life into this game and its DLC, along with the ability to mod it. This is by far my second favorite game of all time, and thats saying something considering the ammount of games ive played. I can always come back to TES:Skyrim and play with a new refreshing experience because of my imagination and the amalgamation of mods i have installed. Do i wanna be a necromancer assassin this round? Or do i wanna be a nature-conjuring , wolf spirt summoning druid ? Or a buff, beefy, sweaty-glistening-muscles toned argonian with a giant greatsword whos 9 feet tall and could crush you under his foot? Yes. Aslong as you have an imagination, and whether or not you wanna mod it [ i recommend modding, it adds near-infinite replayability even more to an infinite replayable base game] , this game is absolutely fun, stunning in graphics, and beautiful in many ways. Also hilarious, considering the people who made this game, they have a sense of humor, something that is great in a game such as this . I am biased to rate this game 10/10 as its one of my favorites, however it does have its flaws some should be aware of. In the hearthfire dlc, when you bould a house, the lighting inside doesnt properly work. I have looked for numerous fixes and downloaded mods to fix it, to no avail, it seems completely broken and unrepairable. That , for me, is a huge problem, as i am a visual type of guy, i like the beauty i find in things, and when you build a grand house where the lighting is bleak and dead because of a glitch rendering the torches not to work, well, it really puts a sour taste in my mouth. However, dont take my word as law, some people dont have the glitch, and some do, it seems. Its different per person from what ive read and spent countless hours trying to fix. There are some other glitches around but alot of the skyrim bug fixing mods fix them. This game is still a 10/10 for me, despite its flaws and occasional bug or blemish. Oh yea, argonians and khajitt for life. Preferably Khajitt, its hard to choose, but my biased love for lions and large cats wins me over this round. DAMN YOU BETHESDA.

game-hours: 265.3
review: After playing over 500 hours (180 on PC and the rest on Xbox) I can say that Skyrim is one of my favourite games of all time. If you are a fan of open world games then this is the game for you, you can spend hours lost in the beauty of the landscape and discovering things. The game has plenty of customization: Swords, Axes, etc.. all work well together and the magic system is a definate improvement over the previous games; combine any two spells or even wield a weapon and a spell together. Along with the armor choices, alchemy and enchanting I think this is what makes Skyrim stand out from the other RPG's out there, not forgetting the world of course! I do however have some points that I feel do let the game down, firstly I feel that the games lacks depth in the quests and npcs, your choices throughout the game don't really affect the world and one of the faction quest endings *cough*dark brotherhood*cough* definatelt lacks the impact of what you do. Another thing that lets the game down is the repetative nature of the quests, after playing for so long I have started to notice the quests follow this format "Go get X from this cave Y" This could be a positive however if you like that sort of quest but for me it really started to make the game feel stale. Overall, I definatly recomend you buy this game as it is a great RPG and if you get into the modding scene you can really make your game amazing.

game-hours: 337.8
review: I started playing the Elder Scrolls series at Morrowind, a game that sucked away hundreds of hours of my life. Skyrim is a wonderful addition to the series, with beautiful graphics, sounds, and a well-written main storyline. I love the player interactions with the NPCs, the interconnectivity of actions (e.g. if you kill someone with a living relative, that relative will send an assassin after you), and the dragons! For new players, Skyrim offers a nice tutorial as your first quest, giving you time to adjust to the controls and learn how to fight in a controlled environment. Plus, the game levels up your enemies as you grow, so you don't have to worry about dying while you walk around. And while people familiar with the Elder Scrolls already know a lot of the lore, new players will not miss out by not playing previous games. SPOILER ALERT: My one complaint is the game's insistence that a player choose one side in the civil war. During the main quest, you learn that the civil war is a construct by the Thalmor. But you cannot use this knowledge to get either side to stop fighting. And I see the good and bad points of both sides. I would love for Bethesda to put out some DLC that allows players to unite the Empire and the rebels against the Thalmor. In the meantime, I avoid joining either side of the fight.

And if you don't stop him he will eat the world. Yeah, seriously. I give it a A quality for storytellling. Graphics: The Graphics are very good for a game of its time. The game was made in 2011 so it had next gen graphics back then. The Graphics are still buetifal and run well on any PC. Just make sure your computer matches the Minium or Recomended builds at the bottom of the store page. I give it a sight seeing quality. Sounds: I love the music for this game. Currently their are 4 expansion packs that you can buy. The Dawngaurd DLC whier you can choose to become a vampire hunter or a vampire lord, the Hearthfire DLC whier you can build your own Skyrim castle instead of buying the Breezehome, the Dragonborn DLC whier you can go to the island of Solstheim with more Dragon Slaying (Adds Riding Dragons too!!), and finally the High Resolution DLC whier you just get a high res update. Overall Grade: A, Would Buy Legendary Edition P.S : I recomend beating most of the game first, then starting with mods on the nexus. The mods are amazing for Skyrim after your down with most of the game.

game-hours: 121.4
review: Disclaimer *********************************************************************************************************************** This review is my personal point of view, as I have never actually played the first games in the series. So don't start commenting stuff like "No way dude, "Morrowwind" was SO much better!" *********************************************************************************************************************** The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.... Wow, what a game it is. With a deep story, superb RPG elements and good graphics, you're in for a hell of a ride! "The Elder Scrolls" series has had it's fair share of ups and downs, but this game made Bethesda Studios my #1 choice for game developer! Bethesda, I salute you! As it is a sandbox/open-world game, Skyrim can feel a bit empty at first, with not much to do. But as you get more and more in to the game you discover that it's more than just a massive world. It's an living world, with workers and children and creatures and dragons and monsters, the list just goes on! Some may say that Skyrim is indeed a fantastic game, but it's older brothers are far more superb. With that I cannot argue, as I have never played the first four games. But for me, it is still one of the best RPGs I have ever played! What more is there to say really? Well, here's a list of 6 good things, 6 things that need improvement and 3 things that just really suck! :) (No reasons why, just listing them! ;) ) ********************************************************************************************************************* Spot-on: + Most of the RPG elements (the skill trees and the exploring, for example) + Music and atmosphere of the world + M.S.L (Main Story Line) + Weapon system + Side quests + Overall feeling of the game Needs a bit of work: = Combat system = A few of the RPG elements (enchanting for example) = Voice acting and variations of voices over all = Animations (a bit less clunky) = Saving system = Selling/Buying mechanic (according to me ;) ) Really sucks!: - Enemy, NPC and Ally AI (It's freaking terrible!) - Lipsyncing (Sometimes) - Fire effects (Just looks cheap) So, what is my final rating? With many spot-on mechanics and some flaws, Skyrim is not yet at 10/10, but damn near it, so, my final rating is a 9.5/10!

game-hours: 1204.0
review: Consider my playtime on this game - most would call me a fanatic. But the simple truth is that the majority of my playtime was not recorded until I was able to link my selection of mods with Steam. Skyrim is an like a Sketch of a masterpeice by a toddler, a crayon scribble with boundless effort and ethusiasm, but very little actual substance. Where Morrowind succeeds in telling a great story, Skyrim fails, yet it's everything Morrowind needed as technological improvements for total immersion. Skyrim with it's arcade style gameplay (levelling up by using abilities) allows the player to control the pacing - yet With Mods, it can both excel and surpass even the deepest of Immersive games like Metro 2033, and improve the combat mechanics to the level of Jedi outcast. The most important mods I can recommend for this game, that has allowed for so much replay would be. Interesting NPC's - 300 NPC's with interesting, funny, lore based dialgue. There's even a regular Joe who asks who you, the player are, If you reply Dragonborn, he interviews you. Start a new Life - Allows the player to skip the Intro sequence and ignore the Dragonborn quests if you want to Roleplay, allows hundreds of back stories, starting locations and items. Want to become a Hunter in the wilds? Want to become a Forsword and learn their culture? Or want to become a Vampire's Thrall? Stacks with Interesting NPC's incredibly fluidly. Sneak tools - Allows the crafting and use of Water and Fire Arrows - Incorporates the ability to light and put out candles with magic and enviromental effects. A total atmosphere changer during combat. There are many more but you need only install the highest endorsed by the community pages of Nexus and Skyrim workshop Lastly - If you've gotten bored of Skyrim. - another recommendation 1 Find and Load - a Save game with 100% Skyrim completion & try out the DLC's for Skyrim fresh?

game-hours: 130.3
review: Buy this game. If you're interested enough to start looking at reviews, especially poorly written player reviews on Steam, then you need to be playing this, right now. I have barely scratched the surface of Skyrim, being currently only 16 hours into it, yet I have already experienced some of the most immersive and memorable moments in this game, from all of my 30 years of gaming. Leaving the warmth of the inn at Riverwood in the dead of night, to venture up the steep ascent towards Bleak Falls Barrow, barely able to make out the mountain path in the dim light, as dawn breaks and the first snow of the day starts to fall. The sound of gravel underfoot replaced with the crisp crunch of fresh snow. The silhouette of a dark tower up ahead, flames of a torch illuminating not only a doorway, looking invitingly warm and welcoming, but also a bandit at it's entrance; I draw my sword... Sure, combat is basic, with left and right mouse buttons corresponding to using left or right hand weapons, shields or spells respectively, but I find each battle to be exciting, gritty and immersive (especially when choosing first person view over the third person perspective). Stats are simplified, although I found this to be a welcome break, coming from Dragon Age: Origins; who needs to know a character's Dexterity, Willpower or Cunning, or a hundred different stats about a shield? Weight, Armour and what it's worth. Sorted. (As much as I prefer my first play through of any game to be the 'vanilla' experience, I would encourage players to download the SkyUI mod, which massively improves the inventory screens and user interface of Skyrim). Simplifying certain elements has helped maintain focus on the player experience, and what an experience. From the superb soundtrack that accompanies your journey; the ambient sounds of every location, from the whistling winds of the plains and those distant howls that soon become a visible threat and inevitable fight with wolves, to the groans of underground temples and the echo of your sword being drawn. To the wonderfully detailed graphics, changing light and shade with the day/night cycle, and weather effects warning of an impending storm. I could go on but there is too much to cover. A morning walk taking in the atmospheric graphics and picking herbs and flowers that can later be used to craft potions; aquiring a bow and arrows, and hunting deer for food, or hide that can be used to craft leather armour; getting caught stealing and having to break out of prison; paying off guards to clear the bounty a village has on your head; or simply getting on with the main quest, and the experience that is Skyrim.

It will look prettier, run faster, hit harder, freeze colder, burn hotter, cut deeper, and crash almost all the time. This is one of the four basic PC Gaming food groups. No questions asked.

game-hours: 521.7
review: The sequel we all hoped for. Set in the beautiful, frozen, frigid north lands, in the same world as previous titles Morrowind and Oblivion. The player takes the role of a hero known as the Dragonborn, a warrior with the body of a mortal but the soul of a dragon, whose destiny it is to destroy a great evil! That being said the game lends it's self to moral ambiguity quite well. The player being able kill or help pretty much whoever he wishes, with your actions actually having an impact as you mold the world around you with your decision or indecision - this is of course the holy grail of any open world fantasy epic. A hardcore RPG'er won't enjoy that turning down missions your charcter wouldn't take on his chosen path of morality can cause you to miss out on some fun parts of the game. but hey! maybe try a second play through as a 'bad guy!' Skyrim really ticks almost all of the RPG boxes, Want to fight Dragons? Demons? Join a clan of Wearwolves? maybe your prefer Vampires? No problem! You want to be a career criminal? Assasin? Hunter? Get married and build your own house? It's literally all in here. With over 400 hours of game time so far I am still finding new areas, quests and things to explore. Throw the workshop Mods into the mix and this is a must have game that I believe will come to be regarded as a classic.

game-hours: 278.3
review: This is an amazing game and I could reccomend it to any fan of the RPG genre. The character customization is amazingly good, as is the gameplay. You have a large veriety of weapons and skills to use. Not a fan of melee weapons? Use magic. That sword to weak for you? Warhammer. This game allows you to choose the paths you walk, you decide your life. Tons of different dialog options that get unique reactions from the NPCs, each one with their own personality and things to say. There are multiple different factions too. The Companions, who are noble fighters. The Thieves Guild, a bunch of thieves who have a surprisingly complex storyline. The Dark Brotherhood, a group of assassins... And many more. This game has hundreds, maybe even thousands of hours worth playing. And the DLC only makes it better somehow. Although the games has its flaws and occasional bugs, its well worth the money and you should definetally spend time playing it.

game-hours: 156.3
review: So lets get this review out of the way, is this a good game for fans just starting to get into RPG's, the answer is.....H*** yes. With a beautifully created world and modding support, the game is virtually endless, though lacking many elements that could have made it a proper RPG, it is extremly easy to learn and get an intro into the RPG Genre, I found flaws in it though, which made it dissapointing. The Flaws: The crafting and selling system is largely un RP and is just simplified into selling or buying, making or selling good gear, I am of the oppinion that if they put in a style of reputation system (such as WoW) where you need to be a certain rep to buy things, that would have been perfect, or slightly more RP. Also, Skyrim doesn't seem too wartorn, now with mods, several of them create large warbands, but without them, the world is quite dull for a country at war. And third, the sheer amount of glitches at release was staggering, but with many mods and patches, these are finally under control and shouldn't break gameplay too much. My Final Recommendation Beautiful vistas, mountains, and rivers flowing with fish make this game amazing, f*** off consols, after comparing console graphics with my PC, I then packed my Xbox360 with C4 and well, you can guess :) In other words, though gameplay and realism is slightly lacking, it is great for a newbie and casual gamer to enter into the RPG genre.

review: This Game really does deserve a 10/10. And 10/10 does not mean "ZOMG BEST *profanity here* GAME EVER, GOOD LAWD MY EYES ARE MELTING." Shame on you. and finally +there's a well written political strife involved within the civil conflict of Skyrim: so factions. Right now, this game is a steal for $30. Even for it's opening retail price, it is one of the best games out there in the market right now. Whether you like by the book rpg games or unique rpgs with a strange twist such as sci fi, Skyrim is a great game for anybody looking for a game that is quite possibly the most immersive fantasy adventure experience. game-hours: 328.3
review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim has taken away DAYS of my life. With so many characters to interact with, and most of them giving quests, the game is hard to get bored of. The province of Skyrim is a vast land waiting for you to explore every last corner, find every last septim, and kill every last dragon. As a role playing game it is fantastic, with a major questline for each player to purchase it. For example, if you want to be a hero then join either the Companions or the College of Winterhold, but it doesn't stop there, if you want to use combat join the Companions. For magic, join the College. You also have the standard 10 Elder Scrolls races (Argonian, Altmer, Breton, Dunmer, Imperial, Khajiit, Nord, Orc, Redguard, and Bosmer) that each have different starting stats and abilities. The combat in Skyrim isn't the best. The weapons are varied and can fit different playing styles, but when you hit something it just seems like you're wacking something with a sword until it falls over and dies. You can't tell that your even hurting it without it's health bar, but it's not the worst combat. Finally, the story. For me, the story was definitely NOT the best part of the game. It was pretty simple, basically you're the "chosen one" and you go on an adventure where more people tell you that you're the chosen one, and then for some reason you need to find an Elder Scroll, and then more boring stuff. This was why I stayed away from the main questline. Overall Skyrim is fantastic and definitely is worth your time. I give it a 4.7/5

game-hours: 460.9
review: Where do I start with game? Well, the beginning is usually good. Skyrim is an amazing game. I have over 400 hours on pc and over 1000 on xbox, and I haven't even nearly completed all the story lines or discovered all locations on both. The massive variety of mods allow almost an infinite number of hours. with countless extra story lines, graphics and textures mods, follower mods, or mods that make you go "What the f*ck", such as the infamous "Thomas the Tank engine"mod. With different playstyles available such as SneakMage or Spellsword, it's completely up to you. make your own. Make it work. You want to main lockpicking and illusion? DO IT. If you enjoy the game, which i believe firmly that you will, then you don't need much more. Combat is fun, allowing for different strategies depending on what weapons you use. In a nutshell, Skyrim is a giant playground, waiting to be populated with dead dragons and various corpses. Now, onto the other side....nothing is perfect. Despite there being mods, i am reviewing modless Skyrim, dlc included. I felt rather at a loss when assaulting the capital cities of the Empire and the Stormcloak, because i just didn't feel i was in a giant battle, stepping back, i could see no more than 15 npcs, Stormcloaks and Empire alike. It just wasn't enough. i was expecting a giant battle of over 100 friends and foes slaughtering each other. but i was left with something so scripted, you could mistake it for a Wrestling match. *Caution, possible spoilers ahead* The final battle with Alduin is, frankly, terrible. Your destiny as the Dragonborn is to defeat Alduin, but why you have 3 immortal Nords who are gifted in the way of the voice helping you is beyond me. The fight is effectively the same as fighting any other dragon. Dragonrend, hack away with your sword, axe, whatever, wait until he flies off and repeat. Aside from some disappointing combat experiences, the odd bug and Lydia, this is a game which you shouldn't go without playing. 98/100

game-hours: 58.3
review: My first playthrough of Skyrim was on the 360, where I played the story of the game to completion. There is a reason for me saying this right off the bat. I'm saying it so you can understand what I mean when I say the PC experience is so much more different than the console version. And it's not because of the usual suspects one considers when thinking of a PC release. Sure the graphics can be set to higher quality and the game loads somewhat faster, but these are really only the most superficial differences. The major difference in Skyrim on the PC and Skyrim on a console is you. By that I mean the collective "you", the Modders and the community around popular and upcoming mods like Skywind and Skyblivion, all enabled by the versatility of the Creation engine developed by Bethesda. I can't wait to see what lies ahead for the inevitable new Fallout running on this engine. This also poses a problem, that being you may find yourself spending most of your time adding and making sure mods are working and cooperating with one another, than actually playing. Just try to actually play the game once in a while and smell the roses.

review: HANDS DOWN ONE OF THE BEST GAMES OF ALL TIME! The lore, the world, the gear!!! This game is amazing! You can spend hundreds and hundreds of hours in this game, with the same save, and still find dozens of new NPC's, dungeons and miscellaneous quests! The combat is fun and satisfying. The voice acting can tend to get a little dull at times seeing as pretty much everyone is voice acted by this same small amount of people. The in game secrets, references, and easter eggs are brilliant. Especially the Three Billy Goats Gruff easter egg. There are dozens of books to read which add plenty of extra lore and history to the game's continents and world called Nirn. Skyrim is an amazing province, with its massive mountains, swamps, grasslands and so on. The DlC's are also brilliant! Adding dozens to hundreds of hours of extra gameplay! The worst parts about the game has probably got to be the common quest glitches, which stop you from starting or proceeding in a quest. Some quests also don't have quest markers at times. The levelling up also takes hours. 215 hours and I'm level 62. Its gonna take a while to reach level 80. Anyway, this game is brilliant and a must own. review: "My friends are all out playing DayZ, and what do I get? Skyrim Duty" This has to be one of my favourite ever games, although I admit my playing hours do not back that up so much. None the less Skyrim is nothing less then brilliant. I've never really understood the meaning of immersion until I played this game, the sandbox freedom coupled with the sheer beauty of the landscape, the lore that follows the series is incredibly detailed and just enhances the entire experience. The quests are incredibly varied, though the dungeons do become a little repetitive at times, and as good as the voice acting is, the AI do repeat themselves a lot throughout the game. A friend of mine recently introduced me into the realm of modding Skyrim textures and it doesn't stop there. The texture mods, though load heavy for PC's, are absolutely stunning, they turn what was already a beautiful game into something that makes real life look like a 2D scroller from the 90's. There are an huge range of mods from Quests to Map additions and even to realism mods, making the game virtually unable to bore you. I could go on and on about how this game deserves your attention, but I can't be bothered, so I will leave it like this: If you enjoy Sandbox games, and you have not played any Elder Scrolls game before, give Skyrim a go! 10/10

review: I recommend this for gamers who like: Open World or RPGs. Issues: The only issues I had were maybe the graphics which I fixxed through mods. You later arrive in Helgen about to get your head chopped along with the fellow Stormcloaks who also got caught along with a horse thief. Just before you get your head chopped off, a dragon attacks Helgen. As you try to escape you can go with either Ralof(A stormcloak rebel) or Hadvar(An imperial soldier). Afterwards you can do almost whatever you want, that's what I like about open world games. You can continue through the main quest or do side quests. game-hours: 390.3
review: This game will bind you to your PC and wont let you go for a long long time. The Main Story-line is good, solid, and befitting of the Elder Scrolls. Some complain that it is nothing special, which might be true it is nothing totally new. But one has to consider that most things seem to have been there at one point or another. Instead of laying the focus on innovation I rather put it on how the story is delivered. The Story unfolds depending on your playstyle, you can have it unfold right into your face if you rush ahead. But you could also spend days or weeks in the game and barely scratch the surface of the Storyline. There is a lot to do in Skyrim, a seemingly endless amount of side-quests offer diversion and immersion into the Lore of TES ( The Elder Scrolls ). Besides delving deeper into the TES universe that way, one will also be rewarded with Coin, magical Weapons, Ancient armor and more. The Combat System is not overly complex but offers enough freedom for creative approaches. Especially on higher difficulties, or through mods, combat can be quite challenging and rewarding. Freedom of choice regarding Weapons and Magic add to the diversion of the combat system. Playstyle changes accordingly to ones choice of Weapon and Profession. The Visuals of the game are good and the design of the world appears Epical. Granted the basic Graphic was not spectacular but through the means of a free DLC it got much sharper. There is also the option of visually modding the game, the results are simply stunning. The Sound is bombastic, it adds to the immersion, the music is putting one in the right mood and underlines the fantasy setting. The Graphical User Interface is clearly a console Port, but it is managable. The game has a very active mod community, especially on the Nexus. One can drastically enhance or change the game there and replay it countless times. Each DLC adds greatly to the game as well, adding new content, options and storylines. The game definately has flaws, logical ones, some bugs, but they are not game breaking. The saying " perfection is made by flaws " fits, in regards of the mod community, very well here. Many a flaw inspired a modder to contribute to the game turning a semi rough diamond into a gem to behold. If you like freedom of choice, action, a nice story, immersion and exploring then you should not miss this milestone in game History.

game-hours: 44.9
review: 10/10!!!!
game-hours: 95.3
review: Previously had this game on 360 but purchased on PC for the DLC. I still haven't played them. Other than being an indisputably incredible game on its own its the modding community that add so much to this title. This is the 1st game Ive modded and Im still learning, but Nexus Mod Manager wasnt too difficult to get my head around. I tried some mods that I usually wouldnt because why the hell not? And now I cant live without them! I highly recommend the Frostfall, Realistic Needs and Diseases, Cloaks of Skyrim and Wet & Cold immersion mods, and while Im add it try out Live Another Life if youve played the core story already. This little combination changes the game so drastically that it becomes an entirely different beast. No longer the invincible Dragonborn I became a one-eyed old-timer complete with weathered face and scraggly beard, mortal and alone in the vast winter wilds. A bounty on my head and nothing but the clothes on my back I sought shelter from the biting cold in an old lighthouse only to find its inhabitants mutilated by something unknown. I pick up an axe and collect what I canmeat, a torch, some wine and stale breadand venture into the cellar only to be attacked by some vile beast. The creature is ferocious and well-armoured, I am barely able to defeat it; it seems they emerged from a tunnel in the cellar and caught these poor people unaware. Having taken all my energy to defeat two of the beasts I decide it best to move on an leave the shelter of the lighthouse. As I walk through the snow in search of civilisation a blizzard rolls in. With no sign of civilisation in sight I need to make a fire, FAST. There are no trees in sight but I spot a beach nearby  I can collect driftwood! I tell myself. I gather some wood but its not enough, but now I spot something atop the cliff. I climb with what little energy I have left and reach the top, and my heart fades  its a magical stone. Im frozen to the bone, covered in a thick layer of snow; I can barely move. I gave it my best shot but my time has comein a few shorts moments I will slip into the icy abyss and be at peace. I reach into my backpack, may as well drink the wine I think to myself. And then I see it. I was SO CLOSE to death and I had not seen this powerful scroll imbued with a spell I could never dream of casting on my own. I murmur the words through icy lips and a dome of protective magic appears around me. From the ethereal appears a bed, chest, table and chair, theres a fireplace and stove, hell, theres even alchemy and enchanting tables! The magic bubble shields me from the blizzard that rages just metres away, and here I stand  inches from death in a luxurious magic bubble atop a mountain that overlooks the coast; if only I had the damn firewood to start a fire. The night was long and it took me some time to warm up on my own, but I survived. The next morning my bubble disappeared and I set off on my journey again, gathering more driftwood and eventually finding my way to a small settlement on the coast. This was a harrowing experience in which I had come dangerously close to the end, but I had survived. In the new settlement I found bed and board and learned of a school of magic on the outskirts of town. With an new found appreciation for the arts I decided to devote my life to the pursuit of knowledge.

Luckily for me, just a swift swing of my sword sent him flying back to Oblivion, but to my surprise I was yet to leave the Danger Zone as a troll began trolling me with the trololol song playing alongside his dumb troll face. With the mix of Kenny Loggins and trolling making my ears nearly bleed, I began to run for my life jamming out to now just Danger Zone when out of nowhere I was hit with a wave of childhood memories as a thundering "choo choo" overcomes the glory of Kenny's voice. As I looked to the sky, down came Thomas the Tank as he blasted me with his fiery breathe. In the background, a faint trolling began to creep back into my ears as that damn trolling troll began to catch up to me with my new aforementioned foe. Overcome with nostalgia, fire, trolls trolling, and ungodly amounts of damage being hurled my way, I noticed my screen beginning to flicker. Faster and faster, the flickering began to overcome my screen and suddenly in a heartbeat, I was no more. All that remained as my body hit the floor was the faint sounds of Kenny reminding me that I was indeed on the highway to the Danger Zone, and the lesson of how you never pick a fight with a troll as the one I took on danced his trololol victory dance. 11/10 would recommend

game-hours: 27.8
review: One of the greatest games ever made, it has so many branching storylines and a great main story which your not confined into completing to travel further in game. The world is yours to do as you see fit and arent constrained by locked areas or blocked paths. Your character feels apart of you, from every battle you take part in , every path you take and all the places you discover you just become engrossed in the world that is Skyrim. The DLC and content the steam workshop adds to the already expanisve world you are thrust into makes a game with a really unlimited about of playability. When you begin your adventure , which is the only way that you can describe the journey your about to embark upon, youll discover a world of different races , beasts, groups , each with its own history and lore which you can spend hours upon reading in the books you find through out the game. My first encounter with a dragon was literally the first time ever in a game where i actually felt panic and fear. The music changes , everything arounds you start to tremble as you peer up to the sky and see a dragon overhead (technically a wyvern), i didnt expect the encounter to happen it as it did , completely random , no warnining. And thats what makes this game great , you can never be to sure of whats going to happen next. the only issue i had with this game is that (now this is going to contain spoilers) is that after becoming the leader if the mages, the leader of the companions (fighting guild), leader of the thieves guild, thane of every hold and being able to kill a dragon with a few blows and a yell of your voice , people who still have a snow flakes chance in hell still attempt to kill you. In my opinnion your reputation should actually hold some weight , and not merely a once off free pass to a crimes and bounty But in saying all that, there is so much in this game to do , so many suprises and so many things to keep you occupied i cant possibly mention it all here. so what are you waiting for , jump in pick up a sword , a staff, maybe even both and carve out your place in skyrim!

review: I recommend to play Skyrim. This is the first game in years, which I would say is worth its money. A lot of content, 5 major quest lines, and uncountable side quests and missions. game-hours: 194.7
review: It's massive. Vanilla story alone will take you 100+ hours to complete, not to mention DLCs. The good: The mechanics are solid, the gameplay is smooth, the scenery is gorgeous, and mods make it even better. The bad: The magic leaves a lot to be desired, it's clunky, the menus are primitive, and you can spend more time scrolling then you do shooting. (Mods recommended to alleviate this) The ugly: It seems that a team of maybe 20 total voice actors voiced about 1500 people in the game, I'm used to some overlap, but hearing the same guy's voice (not disguised or changed in any way) on three different people in the same town of 20 people is a little annoying. Conclusion: Annoyances aside, it's an incredible game with a rich story and the mods will produce more content then you'll ever be able to play in your lifetime. This game will eat your life, and you will love it.

The bottom line though is that this game is basically like Oblivion on steroids. If you liked Oblivion and spent 200+ hours playing it like I did, you will be addicted to Skyrim.

game-hours: 111.9
review: It's Skyrim.... Just play it.
game-hours: 647.6
review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim (or: How I gave up my life and became the Dragonborn then stopped being the Dragonborn and became a hunter, because its better.) From the Studio that bought you the Fallout universe (after they bought the rights to it), Bethesda Bring you the next, fifth instalment in the popular Elder Scrolls series. Packed with Dragons, Civil War and muscular men that kind of sound like Arnold Schwarzenegger if youre passing by them and not paying attention, the northern province of Skyrim (which is the name of the country, for complete newcomers to the series) is in turmoil and needs the help of a certain prisoner caught illegally crossing the border. For those new to The Elder Scrolls as a series, there have been four games leading up to this point that, whilst not necessary to own in order to get the most out of your Skyrim experience, may do you some good if you at least google the background of the lore. Its very deep and if you like fantasy I assure you its worth your time. I personally bought this game first and then purchased TES 3: Morrowind and TES 4: Oblivion because I really enjoyed the series. You can really jump into this world at any point in the timeline and still become an educated historian of Tamriel if the mood takes you. The Elder Scrolls V is really both sides of a coin when it comes to the actual gameplay side of things. On the positive side, the sword/axe/mace play is very satisfying and well presented and, on PC at least, the response and accuracy you receive from the ranged weapons (bows in the vanilla game and crossbows if you purchase the DAWNGUARD DLC) is fantastic and what I would assume these weapons handle like in the real world, coming from a guy who looked at a home-made bow once and thought nah, Im okay, Ill pass on firing that thing. Movement control is highly responsive and precise enough that you only have yourself to blame if you fall off a mountain, which happens a lot in the first 10 or so hours. If you were to play in first person mode (which I recommend, once you get over the fantastic, if sometimes out of place animations) then it is rather easy, with the simple addition of some decent headphones, to convince yourself that you are, in fact, the six-foot talking cat you chose to become at the character select screen. Yes, thats right. Six foot talking cats. No, you cant make them blue and re-enact some sort of medieval style Avatar fan remake, we have fan-fic writers and Tumblr for that. On the other hand, the combat can sometimes feel rather boxy and thuggish. Yes, I realise that this game is centred around the idea that you chose to be a six foot, muscular man (as the trailer suggested), but the addition of a couple of more flowing fighting styles for the other races wouldnt have hurt. If I were to choose to play as lets say, an elegant elven woman then I wouldnt expect her to throw herself at the enemy with the force of the alcohol-fuelled barbarian that the game seems to expect you to play as. Overall I feel that the positives to the combat far outweigh the drawbacks, and if you can get over the times where you line up a perfect shot only to have your target slide to one side and dodge the arrow, or the times where a kill-cam move glitches you through a wall, then I think youll be fine. The UI in game is neither good nor bad. It does its job, stop whining and continue with your life. Yes, it seems to be aimed at people who are less hard core than some players and I have become, but thats because this game is aimed at newcomers to the RPG genre. If you find yourself becoming immersed in the game, and want nit-picky things like item sorting, individual stats etc to show up like you would note down items on a D&D character sheet then google how the Skyrim Script Extender works and download the SKYUI mod from the Skyrim Nexus. If you dont know/care what UI or D&D stand for, this isnt something you really have to worry about. This game glitches. Sometimes they are minor things like texture popping, other times the entire civil war quest line will be destroyed because of something that went wrong in the coding. The latter is very rare - unless you play with the, frankly, stupid amount of mods I play with in which case you got what you had coming. Most glitches you will encounter will be minor texture popping, giants spinning and shooting off into the stratosphere and the occasional war stories regarding arrows to the knee. Why that turned into a meme I will never know, but it annoys me, its a glitch, shush. The game is very late in its update period and most major game destroying glitches have been fixed, to my knowledge. On the system requirements front: I have a friend who runs this on low settings (but not the lowest) on a 350 laptop sporting an i3 processor with 4GB ram, you shouldn't have any major issues getting this to run. The modding community for this game is huge. It is also fantastic. My Skyrim is an almost completely different game from the original release and I love it, because once I finished playing the fantastic vanilla game, I modded my game to hell and enjoyed it all over again in fantastic community-created ways. Once you complete your first couple of playthroughs, go on to Skyrim Nexus, download the mod manager and mod the game to your hearts content. The dangers with this are, of course, massive glitching. Almost everything you do in this game will affect something that happens elsewhere. Its a very delicate infrastructure and not all modders are professionals. If you make a fantastic Victoria Sponge cake and I throw potato peel at it because I think itll look better, doesnt make me right. Same goes for mods. Sort of. Your cake would be a lie. By all means, delve into the modding community. Pretty much all the issues I mentioned about the UI and gameplay functions can be fixed with a handful of very good mods. Also, if you like Lord of the Rings or Game of Thrones then youre gonna be right at home here. Overall: I would recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the fantasy genre (in any medium) and/or RPG based games. The game is a bit buggy in places, but thats because its a massive open world created with the purpose of immersing you within the confines of a country at war. You can do and be anyone, especially with the help of mods. In the 500 hours I have put into this title on PC alone, I have never run out of something to do or people to become. Go buy this game, become the Dragonborn and save Skyrim from itself in the civil war  because when you come back to this game and play through again as a hunter, mercenary, thief, assassin, merchant (all of which have their own dedicated guilds with their own dedicated and lengthy quest lines) you will be free to really experience this world for the beautiful technological and creative masterpiece it is. But dont just take my word for it, go and draw your own conclusions
