review: The Elder Scrolls in general is a fantastic series of games but I would have to say that the Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is my favorite. The immersive gameplay, excellent graphics, and endless things to do definitely makes this game my #1 favorite! Just to prove to you that this game is as outstanding, let me share with you a little story. I used to play fps's on my xbox all the time and I have to tell ya...it got pretty boring. But then for my birthday I was given, by a friend, a used copy of Skyrim. When I first started playing, just to be honest, I never thought I would really like it ( I mean, when you hear people on COD and Halo bashing it because it's not a shooter, you tend to be a little cautios about how much enjoyment you expect). But as I started to play it more and more, I found myself happily wasting hours and hours of my time slaying dragons, exploring dungeons, fighting armys, gaining wealth, and many other strangely-enjoyable things. Eventually I decided I wanted more out of my Skyrim and I started to look into these things people called "mods". As I learned more about these "mods" I read that you could only get these on the pc version of the game. Saddened, I soon returned to playing my old fps games. After spending alot to time away from Skyrim, I decided it was time I play it again. After spending many hours playing the game and watching videos, I wished even more that I had a pc that could handle Skyrim efficiently. About a year later I had made my decision. Getting tired of the constant fighting and incompetence of console gaming, I purchased for myself a gaming computer. After playing skyrim for a while I decided I wanted to finally download mods. This made my game unbelievably awsome! I now have many mods on my Skyrim and spend much time playing it and many other games on Steam. Now if you don't feel as if this review has helped make up your mind, might I suggest you check out some other reviews and maybe go check out some videos on the Internet. - TheTurboLlama

Creatures, monsters, and NPCs are found in every environment, and nearly everything can be killed (except the children.. they cannot die... no matter how many times you whack them with a hammer...) You carve your own gameplay experience based on how you chose to play the game.. whether you become a blood sucking vampire and have to lurk about in the night, or if you become a werewolf prowling under the moonlight. game-hours: 491.5
review: I have been a fan of Elder Scrolls for many many years, and while I would rate this one as being somewhat less brillant than past games, it is still a top rate RPG. I could hate this game for being simplified for more casual gamers, but the success of this game means that future TES games are more likely, and I am a fan of that any day. There is no reason not to love this game, any complaints you have can be changed, fixed, improved, or removed with mods made by you, or by the multitude of people out there. The stories in the ES universe are as good as it gets. It is a complete world with so much depth, you can play the game again and again and find things you never knew before. Older games like Morrowind have even more depth as far as stories go (and your place in them). Skyrim is flashier and more accessible to the average person, but if this game has you wanting more, try the older games in the series, they are arguably better in terms of story and depth. If you can deal with older graphics and game systems that is. In spite of the age, they offer more in the way of character building, and require more effort and are more rewarding as a result. The magic system alone in Morrowind rewards creative and clever people with an amazing number of spell effects that can be mixed any way you want. You can spend as much time modding this game as playing, and the modding community consists of people who have been modding TES games for a decade or more. There is no lack of things to do with this game, and if you are willing to invest some effort it can become many times over the game you first purchased. Worth every penny and then some.

game-hours: 29.9
review: [THE SUBTLE FLAWS OF SKYRIM] (flaws people should consider before purchasing) NOTE: I've invested hundreds of hours into a cracked version of Skyrim before actually making the purchase on steam, so it only shows that I've played 10 or so hours. Screw me, right? Everytime you hear about Skyrim, it's always some magnificent praise. "It's the best RPG of this generation!" they say, "It's the best game ever!" And I don't blame them, Skyrim really is magnificent. The amount of content, QUALITY CONTENT, within this game is phenomenal. It's arguably the longest singleplayer experience in the history of gaming, without ever feeling as if it was being dragged on artifically. In fact, the pace of the game is entirely in your control. Want to burn through the main storyling? Fine. Want to take your time and breathe in the atmosphere, choosing from a variety of interesting quests? Fine. Elder Scrolls games always feel as if you are in control; that your story is yours to shape. It's that signature feeling of control and freedom that makes an Elder Scrolls Game....and Elder Scrolls Game. Unfortunately, Skyrim is the least arguably the least immersive of the series. Here is why: 1. HANDHOLDING, HANDHOLDING EVERYWHERE There are already plenty of videos on youtube going into detail of this flaw. Basically, features that gave the player more room to fail are removed in favor of some forms of handholding. There will be times where an NPC is invincible just because he's essential to the story, and the game does not want you to fail the quest. There will be no need to acquire a sense of direction, (as in Morrowind) due to the giant compass pointing to exact location of where you need to be. Even something as simple as opening the only chest in a small room will have a pointer; obnoxiously telling you what to do. For some people, this is a welcome feature. For me and quite a lot of other people, it's a ridiculous flaw. It breaks the immersion that we always expect from an Elder Scrolls game. There isn't even an in-game option to turn this off. (Mods, of course, are able to change this, but I shouldn't have to mod my game for something as simple as the compass) This game does not treat you like an adult, capable of solving problems. 2. YOU HAVE NO INFLUENCE One of the most common complaints of Skyrim players is that you're never actually able to affect the world. The prime example of this complaint is that once you finish the War questline, you have supposedly conquered the land and driven out the opposing side. And yet you still see the same type of NPC's patrolling the land. Only sometimes do NPC's "recognize" you as a valiant warrior of your faction of choice. I put that in quotations because all they're doing is saying "I've heard of you!" and then moving on with their day. , I was entire reason why the war was won. You should be kneeling down and licking my boot! Everyone treats you the same. It doesn't matter if you slayed Alduin or became the thane of ALL HOLDS. People still treat you like crap. 3. GAMEPLAY IS LESS DIVERSE Your time in Skyrim will follow this exact pattern, deviating only a few times. 1. talk to people 2. murder everyone in a dungeon-esque area 3. talk to more people Remember in Morrowind/Oblvion where you are always faced with multiple ways to complete quests? If you played as a stealthy character, you would always take advantage of the enviroment to sneak around and either poison your enemies by sneaking poison into their food, or finish them off with stab to the back. The quests in both games further promoted this sort of mindset, with some quests that are even impossible to complete without truly thinking outside the box. Here in Skyrim, you always end up fighting the same enemies in an (arguably) bland dungeon. It doesn't matter if you play to be stealthy, you're always going to be fighting head on. 4. OBNOXIOUS LEVEL DESIGN Levels are not made with authencity and realism, but for the gameplay in mind. Nearly every fort, ruin, or cavern will always be a straightforward path leading from point A to point B. The inhabitants of said dungeon will simply just stand around. Not very immersive, is it? And that about does it for my "review" of Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim. It's a brilliant game, but only if you don't have the...refined tastes that'll prevent you from having fun. And chances are, you don't. You won't know unless you try, and at the wonderfully reduced price of $30, there is virtually no reason to have a try at this 200+ hour adventure. Huzzah!

game-hours: 111.2
review: Skyrim is perhaps one of the best and most solid games I have ever played. Everything from the graphics to the combat is top notch quality, worthy of the Elder Scrolls series and that of Bethesda. The one thing I love about Skyrim is how optimised it is. It is a massive world teeming with enemies. I never experience any FPS drops. The graphics are great, but mods only make it better. I've modded my Skyrim to be more realistic in terms of graphics and gameplay. This is a very addictive and time consuming game. You start off as a dirty runt in the middle of the forest with no direction. Soon you meet the locals, and you experience Skyrim. The bandits, the dragons, the Draugr and every enemy lurking in Skyrim will soon tremble beneath you. There are basically three types of gameplay you can pursue, the path of the Warrior, the Mage or the Thief. There are the three core gameplay features, but you can mix them up, such as becoming a Battle Mage. As you play you gain levels and skillpoints. Ther'es lots to see and do. There are many storylines to pursue, from the main story to the College of Winterhold quests or Companion storyline. (There are many more.) But Skyrim isn't all slaying enemies. With the Hearthfire expansion, you can build your own house and adopt a kid. You can also get married. You can smelt your own weapons and armour, brew your own potions, cook your own food and so on. This is the first game every gamer must play. Bethesda did a real good job making it. Now to the bad sides. Every good thing has its downsides. One of the things that I don't like is the physics engine. There are mods available on the Steam Workshop such as the Static Mesh Improvement pack that makes world items behave more realisticly, but I really hate the ragdoll physics. They're very stiff and it just bothers me . :/ Also the combat is a bit weird. When you're locked in combat and you start a powerswing, nine times out of ten you will charge straight at your enemy. Often you will slide along their hitbox and actually swing missing them. I find it kind of annoying. Anyway, good game 9/10

game-hours: 166.0
review: Well, it is an Elder Scrolls game and due to the fact that i watched my dad playing Daggerfall when i was a little cub this is something that is almost melded to my body. The Elder Scrolls games where an essential part of my life in the way that i read EVERY SINGLE BOOK INSIDE OF THE GAMES SINCE OBLIVION. Why did i do that? I really dont know it but what i know is that i know quite a lot about the Elder Scrolls Saga and so i feel like writing a review for this. Before i start i should say sorry because i will bring points up which may be a bit missleading, i really like the game in the state i have it in right now and am a complete Scrolls freak so i could counter every point of mine with the Argument that it is part of the Elder Scrolls. So where to start, maybe with the kind of game this is. This is if you would ask me a Sandbox game with RPG elements and not a fullblown RPG and this is why, the most characters in the game appear too onesided, there is almost nobody that questions his or her own actions and even if you can influence the country's politics and raise up in ranks it doesnt really matter. Well that doesnt make any sense Larker you might say now but let me describe what the difference is. If you usually proceed to a higher rank you feel proud because you accomplished something and this feeling isnt existant in Skyrim because these promotions fly in your direction and the reward almost feels casual. Skyrim is in some respectives an rpg, without any doubt but it just doesnt feel completely like it even though it fullfills one point which i will talk about in a second. The game has a good structure and the World is somewhat fascinating with many locations which are interesting enough to visit. There are some parts in it that are repetetive but its in a way that isnt annoying and that is quie an accomplishment if you consider the size of this world. The Quests are a bit more repetetive but i have to defend them because there arent that many things in a game like this that you could give as a quest. The Skill System is good and the shout system brings an interesting aspect into the game even if i have a bit of an argument with myself about it because i personally believe that a shout is entirely different from a bigger power and thus should be on an other button but well what do you wanna do. There are 2 giant problems though. 1. The writing and the story on its own is mostly just sloppy compared with games like oblivion, the characters feel dumb and the interaction is really basic, i understand that bethesda might have gone for a bigger audience and they succeeded but on the way they dumbed down the game quite hard. Interestingly enough are the facts that the books in the game hold more interesting writing than the characters speeches. It doesnt matter if you are an archmage or a Thane because for the guards those two things both are on the same level (They also are most of the times just annoying). The games tries to be a game and thats actually fine by me, if you consider that most Games that try to send a message these days only cause more problems. Though there is maybe and im really not sure about it, critique about politics in it. At the point where the two factions meet up it feels more like kindergarten than politics, but as i said im not sure if this is a critique made by the game developers that was made intentionally. 2. Some Career choices just arent viable on their own. It is unbelievably boring and hard to actually train some traits, like alchemy for example and even if you do they sometimes dont benefit you that much. I picked alchemy because it was quite recent that i made a Skyrim run with an alchemist. So you level up your alchemy but then you find out that brewing poisons and mixing potions on its own is somewhat useless, sure you could put it on your weapons and potions are always awesome but i imagine an alchemist as a mage not as a warrior. So what else could i do? Well you can obviously poison them not by weapons but by simply putting the poison in there bags, what do you need for that? Well another Trait so yay. You Basically have 5 ways to actually viably fight your fights, these are one handed, two handed, archery, destruction and conjuration. I cant completely say i didnt know that before the game came out but i really hoped that i would be able to go a path and dont have to leave it to actually be viable. Why would I hope such a thing? Well now we can talk about that point i spoke of before. Skyrim isnt a hardcore RPG because you arent forced into a character that socially develops and thus almost everything concerning your character happens in the players mind or happens not entirely. It is Roleplaying in its pure way or you arent roleplaying at all and you rather arent roleplaying because due to the few REAL decisions you are limited to the dumbed down format of the game which doesnt give you enough options to play freely, thank Meridia though that there is Mod support for the game which basically gives it an insane amount of replay value and fixes to play as you want. Pro: Beautiful and giant World, Mod Support, High Replay Value, Easy and smooth Story, (Elderscroooooooolls!!!!!!) Contra: Bad or Mediocre Writing, Bad for Roleplaying, Dumb Characters, Too small influence on the world Who should buy this game?: Well almost every person might try this gem, it is easy to start into rpg's with skyrim due to its simple format and can be lots of fun. However if this is your first RPG you might rather not buy it at a full price, if you already like rpg's and are up for a bit of 'sploring you should pick this game up at any time. Make sure that you always buy the legendary edition due to the bigger content and its cheaper to buy it like that, than all on its own. Also check out the Workshop for skyrim and maybe check out TheGreyLight, he made some amazing and useful mods. Sincerely, Lord Larker the Lurker

review: Skyrim is an open-world RPG with many, many hours of content. You start out picking your race. Do I want to be a Khajiit, and roam Skyrim as a thief and/or assassin, or do I want to be a Nord, running up to enemies and crushing their skulls in with swords and axes? There are over 10 different races to choose from, and each have their strength and weaknesses. There are hundreds of quests that are available to the player. Hundreds of caves, dungeons, and castles dot the landscape of Skyrim. There are various groups to join, each one focusing on different skills. The College of Winterhold, a magic-focused group of people. The Dark Brotherhood, bloodthirsty assassins who kill their targets and claim their rewards. The Thieves Guild, a handpicked-few who excel in the art of sneaking, pickpocketing, and stealing things from other people. Last, but not least, the Companions, A few of some of the finest warriors in Skyrim, who fight and live for glory. Battle dragons, skeletons, trolls, and many other beasts, all while making a bit of coin and arming yourself with deadly enchantments, armor, or weaponry.

game-hours: 185.6
review: you can kill both dragons and your time 11/10
game-hours: 29.5
review: Uber!
game-hours: 292.9
review: A wide open and immersive RPG masterpiece, Bethesda once again proves their proficiency in open world games with the latest installment of their single-player RPG titles. Skyrim boasts an incredibly detailed world complemented with plenty of combat, missions and powerful story to instantly hook in any player seeking to lose themselves in a whole new world. Skyrim's gameplay can be summed up with the sentence: "Jack of all trades, master of none". Meaning that there are multiple methods of combat, from your typical dungeon crawler slaughterfest to management of spells to stealth. Since Skyrim is such a huge game, the budget can be expected to be stretched a little thin on all fronts, meaning that while there is a lot of options for gameplay there are still some flaws keeping them from being perfect. Some examples include wonky hit detection (sometimes I shoot an arrow directly at an enemy, and the immediately slide a couple feet to the left and dodge the arrow all together) and absolutely idiotic AI resulting in stealth mechanics coming up being a wee-bit too easy. But this is generally a minor flaw in the face of the big picture, Skyrim is simply grand in size and spectrum, with a massive emphasis on exploration of the deepest caverns to abandoned ruins of ancient civilizations, each being unique and offering something new to experience with it's composition of puzzles, enemies and layout all perfectly wrapped up with beautiful visuals that make the player feel like they really are somewhere else in the universe entirely. The story of Skyrim is but one of many different quest lines, and none of them are completely mandatory. A player if they so desire can completely ignore the main storyline after the prologue, and can explore this well polished and lively country at their own leisure. There are so many different experiences to encounter with the story in Skyrim that I dare not try to list or summarize any of them, and instead encourage players to go out and discover them on their own. Of course with any good RPG, character customization is a huge aspect of Skyrim. The player can choose from one of a dozen races ranging from humans, elves, cats and lizards. Evolving their respective playstyle and spending points earned through levelling up into perks that can enhance their play method of choice. However, minus a few exceptions, the cast of NPCs in Skyrim are for the most part extremely forgettable as they all share the same lineup of voice actors and use the same animations as well as recycling dialogue. This however is forgivable given the broad spectrum of gameplay that Skyrim has to offer. And as a testament to the PC master race, owners of Skyrim on Steam gain access to the Steam Workshop which allows easy download of endless community-made content which ranges from simple bug fixes to all out re-imaginings of some of Skyrims iconic locales. With access to so much content both official and community made it is easy for a player to spend hours on end in this imaginative and memorable world. Being my first time playing any of the Elder Scrolls games I was completely blown away by Skyrim and I have gained an irrefutable respect for Bethesda (despite my overall lack of interest in their Fallout series). So in conclusion, in spite of it's unfortunately massive collection of bugs and glitches, Skyrim is beyond any doubt one of the best RPG titles on the market and only an utter fool would consider the possibility of denying this.
game-hours: 155.6
review: a must have
game-hours: 228.3
review: Let's make something clear: Bethesda, you SUCK at making a stable and bug free game engine. But thankfully the modders did a better job than you and fixed your problems. If you intend to use a few simple easy mods to fix the game's issues, then I very much reccomend the game. I love playing it with a few mods enabled. My only current problem is the unstoppable freezing issue with the Dragonborn DLC (So don't get it). Other than that the game is fantastic. HOWEVER, if you intend to NOT mod the game, and just play it as is, do not buy this game. I'm not bashing the graphics, (they do suck, has that stopped me from playing? No.), I'm bashing the engine. It's very buggy without mods to fix it, and there are some main quest line missions that can't be done (I.e: A Cornered Rat, and if you have Dragonborn, Dragonslayer and The Temple of Miraak.) So get the game, download the "unnoficial skyrim patch" and the others if you have the DLC, get "skyrim project stability" if you want to increase FPS, and any other mods you may find useful. Don't forget the SKSE (skyrim script extender) mod so that these can run. Don't be intimidated by modding this game, as it is very easy to get the hang of. In fact, the Skyrim Nexus even has a mod manager that will handle installation/uninstallation for you.

review: After 200 hours on PC and 350 on console, I can definitely say this is one of the most expansive and fun RPG games in a long time. The level of options regarding combat are quite limitless; whether you want to be a man-sized cat sneak-thief, a heavily armored medieval warrior, a powerful mage, or an unarmed monk that simply uses ancient dragon shouts to level his foes. The graphics for it's time were stellar enough, but with the vast mod community and official support by the developer Bethesda, there is a myriad of mods to enhance every visual aspect as well as in-game mechanics like player animations, tweaked crafting and leveling, different mounts, improved UI... The list goes on forever. Whether you choose to use Steam's built-in workshop or the third-party Skyrim Nexus site is at your discretion. The game contains a main quest, faction quests, side quests, and miscellaneous chores, as well as a preposterous amount of dungeons to be cleared and looted. However, this is only vanilla version; modders have constructed several well-built custom quests of their own. In one case, a team of modders made an entire game expansion, similar to an official paid DLC. Buy this game.

review: You know, when Skyrim first came out in 2011 I was very skeptical about the whole Dragonborn thing, not being a huge fan of Dragon Lore. But I gave it a go just because I loved Oblivion so much. Played around 7-8 hours and the game was so bugged I just uninstalled it and forgot about it. Then came the Steam Summer Sales and wham! Skyrim was on sale for just 3.7 euros. I looked around and the game was patched to a version 1.9, plus there were thousands of mods on the Workshop. So I gave it another chance to fascinate me, and boy did it do it's job. I am now a bit over 20 hours on my playthrough, and let me say just one thing - it's not about the Dragons. It's not about just being Dragonborn. It's not about killing the ers and using their scales for armor. For me, personally, it's about having this vast open world with tons of unique NPCs to interact with, or just roaming in the wilderness doing what ever comes to your mind. Just because you can. It differs from many other RPGs I played, because it isn't 100% linear. And even when you encounter some linear quests, the world is so beautiful and immersive you forget about it quickly, and you just do your thing, what ever that thing is. You wanna be a hunter? Sure. A two-handed weapon barbarian? No problem. A cat blacksmith? You get my point. I can't recommend this game more, it's easily going in my top 5 games ever. With a creative mind and the right mods you can achieve anything, and that's the beauty of Skyrim.

review: Skyrim is an open-world RPG with many, many hours of content. You start out picking your race. Do I want to be a Khajiit, and roam Skyrim as a thief and/or assassin, or do I want to be a Nord, running up to enemies and crushing their skulls in with swords and axes? There are over 10 different races to choose from, and each have their strength and weaknesses. There are hundreds of quests that are available to the player. Hundreds of caves, dungeons, and castles dot the landscape of Skyrim. There are various groups to join, each one focusing on different skills. The College of Winterhold, a magic-focused group of people. The Dark Brotherhood, bloodthirsty assassins who kill their targets and claim their rewards. The Thieves Guild, a handpicked-few who excel in the art of sneaking, pickpocketing, and stealing things from other people. Last, but not least, the Companions, A few of some of the finest warriors in Skyrim, who fight and live for glory. Battle dragons, skeletons, trolls, and many other beasts, all while making a bit of coin and arming yourself with deadly enchantments, armor, or weaponry.
game-hours: 51.9
review: There are few words which can describe just how amazing this game is. Yes, there are a few bugs but they aren't game breaking, nor will they reduce your enjoyment of the game. A huge, detailed world is at your disposal, for you to do what you wish. Want to complete the story as fast as possible then go ahead, you are free to do so. Want to be a completionist and do all the quests available? Afraid not, as the quests are endless, randomly generated throughout your time in the world. Add to this the Steam workshop you literally have endless amounts of content! Sorry you completionist types :( The combat feels responsive, the heavy blows feel meaty and the varying types of armour make the character feel different, whether you are wearing robes or heavy plate, mould your character into whatever you want them to be. If you are a fan of RPG's and action then you simply have to play this game. If you aren't a fan then still HAVE to play this game!

game-hours: 131.9
review: I was made into a midget and was impaled by a spear thrown by other midgets that were blue. 10/10
game-hours: 27.9
review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is the fifth installment in the main Elder Scrolls series. Despite being a pretty fun and quite worthwhile game, especially with mods, it has continued in a direction that I and some older fans dislike. The game is dumbed down with limited character variety, because of the ease of building a jack-of-all-trades type character. The story of the game isn't stellar, but it is still passable on most occasions. The main quest isn't that satisfactory as some of the guild quest lines, even though I do believe they were better in Oblivion and Morrowind. The game also offers a wide variety of side quests, many of which have interesting stories. The gameplay is not particularly good nor is it bad. The melee combat is simplistic and doesn't feel as fast paced or satisfactory as one could hope, since it comes down to just left-clicking to attack without much variation. The ranged combat isn't special in any way compared to other similar games, but it's a solid and quite enjoyable system. The magic system is very bland, with little variety amongst the various offensive spells. The games most lacking aspect combat-wise is the stealth, as the AI is quite lackluster and offers no challenge. The graphical fidelity on the game is above average, it is definitely not the best out there, but for an open world game it still is very solid. I don't really have anything to complain about the fidelity itself, since the texture work etc is well done -mostly-. Graphically the games short-comings come up when you look at the art-direction and world design: Skyrim is very grey. Simply, the world is very bland for the most part. The colours are toned down and not as appealing as earlier installations. Despite the game's flaws I do still recommend it, especially at its current lower price point. With tens to hundreds of hours of gameplay, it is a good game for any fan of action 'RPGs'. The game has an extremely active and prolific modding scene, with mods to mend many of the games flaws and offer content to re-invigorate it.
game-hours: 230.6
review: I do recommend people play games such as Morrowind and Oblivion too when getting this game. Skyrim has such an amazing feel when running out in its really big open world area. Then a dragon flys off a ledge, grabs an innocent bystander and throws him.The dragon then lands right infront of you trying to kill you. Seriously dragons are the best part of this game. The quests are fun except I dont care to do them again unless it was going to the afterlife of the Nords and fighting alduin again. The characters emotions look alittle blank unlike Oblivion where the character has a bit more of the look in their face. But their voice acting is ok. I recommend a good graphics card to run the game. I cant imagine how this game is already 3 years old. I feel like its still a very new game.

review: Before I start this review, i want to say 1 thing. When I first got the game, I hated it. I couldn't understand the hype behind it, the combat was awkward, there were places everywhere to get stuck and the people felt SOOO 2d with very little personalities. but I stuck at it for about 3-5 hours to see if I was missing something. And holy poop was I wrong about everything. Although my play time won't show you (my pc is terrible so I play skyrim mostly on xbox), Ive sunk easily 400 hours in this game and have got to level 50+ about 8 times, and its made me buy both oblivion and morrowind, each of which ive got over 150 hours on. Although I know skyrim is better than oblivion (sry oblivion fans, although it still beats most other games with a club how good it is) im not sure whether i like morrowind more than skyrim. Yes the graphics are bad, combat is almost unplayable and the lack of fast travel (although it does gives a much bigger sense of achivement) can just be borderline annoying, it is LENGEND-----------------------------DARY at customisation, depth and that soundtrack is the  of every fantasy nerd ever + a billion car revs. But I still have to hand it to skyrim. Yes its dummed down, but I dont care. It's so accesable and epic, the only downside is overpriced DLC (Its great, dont get me wrong, but only get it on deal as it isn't needed to kill your social life and its about the price of the game nowerdays) and, as i said breifly, you will look like the vampire you will inevitably become in-game because of lack of sunlight, as you wont be going out much after you buy this. p.s. I would also say multiplayer, but I hate to say it but ESO crushed my dreams of a truely great online elder scrolls, so I say stick to single player. pp.s. also ZOIDBERG MOD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

review: One of the things I look for in games is replay value - Skyrim is no slouch in that department. The amount of content in this game is incredible - I've been playing this since it first released in 2011 and I'm still discovering quests and locations I've never found before. A single playthrough can easily log in excess of 100 hours, over 200 in some cases depending on your playstyle. It may not be the perfect game, but the ability to customise it with mods allows the community to shape the game: fix bugs, add new content, overall increasing the lifespan and enjoyment of the game. Would I recommend this? Any day of the week, without a doubt.

game-hours: 716.4
review: it a good game
game-hours: 35.5
review: Games so fun to play ripped as  bro
game-hours: 328.9
review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is the new blockbuster RPG from Bethesda. Is it the "ultimate RPG" all the hype surrounded it portrayed it as? No, it is not. But that's because no single RPG is for everyone. If you're looking for Dragon Age or The Witcher in Skyrim, you won't find it, as they're different kinds of RPG. If you're a fan though, and you're mainly looking for more Elder Scrolls, you can't go wrong with this. Much like the previous game in the series, Oblivion, it offers a mindbogglingly huge amount of content from the get go. Content that will take hundreds of hours to completely go through. And by then, you will have forgotten such a big part of it that a second playthrough doesn't seem like such a bad idea. Unfortunately, just like Oblivion, at the end of the day there isn't a huge variety of dungeons and once you've seen one of a said type, you've pretty much seen them all. Skyrim has tried to correct this somewhat, adding flavor to most of the dungeons in order to make them unique, but it can get tiring once you've faced the same enemy 70 times. Combat in this game is the best in the series. Third camera mode is actually viable, and while you cannot pick classes in the previous games like you used to, you can now level up freely by gathering enough skill levels, with enough skills for you to be able to create a specific, personalized character. While this deep personalization remains in Skyrim, some aspects such as spellmaking and custom enchantment creations are completely gone. While some may say this is to avoid your character being a fearsome god of destruction, Skyrim almost makes it too easy for you to do this anyway, allowing even the strongest opponents to fall easily. This includes dragons. Before Skyrim released, Bethesda made it seem dragons were the most fearsome thing on Nirn. And while the first few times you do get to fight them they will put a decent challenge, Bethesda's scaling works poorly to keep it that way as you level and gain vastly better gear. Add that to these encounters being quite common at times, they completely lose that "epic feel" of the fight and just become an annoyance, pure and simple. This wouldn't nearly annoy me as much as it does if it wasn't for the fact that other, clearly looking weaker wildlife found actually put up a better fight than the dragons do. A Shadow of the Colossus or Dragon's Dogma approach to these encounters would do the trick, as those by comparison make the dragon fights in Skyrim disappointingly shallow. While the main quest for this game is mostly horrid, it is the sidequests that offer the most enjoyment. The Daedra quests are especially great. As with the previous games, factions such as the Dark Brotherhood can be joined, and through their storyline, you will eventually rise through their ranks. A minor detail that's bugged me since Oblivion is that these factions never take into account your actual skill levels. Suppose you'd join the Mages College in Winterhold, and the teachers may comment on your great talent, but really, they're just commenting on your lack thereof. You can fully complete its storyline, clearly aimed for mages, having no magic skills at all. I know Daggerfall's old by now, but even there they would check your skills to see if you were a suitable character to join their organization. Why did they not keep this in subsequent games? While these games can be extremely immersive, sometimes that immersion can be broken at times, either by bugs, which will always be present in such a gargantuan beast of a game, or by AI repeating the same lines over and over, notably the guards' comments when you approach them. It could be worse though, no longer will you find the world of Tamriel only having 5 voice actors working on it so there are still improvements. The graphics as well. Skyrim is simply a beauty to behold. Last, and by no means least, the modding community. They have always been a staple in the series since Morrowind, adding hours of playtime to these games. Skyrim has not changed in regards to this, and it fact made mod installation easier thanks to its addition to the Steam Workshop. Find a mod you like? Just hit that subscribe button and open the launcher to see the game download it automatically. It's ridiculously simple, and you'd be silly not to give some of the fantastic mods already released a go. It's almost a sin to want to buy the console versions, due to what they miss on. These are the kinds of games that, 10 years down the road, with their DLCs fully released, will still have people modding them, and that is quite special. All in all, I say Skyrim is a must-have for anyone with a remotely passing interest in the series. It's just that good. Complete with a deep customization, great setting, believable world and endless potential. Make sure you have a lot of spare time, this game will soul trap you for a long time, and you will more than likely thoroughly enjoy it, as I have.

game-hours: 41.0
review: Stepping into Skyrims world is like wrapping yourself in a furry, Nordic cloak that smells like your childhood blanket. Yes, the Oblivion you remember fondly is back  everything that made the last Elder Scrolls so lovable has returned. Yet now its a bit wilder, a bit rougher, and a bit more dangerous, and boy is the game better for it. Whereas Cyrodiil, the province from Oblivion, was a fairly typical temperate climate with deciduous forests and gentle rolling hills, Skyrim is a bitter, cold northern region (remember those impassable mountains in the north of Cyrodiil? Skyrim is just beyond them). This doesnt mean the game world is a monotonous frozen waste: the land is diverse, but it has a wonderful tone to it that is very much Viking Axe Clanking and Visible Frosty Breaths Huddled Around Crackling Fires. Its forbidding, slightly bleak, and yet also incredibly cozy when you come in from the cold.

review: I found Skyrim to be immensely enjoyable. Right from the word go you are able to make a character from multiple races and alter their appearance as you wish. After the tutorial you are released into the vast, beautiful world of Skyrim. As you travel around the land you will experience breathtaking scenery, from snow-covered peaks to glowing caverns, and many unique caves/dungeons/ruins which contain a multitude of enemies from spiders to dragons. You can spend your time mastering the many skills available or completing quests, which there are a ridiculous amount available. In doing so you can gather equipment to allow you to create any kind of character imaginable. If you enjoy an RPG with freedom of creativity, dynamic combat and awesome scenery the Skyrim is for you.

game-hours: 103.9
review: I am aware of the number of reviewes already published, but I believe I have played this game (as well as the other TES titles) enough to give my imput. I would be brief and simply point out pros and cons rather than an emotional review about the past games and melancholic memories they recall. PRO - Immersive and non-repeatable gameplay: whether you choose to be a brave warrior, a sneaky assassin or a wise mage, there is no standard option or guide to obtain the perfect character! As in the other TES titles, you can really get yourself into a variety of classes (even though there is no actual standard class) that influence the gameplay and the advance of the story (it is fun how the NPCs around Skyrim wil lrecognise you not simply as a Dragonborn, but also in various ways depending on your quests) - Lore: TES lore has always been the most fascinating thing in my opinion, and in Skyrim it will hugely affect your experience! You will find all the old lore as well as new local one. - Different difficulties for different challenges: You can be new to the genre as well as a veteran, the different difficulties make Skyrim a game perfect for every kind of player! - Great storyline: besides the Dragonborn quest line (which is already great despite some too "obvious" points), all the side quests and storylines create a fully interactive world with its problems and issues. I find the Civil War storyline the most interesting! - Great DLC: despite many other games, DLCs are definitely worth having! Dawnguard adds an involving storyline to some new great and spectacular abilities, Dragonborn, with its brand new location, offers hours of wonderful gameplay, storyline, abilities and easter eggs, Hearthfire, even if can seem quite useless offers an interesting alterantive gameplay. - Stunning graphic: being a title released in the 2011, we must admit it..even the most powerful PC still have little problems in dealing with the max graphic settings! The visual impact of the world is simply amazing, and the Workshop elements can only make your experience even better! CON - Perk system vs Old level up: I am a huge Morrowind fan, and when I firstly saw the perk I was quite disappointed. It doesn't allow the huge customize possibility as the old title did. - Repetitive dialogues: as the game progresses you will find a number of standard dialogues being repeated over and over, the arrow in the knee joke will not be fun anymoe when every guard will repeat it. - Easy enemies: as your abilities gets stronger, you will find that enemies will be easier to kill. Normally it would be a positive aspect (hey, I level up to be stronger, not weaker!), but when a Draugr is more challenging than a Dragon, than you may be quite disappointed. Overall I would DEFINITELY recommend this game and if someone still has to purchase it...do it, before Jurgen WIndcaller himself Fus Ro Dah you!

review: The game by itself (althought very buggy for a finished product) is amazing and is worth a buy, but then you throw in all the mods and how easy its made with various tools and programs like the steam workshop, nexus mod manager, LOOT (Load Order Optimization Tool), and TES5Edit, you can make skyrim into a completely new experience, many times over, with all the mods out there + the original game you could easily spend all of or most of your life playing skyrim and still not have seen everything, there's seriously that many mods out there (note some may not be compatible with others). If you're going to get into modding thought definitely invest in the nexus mod manager, steam workshop is good but if you eventually decide to switch your mods from steam versions to nexus version you'll have to go through a real headache and possible have to re-install the game like I did, either way my point is BUY THIS GAME.

review: This game is awesome. You get to play as a slayer of dragons in the province of Skyrim. Dragons appear after centuries and there just happens to be a civilian war at the same time. Good idea and, the opposite of most todays games, actually well executed. But the main advantage of this game (besides it's lore) its that you can do anything. Ever heard for a phrase "Skyrim can do that"? Well it exists for a reason. Let me highlight some of the features Skyrim has: -can use magic -can buy horses -can buy houses -can build houses -can become a vampire/werewolf -can catch fish -can have a garden -can kill dragons -can fight in a war -can shoot catapults -can become a thief -can become an assassin -can cook stuff -can have a library -can marry NPC -can adopt children -can go into certain daedric realms (kinda like heavens and hell IRL I suppose) -can shade the sun -can listen to guards But seriously the game is awesome and worth every euro/dollar/any currency. Specially the legendary edition Mods and console commands are a whole new thing and provide even more stuff to mess with.

Having hundreds of hours of gameplay and dlc allows the player to engage in fun combat without becoming bored quickly. Having a large amount of customization also gives the player a bit of a creative and inviting feeling. I would recommend this game to anyone (Apart from the occasional young child that thinks it's fun to play only violent games, that is.) who enjoys a long, action filled adventure through a countryside to only then be attacked by giants and mammoths and the occasional dragon or... well... who am i kidding, being attacked by all of dragonkind.

review: One of the best action RPG games so far, as Bethesda has once again managed to expand The Elder Scrolls saga - this time with norse-themed adventure named after the frozen, snowy tundrous province Skyrim. Altrough not so original like it's predecessors - Oblivion or Morrowind - the newest addition to this wonderful series is heavily influenced by nordic and scandinavian folklore. While Morrowind was the most original place I've ever visited in game, and Oblivion managed to bring the feeling of Imperial Rome - Skyrim takes a different - albeit very common and not-so-original path - dragons, huscarls, fjords, hargravens and it's own version of Valhalla - Sovngarde. Pack your winter clothing - don't forget to bring your axes and horned helmets, and... be prepared for excellence - but not perfection, as Skyrim tries to grasp the throne of RPG genre - but it still cannot best it's older, more mature (and in my opinion flawless) siblings - Morrowind and Oblivion.

game-hours: 151.3
review: What is Skyrim? Well, some say it's a game made by Bethesda as another installment in the Elder Scrolls series, but is it really? First of, let's define aberration: An aberration is something that deviates from the normal way. So in lieu of calling this game another installment in the series, let's say this is an aberration. This aberration of a game brings us idyllic, serene landscapes( with the addition of mods) that make the game so riveting and immersive, especially with the perfect equipoise of dialogue and character development. The Elder Scrolls V offers a extensive open-world map with monumental to non-imposing cities, villages, towns, farming huts and intimidating caves, mines, crevices, dungeons and forts that offer adversity while maintaining the perfect balance of immersion and simplicity. From edifices to primitive dwellings comes a myriad of immersive characters, animals, creatures, patrols, travellers and a cult to offer the player a great deal of convivial entertainment. The story itself, can make players really engange in their decisions because of the level of entrancing dialogue, visuals, continuity and the preeminent factor of overall interaction with the full use of the open world map. Lastly, the inclusion of mods really augments the experience of Skyrim i.e, Graphical Mods, ENB's, environmental mods, texture mods, gameplay mods, immersive mods and a plethora of more categories. ENB's are graphical mods that enhance the use of lighting and shadows to add an aesthetic value to the game. Environmental mods can alter alot of things including: grass, tree's, water, establishments and a multitude of other things. Texture mods change the landscape, character models, animals and basically any texture. So, in conclusion, this game has a myriad of varied factors listed above to make this game in my top 5 favourite games of all time. A superfluity of mods can really alter the experience in a positive and negative depending on the discovering of "good" mods. Dialoge, characters, environment and immersion are really the paramount factors that made this game one of my favourites. I recommend this game to anyone and everyone, including non-rpg advocates. 9.9/10( IGN). Just kidding. 10/10.

game-hours: 447.5
review: Do you like open world RPGs? Games that have a story but don't really force you into it? Plethora of character options? That pretty much describes the Elder Scrolls games and Skyrim isn't any different. If you like these kind of games then you already have Skyrim and probably have numerous hours racked up in play time, this review isn't really for you. If you haven't had any experiences with the Elder Scroll series would you like this game? The main story of Skyrim can be completed with out much difficulty and in about 20 hours, it doesn't require that you have much knowledge of the elder scrolls lore to enjoy the game. The interface and systems are fairly basic and have been streamlined since Morrowind, it is easier for someone new to the series to get into the game. There is some caveats, these games are notoriously buggy. It isn't as hard to block all progress to quests as essential NPC are generally protected but there are still times when things don't happen they way they should. The upside is the console commands are quite powerful and you can normally get out of any mess. This brings me to the final large drawing factor for me to games like this. After you have played the story the game is as much of a sandbox as you can get for a game like this. The Creation Kit is a powerful tool and the modding community continuously pumps out amazing content. There is hundreds of hours in mods and tinkering, playing with the world going about things differently. If you like crazy lore, and I do mean crazy, the Elder Scrolls series has it in spades. If you are looking for a super polished streamlined story driven game, this is not it. If the prospect of getting lost in the game and spending 3 hours collecting butterflies while admiring the scenery appeals to you then look no further. Skyrim is an amazing game but don't go into it expecting it to hold your hand, instead it sets you on fire and tells you there is 101 different ways for you to put yourself out go find one, or not you can always just stay on fire and collect plants.

review: Is breddy good ib you lide de repededive queds and sub ob de nize diddy mods dat dey dow how do made. Dey also hab reeeal niiide budds doo, ib you hab de mod for id, but dat's all dat dis game cad amound do ib you wand reblayabilidy, unbotunadely. In earnest, the scheme that the early Elder Scrolls series had attempted to uphold in its first ventures had rapidly cultivated RPG fans to expect more profound and extensive quests, and although Bethesda perpetually takes advantage of advancing technologies to fabricate their games to be as engaging as its technology will allow, Skyrim ultimately falls short of many older enthusiasts' expectations. On the surface, Skyrim's problems are that of conveyance. This means that although its predecessor, Oblivion, had arguably less depth that of its own predecessor, it is still widely considered a favorite for its setting, execution, and the theme in which the hero's journey takes place. Skyrim's setting is similar to that of Oblivion in how the region takes a "story-book feel" with its glorification of ancient battles, epic wars fought long ago, and endangered cultures rising to the surface to add to Skryim's theme. Unfortunately, Skyrim's ability to immerse the player in this chaotic period falls flat with many goading promises of epic battles turning into fetch-quest mania and visit draugr sepulcher #194725 to fight ancient enemy #27528 at the end and recieve your shout/loot/quest-related thing for radiant quest giver #639275. Simply put, "Skyrim is a game as large as an ocean, with the depth of a puddle" -Totalfatbaldmole. If you appreciated Arena, if you had enjoyed Daggerfall, if you loved Morrowind, if you fancied Oblivion, and expected Bethesda's latest addition to deliver a hard-hitting story with engaging quests and daunting worlds... For the love of god, skip Skyrim.

game-hours: 49.0
review: We have come a long way from 8-bit monochrome Fantasy Role Playing Adventure Games like ULTIMA, trying to capture our childhood memories of reading J.R.R. Tolkien's Lord of the Rings, or similar books. This latest attempt by Bethesda is the most accessible so far, trying to combine an open FPS style game play in a Fantasy RPG 3D world. This game is doing what Ultima IX Ascension tried to do years ago. The richness of 2D RPGs, we all love and know, translated into a 3D world. Gothic, Morrowind, Oblivion, The Witcher - many games tried before. Skyrim (and Witcher 2) show how far we have come. Endless hours of gameplay, from catching bees to fighting dragons with the sword you crafted and enchanted yourself. The Steam Workshop and Nexus mods will keep this game alive for years to come.

game-hours: 408.0
review: I waited to play through this game and get both DLCs prior to writing a review. The graphics hold up today, with mods added. If not still very beautiful and emmersive. A+ The story of multiple different quests had me enthralled from start to finish. Though you have to find the quests that you specifically enjoy. (Examples) I came across a Walking Dog that led me to it's talking deity that then ended in me deciding the dogs fate. I joined a legion to defeat Vampires, and then betrayed them. By becoming a Vampire helping the Lord of Vampires himself. I became the "Guardian" of Solitude before joining a rebellion to overthrow them. I walked across a ice lake in a different dimmension, that then led me to have to fight two dragons. I summoned a dragon to aid me fight, and it led to one of the most enjoyable scene of a realtime battle mechanic I have ever seen. I usually fade in fantasy style video games, but the immersive possibilities allowed me to still want more. Over a hundred of hours of quest experience, and can have more added with mods. Different race aspects, and many different styles of combat you may play. This is a must have for any form of "Gamer". As well as something a casual should ATLEAST give a try. One of the best purchases I have made, and I will be continuing to come back to this game to this day.

game-hours: 212.2
review: I played Skyrim approximately 900 hours on PS3 without any of the add-ons before it started losing it's appeal. When I bought the Legendary pack on steam, I dove right in and am just as addicted to the game as the first time I played it. The game can be extremely tedious sometimes, especially for loot hoarders and people get killed a lot. The graphics are extremely adjustable and therefore are only limited by your hardware. The musical score has an impeccable range and leveling up and learning a Word of Power become unforgettable melodies. The main story line is intense, although a bit short. The real story is completing all of the side quests and conquering all of the dungeons. There is a fairly good balance in the explorable areas but when I finished the biggest and best dungeon, I realized none of the other's mattered. I just wanted more of that one. The combat system is not very unique but manageable. Overall, this game is a good buy.

game-hours: 30.2
review: Step once more into the world of Elder Scrolls. You will be exploring the region of Tamriel known as Skyrim, home to the Nords, and also fight the dragons who have returned and want to destroy everything. As you slay the dragons, you will unlock special magical powers called Dragon shouts that will allow you to summon a friendly dragon to help you in battle, push enemies and objects away not unlike the Force Push from Star Wars and much more. And as you engage in battle against all sorts of foes, you will improve your skills when it comes to handling swords, axes and other types of weapons that will make your life a bit easier. You can even become quite skillful in the arts of being a blacksmith, each new weapon and piece of armor you make at a blacksmith forge will improve your skills, but you are of course gonna need components in order to make these new weapons and armor. You're free to become just about anything as there are no limitations on the works you can have, you can even at one point become a werewolf. And don't forget to check out the modding community for Skyrim as there are plenty of mods that can change the game, there's even a mod that makes it so that when it is night time it gets really dark as well as that caves are extremely dark and will require a torch as well as mods that will make the game even more challenging by forcing you to take care of your bodily needs like food, water and even making sure you stay warm otherwise you might die from either starving to death or of the freezing cold winds.

game-hours: 41.0
review: Stepping into Skyrims world is like wrapping yourself in a furry, Nordic cloak that smells like your childhood blanket. Yes, the Oblivion you remember fondly is back  everything that made the last Elder Scrolls so lovable has returned. Yet now its a bit wilder, a bit rougher, and a bit more dangerous, and boy is the game better for it. Whereas Cyrodiil, the province from Oblivion, was a fairly typical temperate climate with deciduous forests and gentle rolling hills, Skyrim is a bitter, cold northern region (remember those impassable mountains in the north of Cyrodiil? Skyrim is just beyond them). This doesnt mean the game world is a monotonous frozen waste: the land is diverse, but it has a wonderful tone to it that is very much Viking Axe Clanking and Visible Frosty Breaths Huddled Around Crackling Fires. Its forbidding, slightly bleak, and yet also incredibly cozy when you come in from the cold.

game-hours: 510.4
review: Skyrim! It's amazing! Ok so you probably want more detail so here goes. Well at the very start I do enjoy the customization of both races as well as the appearence changes you have at your fingertips, I've at times wanted to change some features on my current dovahkiin and there is a meaning of such a character that can help you do so. Of course thought it won't be able to help you change your race. In terms of the battle system I like the free form of battle you have. Use advantages like tree cover or any form of cover you have around you to dodge archers but be ready to take a shield in one hand and a sword at the ready in the other! Of course if you want to be Rocky then you don't need no weapons and can punch till you are victorious! There is also choice of mage class. Anything from healing and curing illnesses you may have caught from being bitten by certain creatures, to firing fireballs and rain lightning upon your foes. Sometimes you fine treasures upon your travels and depending on what you go for (Mana, health, stamina) then you can carry more loot or if you have a companion then he/she will take the weight helping you to carry more weight for more shiny treasures. The details is breath taking! I would look up at the sky when northern lights come about or the planets are showing and be like, " Ohhh! Ahhhh! " But then suddenly assassin! And so my time is then consumed on fighting him to the very death of one or the other! It's story line is certainly great and with the DLC's it has widened the choice of missions much further. Now you can become a werewolf or a vampire! There are major advantages to this but as is the way in life, there are also disadvantages. But this is all explained in the game as you progress. If you haven't already grabbed a copy of this then watch a few let's plays and see for yourself what this game has to offer. It's rank in my top 3 of all time fav games ever played. 8/10 rating

game-hours: 106.9
review: An ocean with the depth of a puddle, is the best way to describe skyrim. Don't let that turn you away however. If you're new to The Elder Scrolls, Skrims gameplay and easier ability to mod in my opinion gives it an edge over the previous games in the series. The main story for skyrim in my opinion is the best among The Elder Scrolls, and while that will surely not be your focus, while exploring the landscape and finding random quests, dungeons, what have you the main story gives you plenty of interesting shouts aswell as progressively making the game more challenging. If you arent familiar with the open world nature of an elder scrolls game or fallout, it's a vast world with plenty of people to talk to, places to see, monsters to kill, books to read, and cabbages to fill your home with. It has something for everyone and while it may not be a great game for one thing, it does a lot of things well enough to keep your attention for hundreds of hours.

review: An epic game made all the more epic by the fact that it is so easy to mod and so well supported by the modding community. The Elder Scrolls series has a large following and often you will hear people argue over each new TES game comparing it to the last, but for me each TES game stands on its own merits, and Skyrim is no exception. The story is pretty good and there are plenty of side quests, but what makes Skyrim so great even when not modded is its large and open nature. This is a land you can just pick a direction and with no quest in mind and just explore. You will find danger and excitement on your journey ... and loot. Lots and lots of loot. But once you start modding this game, that is when you unlock the true value that is Skyrim. Potentially thousands more hours content (for free) in a game that can be improved ten thousand different ways from graphics, textures and sounds all the way to game mechanics and user interface changes. You can make the game exactly what you need it to be, and play it for so long you may still be playing when the next game in this series comes out.... and sometimes longer than even that. If you are interested in modding the PC version of the game, be sure to check out my guide for beginners:

game-hours: 92.5
review: I was stacking books on a shelf in my house in Whiterun, one of Skyrim's major cities, when I noticed a weapon rack right beside it. I set a sacrificial dagger in one slot, an Orcish mace in the other. They were on display for nobody but me and my computer-controlled housecarl, Lydia, who sat at a table patiently waiting for me to ask her to go questing. The chest upstairs was reserved for excess weapons and armor, the bedside table for smithing ingots and ores, the one next to the Alchemy table for ingredients. I'd meticulously organized my owned virtual property not because I had to, but because tending to the minutia of domestic life is a comforting break from dealing with screaming frost trolls, dragons, a civil war, and job assignments that never seem to go as planned. It's even a sensible thing to do; a seemingly natural component of every day existence in Skyrim, one of the most fully-realized, easily enjoyable, and utterly engrossing role-playing games ever made. Part of what makes it so enjoyable has to do with how legacy Elder Scrolls clutter has been condensed and in some cases eliminated. In Skyrim, there's no more moon-hopping between hilltops with a maxed out Acrobatics skill. That's gone, so is Athletics. The Elder Scrolls V pares down the amount of skills and cuts out attributes like Endurance and Intelligence altogether. There's no time wasted on the character creation screen agonizing over which skills to assign as major. You don't assign major and minor skills at all, but instead pick one of ten races, each with a specific bonus. High Elves can once a day regenerate magicka quickly, Orcs can enter a berserk rage for more effective close-range combat. These abilities are best paired with certain character builds  the High Elf regeneration is useful for a magic user  but don't represent a rigid class choice. Major decisions don't need to be made until you're already out in the world and can try out magic, sneaking and weapon combat, emphasizing first-hand experience over instruction manual study, letting you specialize only when you're ready. It contributes to the thrilling sense of freedom associated with life in Skyrim. Do a quest, kill a dragon, snatch torchbugs from the air, munch on butterfly wings or simply wander while listening to one of the best game soundtracks in recent memory. Despite the enormity of the world and the colossal amount of content contained within, little feels random and useless. Even chewing on a butterfly wing has purpose, as it reveals one of several alchemical parameters later useful in potion making at an alchemy table. Mined ore and scraps of metal from Dwemer ruins can be smelted into ingots and fashioned into armor sets, pelts lifted from slain wildlife can be turned into leather armor sets, and random books plucked from ancient ruins can trigger hidden quest lines that lead to valuable rewards. Skyrim's land mass is absolutely stuffed with content and curiosities, making every step you take, even if it's through what seems like total wilderness, an exciting one, as something unexpected often lies just over the next ridge. Many times the unexpected takes the form of a dragon. Sometimes they're purposefully placed to guard relics, sometimes they swoop over cities and attack at seemingly random times. In the middle of a fight against a camp of bandits a dragon might strike, screaming through the sky and searing foe and friendly alike with frost or flame. Momentarily all on the battlefield unite, directing arrows and magic blasts upward to knock down the creature, creating impromptu moments of camaraderie -- a surprising change from what may have been yet another by-the-numbers bandit camp sweep. Dragons show up often, their presence announced by an ominous flap of broad wings or an otherworldly scream from high above. The scale and startling detail built into each creature's appearance and animations as it circles, stops to attack, circles again and slams to the ground makes encounters thrilling, though their predictable attack patterns lessen the excitement after a few battles. In the long run they're far less irritating than the Oblivion gate equivalent from The Elder Scrolls IV, can be completed in a few minutes, and always offer a useful reward. Killing a dragon yields a soul, which powers Skyrim's new Shout system. These are magical abilities any character can use, you don't have to specialize in spell casting to slow time, throw your voice, change the weather, call in allies, blast out ice and fire, or knock back enemies with a rolling wave of pure force. Even if you favor sword, shield and heavy armor and ignore magic entirely, you'll still be able to take full advantage of these abilities provided you find the proper words  each Shout has three  hidden on Skyrim's high snowy peaks and in the depths of forgotten dungeons, serving as another reason to continue exploring long after you've exhausted the main quest story, joined with the Thieves Guild, fought alongside the Dark Brotherhood, or thrown your support behind one of the factions vying for control of Skyrim. Not only is this land under assault by dragons, long thought to be dead, it's also ripped in two by civil war. You can choose one side or the other, but so much of the allure of Skyrim is how, even outside of the confines of quest lines, the embattled state of the world is evident, and steeped in a rich fictional legacy. Lord of the Rings this is not, but with the release of every Elder Scrolls game, the fiction becomes denser, and the cross-referencing for long-time fans all the more rewarding. Skyrim's residents are all aware of current events. They'll comment on the civil war, some sympathizing with the rebels, others thinking the establishment sold its soul. The peasants complain about the Jarls who control each settlement, the Jarls complain about the rebels or foreign policy, the overprotective College librarian complains when I drop dragon scales all over his floor; many characters feel like whole, distinct personalities instead of vacuous nothings that hand out quests like a downtown greeter hands out flyers for discount jeans. Characters stereotype based on race, they double-cross at even the slightest hint it might be profitable, and they react to your evolving stature within the world. It makes a ridiculous realm, filled with computer-controlled cat people and humanoid reptiles, demon gods and dragons, feel authentic, like a world that existed long before you showed up and will continue to exist long after you leave.

game-hours: 441.5
review: Summary; Points for: Sheer scale and the fact you can never seem to run out of things to do. Well supported with mods from the Workshop - if there's something you don't like, there's probably a mod for that. Pretty good value for money as a result. You don't have to leap right into the storyline, you can just decide to settle down in Riverwood and be a blacksmith/alchemist/hunter for a while if you like; the rest of the story will just wait til your ready and be levelled accordingly (handy if you want to get other questlines out of the way without a dragon attacking you whenever you set foot outdoors). Loses points for; You can't make any really game changing choices (like you can in say The Witcher). While the Dark Brotherhood arc and the Dawnguard arc do allow you to make a few choices, they don't really have an effect on the main story. It's petty, but I'd appreciate some respect from the guards when I'm Arch Mage, Dragonborn, Saviour of Skyrim, Thane of *insert town here*, leader of the Dark Brotherhood and of the Thieves Guild. Thankfully there is a nice mod for this. Again, a handy mod for this, but why does my follower run around behind me when I'm on a horse instead of getting on a horse of their own? Seems a bit unfair... Maybe this is girly, but the character customisation isn't quite up to par with some of its contemporaries, but it's aesthetic really, especially since if you play in first person it doesn't really matter anyway. 96/100 In detail Because somehow it seems dodgy to give something full marks no matter how good it is, but can you really go wrong with The Elder Scrolls? Okay, so reportedly you can *cough*Oblivion*cough* (I have the game but have yet to play it properly so I'll have to see). I first played Skyrim on console (not my finest gaming hours) over a year after the base games release, but I quickly became addicted to the point that I was a constant irritation to the housemate at the time who was letting me borrow the console and game. What's to say about it? It has it all; never-ending list of quests so it never feels like you've completed the game; check, so many skills you can play in a totally different way with every new character; check, continuity from previous games in the series (done so much better in gaming than in the film and tv industries sometimes - Star Wars, Star Trek, yes I am looking at you); check (so I hear, see above re owning the games but having yet to play them). Want to be a tank and hack everything to pieces? Go for it. Want to go against the generally accepted stereotypes and be a ninja orc assassin? Not easy, but why not? Just want to eat loads of random herbs and see funny colors? Sure. Skyrim really could be a game for anyone, and for all ages (not that I'm recommending it to you if you're below whatever age limit it is), and playing on PC becomes exponentially better for the massive number of additional mods you can add to the game, ranging from basic visual changes (I have a lovely set that make all the towns and villages more ...foliaged - is that a word?...and pretty) to mods giving new races (including OP ones for snow elves or witchers). These mods can also include new quests and make Skyrim one of the best games you can buy on PC - they make the game virtually never ending. In truth, I haven't finished Skyrim (not even to the point most people would consider the game finished), in part because there's so much to do, but mostly because I have a peculiar habit of starting a new game with a new character the second I get so much as a whiff of the end of the game. Or of just stopping. This does admittedly mean that writing a review for Skyrim is difficult, but really it's hard to find anything to dislike about the game anyway. If I had to pick something to whine about with Skyrim, I guess it might be the fact that it's so damned easy to get side-tracked; maybe I decide I'm gonna go do a quest at Kagrenzel. Now aside from the whole fiddling around and having to be in the dead center of the thing so I don't die on the way in, on the way there I will a) have probably gotten lost because b) I got attacked by wolves and galloped away leaving that mess for Lydia to deal with c) climbed up the wrong side of a mountain because there was a word wall and it was on the way (kinda) d) managed to kill my horse on the way back down e) experienced a totally unrelated to the word wall dragon attack and wandered haplessly into about 5 bandit encampments. All in a time span I had originally set aside for doing the actual quest before heading out for work. I'll probably come back, forget what I was doing, lose all that travelling time by fast travelling to the other side of the map, remember, curse for a while then repeat the same journey with an extra dragon attack for good measure...oh, but I killed the horse so I'd better go do the Assassins quests so I can get a new horsey (Shadowmere). You see the issue. I have over 300 hours logged in this game mostly spent stumbling around looking for a road to take me where I want to go. Or running into a mountainside to slowly inch around it and hopefully avoid falling to my death. Equally though, that is part of the charm of Skyrim so it doesn't really count as a bad thing does it? Either way, if you consider yourself a gamer but don't play Skyrim, 1) you're not a real gamer and 2) go get it. Mods are free, which makes this game some of the best value for money around, you really have no excuse.

game-hours: 484.2
review: Another excellent game in the elder scrolls series but does not deserve all the perfect ratings it has gotten, however the mods available improve the game many fold I will talk about my problems with the base game plus official expansions Inventory management. ESPECIALLY when it comes to potions. Dialog among different NPCs doesnt vary, which led to the whole "took an arrow in the knee" thing enemy AI is incredibly poor and enemy pathfinding is easy to exploit. A headshot with an arrow doesnt kill and having a bandit come at you with an arrow sticking out of his face is immersion-breaking. Every NPC has the same height and robotic animations. I seriously doubt any motion capture was used in this game which I cannot fathom there being an excuse for. Argonian and khajiit tails are not part of the base body mesh and skeleton and that has always stood out to me. How difficult would it be? Well I guess they have the same human animations so animating a tail would be just more work. The land just seems rather unpopulated for being a whole province npcs follow you through doors if they are in the middle of speaking to you, even if you just run by them. Vampire attacks killing named NPCs in towns and destroying quests. I turned off dawnguard and never completed it. Killing a chicken is an unforgivable crime and will put a whole town into a murdorous rage. The game seriously lacks variation, as far as voice acting, humanoid animations, npc dialog, height and build of npcs. Child races are limited to one. and not only that, there are no babies, toddlers, adolescents, teens, it seems to be only 10 year olds and adults up to old people, but all with the same height and build. Armour and weapons SEEM varied but in reality they are not, since an iron dagger doesnt do as much damage as a steel, and steel doesnt do as much as glass, etc, you will replace a weapon or piece of armor and never use it again, forcing you into a certain progression of look depending on how far in the game you are. the only real variation is whether you use light or heavy armour. What if you like the look of a glass dagger over ebony but dont want to lose the damage bonus? The werewolf mode is more like a minigame to me, and has severly limited use due to how weak he is and the fact that he cant unlock doors, loot, and is only useful against humanoid targets like bandit dens. And also, no variation in the look of the werewolf! Not even fur color or gender! It seems to be a game conflicted over what RPG elements to keep and what to "optimize" for a console audience, although I cannot imagine playing this game without the player community mods available on the PC. Still recommended but PLEASE hire some developers with imagination, Bethesda. The mod community should be putting you to shame, maybe you can hire some of them for TES VI?

game-hours: 254.0
review: After playing this game for 250 hours I have this to say about this game. I loved it. (With mods that is.) Vanilla Game: When I played the vanilla version I had so much fun. The graphics were amazing, the storyline was solid. The items I found across the world of Skyrim were cool. The voice acting was pretty meh in some ways. The characters with thier own unique voice actors were the best. Example: Alduin, Karliah, Poarthanax, The Greybeards, and The beast races had awsome voices. The nords and other races had recycled voices which kinda took away the immersion of the game. Some of the quest were repetitive and dull after playing them a couple of times, but Im not saying all quests were dull. The level up system was significantly improved from the last game, Oblivion, with a star system representing the skills that you focus on. Companion system can be annoying and repetative and I wished they worked on that more to make your companions more interesting. The most awsome thing about this game is... Battling dragons. Dlc: The dlc's of this game were amazing. Hearthfire was a slight dissapointment there. Although your better off getting mods to build your own house. Dragonborn dlc is the best dlc out there. A whole new world to explore. A new villian (who is dragonborn) and new enemies to fight. Dawnguard is a very interesting dlc with a war between vampire and mortals. I promise you the story will keep you on edge. So the question is. "Should I buy the game and dlc's seperatly, or do I get the legendary edition?" Legendary edition most definently. If you're a try hard like me. You'll enjoy a new challenge with the legendary mode. The final verdict for this game is a 10/10. The best rpg game I have played. It would be a 9/10, but the dlc's is what saved this game from a lower rating. And the fact that I had 180 mods installed. (most of them improved the graphics and looks of the game. while others increased immersion and gameplay. The rest was weapons and armor mods.) I highly recommend that you install Nexus Mod Manager and use steam workshop to install mods and make the game more fun. Buy this game by your choice and have fun.
