review: As most people already know, this game is amazing. The vast amount of content is unbelievable. I have put in over 100 hours, and feel like I am only half way through. As much as I like this game, I want to point the issues that I have faced. - This game is not optimized for quad core processors. My rig can run most new games on max settings at a smooth framerate. Skyrim pushes my system to its limits. Even at medium settings, I experience hiccups and frame drops. - There is a large amount of loading in this game. Whenever you fast travel or enter/exit a city, you must endure a lengthy load screen. Although the screens are pretty, it gets annoying. I do not have a SSD, if you do, this may not be as much of an issue. Despite these two annoyances, I HIGHLY recommend this game. This game is a steal at $20 and if you get it on sale, you should be put in cuffs.

review: I spent more time tweaking than I did playing, but with Bethesda you know exactly what you're getting: a moddable, fairly cutting edge open world adventure slash loot crawl. Pity the engine still has so many deficiencies, but you cannot deny the staying power of Bethesda's formula. game-hours: 76.0
review: Skyrim is an excellent game in almost every way. It is graphically beautiful, has an interesting storyline, a wonderfully crafted and large open world populated with a pretty impressive number of interesting and unique NPCs. It builds on the Elder Scrolls gameplay made famous by its predecessors Morrowind and Oblivion and exceeds them in creating truly great combat mechanics. Although the only notable expansion, Dragonborn, is far better than Oblivion's Shivering Isles, it ultimately fails to deliver the awesome experiences provided by Morrowind's Tribunal and Bloodmoon expansions--although any Morrowind fan will love the addition of not only the island of Solstheim to Skyrim's already vast landmass, but also the still-amazing Morrowind soundtrack as you traverse the snowy isle. The Skyrim modding community is also excellent and the steam workshop makes it very easy to add awesome new content to your game. All in all, Skyrim is a must-play for any RPG fan and is a very solid package, exceeding its predecessors in gameplay and in attention to detail in the world. However, the storyline is simply not as interesting or gripping as its predecessors nor is the voice talent quite as great (with the absence of Sean Bean--I'm sure you can guess what happened to him in Oblivion!). Skyrim is truly a great experience and one can really only crticise it in relation to the other amazing games the team at Bethesda have made in the past. It is well worth a look if you haven't already! 9.5/10.

review: Oh, God, I've played so much of this sodding game! Over 500 hours, isn't that sad? Yes, yes it is! But... I had a great time playing it. If I hadn't I wouldn't have played it for several weeks. It's a good game, no one can say anything else. It's very immersive, it has some pretty good storylines, and it has SO MUCH content! But... (there's another one) it's not very good. I know that sounds really weird, and it kind of is; let's take a look at the melee combat-system: the weapons have no weight, at all! No matter how massive the axe you're swinging is, it feels like you're playing with a stick in the forest. And the main strategy is "click the  out of the left mouse button", sometimes broken up by "block, then realise it's about as effective as blocking a sword with a pillow stuffed with balloons can be". And the bloody magic in the vanilla game! It's boring and ineffective. If you want to play with all the schools of magic on the same character, you have to spread your skill points thinner than cheap butter on even cheaper toast. The AI is...not there at times, especially in your companions, who somehow allways seme to find a way to block the doorway. I might be a bit too harsh on the game, but that's just because I've seen it all. I've seen all its ups and downs (mostly downs as it turns out) In conclusion: Yes, I would recommende this game, but not as a game. Think of it more as a roleplaying-experience. Oh, and one more thing, mod the hell out of it, there are a lot of talented people out there, and it makes the game so much more enjoyable.

review: This game is amazing. Very well orchestrated music accompanied by beautiful graphics makes this game the best fantasy adventure I have played EVER. There was one side-quest which the key item was a sword, there were books on this and to get this started I was pumped, but to my dismay it was a regular shape. There are few varieties in crafted weapons, which is my only negative comment, other than the occasional glitch. I give The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim a 9/10

game-hours: 60.2
review: Sir Frankenberry, Esquire visits the city of Solitude for the first time. It's a business trip, but there's much to see in this relative metropolis. The matter of business is attending a wedding reception, but that will go on all night. Let her live a bit longer. Sir Frankenberry, Esquire has time to be distracted. He comes across a clothing store, something else the warrior has never encountered. Non-protective outer chest coverings? How unusual. How... impractical. The shop's owner, Taarie, is as intrigued by the sight of an orcish customer as Sir Frankenberry, Esquire is by the mere existence of the shop. The owner's curiosity bubbles over. She energetically requests that Sir Frankenberry, Esquire model one of her signature garments for Solitude's mayor. The unspoken but understood reason being that if her clothes can make this monster look appealing... Sir Frankenberry, Esquire sees several steps beyond this thinly veiled insult and into the payoff. He would be honored. Taarie passes a formal hip-length tunic to Sir Frankenberry, Esquire and wishes him a good evening. Once out of sight of the shop, Sir Frankenberry, Esquire forces the shirt on over the top of his full plate armor. It stretches, but in credit to its craftsmanship, does not burst. Refusing to smile, Sir Frankenberry, Esquire heads off towards the reception. Solitude's mayor has already arrived, of course. She has predictably positioned herself adjacent to the bride, where the evening's attention will be perpetually centered. A fully armed and armored 7 foot high orc approaches. His face is hidden by an enclosed helmet. The warhammer strapped to his back runs nearly the full length of his massive frame. A strained and battered wrap of cotton fabric clings about his chest. The mayor maintains composure. "DO YOU LIKE MY SHIRT?" "I'm sorry. Hello... your shirt?" "YES. DO YOU LIKE IT?" "Oh. My. It's positively astounding. I do." "TAARIE MADE IT FOR ME. SHE OWNS A CLOTHING STORE IN TOWN." "Taarie did? That's... great. I should visit her later on..." "SHE MADE IT FOR ME TO WEAR FOR YOU TONIGHT." The mayor was on the brink of betraying an emotion of discomfort. But before an eyebrow could be raised, Sir Frankenberry, Esquire's warhammer was lifted overhead, then brought down through the body of the nearby bride. The weapon's weight was more than that of the target. The swiftness of the action combined with the unrecognizable result meant that several seconds passed before anyone knew exactly what had occurred. Anyone except the orc, of course, who was already sprinting towards the city gates. "TAARIE MADE IT FOR ME! SHE MADE IT FOR ME TO WEAR FOR YOU TONIGHT!" Sir Frankenberry, Esquire permitted himself a smile.

review: Wow, can't begin to descibe how good this game is.... When I first heard about people talking about this game I automatically assumed they were nerds, but playing this doesn't make you feel like you are playing dungeons and dragons, or WoW. It feels like you are another person, choosing your own path; slaughtering innocent townspeople, becoming a hero who wants to protect all that is right, or even becoming a master vampire and living out in the marsh with a house you built (DLC required). The landscapes are stunning, the AI is, I can't say the best, but compared to games like Just Cause 2 and and ArmA 2, they are much better. I spent 250 hours playing vanilla, and still have not completed the Dawnguard questline as a Dawnguard member, or finished the companion questline (I hate the companions if you buy the game hopefully you will agree with me), and still am doing quests. Need cash and love killing? Join the Dark Brotherhood, a ancient organization which carries out assinations. want to be a master wizard (you get to zap people with lightning and )? Join the mage College of Winterhold. After 250 hours I got mods which made the game so much better. Buy it. Stop wasting your time trying to find out if its good, because IT IS.

game-hours: 17.0
review: I had never played any of the other Elder Scrolls before Skyrim. I orignally bought Skyrim on the XBox a couple months after it came out. It blew me away even on a console. The character customization is vast, the scenerey is breathtaking, the gameplay is incredible, and on PC, the customizability using mods makes for an awesome game. At the beginning of the game, like most RPG games, you can customize your character. There are so many options you can spend up to an hour just fiddiling with facial features. That just shows how much effort Bethesda put into this game. They put so much into a feature that is almost pointless since you rarely even see your character's face. It just gives you an idea of the quality of the rest of the game. After spending half an hour making my character and doing the beginning "tutorial", I took my first steps into the outside world. It blew me away. It's crazy seeing a spectacular mountain in the distance and knowing that you can climb it. Everything you see can be reached and nothing is just there as just a background... except for the sky. The combat in this game is really fun and rarely gets repetive. You can go in one cave slashing spiders with your sword, go in the next blasting witchs to pieces with spells, and go in another shooting all the draugr in the head with a bow. There are so many different types of weapons and armor and the combat never gets old. Skyrim is full of quests. In fact, that is how the story is moved along. Some of the questlines are really fun, like the Dark Brotherhood quests where you become an assasin. Some quests, on the other hand, get boring in repetitive. A lot of NPCs will give you a quest like, "Kill that thing in the cave." so you can get a favor from them. Lastly, the mods. Wow. When I bought Skyrim for PC, I was amazed. The things you can do with mods is amazing. You can do things like enhance the graphics, improve the UI, and fix annoying bugs. Hell, there's even a mod to replace the dragon at the beginning with Thomas the Tank Engine or make all the female NPCs naked... if that's what you're in to. Overall, this game is stunning and is my favorite game I've ever played.

review: Skyrim in a nutshell - Everything you ever wanted in an action/RPG game. As long as it has been dangerous to go alone, from the time of the first wooden sword, back when we only had top down 8-bit graphics, there have been games that allow you to choose where to go and what to do. Skyrim is a shining example of allowing you to choose exactly what you want to do. Feel like running a totally serious playthrough as a Nord Warrior who smashes and shouts people into Oblivion? Sure. Want to be an Elf mage who is more pretentious than everyone else, oh, and who also throws fireballs? Of course. Had a long day and want to blow off some steam? Console in a few dozen cheese-wheels on top of a mountain and Fus-Ro-Dah those suckers flying across Tamriel... Mod Support? OF COURSE! 10/10 Would mod top-hat wearing mudcrabs again.

review: This review was written as response to the question if it was worth it to pick the legendary edition: I recently bought the legendary version for the pc because i knew i would eventually buy the DLC's, since i already have 500+ hours on skyrim in the ps3. The main game is pure awesomeness, but in my opinion the best missions in skyrim come from the dragonborn DLC (well don't disregard the fact that with this DLC you can ride dragons) and the dawnguard DLC adds a lot of content for something that looked a bit vage in the main game (werewolfs and vampires). Last but not least with hearthfire you can actually build your house not just buy one, but what makes this DLC awesome is the fact that you can adopt kids (it may appear dumb in a game like skyrim but after a while you actually form a bond with the child). So yeah i think it's worth picking the legendary edition. TL;DR: Buy the legendary edition you won't regret it.

Abilities: In Skyrim you can cast magic (Destruction spells, Conjuration Spells - my favorite- and more), have recreational skills (Speech, Smithing, etc...) or Fighting Skills (Archery, One-handed weapons, Two-handed weapons etc...) game-hours: 3155.2
review: Skyrim without mods is like water without a drinking glass. I highly recomend this game but there are few mods that should always be ran in it. Recomend you get Nexus Mod Manager and get your mods from Nexus. There are alot of mods that improve how the game looks. None of those are on my list below, so you can look for those if you have a PC that will run them all it looks like a next gen game. Here are the ones I recomend for game play. Core Mods: 1. SKSE - Extends the capability of mods created, Needed for many of the other mods 2. SkyUI - Redoes the UI so it no longer sucks on a PC. Much better. 3. The 4 Unofficial Patch Mods (Skyrim, Harthfire, Dragonborn, Dawngaurd) they fix hundreds of bug. 4. Immersive Patrols - Makes everything better as you run into patrols from all the factions as you move about. 5. Immersive Armors - Expands armors in the game 6. Immersive Weapons - Expands Weapons in the game 7. Immersive Creatrues - Adds more creature types, expands the ones that are in game and makes them stronger 8. Cloaks of Skyrim - No cloaks in the base game, can you believe it? This adds them. 9. Bellyaches New Dragon Species and Ohdaviing Replacer - Nice looking Dragons, and more varrieties 10. Deadly Dragons - Makes Dragons stronger. Configurable, make them as strong as you like. 11. VioLens - A kill move mod. If you want to adjust frequence and type of kill moves. 12. OBIS - A Bandit modification that makes bandits harder to kill and more unique. Quest Mods: 1. Helgen Reborn - Adds a quest line to rebuild Helgen 2. The Paarthurnax Dilemma - Adds options to part of the main quest, and lets you play more your way. 3. Moon & Stars - Perhaps the best additional quest line developed. 4. Dreadmyst Hollow - Very good Vampire/Horror Campaign 5. Wormstooth - Adds a small new land area and a really good campaign 6. The Shadow of Meresis - Really cool mod that has a kinda dumb ending. Still very worth playing. For a Touch of Oblivian in Skyrim add these, both great mods. 1. The Oblivion Realms Serie - The Gate of Solitude 2. The Oblivion Realms Serie - Morthal Pain Additional Follower Mods 1. Arissa - The Wandering Rogue 2. Sofia - The Funny Fully Voiced Follower (Note some comments from her are adult in nature) 3. INIGO - One of the coolest followers I have ever used. 4. Enhanced Skyrim Followers - Aela the Huntress: Not a new follower but makes Aela very cool and quest aware. Put those in and Skyrim will be twice the game (in play time) the base game was. THere are also many more good mods out there. I picked some of the ones I liked the best to list. This is a great game and a lot of fun to play again with a different selection of mods installed.

game-hours: 193.6
review: Of all the people I've ever talked to, I've never found one who held overly negative thoughts about The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, and rightly so. Sure, it's not perfect; the game tends to hold the player's hand and leveling is easy compared to the leveling in Oblivion, but Skyrim is a big picture game. The excitement of discovery, the sprawling overworld, the power of choice, the ability to craft your character how you see fit - these are the core elements which have drawn millions of gamers into Bethesda's snowy wonderland for dozens, even hundreds of hours. The attention to detail in Skyrim is absolutely ludicrous, and despite complaints about The Elder Scrolls' "floaty-feeling" combat, Skyrim is able to deliver an incredibly realized world with the depth in combat to boot. The Sneak-Archer, Melee-Brawler and Mage builds are all viable (though I don't recommend being a Mage) and feel different enough to warrant multiple playthroughs. The Skill Tree system (now with an infinite level cap) incentivizes further gaming due to the perks it gives for each respective Skill, giving longtime veterans another reason to keep playing. In the end, there's so much to Skyrim. A thorough review of the game could be as long as full-blown college essay, so I'll leave it this: for any gamers who haven't yet played Skyrim, play it. You won't regret it. 10/10

review: (Might be spoilers. Tread with care) Play one of several races. Loot, craft, enchant, fight with weapons or wizardry. Generic sounding? In theory. In practice? Whimsically & groundbreakingly awesome on so many levels. In what other open world game do you get to climb giant mountains, for crying out loud? Though widely viewed as less magical than its predecessor in terms of its atmosphere by Oblivion fans, it is also rightfully recognised for its own grittier aesthetic which complements the celtic/norse house style of the UI in a way that brings the feel of the frosty homeland of the nords forth like nothing else. Also, it arouses further intrigue to see the empire hanging in the balance, & even the Blades forced from their former glory into, um.... well, nine gods know where. Then we have the DLC. Dawnguard? Meh, but having more content for Skyrim was bliss in itself, so I approve. Dragonborn? Now we're talking; what better than to get a glimpse of the Dunmer culture once more, served alongside a deeper exploration of Hermaeus Mora (the fact that his quest was connected to the core game's main quests was a neat introduction to daedric quests, but a bit desperate) as we delve into his realm of apocrypha. Hearthfire? Never bought it myself, but eh, if you WERE looking to build your very own ingame house.... But I must digress. Skyrim: Legendary edition is out there in case you hadn't already caught onto this masterpiece. Although after clocking an, ahem, 800 & over hours of gameplay, I'm not quite as ecstatic these days, I reccommend giving Skyrim... a try? No. This thing was a turning point for my gaming career, from pure nintendo into the world of PC gaming. Go whole hog or go home; you have an albeit small country to fudge around in.

game-hours: 843.1
review: I am perfectly comfortable in saying that The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is by far the best game that I have ever played. The combat is familiar but still keeps things fresh to differentiate itself from previous Elder Scrolls titles. By current standards, the graphics and character models may seem a bit muddy, though this can be fixed by one of Skyrim's strongest features, its amazing mod support and community. While the base game of Skyrim itself can keep most players busy for a few hundred hours, mods add hundreds more, and with DLC-worthy mods such as Falskaar and the Skywind Project, the game seems as though there is no end. Gameplay aside, the lore and quests in this game don't offer as much freedom as Morrowind or Oblivion, but don't tie you down enough to where you feel like you're being forced to make a certain decision. The game offers the player a lot of freedom, as all side quests in the game can be completed as long as the player has obtained the power of the Thu'um, and that's another great feature all together. The Thu'um, or Shouts as the game more frequently refers to it as, is a power that the player (and a few other important characters) possesses that allows him or her to use their own voice to pretty much annihilate the enemy. There are more than 20 different Shouts in the base game, with the DLCs adding even more, and each one is uniquely different than the next, so the player doesn't feel like they're just getting an alternate version of the same power each time. A few other small things to mention is the simplified Level Up menu that allows your character to distribute stat points and perks without having to find somewhere to sleep and the amazing character customization. Honestly, there isn't much that I could find wrong with this game. And I'm pushing 800 hours of gameplay. So seriously, if you don't own Skyrim and you need to blow a few bucks, buy it. Trust me, you won't regret it. On a scale from 1 to 10, I think it's quite obvious at this point that the Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim receives a strong 10/10 from me.

game-hours: 74.1
review: Wow. This game. Where do I start?! Well, a short summary of Skyrim would be: Massive, Immersive, Addictive, Full of quality content, involving, can be as easy or as challenging as you like, gritty, realistic (for fantasy), magical, full of exploration and discovery. Is there a limit of how many commas I can use because oh boy, I could just keep going & going. Here is the true review: Skyrim is the ultimate fantasy RPG and is arguably the best Role-playing game ever. It may have a few flaws, bugs & glitches, but the large (and I mean LARGE) majority of the game is truly breath-taking! *Visuals - While this game was released back in 2011, the visuals were (and still are) great in bringing a realistic feel to a fantasy world. Although there are some low resolution textures, the overall look of the game is VERY well done. On the PC (with mods) the graphics can be easily upgraded for the current generation of gaming. *Gameplay - Although many people criticise the seemingly 'clunky combat,' I think it gives a really gritty and realistic feel which fits right in with the tough barbarian-esque atmosphere. The only 'clunky' combat that I have experienced is with two-handed weapons (Great Swords & Warhammers). Weapons like regular swords, daggers & bows don't feel clunky at all but they still feel realistic. Magic is very enjoyable to use. When you're not spraying your enemies' face with flames or casting a ball of light inside a cave, you're turning enemies against each other with a powerful conjured Daedra Lord attacking them all whilst invisible and unseen. You can even use staves if your magicka is low or you can wield a spell in one hand with a staff in another. Oh, I forgot to mention; you can dual-wield! Dual-wielding is when you have a sword in one hand and a spell in the other. Or, you can even wield two swords as well as dual-casting spells for a more powerful effect. Overall, I think the combat is fun, rewarding & enjoyable (especially on higher difficulties). The rest of the gameplay mechanics are very well done; especially when it comes to crafting, collecting loot, harvesting etc. *Levelling - The levelling system in the game is simple yet effective (yes, I'm talking about vanilla). The more you use a certain skill, the better you will get a it. It is as simple as that. For example: If you're a mage and you just start using flames, it won't do much damage at all. But the more you use them (or any other spell in that particular school) the more your Destruction skill increases. When you've levelled a skill (or several skills) enough times, you will 'Level Up' your character's level. For example, if you're level 1 and you increase your destruction & one-handed skills a few times, your character's progression bar will glow and you can level up your character. The levelling up process consists of choosing either Health, Magicka or Stamina. These three attributes are your main buffs in the game. While Health is obvious, Stamina increases the duration at which you can sprint as well as perform power-attacks. It even increases your carry-weight which increases the amount of items you can carry. Magicka increases the duration of your spells as well as allowing you to cast more advanced spells. #NOTE# You can find/buy/make jewellery/armor that can give you buffs in certain skills so you don't have to fully rely on perks. You also get perks. Perks are points that you can use to increase (decrease Magicka cost of spells) your chosen skills' power/damage as well as unlocking new abilities. You must spend your perks sparingly because you only have a limited amount. So choose wisely! *Crafting - Instead of just buying weapons, armor, potions & enchanted gear, you can make them yourself! With a little (or a lot) of skill, you can create extremely powerful weapons, potions & enchantments as well as very protective armor. Smithing: Is the skill to improve weapons & armor at forges, grindstones & workbenches. A high Smithing skill means that you can forge more varieties of armor as well as being able to improve them (and the associated weapons) twice as much! Enchanting: Would you like to absorb the health of your enemies as your own? Set fire to them with just a touch of your blade? Paralyse them? You can do so much with enchanting. You can enchant both weapons & armor. In order to enchant an item, you need a filled Soul Gem. You can buy soul gems or use the Conjuration spell, 'Soul Trap' on an enemy in order to trap their soul. (The tougher the enemy the more powerful the soul = more powerful enchantments) Weapon enchantments mainly consist of a type of damage buff such as shock, frost, fire or poison. You can also apply Soul Trap to a weapon in order to easily trap the souls of enemies instead of using te spell. Armor enchantments consist of effects such as: *Increase Health/Stamina/Magicka *Muffle (harder to detect when sneaking) *Resist frost/shock/fire/poison *Increasing a certain skill (E.g. one-handed weapons do 25% more damage or increase heavy armor skill by 10%) Alchemy: Allows you to make powerful potions & poisons. Although you find many potions/poisons throughout the world, none can compete with a master Alchemist's skill. For example, a normal poison may do 2 points of health damage for 10 seconds. You can make the same poison of lingering health that does 7 points of health damage for 30 seconds. The equivalent of a health potion would be: Regular Minor Healing Potion=Restores 25 points of health vs Master Alchemist Health Potion= Restores 100 points of health. #NOTE# The in-game potion/poison strengths/types will vary as well as the types/strengths of potions/poisons that you make. All that I'm trying to explain is, your potions & poisons will always be better than any potion that you can buy/loot if you level Alchemy. *Overall Opinion - While Skyrim was the first RPG that I had ever played, it still remains my all-time favourite. I look up to this masterpiece of a game as it introduced me to my favourite gaming genre. I do love other types of Role-playing games besides open-world such as dungeon-crawlers (Dark Souls & Legend of Grimrock) and the Witcher. Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning & Dragon's Dogma are two other open-world RPGs that I enjoy playing and have spent hours on, but no game has ever given me the total feeling of immersion & depth like Skyrim has.

review: 9.4/10 Skyrim, this, I can truthfully say, is onle of the best games I have ever played. The immersive feel of whenever you're trying to bow down enemies of your guild with a bow, the role playing of drinking beer i n a bar, the fear that you feel when you see a troll. All of these factors make Skyrim my favorite RPG. The sheer quantity of things you can do, the ways you can play, you way you can look! When you play Skyrim, you feel like you're really choosing your own path, more than just an alternate ending, or a certian team. You choose what you do; and how you do it. I've never played a game like it, you really get to know it well, get in to routines, without it ever seeming repetitive, you just enjoy knowing where to run, or how to hide. Even when you do get to know Skyrim, complete the quests, max out your skills. You introduce yourself to the vast modding comunity, both on the Nexus and on the workshop, you can get so many different types of mods, being able to see that dragon's wing in more quality, or adding a whole new hold on a far away island, you never run out of mods to explore. These things are what add to why Skyrim is one of my favorite games of all time, a must buy for and Roleplayer, Explorer or Combat-Lover

game-hours: 56.3
review: My favorite game ever made. I've owned it on Ps3, Xbox, and now PC. The game lets you do whatever you want, and gives you the most lovingly crafted, beautifully designed game world I've ever seen to do it in. One of the only games that you can truly keep coming back to. You can look at any door, open it, and explore what's behind it. You can see an impossibly far away mountain peak, and you can scale it. You can make potions, weapons, armor. You can be a thief or a knight or an alchemist (all with the same character if you want). There are just so many things to see and do that I won't ever be really sure I've seen or done them all. That alone makes it worth the purchase tenfold for me. People will complain about the combat system being shallow (and I mostly agree), and there are some definite bugs, but I will gladly accept those things in exhange for the world of Skyrim. The soundtrack is beautiful, the modding community is absolutely insane, and the team at Bethesda are so obviously passionate about the world of The Elder Scrolls. There are so many games that I love, but I have never been truly immersed like I am while playing Skyrim. If you can't tell, I heartily recommend this amazing game.

game-hours: 191.4
review: I have played this game on PC, PS3, and Xbox. This game is one of the best games ever made by Bethesda etc. Well, that is, at least in my opinion. I suggest, if you are new to the game, do a runthrough with no dlcs of any sort to get your base "idea" of the game. Then buy the Dragonborn, Hearthfire, and Dawnguard addons. After experiencing those addons, if you're up to it, try out some of the workshop mods! Some starter mods I suggest are RAS (Random Alternate Start), the CCO (Character Creation Overhaul {that is if I am thinking of the name correctly}), and the Blue Bear Lodge. Overall, this game is amazing and I would recommmend the entire Elder Scrolls Series (except ESO, cause I have not tried it....) to anyone who is looking for a old, yet new fantasy, roleplaying based series. SO MUCH FUN.
game-hours: 3.5
review: Awesome game, i suggest this game to people who love open world, action games :D
game-hours: 263.3
review: One of the best games of all time
game-hours: 491.8
review: I reccomend this game wholeheartedly, but with a lot of asterisks on the end of that statement. The game overall is awesome and in its vanilla form its the best an elder scrolls game has ever been. The world feels more interactive, people no longer look like potatoes, the game doesn't crash as much as older games, dungeons are designed better, quests break less often. HOWEVER, a good deal of things have been simplified from earlier games in the series and the game suffers for that in a gameplay sense and a modding sense: Seriously toned down stats mean that there is less character customization, less modability there. Paired down spell schools and removed spellcrafting means that builds will start to play the same after a wile, and its harder to mod the skill trees into something interesting. Paired down leveling system makes more sense than Oblivion's but is much more rigid. A lot of secondary stuff has been completely removed from the game such as: seperate body and leg slots, faster horses, unarmed/hand to hand skills, acrobatics/athleticism etc. skilltrees, a good deal of the spell effects from previous games. While I don't miss a lot of these from a gameplay sense I miss them from a modding perspective because they allowed for mods to change the game in more ways than Skyrim's engine will allow. Sure Oblivion was broken but I felt like you could take the game and expand it beyond what Skyrim is capable of(gameplay wise) simply because the base game was more varied and granular with the tools made avalible to the players and modders alike. And while I did have a lot of fun with Skyrim, starting new characters all over the place and expierimenting with character builds. I feel like its really lacking that serious modding passion that other bethesda games have had since morrowind and thats what kept me coming back to those games even to this day.

review: This is hands down one of the best games of my life. I already enjoyed Obilvion very much, even though I got to play it not too long before Skyrim came out, meaning that it was a great game years after it was released. The only issue with Oblivion that annoyed me somehow were the UI, and graphics, but those did not take the fun away at all. Skyrim is very similar to Oblivion compared to other games, but with massive improvements in those 2 things, so for me this game is close to perfection! You can be an explorer, you might like the side quests, you might like the combat system, or you might like simply walking by and admiring the landscapes (there's a lot of them). I can't possibly describe all the aspects in the game which I love since I spent quite some time playing it and there's a lot to love, but long story short, if you're even remotely considering buying it, buy it, it's worth every penny.

review: Fantastic game. So much to do, you can re-play and re-play a multitude of times and still find different things to do every playthrough, guaranteed. There's tonnes and tonnes of stuff to do and see in the vanilla version of the game, too, if modding isn't your thing. In the time I've spent playing Skyrim I could have quite easily mastered a foreign language, learnt to drive a car or settled down with a wife and kids. I'd still choose Skyrim any day.

review: This game is legendary. It has a tons of stuff to do, and even after 600 hours of playing you can still find new stuff. review: "10/10" - Benny This game... I remember when I first got it... I was so excited that the sequel to oblivion was going to come out, I insisted to my mom that I go to the midnight release. I told my cousin and my friend that I was going, and said they should come along as well. We went to the midnight release and waited in the cold with a lot of questionable looking people *cough* fat nerds *cough*, it smelled horrible and was one hell of a time. All three of us got our PS3 Skyrim disc and my mom dropped off my friend & cousin first, so they got a head start on playing it. I came home and it was a day I will never ever forget, finally a game I've been waiting for, an amazing adventure to be made entirely by me, endless possibilities all at my fingertips, I could do whatever I want with the freedom of my imagination and the limitations of the games capabilities. This game is by far one of my favorite games, and I'm glad that it caught on to other kinds of gamers, so much so that it is one of the most renown games ever. I'm so proud of Bethesda. This is a game I can keep coming back to, the mods make it so that you can never get bored. Hell, I've finished this game many, many times on ps3 (in which I have over 500 hours on this game) and every time I'd end up finding something new. There are no games that are good enough to rival skyrim, with the exception of fallout (but that is another bethesda game, its like skyrim with guns) I love adventure, and this game always brings me joy when I play it. I couldn't imagine my life without such a game. I'd hope that people don't "consider" buying this game and just do it, I haven't even met a single person who doesn't like the game. *bless*

review: Skyrim is not game of the year , Skyrim is game of the decade. Perhaps the single most non-linear game with a beautiful open world and dynamic settings where you can almost literally go and do anything you please, Skyrim was my first experience with The Elder scrolls series , I had got it as a Christmas gift in 2011 for the PS3 , I managed to log well over 800 hours of game play ,always starting a new game after hitting level 50ish .also got all three DLCs (Dragonborn) (Dawnguard) (Hearthfire) after they become non exclusive (still sort of pissed about that one ) and that added another 100 or so hours of game play . But even so, eventually the grind catches on , i had done the whole story , every side quest and nearly every radiant that you can think of several times over , it would be a safe guess to say that I had done the story nearly 20 times , and so after my love of skyrim died I turned to Oblivion ( and eventually getting well over 200 hours of gameplay ) . and then Steam puts Skyrim Legendary edition on sale (from what i can remember it was 25 % off ) and so after playing it on a console for the past few years, and always wanting to be able to mod it , I grabbed it on steam , and the love for it found me again, after finding a few wonderful mods here on the workshop I found myself wrapped in it again , and while the story line is pretty much the same (aside from a few mods) , the ability to add and take away elements from this game makes it all worth while again . so would I recommend Skyrim to You ?, most probably, if you like playing games that utilize critical thinking skills , and if you like open world RPGs , and if you have somewhat of an Imagination , then yes I would .

game-hours: 161.8
review: I used to be an adventure like you , but i took an arrow to the knee
game-hours: 572.0
review: This is a great game. Basically, you are put in the shoes of the one warrior in Skyrim who can stop the World-Eater Wyrm, Alduin. You accomplish this through your steel, your spells, your wits, and your Dragon Shouts (the power to warp reality by yelling in the dragon tongue). Along the way, you must battle the likes of vampires, bandits, frost trolls, and more. And the story does not end after you save the world once, oh no. The DLC adds two more possible armageddons, one in which you may choose to be a villain. It is extremely choice-based as a game. Combat is easy to learn, hard to master. Left clicking attacks, holding left click performs a power attack, right clicking blocks, and power attacking while moving results in a more powerful strike, which changes depending on the direction. Spells are powerful tools, but it can be difficult to cast them at first due to low Magicka. Each attack is governed by a different meter. Power attacks drain Stamina, spells drain Magicka, and getting hit will (of course) drain your hit points. The Perk system is a unique class approach that allows you to govern how you play. Want to wield heavy weapons alongside spells (my personal favorite)? Choose the right perks and you are all set. Want to sword and board, but also don't want to miss out on archery? Done. Options include Stealth, Combat, and Magic perks. The world itself is amazing. Every detail, from an underwater cavern to an aurora borealis is crafted with painstaking detail. The dungeons can start to look alike after a while (especially Nord crypts), but the world is simply compelling. Dragon battles are big enough to get their own review point here. It can be difficult to slay dragons at first, but you eventually will get the Dragonrend shout, which forces the beasts to land. Moddability is amazing for this game. I run it heavily modded (mostly it adds spells or new swords) and it is amazing. Highly suggest grabbing mods for this game when it suits you. In conclusion, great game. I'd recommend this to anyone who enjoys a Role-Playing Game.

review: GREAT GAME!
game-hours: 87.9
review: Elder scrolls V Skyrim is a majestic experience. You begin as an ambiguous anonymous bystander, and from those humbled beginnings you begin the journey to become the greatest warrior to ever exist in Skyrim. The game is riddled with various ways to go about it. There is always a different path that one can take, but it doesn't end at the path. You can go off the path go to any direction, in any area and become involved. One could talk to any of the NPC's and still feel genuinely immersed in a beautiful overwhelming world. From archer to thief to light armor, heavy armor, to double handed weapons & single-handed weapons, from restorative magic to distractive magic, the game was always on point always engrossing, because of the amount of detail that I could personally choose to incorporate into my player. It gave me such a strong sense of intimacy and identification that I feel compelled even more really compelled to help what is basically NPC's code but not even real people. The story is deep, convoluted, and realistic in the sense the world has intrigue. The gray in the reality of the moral landscape, who is actually on the right is actually on the wrong. Our relativity to the scenarios is key for this game because that is another aspect that gets you to get into even more immersive for choosing what is right what is what is wrong. I wish that more games where there is such a depth to their world. I understand it would be practically difficult but there is just something that is missing in many of the new games that this game still has and I am sure will not lose for quite a long time. So without a doubt this game is definitely a number one purchase, needed for every game, needed for anyone who wanted to experience something with such beauty.

game-hours: 87.8
review: The Elder Scrolls Skyrim is a strong single-player only classic RPG. It features a skill-based system and an open world. This game has tons of content and a decent story. Some of the side quest writing is exceptional. The game also features dragons that fly around and can attack you at any time. These dragons don't really provide a challenege (especially towards the end game) but add to the world immersion. Overall the game suffers from being way too easy. Any experienced RPG player will fly through this game with little effort. It's still worth a play through and still tons of fun but I'd go somewhere else for a challenege. Never played the DLC. Genre Lovers: Must Buy (doesn't get anymore RPG than this) Non-Genre Lovers: Worth a try (tons of value and pretty easy) Time to Beat: ~80 hours (I did every side quest in the vanilla game)

game-hours: 68.4
review: Wasted life on this game and i would do it again
game-hours: 238.1
review: There are so many mods for this game that extend the life of it a ton more than on the consoles, even though I have played on both a large amount. Not to mention the game itself, without the mods, is great. I have put what steam says around 140 hours on pc online, I have put some more offline on the pc and have put well over 200 hours on the ps3. My experience with this game is extensive and I want it to continue. Bethesda is a great studio, and you can tell that they have put time and soul into this piece of work. There is so many handplaced stories, objects, easter eggs, allusions and just uniqueness that you can't find in any other game maybe other than the other elder scrolls titles. For those who have played The Elder Scrolls 3 and 4 this game is still different and worth playing just because of the new lore, stories, characters, gameplay mechanics, skills, lands, and opportunities that you can have and interact with in this game. It provides a different experience that I would consider unique from any other fantasy rpg that I have played. But I truly do not think that you can consider this game without considering its full potential that it gains in modding that the community right here on steam and other sites like the skyrim nexus provides. Especially with the ease of which steam allows you to access mods. You can alter gameplay that you have already experienced to make it different, or you can leave every single piece of skyrim that is already there alone and just add on to it. You can do realism mods that it make it feel even more immersive than it is currently, you can do goofy mods to mess around with when you feel like it, you can do hardcore mods to make it more difficult than it allows normally, and you can do mods that essentially make you allmighty; there are so many mods that I have not even seen and I have over 100 mods currently enhancing my skyrim experience from steam and the skyrim nexus. It is all there and it prolongs a game that will give you over 100 hours of gameplay to probably double that amount. Without the mods alone the quests there already are created well, written well and large in number; with all the hours I have on this game, not yet have I completed all of the quests without a doubt on any of the characters that I have rolled. If you are a graphics snob and only want the best, the game alone has very good graphics especially when you download the free hd graphics update, but if you feel that it is still not enough, which I can at times, the skyrim nexus provides mods that make the game more than my alienware computer can handle, and many more that it can handle that still make the game beautiful, colorful, and full of contrast and bloom, so if you are worried about that, you need not be. I have heard people say that they have not liked this game, first of all I think they are crazy, but that just goes to show that there can be a difference in opinion and that to truly know whether you would like it or not is to try it for yourself, actually put a little bit of time into it, and take advantage of the mods especially if you notice it on sale. I have seen this game on sale for a comparably cheap price thanks to steam's generosity. The DLC that can come with the complete edition or seperately are worth the price as well, again especially if they are on sale. They add new lands, mechanics, skill trees, player housing, quest lines, modding capabilities, and in-game items. If you feel that the modding community that is huge for skryim does not do the type of mods you want or does not do them the way you want, there is the free creation kit that bethesda provides right here on steam; this allows you to create those mods that you can download on your own for you, your friends, at someones request, just because you feel like it, or to see if you can do it. After playing this game for so long, the only complaint I have about this game is that it is rather big in storage space requirement when you have as many mods as I do(a lot) with the base game and my limited amount of space, however despite that complaint it is still worth keeping on this computer always just because of how amazing and nostaligic I feel when I play it. And I am not saying that I don't need to take breaks from it, I do and I have, but I know I can always go back to this game and enjoy myself even if I only play it for 20 minutes at a time and get only a small portion of a quest done.

review: This is my favourite game of all time. I have so many great memories of this game, questing, roleplaying, killing, it was such a great experience. I love the landscape in this game also, there is so much variety it should make everyone happy. Environments such as the harsh cold mountains of the north, the beautiful forests and flora of Whiterun and Falkreath, the amber trees and golden grass of Riften. And the rocky, Dwemer feel to Markarth. Playing through the vanilla game was one of my favorite and greatest experience ever. And then I started modding. WOW. The modding support for this game is both ridiculous and amazing at the same time. There are mods out there for absolutely everyone. Whether your a hardcore survivalist ( Frostfall, RNAD), or roleplaying a hunter (Hunterborn, A hunting guild) or maybe your a fearless brute, a mercenary, this game is perfect. If you are not a fan of the 2011 graphics, do not worry there are several enb's out there which vastly improve the look of this game. My favorites are: Realvision enb, Seasons of skyrim enb and project enb. All look absolutely stunning. Honestly, I could write a thousand word essay on why you should buy this game or why it's my favourite game of all time. To anyone wanting one of the best gaming experiences out there, I recommend this game. It's perfect.

review: Skyrim, that game is about distraction. What? You tell me there is a main quest line? Hm hm, we'll see. But first things first. After the beginning you start your journey to whiterun, where your task is to warn the ruler about coming dragon attacks. Well, good luck. Distraction, saying it once again. On your way to Whiterun, you're invited to join the Companions, which is one of the factions you can join. Yep, you played Skyrim for 5 minutes and already have sidequests. Thats what I'm talking about. Would you rather rush to the Jarl and warn him about Dragons, or do you follow the invitation of Aela the huntress (who btw is a tough girl with bows n stuff, jsut sayin, not to mention side boobs) to join the companions? It's simple, distraction. But thats not a bad thing. Playing the game for the first time, you'll be amazed and confused about the many options of tasks people will give you in this game. Definitely one of the best aspects of Skyrim is the diversity and the freedom to choose what to do. Go hunting? Raid ancient graves and ruins? Slay dragons? Craft awesome gear? Be a thief or an assassin? Why not both? Be a hammer swingin', heavy armored berserker orc or rather a sneaky bow / hit'n'run assassin? Mage? Shield bash everything into the ground? It's up to you! Or, do what most of the players experience once they are done with almost every quest, every tomb, all the factions. One word: MODS!!! There are tons of em, and boy! so many amazing ones! For free. It's that simple. There's just one thing left to say. Never! Ever! lay your hand on a chicken. They are even worse than dragons. Believe me. What? You don't? Well, go buy this game and find out yourself!

game-hours: 220.4
review: Actions speak louder than words they say - well, at least that's what delved into the minds of bethesda's designers when skyrim was conceived. Skyrim shamelessly takes the cinematic goodies from theaters and crushes it into a mix with highly interactive gameplay and, like every good mix of elements, explodes brilliantly but leaves something valuable behind. Climb a mountain, kill a dragon, steal a sweetroll, raise zombies, everything splashes and rumbles like a great parade. Boredom is blasphemy in Skyrim. A cent for each fun popcorn greased, action filled cinematic moment would cumulate into enough wealth for buying out Microsoft just for the sake of comparison. Skyrim finally moved into her own and makes no apologies about it. Let's face it, TES is no longer in the D&D generation. Skyrim set out to the original TES ambition of a free roaming action RPG but made no compromises with her older siblings. You set out to do something and the world doesn't hold you back, right? Well, that idea doesn't only apply to the gameplay but the evolution of TES-series in general. It had it coming for sure but the foundation was already laid back in the days. So what is wrong with Skyrim? Well this question cries out a bit of precision: There is a more-or-less fine line between failure and the burden of choice. You can't pull a lever to both sides at once; you set out to erase the D&D scheme - you strip off the attributes. Well, tough. A failure, however, means not exceeding the set goal. So, for the most part, the criticism I've seen about Skyrim incline towards the former because Skyrim was great about the things it set out to accomplish and, to be fair, it set out to do a lot. Where Morrowind succeeded as a good book, Skyrim succeeded as a good movie. Movies made out of vast worlds tend to be spread thin in raw content but the experience is ever more vibrant and lively than the written counterpart. Despite that, Skyrim doesn't leave you cold in the sheer amount of awesome things to explore and experience, it's stuffed! As books are not as big part of the zeitgeist anymore, the issue people take in Skyrim is usually more about the taste of the average player rather than the match of vision and craft of the developers. It's evident that whatever category Skyrim assumed for itself, it gave one hell of a shock, not only, to the rivals in its respective field, but the ones outside of its assumed borders. Coincidently, Skyrim may have dealt the critical strike to the dragon phenomenon in videogame industry for a temporary demise. But for the time being: Get ready for the copycats.

game-hours: 88.3
review: It took me two years and much convincing to buy Skyrim. To give context, let me explain why I was so wary. At the insistence of both friends and online review, I picked up a copy of oblivion years ago. I played it for slightly over an hour and was completely uninterested. I've never been able to enjoy an MMOrpg, and lost my taste for FPS games about ten years ago. Basically, all my experience told me that Skyrim was going to be another huge and boring game that got a lot of acclaim but let me desiring something to get attached to. Luckily for me, it did just that. Skyrim's draw for me lay in it's polish, and the depth and extent of it's vision. I've spent 20 minutes looking at the aurora Boryalis. I spend time actually listening to the dialog instead of button mashing to get the quest, and I'm constantly blown away with where the story, and the environment of the game take me. It's gameplay is solid, yet there isn't some interesting feature that marks it as special, besides maybe the vastness of it. The three varying paths of mage, rogue and warrior offer a plethora of fighting styles and tricks that have kept me engaged while I further along the plot arcs. It's satisfying to sneak through a dungeon never being seen, only to place arrows in the backs of every foe's head. Similarly, rounding up all the baddies to be dispatched by a bombardment of fireballs is satisfying in a totally different way. But the entire time I'm doing that, I know it will get me one step closer to finding that scroll, learning that new word of power, or getting that huge chest of loot at the end of the tunnel. Skyrim is a beautiful game that has taken the beauty of storytelling and let you immerse yourself as an adventurer in a fantasical, beautiful, and fully realized world. If you are looking to get lost in a story, or tame a dragon, I think you've found the right game to do it.

game-hours: 112.4
review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim blew my mind when I played it for the first time. The world is massive, the water is prestine, and there is life everywhere you turn. Wether it be a mushroom, a flower, or a magestic deer walking through the forest, the world feels alive and vibrant. There are so many things to do in this game it can be sometimes hard to chose what you want to try first. The crafting is fantastic - you can make your own armor, weapons, potions, or cook your own food... all using materials you collect throughout the world. Creatures, monsters, and NPCs are found in every environment, and nearly everything can be killed (except the children.. they cannot die... no matter how many times you whack them with a hammer...) You carve your own gameplay experience based on how you chose to play the game.. whether you become a blood sucking vampire and have to lurk about in the night, or if you become a werewolf prowling under the moonlight. The game constantly changes depending on the desicions you make, and that is very cool. Also, there are dragons. Who doesn't love dragons?

game-hours: 226.2
review: One of the best open-world experiences out there. Skyrim is perfect for any player who prefers to create their own character and then to customize how they level up, the levelling system is near flawless giving you options between the more melee based heavier type of character, the warlock mage or the sneaky theif archer. Needless to say you can mix it up so for example a battle mage could be created who would be great at swordmanship and armour aswell as spell casting ability. The story is probably not as intriguing as Skyrims predecessor and sometimes can seem to be a questline you want to progress through just to get it of your quest journal. This been said the amount of side and miscellaneous quests which will either be pretty serious or great fun with humour more than make up for the lacking main story, to add upon this the amount of these quests are insane and will keep yo treking in efforts to find more. Graphically the game looks fabulous and if you are the player that likes to add some game enhancing graphic mods then this game is most definetley for you, mods are released constantly and really do make your game look better (not that it looked bad in the first place) The GUI works the same as all the other Elder Scrolls games and will come to no surpise for most players, the inventory and skill system has been managed amazingly making it easy to access things in battle. The AI has become slightly more evolved but still what you would expect from this sort of game. Overall I would rate this game 8.5/10 and would say that it definitely is one of the best RPG's I have ever played.
game-hours: 98.8
review: drugs
game-hours: 122.3
review: Transitioning from one era to another in the story, Skyrim does a great job of cleaning up a lot of frustrations from previous TES games and putting every perspective that we love from Open World RPG's: Dynamic Settings, Beautiful Enivornments, and Epic Combat. The Combat doesn't feel so static and weak anymore, like you're hitting a fence with a wooden sword, first person combat now feels fast and fluid, sprinting, attacking, and blocking feel better as well. The Status bars are also a plus as well, having them conveniently placed across the bottom of your screen, to minimalize HUD flogging when you want to get immersed in this game. Environments look great, like the fog and cloud system in this game is by far the most photorealistic detail that I've ever seen in a game, that from looking at it it is almost palpable(big words). The Water system has improved a alot, but sometimes I'm swimming in invisible water due to glitches. Enchanting weapons is now a useful skill, rather than those cores you'd retrieve from closing oblviion gates. Weaponry Combat is now divided between One-Handed and Two-Handed, rather than Maces and Swords, and while either one can be argued over which is better, both are evetually equally helpful. Although, trying to get re-acquainted with certain magic skill sets is a little trifling, considering that Mysticism no longer is a magic skill set and we are left with Illusion, Destruction, Restoration, Alteration and Conjuration. Mysticism's spells have been divided among each other skill set, which can make finding the particular spells difficult if you are not familiar with The Elder Scrolls. But most importantly, Skill Sets are a big improvement to this game. Leveling Up is now more diverse; if you leveled up just using Marksmanship, you can put a Perk into Enchanting if you feel like it, where in Oblivion it had you forced to increase skills based on what skill you used most. Also, Magic, Stamina, and Health also have their own perk points, where each time you can level up, you can add 10 points to either one. The Story, well, it has some strengths, but also weaknesses. In terms of communication, Now all communication is in real-time, so when you communicate to one person, not everyone else will just freeze in place. Also, you won't have to stare at the NPC you are talking to face to face. In fact, you can actually move your first-person view while conversing, providing a more thematic and realistic ideal to communication. But to the story. Now, the Dragonborn Quest was epic, especially at the end when you finally face Alduin once and for all, but the other main quest on Civil War was very watered down and shallow. Now, you can never win a civil war with one person, that never happens. Throughout the whole time you are doing this quest, you never actually feel any tension from your foe, either being the imperials or the stormcloaks. And when you do enter Enemy territory, you aren't even threatened from there. Even after stopping Imperial/Stormcloak armies, capturing cities and ransacking forts, all that the leaders ever do is just curse your name and talk passive-agressively towards you, not even once bothering to mention that In that case you'd be a high profile target for assassination. Hm, maybe I'm just being too demanding and harsh on an already great game. However, on a technical level, there are a lot of issues with this game that bother me. From the endless amount of low-end, meaningless glitches (visual glitches and invisible,clipped enemies) to the extremely common game-breaking glitches( such as corrupted data and quest characters clipped into walls) Overall this game is worth your money, but if you want to play and have a good experience, then install patch mods because this game will become a nightmare if you don't. Apparently, my review was too long. Dammit steam. 9/10

game-hours: 840.0
review: I have clocked in so many hours of my life into this game and its DLC, along with the ability to mod it. This is by far my second favorite game of all time, and thats saying something considering the ammount of games ive played. I can always come back to TES:Skyrim and play with a new refreshing experience because of my imagination and the amalgamation of mods i have installed. Do i wanna be a necromancer assassin this round? Or do i wanna be a nature-conjuring , wolf spirt summoning druid ? Or a buff, beefy, sweaty-glistening-muscles toned argonian with a giant greatsword whos 9 feet tall and could crush you under his foot? Yes. Aslong as you have an imagination, and whether or not you wanna mod it [ i recommend modding, it adds near-infinite replayability even more to an infinite replayable base game] , this game is absolutely fun, stunning in graphics, and beautiful in many ways. Also hilarious, considering the people who made this game, they have a sense of humor, something that is great in a game such as this . I am biased to rate this game 10/10 as its one of my favorites, however it does have its flaws some should be aware of. In the hearthfire dlc, when you bould a house, the lighting inside doesnt properly work. I have looked for numerous fixes and downloaded mods to fix it, to no avail, it seems completely broken and unrepairable. That , for me, is a huge problem, as i am a visual type of guy, i like the beauty i find in things, and when you build a grand house where the lighting is bleak and dead because of a glitch rendering the torches not to work, well, it really puts a sour taste in my mouth. However, dont take my word as law, some people dont have the glitch, and some do, it seems. Its different per person from what ive read and spent countless hours trying to fix. There are some other glitches around but alot of the skyrim bug fixing mods fix them. This game is still a 10/10 for me, despite its flaws and occasional bug or blemish. Oh yea, argonians and khajitt for life. Preferably Khajitt, its hard to choose, but my biased love for lions and large cats wins me over this round. DAMN YOU BETHESDA.

review: even though this game is seven years old now, Skyrim is still my all-time favorite RPG adventure. What it lacks in default graphics it makes up for in mods and overhauls produced by the gaming community, making your skyrim equal (if not better) to most games on the market today. As far as content goes, if you've finished every quest, explored every cave, and cleared every dungeon, then there are plenty of fantastic quest mods out there and i doubt i'll get bored of skyrim any time soon. be sure to check out the skyrim nexus for the latest and greatest mods to keep your game looking fresh. sorry for the rant.
game-hours: 100.2
review: I seriously overlooked this game when it first came out, believing it was grossly overhyped and thinking it was another paint-by-numbers RPG that had great aesthetic but typical gameplay - I was certainly wrong. It now stands as one of my favourite games, not only because of its sheer amount of content, but also because it's honestly the most fun you can have in an RPG adventure. While it does hold some less than desired glitches (one of which that had me forced to noclip), that's something that I've pretty much accepted as a part of Bethesda's larger than life charm.

review: 11/11 The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is the best game of all time. The scope, scale and freedom of the game is unimaginable. The atmosphere is vibrant with a deep lore and story. A beautiful masterpiece with an amazing soundtrack. I urge you to keep your favorite screenshots and music tracks somewhere safe because in 10 years time when new games have rendered this one obsolete you can go back through those memories again and remember just how special Skyrim was to you. You'll argue with fans of the newer games sharing reasons for why Skyrim was better. They won't understand and how can they. Their memories will be with newer games that have built on Skyrim's strengths further. They won't appreciate how without earlier games the ones that they're playing now wouldn't be possible. You too can become a nostalgic loser who hates new games just because they change things. Got this game for the PS3 and sunk in hundreds of hours. If you got it on console it is totally worth getting it for PC for the massive modding community. If there were one thing I would forget. It would be this game only so I could experience it again. Skyrim is love Skyrim is life.

game-hours: 108.5
review: TES V: Skyrim is an amazing game from start to it's seemingly endless end. I began the Elder Scroll series with Morrowind, which was captavating and well written, it was my favorite xbox game for a long time. Then on the xbox 360 I ended up investing probably around 400 hours into Oblivion. And then Skyrim was released. I got it on its release date and have put probably more than 200 hours into this game (despite my steam says otherwise). After all of my Elder Scrolls gameplay comparisons, I'm making this Skyrim review relative to the other games. The Good: > The graphics are absolutely stunning and mods make them even better. > The voice acting is incredible. It seems that SO many NPCs have their own unique voice, which is impressive for a video game. > Dragons! (Or should I say..... Wyverns!!!) > The thieves guild questline is amazing, probably the best guild questline in Skyrim. > Dual-wielding is a fun mode of combat that is definitely welcomed. > Particle effects and spell effects are numerous and beautiful. > AI has improved considerably. The Neutral: > NPCs you interact with most often (merchants, guards, etc) have too similar sounding voices that can soud a bit monotonous. > Certain aspects of skill training seem to be more of a grind than others with less immediate rewards. (Smithing, Enchanting, Alchemy) > The horses in this game definitely did not come from Cyrodil, these brutes are next to worthless. However, I find that riding via horseback is unnecessary for too many reasons. The Bad: > Texture glitches exist throughout, especially on mountains from my experience, where much of the landscape disappears or fragments. These are small bugs and are few and far in between. > Skill customization. I did prefer Oblivion's skill set up much more. Having primary skills that affect the development of secondary skills was a great system that they shouldn't have given up for Skyrim. > Speed and Agility are no longer traits of a character. That's unfortunate mainly because I like to play the role of a quick thief. > This game won't give back the many hours it takes from you. Bottom line: I'd recommend this game without hesitation to anyone. 10/10 The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is nothing short of amazing and has lived up to the incredibly high standard set by it's predecessors Morrowind and Oblivion.

game-hours: 346.5
review: Skyrim is the fifth game in the Elder Scrolls series of RPGs. It's an open world, western-style role playing game in which you assume a character that you create in a fantasy-type setting. You choose the charcter's race (various types of human, elf, cat-person, lizard-person, etc) and it's starting abilities. From there, you level up the character however you want, whether you want to specialize in stealth and stealing, bows, one-handed or two-handed weapons, or combinations therein. You also level up their health, stamina, and many other statistics, as you wander around the world. There is a main quest to complete, but much of the draw of the ES games is that you can literally go wherever you want, completely ignoring the main quest, and many other paths open up to you. You can even become a vampire or a werewolf if you want, though both have their drawbacks. The game also changes and reacts to your different decisions. So if you want to play through again as a different character, with different abilities, you can do vastly different things and basically it's like a whole new game. This game has a lot of content plus DLC's. Steam workshop and mods bring a lot of different things and lots of replay value! Highly recommended!

I loved the game but couldnt play it, because it made me depressed. Instead i watched my friend playing and i had so much fun. But in Skyrim i dont have to worry about that. Because the atmosphere is too damn cool. Just look at that huge mountain or "wow that city dude" If you still wondering, stop and buy this game. Get your coffee at 8 pm, and start playing. :)

game-hours: 128.8
review: Now that I have 100 hours on my steam version, with probably over 500 on my legendary edition that I bought when it came out (huge elder scrolls fan), I thought it would be a good time to write a review on this fabulous thing Bethesda created. This game, is definately in my top 5 favorite games ever. I find it better than all of the previous games. Elder Scrolls fanboys probably just punched through their monitor with that one, but here's why. It easily surpasses ever game except for Morrowind in terms of story. Sure, when you look at it, not the best story ever. And the voice actors are repeated. But the feel of the game, the choices, everything about this game Bethesda blew out of the park. They aced it. Home run. Vanilla Skyrim is a pure masterpeice. But, add mods to the question. Of course, there will always be those people who have the body mods, there's always someone who does that. But the modding community in this game is like nothing ever seen before. People can edit, and create new things in this game and they do it in a masterful way. I could seriously go on for hours, more hours than I've played Skyrim and Morrowind combined in fact, but I'm not going to make a 200 line review for this game. Main things that you need to know: 1.) This game is absolutely gorgeous, both physically through graphics and design, and through dialouge and the small touches throughout it. 2.) The modding community is revolutionary. 3.) This game is so good that critics everywhere will be comparing any game, doesn't have to be an RPG even, to The Elder Scrolls V. 4.) The lore is ridiculously good. 5.) BUY THE DAMN GAME ALREADY

game-hours: 150.4
review: Although every man, woman, game reviewer and their cat has said this, I might as well jump onto the band wagon and confirm that Skryim is a GREAT game. The side quests usually vary (Although a lot of them are just go to location x and kill a certain number of enemy type Y) and the NPCs actually look like they're talking to you (I.E. They don't stare directly into your eyes for the entirety of the dialogue). The combat is fairly challenging, and the number of spells you can use is sufficient. However, the melee weapons are slightly underwhelming compared to games like Condemned 2. It's usually rather anti-climatic when you're using melee weapons to attack somebody, you hit them and their reaction is equivalent to the reaction of a man getting hit by a piece of paper. However, these are small complaints, and overall the game is very solid and I'd highly recommend it.
game-hours: 456.1
review: Why I bought the game: It's a classic series, a must own for rpg fans. What I liked about the game: The graphics, the atmosphere of Skyrim was desolate and cold, and on the other end warm and blooming with life. The combat was some of the best out for it's time, stamina was used very well. Dragon battles! My absolute favorite and most time consuming feature would have to be the modding community, and it's hard not to spent an equal amount of time in the steam workshop. What I didn't like about the game: No acrobatics?! I was highly disapointed with this, as my favorite class is Khajit. The story, for me this was biased to Nord - even more so than almost any other Elder Scrolls, to me personally it almost makes no sense to do the main story as a Khajit, and especially Argonian, I will not elaborate as I will not spoil the game. Side note: I cannot stand how they came out with a version with all the expansions, however if you purchased the game prior, you cannot purchase the expanded edition to save yourself money on the expansions which are not priced with empathy of this, and promoting customers to want to wait to purchase games. Would I buy at current asking price of 19.99? Yes, despite the stated above issue with pricing the game, especially Legendary Edition, is completely worth it. **Disclaimer** I would like to state all changes made by the developers of the game after this review could potentially make this entire review i 400 hours moding, 20 hours play time, would do again.

game-hours: 129.2
review: It's nearly impossible to write a review for this game after viewing the insane range of reviews for this game. So I am not writing this to stand out. Instead i'll just tell you my history with the game, this will give you some insight into why this can become an "Ecosystem" rather than just a neat game you play for a few hours. Don't worry, I'm not going to write a life story, just the basics. The reason this game is quite so dear to me, is because of it's blank canvus nature. Skyrim is an almost endless experiance when you get it, and leave it unmodded. I still remember my 'awe' when i was released into the open world when the game was released. However once you start the boring and tiresome process of learning how to properly install mods for the game --- and I am not talking the mods you get on steam workshop that give crabs tophats or make dragons sing -- I mean actual immersion mods -- then you will be awestruck by how you can make skyrim into a complex machine of your liking. Changing every little element, and allowing you to explore a familiar world that has been expanded apon in a billion little ways. Once you become confident with moddding, you an truly appreciate the sandbox that skyrim can become. It starts small, with flowers that look better, more butterflies, but eventually you will add mods that will change the core fundamentals of how the game functions. And then you can tweak each thing until it's to your liking. Essentially forging your own ideal game within skyrim. If i am unhappy with how enemies have a scripted death animation, i can install a mod that removes that. If i don't like how they don't react when i hit them with a sword, i can fix that. If i preferred how dark souls works, I can use a overhaul mod and make each encounter last for hours, with greater rewards. Almost anything you can think of, someone else has added to the game. And the scripting extension skse, will keep allowing for more of the game engine to be changed. Allowing things like realtime season changes in the future, as well as new graphics engine features. Visually, you can also install so many things that skyrim looks like something from the future, and you don't even need ENB to do that. You can do that with the vanilla game and still get a smooth framerate. Thats why I said it's an ecosystem. I wish more games had a similar endless horizon. I think that's why a lot of us look forward to fallout 4 so much, we get to do all of that again (hopefully on a dx11 modern engine). And that's exciting.

Learn to clean your files, etc, it's just so much more enjoyable. Probably one of the best looking games I have now. Learn more at the link.

review: Basically you start off a a man named Jimmy who is kidnapped by the russians in WW3. Jimmy has no idea what the hell happened so he begins to pick his fingers until the skin begins to molt into a blackish scar. He is recuited into the Russian army to take down Bin Laden Iskish, who is the number #1 sniper in the world. Why you? Because you are Jimmy Iskish.. His brother. Surpised? Just wait for it. You end up following Iskish down through West Emnet --> over to East Emnet right over the Rohan Mountains. As you line up your shot to blow off Iskish's face, a small hairy foot creature appears in your sights and starts yapping at you. You run like hell. Your body starts to pump battery acid from all the running. You keep running. Soon you end up im mordor where you run into a little fella called Sam Wise, and boy.. Was he wise. After running into him he only said one wise thing... "Please.. Please! Do you have any spare bread?" You nodded slightly and raised your eyebrows as the erotic excitement caught you. It was code! You had to go to the land of the Milk and Cookies. So you went, and boy did you went and went, you walked across the plains of the leper rainbow. You went across the sacred ancient city of New York, you went through Kiran, Firan, Byran Nelson, Gold Courses, Molf Morses, Horse Courses, Pools, tools, and balagools, you went through the lands of Chinese soaps, through Paper St. Through Atticus finches house, through the balconies where Michael Jackson lived, through the whole story of Pulp Fiction, and even through Narnia, then you arrived at the land of Milk and Cookies. There you met two strange people, one wore a Fin on his back and had shark teeth, the other was made of molted lava. They took you across the land of Milk and Cookies and let you arrive in a place called Elysium. From here a huge boring war was happening and you ended up downloading a virus on the main website because it was a funny prank. It saved the world. From there you hiked and walked the earth until you were suddenly shot by an arrow to the knee. It put you in acoma. You wake up with some weird people who talk nonsense about dragons and stormcloaks and imperialism and stuff, and they don't even know who you are. You are taken to be beheaded but end up making it free because of the Dr*gon and this is your story.
