game-hours: 624.1
review: Alright 350 hours later, I'll finally write a "real" recommendation. It's the buggiest game I've ever played, NPC dialogue is recycled and annoying when walking by them, the textures look awful up close, AI is hilariously bad, melee combat is unvaried, etc. And yet despite all the flaws I can't get enough of this game, exploration is just so much fun and the world is fantastic. When you have mods it gets even better because there's thousands of them. The lore is rich and there's hundreds of books and notes to read. There's not as many spells as previous TES games but the spells look great and feel great provided you have a mod to make them scale to your level. The score is amazing despite some repetitive combat music. Models for items and creatures look great, blah blah blah. Technically the game is pretty bad but if you're able to get past that stuff, it's arguably the best open world game ever made. 10/10, game of the decade, would recommend to my cat, thumbs up, best game since duke nukem forever, etc.

game-hours: 135.4
review: Honestly, I'm recommending this game because just about anyone can find something enjoyable for quite some time. Now there are some caveats to this game. 1st. This game absolutely requires mods to run like a true RPG. It actually really needs mods to really shine in general. The graphics and textures get much better looking and everything that can be improved does get improved. This includes the staggering amount of small bugs that the game has. While these mods are easily accessible and there are entire sites dedicated to the installation and use of these mods, I personally believe that any game the needs mods to shine isn't that great of a game. The community IS that great, but the game isn't without its community to drive up the quality through mods. A good example of this would be the console versions of this game, which are clearly no where near as fun as the PC version, not because of some PC master race bias, but because the modding community really helps out. 2nd. This game can require some hardware that a casual gamer may not care to shell out for (myself included) and it really can deter from the experience of the game. It looks absolutely gorgeous on the console versions, and slightly better on the PC but you'd have to pay the very noticable price. If you're a very consistent PC gamer, or have the cash to spend you probably don't have to worry about this bit. 3rd. "Wide as an Ocean, Deep as a Puddle" accurately describes Skyrim. Combat is hack-and-slash, unless your are using the somewhat poor stealth system, which it then moves to a much slower placed hack-and-slash lulled by bouts of intermittent shuffling from cover to cover. Ranged combat takes place with either the bow, or the watered-down magic system which would make Oblivion and Morrowind fans quite sad. The magic creation abilities are gone, and the amount schools have been decreased and their viablility followed suit. You'll find that using magic in the endgame on harder difficulties without mods nigh impossible, but on lower difficulties it's very pheasible. There is no stat system in the game, which I assume was considered a streamlining attempt but ended up making absolutely no sense in-game. Think of it this way: Your legendary swordsman is as fast, strong, intelligent, charming, and lucky as any random peasant or homeless man because their is no stat sytem in-game to differintiate them. Weird, huh? The story is alright, but diehard fans of the series will be sorely dissapointed I believe. That's about all I have, if you read all this I appreciate it, and I hope it truly helps you either buy or turn away from this game, because I believe informed decisions are the best. Hope it helped!

review: There's a learning curve to properly modding Skyrim, but once you get it down, this game is ... IMHO, the greatest PC game of all time. Certainly the best RPG. My advice: use Mod Organizer instead of Nexus MM. Watch Gopher's MO tutorials on Youtube. MO leaves your Skyrim install folder in virgin condition, and makes it easy to switch between mod sets, as well as manage your save games and other features. My must have mod list: * Unofficial Patches (for Skyrim, Dawnguard, Dragonborn, and Hearthfire) * SkyUI * Climates of Tamriel * Static Mesh Improvement Mod * Skyrim HD * Enhanced Lights and Effects (ELFX) * Audio Overhaul for Skyrim 2.0 * Amazing Follower Tweaks * Convenient Horses * Immersive Weapons * Immersive Armor * High Quality World Map (with Roads) * Xenius Character Enhancement * Ultimate HD Fire Effects There are many more great ones, but those are my "core" mods. Skyrim Legendary is a masterpiece and contains endless hours of immersive content. At $13.59, it's one of the greatest values in the history of gaming.

game-hours: 11.2
review: Sweet Rolls for the Dragon Born and friends, from The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, following as close to the in game recipes as possible. Warning, abuse of moon sugar can cause tooth decay. Use at your own risk! Sweet Rolls 1/2 tsp from Salt Pile 1/4 cup from Jug of Milk 2 cups from Sack of Flour 2 sticks (1 cup) of Butter 5 Chickens Eggs 1 1/2 tsp Extract from Vanilla Plant 1 2/3 cups Moon Sugar (aka granulated sugar) (you can add in 1 tsp of baking powder to assist in rising, but if you whip the butter and eggs enough, you wont need it) For the glaze: 4 TB Butter 2 TB from Jug of Milk 2 cups Powdered Moon Sugar (aka confectioners sugar) 1 tsp Extract from Vanilla Plant Sweet roll pan (mini bundt pan) Step 1: Gather Ingredients 1. Gather your ingredients and allow to reach room temperature. Preheat your hearth to 350 degrees F. 2.Cream the butter and sugar together and beat until fluffy (at least five minutes). 3. Slowly add in each chickens egg and beat well. Add the milk or cream. 4. Add the flour, salt and vanilla extract and stir gently until mixed. 5. Pour into greased swell roll pans and bake until golden, about 20 minutes. Allow to cool. Step 2: Glaze and Consume 1. For the glaze, melt the butter and add in the milk. 2. Slowly mix in the powdered sugar and vanilla. Drizzle over cooled sweet rolls. 3. Do not fight any dragons for 30 minutes after consuming more than 5 sweet rolls.

review: Skyrim has got to be one of the best games of all time. The graphics look great, gameplay is solid, voice-acting and music is superb, story is epic, and there are thousands and thousands of things or places to or explore. After the first mission, you are free the roam the entire state of Skyrim, with nine main cities and hundred of small towns and villages, and a vast countryside, as well as countless snowy mountains for you to climb. Basically, Skyrim is an RPG action-adventure game, where you can create your own unique character, and explore the world. You could go the College of Winterhold, to learn new magic spells, and also uncover some interesting secrets. You could go to Dark Water Crossing, and mine ores and sell them. You could go to Riften and join the Thieve's guild and do various missions, or join the Dark Brotherhood and kill the Emperor. Or explore the wilderness and kill several interesting types of animals, including the long-awaited dragons, and sell their pelts or skin for gold, or even use them to craft things. And with the mods on PC, there are unlimited possibilities. Skyrim really is the game that never, ever ends.

review: It's hard not to appreciate a lot of what Skyrim does well. It is a vast game world with a lot of detail. Visually impressive with enough content that demands hundreds of hours of gameplay if you wish to explore it all. As it turns out, I did put in a few hundred hours. The mods, never forget the mods. This is a big part of just about any elder scrolls game and deserves to get some attention. Oblivion had an impressive array of mods and Skyrim boasts the same if not more. What's disappointing however is that I came away from the vanilla game unsatisfied. I completed the majority of the content but just had to drop the game before even getting to the Dragonborn DLC. This is after taking several long breaks between playing it. To put it simply, the game is just downright glitchy. I hate to put that in writing because for a game this size, it's bound to have some problems. Some quests (mostly secondary or side quests) just won't complete. Saving often is a necessity so get used to pressing F5 a lot to quick save. If you're into achievements, there are several that may not unlock and what's disappointing is that some of them have requirements that can take a long time to complete (Oblivion Walker for example - 2 separate play throughs and nothing). But ultimately, after finishing the main quest line, it didn't feel very epic. The voice acting started to get to me when you hear the same 3-4 voices and you really want to start murdering everyone you come across (which to the game's credit, you can do if you so desire). I so badly wanted to love this game. The hype got to me as well as the positive reviews. The first time I took down a dragon, it was rather exhilarating. But for me, it all went downhill from there and plateaued in an above average experience (not epic). The game is plenty difficult for those wanting a challenge and you can adjust the difficultly at will. I for one, love a challenge and kept it maxed out at Legendary. This fact alone is probably what kept me coming back. Until I got to a higher level, nearly every encounter was a challenge and required quick action, use of potions, on occasion different gear and maneuvering. But...the glitches... I'm ballparking it but I'd say at least 40-50 hours of my game time was devoted to reloading saves to get around bugs and game glitchiness. That's roughly 20% of my time playing this game. Last but certainly not least, after my first play through I went ballistic with mods. The vast amount of community content is staggering. If anything, that is the most impressive aspect of Skyrim. I'm of the opinion that this fact alone has helped keep Skyrim near and dear to many gamers. I can see why, the community contributions (free I might add) in many cases, out-do content in the vanilla game. It is not my intention to belittle what Bethesda has accomplished with Skyrim either. I am but a lowly gamer (years late to the Skyrim party) that just took issue with a few aspects of the experience. An experience that was overall positive with a few reservations. So despite my misgivings...I still need to give it my recommendation. If you want an open world, detailed, vast and moddable game, Skyrim checks all of those boxes. As it stands right now, there really isn't a game like it.

game-hours: 251.4
review: This is one of my favorites, but still not as good as Morrowind (IMO only). If you liked any of the prior Elder Scrolls games, then grab this and make sure to take a close look at the mods, as they can add tons of fun things to the game. If you are new to RPGs or slightly interested, then still get it - if you aren't an RPGer, but like action/adventure, then yes, still get it :) - you can lose yourself for hours in the gameworld. Now that there are pretty much literally TONS of mods for this, there isn't any reason you shouldn't own this. There are mods that remove all of the hand-holding Bethesda built into the game, such as fast travel, quest markers, etc. Mods that add realistic hunger and thirst, as well as exposure to the elements. Mods that fix bugs in the base game and DLC. Basically there is a mod for practically anything you can think of. So if you were one of those people on the fence, time to make the leap and buy it. Oh - if you have problems with the in-game physics or graphical issues of any sort - get the FPS Limiter patch (trust me on this one).
game-hours: 77.0
review: If one day I was faced with the choice of only being able to play one game for the rest of my life this would be it. Even the vanilla version and all the following DLC is so expansive one could play on forever. Even if you complete the main storyline, that is if you are not side-tracked by all the lovely side quests, you can always play it again with a completely different character and mindset. Wreak havoc with big hammers, sneak what your mama gave you, crave the pink mist as a bow sniper, or just Harry Potter some fools with your awesome magic. However in all seriousness Skyrim although not as intricate as it's predcessor Obilivion it creates an ambience like no other game can acheive so far. It has powerful rendering capabilites, a great environment, great sounds, great effects, and most importantly satisfying gameplay. I highly reccomend this title and all of it's DLC. While your at it also make sure to check out the Skyrim Nexus for extra content that adds litterally decades worth of value to an already worthwhile game.

game-hours: 2691.2
review: So much to do, so many different paths you can take. There is a reason I love Bethesda games and Skyrim embodies all of them. To start, I love the movement and combat system. It is realistic enough, but leaves the wiggle room I enjoy to take advantage of certain mechanics. I love RPGs, but get frustrated with a lot of the ones that force you along a linear path. Within the first couple hours you can open up most anywhere on the map if you choose, and you really can individualize your fighting style without too many major issues. Sure, like most games, there are certain styles that can be more impactful, but in the end there isn't really one style that is head and shoulders above the rest to the point that it makes no sense to do anything else. It is easy to put countless hours into just exploring and hoarding, but it can be beaten fairly quickly if you choose to be direct. Admittedly, I haven't seen much of the DLC (shocking with the amount of time I have on the game), but that is coming soon on my to-do list.

review: Skyrim can be summed up in one word. Brilliant. The gameplay is brilliant, and the world is immersive. The combat is balanced (most of the time) and the world is rich with lore. Skyrims world is beautiful yet harsh, and it has masses of content. Add on the ability to mod it to oblivion (no pun intended) and you have a great game. all together I give it a 9/10 because of the sheer beauty and immersion this game provides. It would be given a 10 if not for some relatively major bugs.

game-hours: 141.6
review: One of the best action RPG games so far, as Bethesda has once again managed to expand The Elder Scrolls saga - this time with norse-themed adventure named after the frozen, snowy tundrous province Skyrim. Altrough not so original like it's predecessors - Oblivion or Morrowind - the newest addition to this wonderful series is heavily influenced by nordic and scandinavian folklore. While Morrowind was the most original place I've ever visited in game, and Oblivion managed to bring the feeling of Imperial Rome - Skyrim takes a different - albeit very common and not-so-original path - dragons, huscarls, fjords, hargravens and it's own version of Valhalla - Sovngarde. Pack your winter clothing - don't forget to bring your axes and horned helmets, and... be prepared for excellence - but not perfection, as Skyrim tries to grasp the throne of RPG genre - but it still cannot best it's older, more mature (and in my opinion flawless) siblings - Morrowind and Oblivion.

game-hours: 116.6
review: Definitely not the best TES game. Not by a longshot. Still, it's decent. I could sit here and write a scathing review of what I think Bethesda did wrong, but nobody really cares about that. If you're new to The Elder Scrolls or RPGs in general, you're probably going to enjoy this game. It's a big, open world with lots of things to do that really won't punish you for your actions. Sure, some of the choices you make are going to have an impact on the game world and all that, but nothing overly major. The leveling system is revamped and actually makes sense in a lot of ways, even if the developers didn't use it to its full potential. The combat is enjoyable and your enemies are always around the same level as your character, so things shouldn't get to difficult for you. If you're an older fan of the series, you're definitely going to need to get a few mods to get this game in a playable state. Or a lot of mods. Probably a lot. I heartily recommend Requiem to start off with. You're pretty much going to find a way to enjoy this game one way or another. There's a ton of mods out there for it, so you can potentially turn Skyrim into whatever you want it to be (or what it should've been... unfortunately there's not much that can be done for Bethesda's uncharacteristically ****** quest writing) if you know what you're doing and you take your time. And by "take your time," I mean don't be an idiot and go and find a bunch of mods and install them without reading the description/Readme (they are called that for a reason, you know). So um, yeah, after all of that rambling, I recommend this game.

game-hours: 142.5
review: Let's get right to it. As far as playability goes (ease, expansiveness, etc), I would give it a 9 out of 10. I only take off a point because the game can be a bit glitchy at times. But this is to be expected from any game with an open world enviornment. visuals are a 10 out of 10. The developers put so much time and effort into this game and it really shows. I play on Ultra High and the graphics are amazing to look at from atop a mountain in the game. Yes, not everyone can play with the graphics way up, but it is visually stunning all the same. Re-play value is off the charts. 12 out of 10. I have had this game for x box, and pc alike, putting over 400 hours combined into this game and I never get tired of it. Truly one of the greats when it comes to replay value. DLC- 8 out of 10. They really tried, and it still has the skyrim/ dragonborn feel to it, but it simply isnt quite as good as it could have been. They are definitely good for a one time play through for all the loot and new quests, but some of the quests feel cumbersome and it makes rare gems much to common. loot is basically given away in the dlcs. Overall rating 9.5 out 0f 10. No one should pass up playing this game and lately it has been on sale a lot for very cheap. I highly recommend this.
game-hours: 63.7
review: Best form of abstience out there since 2004, with WOW, In all seriousness, this possibly may be the best open world RPG of all time. It's a tough stander with some other games but this one blew me away back in 2011. Had to buy again. DLC: it's worth it, gives you at least another 40+ hours of playtime if you want to kill time, plus a super hard boss. Story: One of the best, Starting in a little village called Helgen, you are a prisoner, you almost get beheaded, a dragon attacks. Then you have to escape with a few guys to Riverwood and go to Whiterun to find out that you the player's character, is the Dragonborn. Gameplay: Top notch RPG, but not the kind of RPG you expect, like kill stuff and level, thats still there. But you level with crafting, sewing, etc. Difficulty: Suited to all, from Novice as in a new person playing to Legendary where we have a Major League Gaming tryout. Play Time: Didn't play it much again on PC, but I played it a TON on the PS3 when i got it on there. Probably at least 4000 hours+ on PC. Mods: Go ahead and mod everything possible. Theres unlimited possiblities in the Steam Workshop. 10/10 the best of the decade so far. Lets see if there is a game that can top this one.

game-hours: 142.7
review: I used to own Skyrim for the PS3 a while back and played it for 8 months straight doing every side and main quest there is to do. I feared that once I finally ran out of things to do I would never look upon Skyrim again. How wrong I was. It seemed I have been living in the shadow of the PC version of Skyrim all this time. Here I am again a few years later having already clocked over a 100 hours on the game. I picked up the Legendary Edition on one of the Steam sales and fell in love with Skyrim all over again. Why do you ask? I would simply say this: MODS! I WANT ALL THE MODS!! Modding Skyrim is like opening a can of Pringles. Once you pop you can't stop. No seriously, it becomes an addiction if you're not careful. I am just so impressed by the way you can mod this already considered dated game, into a beautiful new environment where you can relive the games greatest moments with in-game graphics that look like they belong in a game released today. (Either that or go completely silly, and make the game as weird as possible) Dislikes? I do not have any when it comes to Skyrim. This is surely a game for the RPG enthusiast, who also loves to hack-slash away at things too. Everyones experience playing Skyrim is different. I found the best way to play the game is to not just stick to the main quest and just go and explore the beautiful scenery and surprises it holds :)

review: No Elder Scrolls game is about story. Skyrim captures what the entire mission of The Elder Scrolls series is about: Adventure. When you're walking on the road and bandits attack you, when you stumble upon a cave loaded with enemies and treasure, when you stay up through the late hours of the night because you don't want to go back to the real world, you know you're playing Skyrim. The story driven quests are there to give you a general direction. The random encounters are there to make sure you take the longest route possible while going in that general direction.

game-hours: 82.2
review: Is there anyone on the internet who doesn't know at least something about Skyrim? Now, the main gripe people have is that Skyrim needs serious mod work to be enjoyable. I've done bugger all (aside from running around with anduril for a while...) and I've got like 70 odd hours so far. No, I didn't even mod the UI. Is the UI bad? It annoys me at times! Is the combat bad? It's a bit shallow, too hack n slash. Do either of these things or any other complaints I might have stop me from playing it? No, not at all. Skyrim is an RPG in the most basic sense - you create a character and you go play with them. Most of the fun I have from Skyrim isn't from the gameplay itself, but the emergent gameplay - the thought of my unlikely adventurer hacking off a troll's face, thinking "well that was close" and then the look on his face when another two come storming around the corner. Or cutting someone free only for them to try to run away at which point I run them down and hack their legs out with a greatsword. Or sneaking through a bandit-infested cave dispatching all the guards with a single arrow to the head like some weird crouching version of Legolas. Skyrim is about the stories you create, and there's enough in the world to give you a bit of a head start.
game-hours: 11.3

review: Don't harm the chicken gods... ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ This game was one of the first games I ever played. I was in love with the freedom to make my character how I wanted. It was beautifully thought out, and the quests are, for the most part, very fun. I think Skyrim is just one of those must-have games. You can waste hundreds of hours hunting down dragons, killing bandits, and stealing books for your bookshelf. Pros: Huge amount of quests and story branches, allowing virtually endless gameplay Mods that improve the game greatly, fixing anything from striping to buggy blacksmiths DLCs that add even more content to the game Easy to understand levelling and gameplay Cons: The beginning is horrible to sit through, and is altogether sloppy In order to have the highest quality game experience, you MUST install mods Some bugs that have been there for years Sometimes hard to follow questlines Is the game perfect? No. But honestly, Is any?

review: I think it is safe to say that this is the best game in TES series, and the best classic RPG game in the world, even today. The sheer detail and thoroughteness of the world is astonishing, there are so many things to do and things to be, and you can be absolutely anything you want to, ranging from a loyal Imperial soldier fighting for the unification of Tamriel to an assasin plotting to kill the emperor. I have bought this game when it cost 30 euros and it was worth it. Now it costs 15 euros, and it's still much better than a lot of RPG games costing much more. And the earlier mentioned features are just vanilla, if you aren't lazy to mod a bit, you can download endless stream of content. If you like RPG games, then I dare say that Skyrim is the best one on the market, even today.

game-hours: 300.5
review: I reviewed Skyrim about a year ago and looking back on it, I think it's time I wrote a new one. Bethesda did such an amazing job on making Skyrim immersive that you will spend hours arranging book on a shelf and eating a meal in an inn whilst talking to an npc and you won't even give it a second thought. The scale of the world is immense, and that's only on the surface. There are also huge catacombs, ruins and caverns to explore and with the dlcs (which I highly recommend) it adds a whole new island, more castles, a whole dimension of lost souls and a huge area you access just by reading a book. This might all seem strange but you never stop to question it as the whole world has it's own lore, gods, races and history that continues throughout. The sound track is absolutely beautiful and the voice acting is amazing considering it is on such a colossal scale. Although the combat isn't as polished as some other games it still has a large diversity (melee, ranged, magic etc.) and Skyrim's concept of skill trees are fantastic. The skill trees allow you to specialise in some things over time and also master multiple things if you desire. The skills will add more and more layers to combat, exploration and tactics when it comes to surviving. The quests are brilliant as well whether it is the main quests or just the small side quests that you get from npcs you find wandering through the 9 holds which add even more life into the game. You really can make whatever character you want even if it's a cat-man (khajit) who turns into a huge wolf and terrorises villages whenever the two moons come out or a patriotic nord who will protect her homeland with her life and drive out the empire all by herself. Overall this game still holds up being, in my opinion, the BEST RPG ever created even after almost 4 years after it's release. An easy 10/10.

And in the center of all these great values stands, the player. This is quite possibly the most customizable and beautiful game I have played and for now nothing stands between it. PS: Thank you Mel.

game-hours: 129.1
review: This game....is a masterpiece..... I'm the kind of gamer who likes to jump around games a lot, meaning after a few months I completely drop a game and stop playing it...(Bought Deus Ex during the holiday sale...still haven't touched it). However, Skyrim is a game I just can't drop....I bought this game for my xbox when it came out before I switched to PC...I have 200 hours on it, and I have a good amount of time on pc. The scope of this game is huge. The number of quests to do is astounding and the world is created so masterfully you have to wrap your head around the fact that this was a game made 3 years ago. Do you want to save the world from the return of the dragons? Do you want to join the stormcloaks and drive out the empire? Do you want to buy a house, get married, and adopt children? Yep, whatever you want...Sometimes the best moments aren't even related to quests. Personally, I love hunting in the Whiterun plans to get venison and deer hide to sell, and I will admit, as lame as it sounds, I got hooked to improving my house in hearthfire. Another thing I absolutely have to mention is the character creation. You can be whatever you want. Do you want to be a tank? A mage? A bowman? A thief? You can even mix and match things. For example, I use my magic spells to temporarily increase my sneak, and Currently I play as a mage who carrys a bow for game hunting and further distance sniping. This game isn't perfect. Glitches in all of Bethesda games are annoying as crap. From floating trees to uncomplete quests, they are everywhere. Also, combat can feel floaty at times,like you just swinging your sword and hoping it hits. I highly reccommend downloading a few combat mods. Speaking of mods, THEY ARE AMAZING. I mean, have you checked out graphic overhauls on youtube! Mods range from bug fixes to combat/graphical overhauls to full out new quests and lands! For example, skywind is a mod in progress which aims to bring the land of morrowind into the skyrim game...Amazing isnt it? Two great examples of great simple mods are realistic needs and frostfall. realistic needs creates the need for basic needs such as food water, sleep, and frostfall makes it so you have to keep warm. Lore is also something to be noted. ES lore has always been some of the best in gaming. their are thousands of books in skyrim. I highly reccommend reading them if you want to learn more Although the combat isnt great and glitches can be annoying, I highly reccomend the game. The scope of the game in every aspect is what sets this apart from all the other open world RPGs. a solid 10/10

review: Anyone who is a fan of videogaming will love The Elder Scrolls V Skyrim. It seamlessly blends adventureous spirit with loot collecting in all the beautiful environments and well designed quests. Character development and customization is virtually unrivaled here, and it is easily the best Open World RPG on the market as of 2015, four years after the game's release in 2011. Indeed, Skyrim's playability has stood strong throughout the test of time, partly due to the endless content in the base game and expansion packs. And for the love of all that is good don't forget the Steam workshop. There are enough mods there to keep anyone's game fresh for several lifetimes. This game has yet to get old for me, and I promise you this is well worth your money. This game has honestly changed the way I judge all video games. It has set the bar to a point so high I doubt it will ever be surpassed, but until that day, I'll be at home... PLAYING SKYRIM!

game-hours: 247.4
review: An epic game made all the more epic by the fact that it is so easy to mod and so well supported by the modding community. The Elder Scrolls series has a large following and often you will hear people argue over each new TES game comparing it to the last, but for me each TES game stands on its own merits, and Skyrim is no exception. The story is pretty good and there are plenty of side quests, but what makes Skyrim so great even when not modded is its large and open nature. This is a land you can just pick a direction and with no quest in mind and just explore. You will find danger and excitement on your journey ... and loot. Lots and lots of loot. But once you start modding this game, that is when you unlock the true value that is Skyrim. Potentially thousands more hours content (for free) in a game that can be improved ten thousand different ways from graphics, textures and sounds all the way to game mechanics and user interface changes. You can make the game exactly what you need it to be, and play it for so long you may still be playing when the next game in this series comes out.... and sometimes longer than even that. If you are interested in modding the PC version of the game, be sure to check out my guide for beginners:

game-hours: 92.5
review: I was stacking books on a shelf in my house in Whiterun, one of Skyrim's major cities, when I noticed a weapon rack right beside it. I set a sacrificial dagger in one slot, an Orcish mace in the other. They were on display for nobody but me and my computer-controlled housecarl, Lydia, who sat at a table patiently waiting for me to ask her to go questing. The chest upstairs was reserved for excess weapons and armor, the bedside table for smithing ingots and ores, the one next to the Alchemy table for ingredients. I'd meticulously organized my owned virtual property not because I had to, but because tending to the minutia of domestic life is a comforting break from dealing with screaming frost trolls, dragons, a civil war, and job assignments that never seem to go as planned. It's even a sensible thing to do; a seemingly natural component of every day existence in Skyrim, one of the most fully-realized, easily enjoyable, and utterly engrossing role-playing games ever made. Part of what makes it so enjoyable has to do with how legacy Elder Scrolls clutter has been condensed and in some cases eliminated. In Skyrim, there's no more moon-hopping between hilltops with a maxed out Acrobatics skill. That's gone, so is Athletics. The Elder Scrolls V pares down the amount of skills and cuts out attributes like Endurance and Intelligence altogether. There's no time wasted on the character creation screen agonizing over which skills to assign as major. You don't assign major and minor skills at all, but instead pick one of ten races, each with a specific bonus. High Elves can once a day regenerate magicka quickly, Orcs can enter a berserk rage for more effective close-range combat. These abilities are best paired with certain character builds  the High Elf regeneration is useful for a magic user  but don't represent a rigid class choice. Major decisions don't need to be made until you're already out in the world and can try out magic, sneaking and weapon combat, emphasizing first-hand experience over instruction manual study, letting you specialize only when you're ready. It contributes to the thrilling sense of freedom associated with life in Skyrim. Do a quest, kill a dragon, snatch torchbugs from the air, munch on butterfly wings or simply wander while listening to one of the best game soundtracks in recent memory. Despite the enormity of the world and the colossal amount of content contained within, little feels random and useless. Even chewing on a butterfly wing has purpose, as it reveals one of several alchemical parameters later useful in potion making at an alchemy table. Mined ore and scraps of metal from Dwemer ruins can be smelted into ingots and fashioned into armor sets, pelts lifted from slain wildlife can be turned into leather armor sets, and random books plucked from ancient ruins can trigger hidden quest lines that lead to valuable rewards. Skyrim's land mass is absolutely stuffed with content and curiosities, making every step you take, even if it's through what seems like total wilderness, an exciting one, as something unexpected often lies just over the next ridge. Many times the unexpected takes the form of a dragon. Sometimes they're purposefully placed to guard relics, sometimes they swoop over cities and attack at seemingly random times. In the middle of a fight against a camp of bandits a dragon might strike, screaming through the sky and searing foe and friendly alike with frost or flame. Momentarily all on the battlefield unite, directing arrows and magic blasts upward to knock down the creature, creating impromptu moments of camaraderie -- a surprising change from what may have been yet another by-the-numbers bandit camp sweep. Dragons show up often, their presence announced by an ominous flap of broad wings or an otherworldly scream from high above. The scale and startling detail built into each creature's appearance and animations as it circles, stops to attack, circles again and slams to the ground makes encounters thrilling, though their predictable attack patterns lessen the excitement after a few battles. In the long run they're far less irritating than the Oblivion gate equivalent from The Elder Scrolls IV, can be completed in a few minutes, and always offer a useful reward. Killing a dragon yields a soul, which powers Skyrim's new Shout system. These are magical abilities any character can use, you don't have to specialize in spell casting to slow time, throw your voice, change the weather, call in allies, blast out ice and fire, or knock back enemies with a rolling wave of pure force. Even if you favor sword, shield and heavy armor and ignore magic entirely, you'll still be able to take full advantage of these abilities provided you find the proper words  each Shout has three  hidden on Skyrim's high snowy peaks and in the depths of forgotten dungeons, serving as another reason to continue exploring long after you've exhausted the main quest story, joined with the Thieves Guild, fought alongside the Dark Brotherhood, or thrown your support behind one of the factions vying for control of Skyrim. Not only is this land under assault by dragons, long thought to be dead, it's also ripped in two by civil war. You can choose one side or the other, but so much of the allure of Skyrim is how, even outside of the confines of quest lines, the embattled state of the world is evident, and steeped in a rich fictional legacy. Lord of the Rings this is not, but with the release of every Elder Scrolls game, the fiction becomes denser, and the cross-referencing for long-time fans all the more rewarding. Skyrim's residents are all aware of current events. They'll comment on the civil war, some sympathizing with the rebels, others thinking the establishment sold its soul. The peasants complain about the Jarls who control each settlement, the Jarls complain about the rebels or foreign policy, the overprotective College librarian complains when I drop dragon scales all over his floor; many characters feel like whole, distinct personalities instead of vacuous nothings that hand out quests like a downtown greeter hands out flyers for discount jeans. Characters stereotype based on race, they double-cross at even the slightest hint it might be profitable, and they react to your evolving stature within the world. It makes a ridiculous realm, filled with computer-controlled cat people and humanoid reptiles, demon gods and dragons, feel authentic, like a world that existed long before you showed up and will continue to exist long after you leave.

review: Skyrim is a well executed epic open world RPG with stunning graphics and great story. I would highly recommend this game as you can get tons of play time out of it. The only issues I had with the game were as follows. 1) Like some of Bethesda's other games, this one can; and I say "can" not will, have crashing issues with save files being corrupted. 2) The combat system while being robust, isn't as robust as it was in previous Elder Scrolls titles. However, you shouldn't let these two things deter you, the crashes don't happen to everyone, and the combat system is still great. Plus, if you include all the DLC and the workshop mods, this game has nearly limitless content. Well worth anyones time.

game-hours: 988.9
review: The Elder Scrolls has never been more playableI can say that, at least, about Skyrim. Gone are the gameplay headaches, like the dice-rolls from Morrowind or the glitchiness of Oblivion. Visually, though perhaps not artistically, Skyrim is the most splendorous of the past three Elder Scrolls games. The different races and the landscape have never looked so good. Skyrim is always a steady gameplay experience; yet it still, in my eyes, is somehow less-expansive than Oblivion, and somehow less-detailed than Morrowind. It has the least flavor of the three games, perhaps because it is the most streamlined, the most pandering. The races are almost functionally identical. The actual differences between them (abilities, starting skill levels) are small in the first place and quickly grow completely irrelevant, effectively eradicating any real need to play the game as more than one race. It's fun to role-play different races, but the designers could still help out a little more. For example, yes, it should be possible for a High Elf to become a heavy fighterbut it should be much, much harder to doand much more fun and interesting than it presently is. The game is goodjust not as good as it should be. It's too one-size-fits-all.

game-hours: 30.9
review: All right. As probably no one person that will read this review knows, i did NOT have internet for 8 months. This game was the only thing that i had installed aside from terraria. I played it because i was bored to beond belief after 3 months. i had tried playing it when i first got it, and i lagged more than i ever knew possible, so i shut it down. When I tried it again, i just sat back and tried to endure the lag. IT PAID OFF. I had no idea this was made by the same people of fallout one of my favorite games of all time. And once i started playing it was well worth it. I will review this game the way i want to. If anyone disagrees, they get a BOOT TO THE HEAD. Gameplay Skyrim had very basic battle mechanics most people will understand if they read the directions given to them, but the real thing that stopped me was the lag. this game will lag beond belief if you dont have a good computer. All factors considered gameplay is 8/10 Graphics This game is aboely BEUTIFUL. if you run it at maximum quality the framerate takes a blow under the belt, but if you can handle the game running at high it is a work of genius. 9.5/10 Story Honestly the MAIN storyline was nothing to gawk at. typical middle earth storyline, hero arises saves the day. But i have to give credit where it is due. the secondary storylines are where it is at. the dark brotherhood and theives guild is where the story was great. 7.5/10 Replay value This game has the highest replay vaule ive ever seen. Pretty much you can play this game 500 times and still find stuff you missed on the way. with that said this game gets a 11/10 for replay vaule. Music Skyrim has the best soundtrack i have ever heard. the music was well balanced and placed where it was needed. 10/10 Modding Skyrim has the biggest modding fanbase in the world. anything you could want in skyrim, there is a mod for it. and then there is the offical DLC's as well. 10/10 for modding. After taking all elements in, i give skyrim a 9.5/10. and it is an absolute MUST BUY.

review: Skyrim is a good RPG, but not a great one. I have been an avid fan of the Elder Scrolls series since Morrowind back when I was a wee lad playing that lovely dirt-colored game on my brother's original Xbox back in 2003-2005. Anyways, I was expecting this game to be a more refined version of Oblivion, which has a special place in this Cuban's heart, but Skyrim was different. It felt targeted for a broader audience, not one the typical Bethsesda RPG fan like me and many others. Forgive the word, but Skyrim is the epitome of a casual RPG. If my brother, the same brother who bought Morrowind for me and my other brother back in 2003 but hated it, can sink hours into this game like it was Call of Duty, then it definitely is a casual RPG. Does that make it bad? God no! Skyrim is an extremely pretty game that I would love to indulge myself in if I had more time to. I just feel like if anyone can pick, swing a sword, and kill  in an RPG, it is casual. Try doing that in Oblivion against some tougher creatures and your  will become mudcrab food along the shores of that bloom covered and colorful land.

review: The last time I played Skyrim was back in 2011 on the Xbox 360 and although I enjoyed it I never touched it since, I was told that it was still very popular on PC which I found a little hard to believe considering how quickly titles age on console. I was wrong. For a three year old game that I played a fair bit of in the beginning, wow, the modding community have made this game their own. With some graphical and gameplay enhancment mods as well as the mod that universally improves the game and removes a lot of bugs Skyrim looks amazing on PC! I get lost in the games sheer beauty, the amount of work that has gone into the Skyrim mods is astounding and it shows! For me it has brought back my desire to play Skyrim again, to see the game in sublime graphics and the enhanced performance granted by PC and the mods makes so much difference. I got Skyrim and all of the DLC on sale for about 5, which is exceptional value, but it is the mods that make this game so good and by far superior on PC. One word of advice, be careful what mods you download and do your research first. The highest rated mods on the workshop and nexus are pretty much a given, you will download them because everyone else does, it's when you get a few pages in. My Skyrim would often through me back to the desktop which was annoying, but after a bit of mod housekeeping I managed to make this happen less, maybe once a session rather than several times. If you have a PC, which I assume that you do as you're reading this, and you don't have Skyrim already please buy it now. Just go, buy it... BUY IT NOW!!!!!!!!

game-hours: 295.4
review: Skyrim is my favourite game of all time, I have so many hours of gameplay across both xbox and pc but I am STILL not anywhere near bored. I have played more hours on the xbox verison so far since I got that a year before the pc verision but I definitely recommend the PC version over xbox because it is so much more beautiful and you can add some truly genius mods! I think you need a pretty good pc in order to run this game, otherwise your laggy experience may cloud your judgement of the game. Using mods also significantly decrease FPS too so be warned. I love this game because I'm pretty sure it's almost impossible to actually do EVERYTHING in the game, theres just so much to do! And the beauty of that is, you barely even have to do any of the quests if you don't want..you could just spend your entire time raiding caves and dungeons and exploring the beauty of Skyrim's wilds. I currently have 100+ mods installed and although that may seem like an insult to the game..I actually think it is a huge praise since it is so well adapted to mods. Ok, some people can go silly with mods..sure, have everyone running around naked if you want to..but I recommend trying to build yourself a more immersive experience once you feel quite comfortable with the vanilla game. Want more of a challenge? Don't increase your difficulty, install mods such as Frostfall, iNeed and Warzones! Mods can be found at the Skyrim Nexus (generally bigger mods) and the Steam Community (generally smalled add-ins). Of course, there is nothing wrong with not touching mods at all..like i said..I have many hours of gameplay on my xbox version of Skyrim. Skyrim is so entertaining and addictive because it has rich, interesting lore, endless varied quests, and stunning sights! I rate this game 10/10 and I think it can be anyones' type of game...you can play however you like! You could be a swordsman, archer, mage, hunter, explorer, hero, assassin, theif...you can even be all of them if you put the time and effort in! I'm really excited for Elder Scrolls 6 but don't wait around for that..it will be at least another 3 years! This game is not at all outdated so add this game to your basket right now! I hope my review was helpful and I hope you agree with me!

review: With as many hours as I have on record any words in saying this game is good is meaningless, but here it is. It's a great game. game-hours: 293.8
review: In a lot of ways, it is a typical open-world game: there are missions you can go on, if you chose to accept them; there are no level restrictions to certain areas; you are free to level up your character as desired with no pre-set formats. In other ways, the game can be a bit tedious: the combat is not that complex; archery is a bit over powered; and the skills system is mundane to level up (you either gain skill points by using the skill or purchase them from trainers). But that said, I love this game, a fact evidenced by the almost 300 hours I've spent playing this game. The level of detail to the environment and atmosphere is tremendous. The ability to mod the game, and the mods that have come out, its what truly give this game its beauty. If you are the kind of person that loves expansive, immersive environments, you must have this game. If you are a game-lore nerd, you must buy this game.

review: IF YOU HAVEN'T PLAYED THIS GAME, PLAY IT. ----- IF YOU HAVE PLAYED THIS GAME, PLAY IT AGAIN. After 400 plus hours playing Skyrim and all of its DLCs on the peasant console race, I thought I had done it all. I was Archmage, Guildmaster, Listener, Harbringer, Civil War hero, Vampire Slayer, and the best Dragonborn ever (sorry Miraak). I built houses, slayed dragons, murdered who I could, and generally brought total chaos to Skyrim. I truly believed the game had no more to offer me. Soon I discovered PC, Steam, and modders. Steam Summer Sale did its job and made me buy Skyrim. Seriously, ten bucks? Who would pass a deal like that up? I still had my doubts though. I already owned the game on console, so why should I buy it again just to play it on PC? I'll tell you why: Mods. ing mods (excuse my language). Not just mods about ing, though. I ensure you that if you search hard enough, you will find a mod for just about anything. Whether it'd be a mod that makes everyone nude underneath their clothes, a mod that turns dragons into trains, a mod that adds realism through thirst and hunger, a mod that adds DLC sized content, or a ing mod. Yes, you'll find those. The possibilities of modding are endless with Skyrim. You can make it as realistic as possible or create the fantasy RPG you've always wanted. The choice is your's with mods. No vanilla options holding you back. No console peasant race pulling you down. So go my children. Purchase this game. Mod the hell out of it. And spend possibly +400 hours of your life slaying dragons, testing out new mods, and Fus-Ro-Dah-ing all over your keyboard.

game-hours: 245.6
review: Man, oh man. Where can I begin with this game? It's epic in proportion, production, immersion, emotion, frustration, elation, ...and other various 'tions that may or may not apply to you specifically. The story itself is really good, though now that I've played through the game at least a dozen times. It's kind of lost its luster to me, but that doesn't mean it's bad, just that now that I know what to expect, I have to really immerse myself in something different in order to not completely abandon the main quest chain. That doesn't subtract from the replay value at all, however, for a couple of reasons. First, like many open world games, Skyrim is the kind of game you can lose hours in just wandering about and never really doing anything. I devoted an entire playthrough (if you want to call it that) to leveling a hunter/gatherer type character, just roaming the countryside hunting animals and selling their meat and pelts. I'd stumble across landmarks and geographic features I had no idea existed, run into NPCs I had never met, and see the world through the eyes of a character who, for once, wasn't destined to save it. The second thing that gives this game seemingly endless replay value is the modding community. There are mods that improve, add, change, and overhaul just about any aspect of the game you can imagine. From epic DLC-sized quest mods like Falskaar and Wyrmstooth, to little details like better footprints in the snow. There are mods that completely overhaul the perk system, and total conversion mods like the Game of Thrones Adaptation mod. The possibilities are nigh endless and the end result is often very very enjoyable. At the time of writing this review, Steam says 207 hours played. That doesn't count the non-steam version of the game I played for at least as long, if not longer. I find myself coming back over and over again, and each time I do, I discover something new to do. If you haven't yet, do yourself a favor and play this game.
game-hours: 410.4
review: Wonderful, wonderful game. Everything it was hyped up to be. With the ability to mod this game (on PC), this game really has so many possiblities and extras that will have you playing over and over again. There really aren't many games that have the type of re-playability that Skyrim has (even if it's not modded), and that's what makes this game incredible. It's arguably one of the top games of all time.

review: I used to hate RPG, fantasy and middle age themed games. Then I met Skyrim. If you are the GTA, Battlefield, The Sims or Mario kind of gamer and think Skyrim is not for you, think again and try. I never believed I would like to play this genre of game.
game-hours: 106.6
review: After a very long and over due time I finally got Skyrim. I must start off by saying this game is astonishing, and it is anything an elder scrolls fan boy could ever want.. Or is it? Well you see I am 15 hours into the game now and right off the bat I fell in love with amazing look of the game. Also the magic in the game is something far more superior looking compared to what we have seen in previous games *Which is no surprise*. The game has such a great setting in my opinion I also like how often the climate changes it really follows the lore. Right off the bat I knew I wanted to play what I played in the previous games a Witch Hunter. I just love the thought and endless role playing possibilitys there are behind it. In Skyrim I knew it would be different to play but I didnt realize how different. Playing a Witch Hunter in Skyrim has brought a whole new meaning to it for me there is just so much more you can do! The start was well just as the others were your a prisoner *No Surprise* But the game throws you right into the action as you are running from a dragon. After a few minutes of running you have to make your first big choice in the game, side with the Imperial or Storm Cloaks. I chose Storm Cloaks due to it being something new. Then you have to go through a short part where you run around killing things and getting a feel for the game. After its all said and done you exit through the cave and are thrown into the wonderful world of Skyrim. You travel down a path and choose your first stone, which i though was very cool in the sense that you are not locked down to one character type you can mix match and are not stuck with Able to turn Invisible or Plus 20 to -insert skill- the whole game. Also the talent trees and the fact there is more then one way to branch off from one talent were a very great idea so thanks Bethesda! They in my mind open up so many possibilitys. Blacksmithing also adds so much to the game. I have always wanted the ability to make my own armor in elder scrolls games. Combat in the game was an improvement. One of my favorite parts of it was the killing cut scenes you get from time to time that show you in slow motion getting a head shot or showing you swing an axe over youre head and straight down onto an opponent. The dual casting system is fantastic and adds so much more you can do with magic. The ability to dual wield weapons also seems as if it would make playing a thief or fast melee type character much more enjoyable. The alteration in this game was also a huge improvement over its predecessor. At first I just started to go through the main quest line and found myself getting a bit bored of it and feeling as if i was missing so much more of the game. So i decided to start doing side quest. I did a few side quest then stumbled upon a few people killing a vampire the Dawnguard I spoke with them then got a quest update so I followed what it said knowing that this would greatly increase my RP experience. All in all Skyrim is a fantastic game with so many things to do and places to see.

review: Very very amazing Open World - RPG - Adventure game, so much to explore! > 9 holds of Skyrim. From Solitude in the northwest: stronghold of the imperial; to Riften in the southeast: home of the thieves guild. > Lots of side quests outside of the main quest: faction quests, radiant quests, contracts, etc. > Be part of the Dark Brotherhood, The Companions, Thieves Guild, and College of Winterhold. > You may choose to join the Imperial Legion or Stormcloaks. > Improve your skills: Combat, Magic, Stealth, or all of them. > Smith and enchant weapons and armors, brew potions and poisons. > Explore mountains and dungeons, collect the daedric artifacts, learn the shouts, fight the dragons. > Be a Thane for each hold, have some followers, buy houses, get married, adopt a child. > Want more? Skyrim DLCs: Dawnguard, Dragonborn, and Hearthfire. > Also lots of great and useful mods.

review: Dovazhul: Faal Zuwuth Deykel V: Keizaal los gein do zok dil, zok korin saavir RPGs do un tiid. Niist los lov vozah edil customization, voth pogaan reyliik, noot reyth, zun ahrk qah. Faal DLC expansions los bal ter makil korin wah kred vortii kodiist undoro. waarth do abilities los vorohah ahrk miik pogaan moor vomedaas poguk fah . Zir ko kred los moor, ahrk nid graal pruvos nir tum Deyra fah niist hil wah geblaan hin Deyren qah. Modding vetgar vos fah optimization ahrk pusojur fixes, ol pruzah ol entirely yun undoro, zun ahrk qah. Waan hi lost pruzah rihahdrim, definitely bir faal Zooruv rediirend fah PC sinon do fah franvoth. Pahnim Keizaal los lot kred bal enook cent. Waan hi haven't kiird nii tul, zemqulek nii vok nu. English: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is one of the deepest, most content rich RPGs of our time. Their is near infinite character customization, with many races, skill trees, weapons and armors. The DLC expansions are worth it adding immense content to the game beyond the initial adventure. The amount of abilities are insane and offer many fun different option for combat. Crafting in the game is fun, and nothing beats the feeling of hunting down Daedra for their hearts to complete your Daedric armor. The modding scene allows for optimization and bug fixes, as well as entirely new adventures, weapons and armor. If you have a good computer, definitely purchase the Legendary edition for PC instead of for console. Overall Skyrim is a great game worth every cent. If you haven't played it yet, pick it up now.

game-hours: 274.8
review: Ah, Skyrim. What a game. I don't even know where to start when describing the sheer brilliance and genius that this game is. I know I have said in a previous review that Team Fortress 2 is my all time favourite game, but now I'm not so sure. After returning to Bethesda's world of Skyrim again and again, and investing the amount of time that I have into it, I believe it is time for Team Fortress 2 to be removed from the prestigous podium that is my all time favourite game, and for Skyrim to replace it. I suppose I should start with the one aspect that the developers of Skyrim were so keen to get right (and believe me, they did), and that is the amount of choice the game offers the player. You can play the game however you want, and be whatever character you want. Do you want to play a psychopathic maniac who thirsts for the blood of the innocent? Or perhaps you want to play a bright wizard eager to uncover the mysteries of the magical world? Or even a hunter or rogue-like character who lives off the land and despises civilisation. These are just a few of countless potential characters that the game allows you to create. Think of a character, and you will be able to play him/her in the world of Skyrim. The game provides this freedom in many different ways. Firstly, you are never assigned to a class that limtis what skills you can divulge in. If you have been playing a thief-type character for 20 levels but you suddenly decide you want to try your hand in magic, then go for it! The game won't stop you. The factions scattered throughout the world of Skyrim provide a perfect training ground for all play styles, filled with intriguing NPCs, enjoyable quests and curious locations. Dialogue choices also allow you to flesh out your character's personality and make you feel like you are playing the character that you want to play. Also, there are little to no cutscenes. This could potentially sound like a disadvantage of the game, as cut scenes are generally considered 'cool' in most games. However this is not the case with Skyrim, as the lack of cut scenes means the game does not force a type of character onto you. Your character also has no voice, meaning that he or she is not forced to sound a way that you would not like you character to sound, if that makes sense. It is small details like this that allow you to create a genuinely fleshed out and truly unique character that you will love to play. The environment of Skyrim is also stunning. There are nine holds, and for each of them you can really see the thought that has gone into them form the developers to make each one seem unqiue and intriguing. The land of Skyrim is filled with huge mountain ranges (all of which are scalable, they are not mere backdrops to the game. If you see a mountain, go climb it, its yours for the conquering!), lush plains, deep forests and deadly, snowy wastelands. The diversity of the holds prevents the environment from becoming stale or dull. The same goes for all the cities throughout Skyrim, each one has been carefully thought out and crafted to have its own, unique personality. One cannot forget Jeremy Soule's beautiful and badass soundtrack that accompanies you on your adventures. It is truly a masterpiece, my all time favourite video game soundtrack. Despite my love for the game, I feel like it would be unfair if I ended this review without mentioning some of Skyrim's (admittedly few and petty) flaws. Firstly, it can be buggy. With a game as large and daring as Skyrim, bugs here and there are somehwat inevitable and to be expected. But they are not so frequent or disastrous to take away from the feel of the game. Some skills could have been rebalanced more effectively, and there are many exploits that can be used to turn your character into a God, but again it is not enough to take away from the joy of building your character the way you want them to as you go on your adventure. Lastly, most of the NPCs are not all that interesting and their dialogue choices are somewhat limited (but this only really becomes obvious after installing and playing with a mod such as Interesting NPCs, which adds over 230 fully voiced NPCs to the game that, to be honest, make the vanilla NPCs feel like interactive walls that serve to give you quests and maybe a bit of information, as oppose to real, living people with a fleshed out personality). To conclude, I would recommend Skyrim to everyone I met, regardless of their opinion towards games or how much they play or what games they prefer. Everyone should be able to appreciate Skyrim's ability to let you, the player, be in control of your character's story. Stunning setting, glorious soundtrack, intriguing quests and of course that peerless freedom of choice, Skyrim is an absolute bargain for 10, the DLCs are well worth the extra money and if you can get the game in a sale then you have pretty much cheated the system, for the amount of time one is able to invest into the game (particularly if you enter the world of modding, which i thoroughly recommed) is practically unmatched considering it is a single player experience.

game-hours: 1204.0
review: Consider my playtime on this game - most would call me a fanatic. But the simple truth is that the majority of my playtime was not recorded until I was able to link my selection of mods with Steam. Skyrim is an like a Sketch of a masterpeice by a toddler, a crayon scribble with boundless effort and ethusiasm, but very little actual substance. Where Morrowind succeeds in telling a great story, Skyrim fails, yet it's everything Morrowind needed as technological improvements for total immersion. Skyrim with it's arcade style gameplay (levelling up by using abilities) allows the player to control the pacing - yet With Mods, it can both excel and surpass even the deepest of Immersive games like Metro 2033, and improve the combat mechanics to the level of Jedi outcast. The most important mods I can recommend for this game, that has allowed for so much replay would be. Interesting NPC's - 300 NPC's with interesting, funny, lore based dialgue. There's even a regular Joe who asks who you, the player are, If you reply Dragonborn, he interviews you. Start a new Life - Allows the player to skip the Intro sequence and ignore the Dragonborn quests if you want to Roleplay, allows hundreds of back stories, starting locations and items. Want to become a Hunter in the wilds? Want to become a Forsword and learn their culture? Or want to become a Vampire's Thrall? Stacks with Interesting NPC's incredibly fluidly. Sneak tools - Allows the crafting and use of Water and Fire Arrows - Incorporates the ability to light and put out candles with magic and enviromental effects. A total atmosphere changer during combat. There are many more but you need only install the highest endorsed by the community pages of Nexus and Skyrim workshop Lastly - If you've gotten bored of Skyrim. - another recommendation 1 Find and Load - a Save game with 100% Skyrim completion & try out the DLC's for Skyrim fresh?
game-hours: 514.2

game-hours: 103.7
review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is an action role-playing, open world game. It's 200 years after oblivion crisis. The game sets in the land of Skyrim, a province of the Empire on the continent of Tamriel. The land is suffering a civil war between two factions the Stormcloaks and the Imperials. To make matters worse dragons start to appear, and it was believed that they were instinct a long time ago. And the only one who can defeat a dragon permanently is a drogonborn. And your quest begins. In this game you can choose a race you want to play, each one possesses its own unique racial abilities and powers. And you can customize your looks, so thats always a plus. In this game theres a total of 18 different skills. Also there's a lot of side quests that you can do, almost every object in the game is interactive, a huge variety of enemies, and a huge map will have spend hundreds of hours and you'll still be able to find something new to do. The main story is pretty interesting, but it's not the main point of the game. Graphics and visuals are well made. The games soundtrack is overwhelming, when exploring the music is calm and relaxing, when you start to fight you can hear energetic, battling music. In overall this game will have you stuck at your computer screen for weeks maybe even months. I really recommend this game for everyone, trust me you wont be disappointed.

game-hours: 138.3
review: So I bought this game in Christmas of '11 origionally as a gift for someone else (for the Xbox 360). He had already owned a copy and I didn't know it. As a result I took this game and gave him another one from my stash, which I believe was the newest Call of Duty (MW3?). Let me begin my actual review by stating this was my first Elder Scrolls game, and it got me so hooked that I own every game in the series and am beta testing ESO. I Love This Game. So when I got into it on the Xbox, the first thing i noticed was the possibilities of doing whatever you wanted. It hooked me with a narrowly avoided decapitation, and then the evasion of a dragon, going through Helegan Keep, and thats where the magic happened, both literally and figuratively. Haadvar gave me countless posibilities to get through just the first quest. Magic, Two handed weapons, Dual Weild, Shield and sword, bows, and even subcategories in between (Sword swings faster than warhammer, but sacrifices power). Then comes the choice between nice, enchanted robes, quick and light Light Armour, or slow but strong heavy armour. And that is just the first thirty minutes. Once you really get into the game with quests and what not, you have tons mre options. You can do short, sweet, and simple Miscelaneous Objectives, Side Quests which are a bit longer, but with a greater reward, or Main Quests, which are usually long, but add the most to your experience and give you the best loot. I could go on for hours about everything you could possibly do in this game, but the sad part is that I have hardly scratched the surface. On the 360, I have 1,271 hours, PS3 I have 767, and on the PC I have a good 312 hours (most are offline because I am rarely home lately, which is why I started PC gamming in the first place). The moral of the story is not that I have no life, just I choose to do what I love with my life, and Skyrim is just that thing.

review: Skyrim can be summed up in one word. Brilliant. The gameplay is brilliant, and the world is immersive. The combat is balanced (most of the time) and the world is rich with lore. There are, however, some bugs though, many of which can be avoided, but some of them can be quite a pain. Bugs are more prominent when using a modded version, however. Skyrims world is beautiful yet harsh, and it has masses of content. Add on the ability to mod it to oblivion (no pun intended) and you have a great game. all together I give it a 9/10 because of the sheer beauty and immersion this game provides. It would be given a 10 if not for some relatively major bugs.

game-hours: 30.9
review: All right. As probably no one person that will read this review knows, i did NOT have internet for 8 months. This game was the only thing that i had installed aside from terraria. I played it because i was bored to beond belief after 3 months. i had tried playing it when i first got it, and i lagged more than i ever knew possible, so i shut it down. When I tried it again, i just sat back and tried to endure the lag. IT PAID OFF. I had no idea this was made by the same people of fallout one of my favorite games of all time. And once i started playing it was well worth it. I will review this game the way i want to. If anyone disagrees, they get a BOOT TO THE HEAD. Gameplay Skyrim had very basic battle mechanics most people will understand if they read the directions given to them, but the real thing that stopped me was the lag. this game will lag beond belief if you dont have a good computer. All factors considered gameplay is 8/10 Graphics This game is aboely BEUTIFUL. if you run it at maximum quality the framerate takes a blow under the belt, but if you can handle the game running at high it is a work of genius. 9.5/10 Story Honestly the MAIN storyline was nothing to gawk at. typical middle earth storyline, hero arises saves the day. But i have to give credit where it is due. the secondary storylines are where it is at. the dark brotherhood and theives guild is where the story was great. 7.5/10 Replay value This game has the highest replay vaule ive ever seen. Pretty much you can play this game 500 times and still find stuff you missed on the way. with that said this game gets a 11/10 for replay vaule. Music Skyrim has the best soundtrack i have ever heard. the music was well balanced and placed where it was needed. 10/10 Modding Skyrim has the biggest modding fanbase in the world. anything you could want in skyrim, there is a mod for it. and then there is the offical DLC's as well. 10/10 for modding. After taking all elements in, i give skyrim a 9.5/10. and it is an absolute MUST BUY.

game-hours: 425.8
review: Honestly. Without any mods at all, this game is a strong 7/10. It has the base for what is a great modding project. It has an engaging story that builds on a large catalogue of games worth of lore and backstory. It has a fair graphical setup, though it is shamelessly "consolized". Sound design is good and gameplay is solid. The game gives you a great ammount of freedom so that you can make the game into what you want. You can ignore the story completely and just forge your own story throughout Skyrim, or spend hours just doing sidequests, or maybe just spend your gametime becoming the ultimate enchater. Anything is possible. A fair game worth your time and money. But that all changes when mods enter the ring. When mods enter the ring this game becomes the jungle-gym of modern games. You can do anything you want. Want to turn Skyrim into a tropical paradise? There's a mod for that. Want to turn all the dragons into characters from My Little Pony or Thomas the Tank Engine? You can do that. You can even make Skyrim into the most realistic looking and playing game ever (minus the dragons/mosters/spooky ghosts). With mods, this game is amazing. The game is your oyster in any way you want. And that is why you play it. Summary: Holy  this game is good. 10/10

game-hours: 712.6
review: Score: 9.8/10 The Elder Scrolls V is an open world, western role playing game, set in the ice cold, fantasy realm of Skyrim. You play a fully customizable character imprisoned for crimes untold and being led to your execution. The world of Skyrim is vast and beautiful. Landscapes range from forests, tundra, ice, snow, swamps and everything inbetween. Exploring and satisfing your curiousity is where the most fun in the game is to be had. This game has at least 300 hours of content in a single playthrough, though there is no multiplayer. Skyrim is very mod friendly. You can find a mod to tweak just about any aspect of the game and if not, the developers (Bethesda) have released a utility called the creation kit to let you mod it yourself. One downside of Skyrim is the sub-par main Quest. The real story to be told by Skyrim is the one forged by you. And it can be amazing if you embrace that fact. Despite a few shortcomings, Skyrim is the best at what it does. Immersion, value, exploration, mods, and above all else adventure.

review: I think that Skyrim is one of the best Roleplaying games out there. I like the fact that the player can do what he/she wishes, and doesn't have a fixed mission that they have to follow. Instead, there are many missions and quests that the player can do, each with their own set of rewards alike. The graphics make the game equally pleasing, as it has way better graphics than the previous Elder Scrolls games. Just the amount of detail make Skyrim a beautiful game. But, of course, there are glitches. Once, near Whiterun, I was hunting deer, when one started floating, but still somehow running. And, I'm not going to go on about the floating Mammoths . . . I suppose that's what mods are for, anyway. Anyway, I would DEFINITELY recommend this game! It's fun and enjoyable, and it is easy to get immersed in the lore and the game itself. :D

game-hours: 256.7
review: As an long-time Elder Scrolls fan, I can't deny that I love Skyrim for what it is - an Elder Scrolls game. The lore, storylines and world is all there - ready to be explored with the various books and tales that characters tell. The argument that Skyrim is a sea with the depth of a puddle is a valid arguement though, the world doesn't really feel as alive and deep as it could have been. While the gameplay is good - it isn't particularly anything amazing. The engine of the game, "Creation", is just a rehashed and reworked Gamebyro engine from previous installments. As a result, it doesn't utilise the full capability of a PC. And while there are various issues with the game itself, these are all mainly fixed and improved by the community. This is thanks to Bethsedas extended support for modding with the release of the Creation Kit and Steam Workshop (Although I use the Nexus sites and Mod Organizer myself). The vast number of mods that accomplish a sheer amount of things is nothing short of amazing. From bug fix compilations to whole new lands, you can pour hundreds of hours into Skyrim when you add mods, breathing new life into the game.

game-hours: 156.0
review: Currently in the midst of playing Skyrim for the second time. Take your time with this game, at the beginning you'll be propelled right into the thick of things...but only if you choose. I suggest exploring first, where you'll find NPCs and various quests. Over time, you'll level up and you can up the ante through difficulty settings especially so when fighting dragons! But take the time to just look around and enjoy the scenery - there's so much detail with butterflies flying around and beautifully textured rivers and lakes along with huge gigantic mammoths protected by equally as massive trolls. The whole point of exploring is to make the game your own and play at your own pace - then and only then will you begin to appreciate what a glorious game this is with such intricate detail in textures (especially so with the high texture pack) and vast range of dialogue options and choices in game. The decisions are numerous and the choice is all up to you...Dovahkiin.
game-hours: 362.6
review: Skyrim, the finest Elder Scrolls game to date. You can go anywhere, do (almost) anything, whenever you feel like it.. caves, dungeons, tombs, lairs.. so much to discover, with multitude of enemies to vanquish. Be a fighter, mage, thief.. or maybe a sneaky hybrid, a caster who uses illusion spells and strikes from the shadows.. an archer who is not afraid to wade into melee range when needed.. all paths are very much viable. If you are a fan of roleplaying games, Skyrim will keep you entertained for countless hours as there is always something to do, some new place to discover, some new loot to find.. and thanks to mods, all that is multiplied, making the game a worthy purchase indeed!

review: Let me tell you right now: If you do not own this game, and you have even the slightest itch to press that "Add to Cart" button, do so without any hesitation excapt that of your wallet. I have played 99.6% of my total playtime without downloading a single mod, and up until recently I played with no DLC. Still the best game I have played in my life. Let me hand it to you straight. When you first buy the game, you are one of two people. You either A): Research in-depth into every nook and cranny of every story, main, and side-quest, know the in-and-outs of every NPC, location, weapon, enchantment, potion, ingredient, and food item, and end up playing the game for about as long as you have time, or B): You spend the first two weeks of owning this game stumbling around like a big oaf with a two-handed warhammer and beat the game at level 10 and dont play it for a year, then start conversing with your friend who followed option A and get back into it and can't stop and eventually get sucked into the eternal loop of "Whiterun, Riften, Markarth, Riften, Windhelm, Riften, Riften, Solitude, Riftern, Repeat." Trust me, I speak from experience. But seriously, here's what you get for buying this game: -AMAZING GRAPHICS that don't take a goliath alienware desktop monster to run. -BADASS STORYLINE AND CRAP TONS OF SIDEQUESTS (honestly I forgot there was a storyline). -Dragons. -YOU CAN BE: A thief/rogue(best), a battlemage, a warrior(not best), someone who's good with a bow, a smith, an enchanter, or any combination of those thirty. -Dragons. -HOURS UPON HOURS OF EPIC GAMEPLAY followed by six months of meh FOLLOWED BY HOURS UPON HOURS OF EPIC GAMEPLAY!!!! -DRAGONS. -GREAT MODDABILITY. -DRAGONS FOR GOD'S SAKE!
