game-hours: 202.2
review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is the epitome of fantastic game design, world design, and just blatant creativity. The game looks great, with or without mods, even to this day, though if you have a higher end PC, I would recommend dowloading some visual enhancements. No point not to, since you can make a beautiful game more beautiful. The stories are epic and compelling, and make you feel like you're the embodiment of an ancient Hero of Old. From the first minute and onwards, the story grips you in. That is, if you want it to. The Elder Scrolls is all about freedom to choose your on path. If you wish to join the Guild of Thieves instead of becoming a stalwart warrior and following your 'destiny', you can do so. Or if you wish to merely chop firewood for days on end, you may do that too. You can go where you want, when you want, and how you want. Nothing is stopping you. What makes the game, in the end, is how you do it and why. I am a man of lore. I like researching the backstories and foundations of the games I play, especially those set in fantasy worlds. The world of Nirn, especially Tamriel, has one of the most interesting and fundamentally gripping lore I've ever had the pleasure of being a part of. The world feels so real, looks so real, and the characters act so real. How can one not appreciate that? It's done superbly, because the given material, the material of the Elder Scrolls series, is simply so great. Skyrim is not perfect, however. I am not sure how I feel for the simplified magic system, for instance. It makes magic, in the game, slightly more tedious and boring when compared to it's predecessor. Which brings us to the Guilds. One of the best thing about the Elder Scrolls is the fact that the game gives you free reign to do what you wish. But it can also guide you. That's when you join a guild. But the Guilds in Skyrim,I did not care for them. The College or Winterhold quests, while superb, were much too short. It ended abruptly. The Dark Brotherhood quests were good, in essence, but when I look at the retconned material from the previous game, I can only cringe. The Dark Brotherhood was entertaining, but falls short when compared to it's 2006 counterpart. Which brings us to the Thieves Guild. The Thieves Guild was a complete insult to it's predecessor. The characters were boring, the thieving was boring, and the ending was utterly stupid. There is no Ultimate Heist in this game. All you get is a would-be antagonist, who doesn't even do anything to warrant any anger and/or hatred towards him. The Oblivion Thieves Guild didn't have to resort to such cheap tricks. Even the simplicity of the joining quest in Oblivion was better. Thieves Guild is good once. After that it has almost as little replay value as the Oblivion main quest. The Companions -quests were nothing special, though neither was the Fighters Guild in Oblivion. All in all, don't expect the Guilds to be Oblivion -tier good. Some people like them, some people hate them, but what we can all agree on, is the fact that they aren't the main focus of the game. There is much better solo non-guild content out there, such as the Daedric shrine quests etc. Skyrim is great. It's a solid 4.5/5. It doesn't hold up to the previous Elder Scrolls in some ways, but blows Oblivion out of the water in others. You'll get a solid 100-200 hours of fun out of it, if not more. Long live the Elder Scrolls. Long live Bethesda. Peace out, -SliQster

review: For once in my entire lifetime I'm going to be serious here. This game is neck-deep in bugs, the voice actors are overused to the point of where I get all too common irreversable headaches. The A.I. is completely ed and the combat system needs to be tweaked. With all the community support with mods this can and has been reversed on many levels, but knowing that Bethesda neither had the time nor the funds to make this game the way they wanted, I can indefinitely say with no hesitancy that this game is no doubt the best game of the 2000's. There is no rating that can tell you how amazing this game is.

game-hours: 55.0
review: Dragons, shouting angry people who are called 'Dragonborns' and lots of spells, weapons and beautiful scenery, with a tad amount of annoying animals, mages and other NPC's that like to sneak on you and want to take a nibble, crush you or seriously hurt you through poisoning, burning or freezing your  to Oblivion. Welcome to Skyrim! A land where if you turn a corner and see a frost troll when you're a level 2, you're basically ed on sight. You are a 'Dragonborn', in which you steal dragon souls to fuel your own ambitions and skills, you greedy person. While dealing with dragons coming back, you have to choose a side to a war between the Empire and the Stormcloaks, all the while, you can join multiple cool kids clubs like The College of Winterhold, The Theifs Guild, etc. and get some cool stuff from them. Also, you can mix universes together by putting on some Stormtrooper armour, getting a lightsaber and then cutting down some mothertruckers. This game is a real gem. It can open up so many paths of which you want to take. You can do all of the quests available and become the Dragonborn hero you are meant to be, or you could go on a killing spree in Whiterun with some crazily OP spell mods you downloaded. The world is your Nordic oyster, in this ultimate tale of Dragons and... humanoid races? Not to mention you can become so many different races. But lets be honest here, if you're an Argonian, Elf, Tusken Raider, you're gonna get a discrimination bomb thrown on you. Some nords just love their xenophobia... ahh. But it's okay because you can shoot their racist asses with a M16 if you want. All in all, this game is awesome, and is so, so worth it. There are few games like this that can stand up to Skyrim elegance, complexity and overall epicness. Plus the modding community, not just on Steam but also on NEXUS, are also making this game about 1000x better too. A tip of the hat to you great modders. Buy this game, and fus ro dah everyones sweet roll! 9.5/10

game-hours: 265.3
review: After playing over 500 hours (180 on PC and the rest on Xbox) I can say that Skyrim is one of my favourite games of all time. If you are a fan of open world games then this is the game for you, you can spend hours lost in the beauty of the landscape and discovering things. The game has plenty of customization: Swords, Axes, etc.. all work well together and the magic system is a definate improvement over the previous games; combine any two spells or even wield a weapon and a spell together. Along with the armor choices, alchemy and enchanting I think this is what makes Skyrim stand out from the other RPG's out there, not forgetting the world of course! I do however have some points that I feel do let the game down, firstly I feel that the games lacks depth in the quests and npcs, your choices throughout the game don't really affect the world and one of the faction quest endings *cough*dark brotherhood*cough* definatelt lacks the impact of what you do. Another thing that lets the game down is the repetative nature of the quests, after playing for so long I have started to notice the quests follow this format "Go get X from this cave Y" This could be a positive however if you like that sort of quest but for me it really started to make the game feel stale. Overall, I definatly recomend you buy this game as it is a great RPG and if you get into the modding scene you can really make your game amazing.

game-hours: 1058.8
review: Fantastic game, great story and an immersive environment. All that said, it does suffer from some issues concerning enemy scalling and a less dynamic and influential questline, then say Oblivion. To fully enjoy this game I think one should mod the game. I recommend the nexus, just google it, this offers a mod manager, which is generally much safer to work with. So I would decline on using the infamous steam workshop (although great for other games) because Skyrim is a bit more delicate with its mods, and manual installation of a mod. But back to the game. Sadly it also suffers from some major bugs, although mods can fix most, it is a little annoying that they were left in by Bethesda. That brings me to what I call not being mod friendly but mod depending. I don't know if Bethesda intentally depends on the mods, and as a direct effect brings out unfinnished games, but sometimes whilst I am modding my game the thought comes up, that alone annoys me a little bit. But what annoys me the most is that eventhough it is so dependant of its mods, a limit has been placed on the amount of mods. That is like giving someone a car (very gentel) but saying that you can only drive 2 miles with it ( sorry for this silly example but you get the point). But I am ofcourse talking very negative about the game, whilst it still is my favorite game on steam. The superb voiceacting and 2 major questlines, 4 if you include the add-ons (which were fantastic, except for Dawnguard, if you were with the Dawnguard you do this whole questline just to eventually invade the castle, why could you not just attack it as soon as possible...) All in all if you are considering to buy this game, buy it! You can then tell all your friends how cool it is to be a vampire just like you did in Oblivion and Morrowind. Sorry for any mistakes in the review, English is not my first language. Hope you enjoyed reading my review, wich is absolutly not for the completion of the pillar of community badge...

review: I've been an elder scrolls fan for the past 5 years, one of the most interesting, longest game I have ever played is Morrowind. Then came oblivion I could play out the game, but seriously, that game is nothing without mods, horribly boring conversations (Not like skyrim's any better... "... an arrow to the knee"). When skyrim came out, I was pumped for it, I had a reason: The game looked amazingly cool in the gameplay trailer, it was an amazing adventure. But if we look deeply into it, skyrim is just a bit better than oblvivion. Insanely boring conversations, oversimplified puzzles, if you play out the game for the 5th time, even the legendary difficulty is mouse crap in a sack of flour. Mods make this game even more beautiful (ENBs, Weather mods, W.A.T.E.R,), even more harder (Deadly Combat, Duel Combat Realism etc.), there are some interesting quest mods also. (Falskaar, Wyrmstooth etc.) I kinda stopped playing, never even heard of DLCs coming out, Dragonborn, Hearthfires, Dawnguard. I was excited about them, my favorite DLC was and still is: Dragonborn, a completely new land (Solstheim), with returning topics, houses. Netches, House Redoran, House Telvanni. And a dying Silt Strider ;( I recommend buying the Legendary edition, it comes with several bonuses: All DLCs, Legendary difficulty, when a skill reaches lvl 100, you can make it legendary and regain all perk points spent in that skill. I overall recommend skyrim for anyone who likes RPG adventure games or just likes Bethesda games.

review: It was an ordinary day. I was in Solitude, heading to the blue palace. I needed to do some buisness with the queen. As I entered the palace, I noticed an older gentleman seated to my left. He look concerned. As I glanced him over, I noticed something percular about his legs... I realised that he had a platter stuck in his left knee. Instantly horrified, I ran over to see how I could assist this poor man. Grabbing with all of my might, I ripped the platter from the mans leg. He was clearly thankfull and obviously in a much better state health wise. I felt proud. I did a good deed for skyrim and her people. Suddenly a loud noise came from my right. It was the guards. Hmm.. They must be after someone.. They came closer and closer until studdenly I realised the person they were after, was in fact me. Confused, I wondered what I did to deserve such strife. Then it hit me. I was holding the platter. They thought I had stolen this. Surely I can explain. I even have a witness. 1 day in jail later, I learned my lesson. Don't help someone if they have a platter stuck in their knee. Leave them alone. To die. 10/10 fantastic. Would platter again.

game-hours: 149.2
review: Skyrim on PC is remarkable. The Vanilla game on my 360 pales in comparison. I only put about 10-15 hours or so on the console version because it did not do a good job sucking me in like Oblivion did. I was left dissapointed by the console release but then, I built my first gaming computer, but it was sometime before I really began to make the complete shift over the mouse and keyboard. About a year ago, during a steam sale, I decided to get the Legendary Edition of Skyrim, having missed out on all of the DLC on the console and even most of the base game content. I figured i could at least play the game in full hd and at 60fps, more than I could get on console. However, I began to mod my game pretty vigorously to get the game that I wanted. I know that I am playing MY Skyrim and not something else. I have graphics mods, new followers, new weapons, complete new areas, and gameplay overhall that involves having to eat, sleep and drink to survive as well as staying warm in the harsh Skyrim winters. While I still feel like Skyrim is a step back in the series as a vanilla game, my modded Skyrim makes it a hardcore, immersive and challenging game that the vanilla game did not offer me. At the time of this writing, i have put 130 hours into my Skyrim and I will happily double that number as well. Skyrim is legendary in it's own right. The community is always coming up with new ideas and content to keep pushing the game forward. From what I have learned playing Skyrim is that the journey is much more awarding than the destination. The adventures I have had with my companion Inigo have been great and I can't wait to have many more. Fighting bandits, finishing quests, finding new items and soaking in all the sounds and sights of the land. Then I get a crash to desktop. I throw my mouse across the room and take a cold a shower.

review: Hands down, best RPG I have ever played, 10/10 (with mods). With over 500 hours played on my main account and around 200 spread across several others on Xbox, I am happy to say that I have enjoyed every bit of it. This is my favorite game of all time and I didn't even play it with mods :O Now that I have it on PC I have modded everything from the way I walk, to having every object retextured in HD, to how NPC's react when I'm naked :P This game still has one of the best immersive experiences even after 3 years of being released, not even the newest games have a chance at measuring up to it. Definitely would recommend this game to a friend, this is a must play before you die kind of game. Without a doubt you will love it once you get the hang of it. It's not the easiest game to grasp, you will always have something new to discover or level up.
game-hours: 309.4
review: SKYRIM an rpg you will love if you take the time to learn its personality. A personality of explore! explore! explore! Which after two years of playing I have found out is SKYRIM's greatest strength along with the other things your character does on their own such as blacksmithing weapons and armor, enchanting items with magic effects, researching alchemy for creating healing and fortifying tonics as well as toxic death dealing poisonous potions, hunting for food or sport and cooking the spoils of the hunt, reading books upon mountains of books (No you still cant write your own but they got a mod for it LOL ) which fill out the missing spots in lore and interacting with the world. There is so much to do in SKYRIM its mind boggling. Game mechanics such as combat have improved greatly since the nostalgic old days of MORROWIND. Not only can you block with a shield but you can stun an opponent with it and do the same with any weapon in your shield arm such as a bow. Its a lot of fun taking a non-melee weapon like a bow and bashing the stuffings out of my enemies as they stumble about stunned and confused. Of course it takes timing as well as stamina which is always being used up for such attacks. Another excellent combat mechanic are power attacks that can make a big difference when dealing with a powerful bandit chief or high level monsters like Draugr Death Lords. It always comes in handy to buy or with the alchemy skill create stamina potions once you have learned the recipe to use in battle to keep those power attacks going or at least to have enough stamina where the enemy wont knock you on your rear end creating the perfect situation to finish you off. One of my favorite ways of dealing with enemies is to swing a burning torch at them and watch them go up in flames. This is great because it means my melee based barbarian character doesn't have to break character and learn magic to use fire which weakens enemies to physical blows. I just grab a torch like a raging villager out to burn the Frankenstein monster into a crispy critter shade of well done. You can also attack on horseback which is done in a realistic manner with a sense of awkwardness since after all who has ever seen a jousting match where combatants felt graceful. Kill cams add some eye catching coolness when killing enemies just like in the grand sci-fi b-movie styled rpg masterpiece FALLOUT 3. Oh! Ah! The demented joy of decapitating an enemy after learning the proper perks in the skill tree. Everything in the world of SKYRIM is lovingly hand placed allowing Bethesda to tell a story in many set piece situations like a husband and wife whose burnt bodies you discover outside their isolated cabin. With further exploration you eventually find out what may have most likely been the cause of their untimely demise. The world is full of hostile and non hostile npcs and creatures. Just when you think you have come across something that is menacing and bound to attack it turns out to be the opposite as long as you don't get on it or their nerves. Enemies such as bandits many times will not out right attack you and will instead warn you to keep away which is a wonderful welcomed change from enemies that kill everything in sight. I have come across many traveling npcs on the roads of SKYRIM such as bards who will sing for coin, damsels in distress, groups of people traveling to special engagements, prisoners being taken to who knows where which I can choose to liberate and will fight by my side in their bid for freedom. Hunters roam the land searching for game to kill and sell. One more reason the world feels so alive and not just a landscape of death to kill in. Npcs in towns and cities look and act very alive thanks to the Radiant ai. Conversing with them many times I have found myself unable to stop talking with them due to their interesting personalities and backgrounds along with quests many may send my characters way. The incredible huge variety of npc's and how different from one another they are is amazing and really breathes life into them making me curious of what an approaching villager is up to. Its also nice to see that important npcs are not killable which prevents a lot of problems due to the life like randomness of the Radiant ai. Wouldn't want a Dragon killing the Jarl of Whiterun and messing up the main quest etc. Companions are nice though I longed for them being much more talkative and reacting to variables such as my speech skill with a higher skill making them open up more and a low speech skill or charisma having them get angry at my character or treating them as amateur etc. Environments are detailed works of art as if someone created some imagination machine and strapped it on to the players brain where a world alive consumes the players vision and soul in a fantasy tapestry which seems to change and form into whatever the player wishes it to be. The dream controlled. The reality beyond touch kissing the minds eye. The world map is very different from past Elder Scrolls if not daring with its "live" view of the world helping to keep me in the blistering cold mindset of SKYRIM with its puffy white clouds and snow ravaged landscape. Nice change from the classic paper map view of old. It could have done with some proper looking roads though. Perhaps in the next game we will have a paper map that wears away over time with the player having to buy new ones at a town store. Who knows they might even keep the current view we have now only for magic users alongside the paper map for non-magic melee type characters to use in the next Elder Scrolls. Optional quest and map markers are great to have in-game making it easy to have some idea what direction I should be going for a quest or if I just want to find the nearest dungeon to plunder when am not in the mood to blindly explore. Most of the time I ignore the markers buts its nice to have them there just like with fast travel where I can go anywhere on the map if I have already traveled there when the horse and carriage service is not nearby. The music soundtrack is one of the best and diverse since TES 2 DAGGERFALL. From heroic bombastic songs in combat to almost spiritually transcending music when traveling in the world the soundtrack for SKYRIM is one of a kind and a moving work of audio orchestral artistry. Not to mention like all Elder Scrolls and Fallout soundtracks it leaves a very relaxing aftertaste making one feel as if they just woke up from a wonderful dream when ending a game session. Character creation is the best I have seen allowing me to create a visually gorgeous heroic character or a ghastly ghoulish looking murdering fiend. Along with the stunning environment with its sunset reflecting lakes and mountainous physique your player character will fit right in with the epic fantasy landscape making one feel they just stepped into a Frank Frazetta, Simon Bisley masterpiece of fantasy art. The so called removal of classes is actually the opposite. Now instead of having a few classes to choose from the player can create a near infinite amount of classes by playing their characters the way they want. Game balance is still kept since the skills the player uses most are the ones that will keep on improving. So a melee warrior who all of sudden decided to learn magic at level twenty will have a harder time mastering it compared to if he/she had started from level one using magic related skills. On top of all this epicness we also have the good fortune to indulge in the creepiest action packed and creative DLCs to ever grace an Elder Scrolls rpg since OBLIVION's SHIVERING ISLES expansion with the HEARTHFIRE, DAWNGUARD and DRAGONBORN DLCs which add many new things to the base game as well as their own main subjects of building a home, vampirism and vampire hunters, things ancient and of long ago. DRAGONBORN especially has a very thick MORROWIND theme to it.
game-hours: 51.5

You can create your very own character with a unque and personally-tailored playstyle. The things you can do alone are staggering. In one moment you can be exploring an Ancient Nordic ruin, the next out hunting in the woods for deer, killing dragons, gathering ingredients, it's amazing! Definitely a good one to pick up for any RPG lover out there!
game-hours: 4.2
review: I've noticed that the reviews for Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim tend to be about why that game is the best Elder Scrolls game and the others are terrible in comparison. I really enjoy all three of them (sorry, Arena and Daggerfall, you're just not very enjoyable by today's standards), so I figured I'll give reviews for each that focus on what's unique about each of them, and what kind of players that will appeal to. Skyrim is the most mainstream of the three. It's a big, grand production, meant for a big. grand reception. In other words, this was the first TES game specifically designed to be in the headlines a ton. Think of it as the difference between a film with a 30 million dollar production budget and one with a 300 million production budget, meant to be one of the grandest films of the decade. Morrowind and Oblivion are the former, Skyrim is the latter. It's easily the most professional of the three. As such, the game is meant to be most appealing to a wide range of players. Morrowind is pure chaos, Oblivion is pure order, and Skyrim is somewhere between those two extremes. It's safe when it wants to be and wild when it wants to be. It has some of the rugged freedom of Morrowind, while being polished like Oblivion and therefore avoiding any of the major negatives that Morrowind also has. For the positives of the game, let's go ahead and start with the graphics and scenery. Morrowind had rugged scenery, but the graphics weren't good enough to really be stunned by it. Oblivion had soft graphics and scenery, which left you feeling perfectly content but not awed. Skyrim has both the graphics and scenery to take your breath away. It's rugged, majestic, powerful, and all sorts of other things. It's easily the most immersive of any of the three games. No matter how many thousands of hours you've spent playing it, there will always be views that strike awe in you. Whenever a game can get you to willingly just stop and stand there and take in everything, it's succeeded. Skyrim does that all the time. The skill and perk systems are also the best of any TES game. It allows you to really forge your own path and adapt your character however you want as the game progresses. Morrowind and Oblivion basically make you decide at the beginning exactly what type of character you want, and keeps you confined to that choice. Skyrim is much more fluid, and each playthrough is much more customizable, which also allows you to add much more depth to the story you come up with for your character. Want to be a high elf who is disgusted by the actions of the Aldmeri dominion and decides to shun magic and adopt the rugged combat and lifestyle of the local Nords? Want to be an Orc who feels no connection to the brute stregth emphasized in your culture and instead explore the arcane and master the ways of the mage? Want to be a Redguard who shuns the sword and shield and instead masters the bow and slips silently through the shadows? Well, in Skyrim you can be any of those things, and pretty much anything else you could possibly imagine. Another big positive is the crafting systems found in the game. The smithing skill replaces the armorer skill, and is a gigantic improvement. You don't have to worry about maintaining your armor and weapons, but instead you will be able to smith powerful weapons and armor the more time you devote to it. If you want to have daedric weapons before you even hit level 20, you can, but remember that it means you spent so much time smithing that your combat skills might not be up to par. The same goes for brewing powerful potions or creating powerful enchantments. It's determined less by getting lucky and finding good stuff, and more by deciding what to pursue. For the negatives, we have to go back to the earlier analogy about the Hollywood films. The 300 million dollar budget film has a ton of things that you could possibly want, but it also cant take the risks or be as quirky as the 30 million dollar budget film. So everything in Skyrim is polished and streamlined, and sometimes you find yourself wishing that it would be less powerful and more quirky or nuanced. The magic is a good example. There are fewer schools of magic, and fewer varieties of spells. No levitation, no damage weapon or damage armor spells, no school of mysticism, etc. Destruction spells basically come in three varieties (frost, fire, and shock). There is a good variety of types of those spells (cloak, rune, constant cast, etc), but sometimes you want to be able to hit someone with something other than frost, fire, or shock damage as a mage, and in Skyrim you can't. The DLC's do add some good variety (restoration school spells that do direct damge to undead or do posion damage, conjuration spells that allow you to bring forth powerful creatures made of ash, etc.), but it's still less options than Oblivion or Morrowind gave you. And that's really what a lot of the negatives of this game boil down to: things you loved about Oblivion and Morrowind that weren't included in Skyrim. It has so many improvements over those two, but it also gets rid of some of the things people loved about them. The soundtrack, for example, is a powerful soundtrack, but it feels like it's always in "adrenaline-pumping" mode, whereas Morrowind and Oblivion had music that would really draw you in emotionally. It's not that Skyrim's soundtrack is bad, it's just that Morrowind's and Oblivion's were better overall. Overall, this is the crown jewel of the TES series so far, but that doesn't mean it was perfect. You'll love it, and yet you will still sometimes prefer to play Oblivion or Morrowind instead.

game-hours: 69.1
review: Flat out one of the best games I have ever played. Endless customisation, deep lore, a huge breathing world to explore, stunning visuals, epic storylines and choices galore. This game can be played anyway that you wish. You can blast through every storyline, creating a death dealing beast of a character; be it mage, archer, elf, orc or lizard. Or you can roleplay the day in the life of a poor fisherman or farmer, or a hunter or soldier...the opportunities are endless. You can literally do whatever you want in this world. With a choice of ten playable races (more with mods), and a complex and detailed characeter creation screen, you are free to birth any denizen that you desire. And hello old school rpg-ers: no classes. Thats right, build whatever playstyle you so wish; from a duel weilding ice mage to a pickaxe hefting orcish maid. Choose your own story, and make choices that will be reacted to and remembered (mostly). And MODS! This game has a colossal modding communtiy, from the Steam Workshop to the Skyrim Nexus, you can completley change the way you play the game, or the way the game looks and more. Seriously, this game can look next-next-next gen :) Honestly, I can't recommend this game enough; play this if you are looking for immersion, quality, roleplaying, story, lore...I could go on for days, but I appear to have taken an arrow to the over-used-internet-meme.

game-hours: 246.8
review: Once upon a time, I began playing computer games in deep shadows of our house in times of old pentium processors and three digit Geforce Graphic cards. I began with games like Diablo, Gothic, Arx Fatalis, and when I did learn about Bethseda and saw their products, I was astonished. In TES series, I foresaw my destiny. I could work out, I could learn stuff for school, hell I could improve my life in any way which I would find. But I said NO. Ever since my life did change. It was rollercoaster of gaming, despair, endless nights spent by playing TES series over and over and OVER OVER AGAIN. Honing and improving your character, mixing potions, killing monsters, killing monsters again, and again, then killing guards in city, anihilation of entire city population only to LOAD your game and just do it again. With our friend HAVOK physics, its fun to do it not once, nor twice. Its enjoyable after doing it so many times before that its unbelivable. Did I mention you can kill and ride horses, kill guards on horses, kill creatures and make them fall off the cliff sneak into entire dungeon killing one by one stealing their stuff. Running naked in like -50 degrees of Celsius, hunting deers with your bare hands and fishing not with rod, but with spells. Crabs, horses, deadric creatures, dragonz (yes DRAGONZ!), horses, guards on horses, all zoo team (but not penguins!), frying deer with fireball en route on your plate (just to throw out that meat because you didnt want it anyways), and killing giants. Watching giants kill other creatures and then killing them which- if you have hearth- will make you really sad because they are so un-evolved and so dumb. Unfortunately those are only creatures which probably will evoke any (if ANY) empathy in you. And after you kill all those hordes of creatures, you will feel like a boss of this world and will demand.... to do it again. 97/10 legit and reasonable score for such a remarkable game. Check those horses! The only reason to not play this game is to not get contracted by its addictivity. If you think Diablo is mother of all RPGs, well sad to say it, but I have found Adam and Eve of RPGs. With snake, apple TM, tree and god himself...

review: I used to own Skyrim for the PS3 a while back and played it for 8 months straight doing every side and main quest there is to do. I feared that once I finally ran out of things to do I would never look upon Skyrim again. How wrong I was. It seemed I have been living in the shadow of the PC version of Skyrim all this time. Here I am again a few years later having already clocked over a 100 hours on the game. I picked up the Legendary Edition on one of the Steam sales and fell in love with Skyrim all over again. Why do you ask? I would simply say this: MODS! I WANT ALL THE MODS!! Modding Skyrim is like opening a can of Pringles. Once you pop you can't stop. No seriously, it becomes an addiction if you're not careful. I am just so impressed by the way you can mod this already considered dated game, into a beautiful new environment where you can relive the games greatest moments with in-game graphics that look like they belong in a game released today. (Either that or go completely silly, and make the game as weird as possible) Dislikes? I do not have any when it comes to Skyrim. This is surely a game for the RPG enthusiast, who also loves to hack-slash away at things too. Everyones experience playing Skyrim is different. I found the best way to play the game is to not just stick to the main quest and just go and explore the beautiful scenery and surprises it holds :)

review: This game, guys. For anyone who, in younger years, obsessed over Elder Scrolls while the rest of the world wondered what the hell was wrong with them, this game represents a cure. Few heard of Morrowind in my hometown. None had beaten it. Three or four classmates knew of Oblivion, and only two got past the battle of Kvatch. I honestly thought no one else could obsess over the series the way I had. Then came Skyrim. It wasn't Morrowind or Oblivion. It didn't need to be. Skyrim gave me more than gameplay, more than caves and barrows. It showed me there were others just as obsessed, just as excited to see the secrets hidden in the next ruin, the next chest, the next mission. Forget graphics. Forget story. Forget immersion. Skyrim is perfect because it showed me I wasn't alone. Beyond that, I can say nothing higher.

review: I adore this game, it really appeals to the role player in me. The graphics are stunning (if a bit same-y occaisionally), and I adore that I can customize it with mods members of the community have made. I do have an issue with it though. This is an issue I have with all the Elder Scrolls games, I don't like having to be led by the hand for the first half an hour. I like to just jump in and do what I want, rather than wait for the myriad of partial cut scenes to play out. I realize that it helps engage you in the storyline and give you a cursory understanding of the controls and mechanics, however I find it incredibly annoying. Other than that, it's a fabulously fun game. I really wish there was a way to play with your friends though, even if it was just over lan.
game-hours: 85.5
review: Having played over 1,000+ hours on console and now having picked up the PC version and getting to play around with some of the mods, I can now without a doubt say that this is my absolute favorite game... ever. This game has me at a loss for words to explain its "amazingness", it truly is a spectacular game. Graphics wise it is ever so slightly outdated but, not to the point where it is a pain, just some really low res textures here and there. The gameplay is incredible, out side of the melee combat which is a god-awful MS1 spamming pile of crap, that is compromised mainly of aiming your courser to make sure it hits and watching their health bar as you spam away. The in-game elements such as the magic and the "shouts" are very fun to play around with for example, one of the starting shouts, if not THE starter, "unrelenting force", allows you to ragdoll people to your heart's content, whether it be a bandit, or even giant naked men. Anyways, more to the point, this game is tons of fun if your someone who enjoys deep RPG experiences like myself, if you are someone who likes more fast-paced and more linear games, or basically any genre that isnt RPG, I'd still say give this a try, you never know.

I can run through the woods on my way to work on a quest, and I find a bandit lair, which is actually a huge dungeon, start up another story line from it, and then go back to my other quest. It's amazing. The reason that I even bought Skyrim in the first place was only from the repeated nagging of my friends. I got the legendary edition because this was during the big summer sale. I have no idea what the base game is like by itself. All I know is: being a vampire is awesome, and why would you choose to get the base game and not be a vampire, instead of spending a bit more and being a vampire? I know that I only have about 60 hours on record for Skyrim, so I may not be the best source for review, but I plan on gaining plenty more in the future, because this game is something that I could never have imagined. game-hours: 114.0
review: The latest installment to the elder scroll franchise (not counting online, as far as I know there are no provinces called "online" in tamriel), Skyrim is a big and beautiful yes gritty and restricted take on the elder scrolls series. It keeps plenty of elements people gamers loved from the older games but refined it to be more convenient to the player (dual wielding, alchemy and leveling). I think Skyrim's biggest flaw (and possibly the only thing stopping me from entitling it "better than oblivion") is that the quests just seem too generic. In Oblivion you may be tasked to find a man who has been taken to an isolated island, used for hunting fun by other people, but the twist is after you've been sent to the island, you become the next victim. In Skyrim, you may be told of a man who is trapped on an island being used as hunting fun by others, and you must go through a draugr infested cavern to get a specific item to get the guy back. Overall an amazing game which I need to play more of, 8/10 would slay dragons again

game-hours: 163.4
review: Some people find this game tiring because it's endless. That's precisely why it's the best one I've ever played. There are main quests, side-quests, an immense world to explore, you are free to do as you please, your actions or choices can have certain consequences, the expansions and mods just make the experience even more unforgettable, your character can become whoever you want it to be, no matter whether it's a peerless assassin, a mighty warrior or the most powerful sage. Or all of these. I love being able to decide which skills I want to train. As for the stories in the quests, I find them amazing and very interesting, and they just make me want more of Skyrim, especially the smaller quests. Details make the difference. The graphics are just beautiful, and the game itself is full of life (can be increased with mods, although these are not essential). If run on a desktop PC, the game can be enjoyed at its full capacity, but it can also run pretty smoothly on a good laptop. I'd definitely recommend it to people who look for the perfect equilibrium between adventure and exploring (action-visual enjoyment), and to make their own path without the game building it for them.

game-hours: 245.6
review: Man, oh man. Where can I begin with this game? It's epic in proportion, production, immersion, emotion, frustration, elation, ...and other various 'tions that may or may not apply to you specifically. The story itself is really good, though now that I've played through the game at least a dozen times. It's kind of lost its luster to me, but that doesn't mean it's bad, just that now that I know what to expect, I have to really immerse myself in something different in order to not completely abandon the main quest chain. That doesn't subtract from the replay value at all, however, for a couple of reasons. First, like many open world games, Skyrim is the kind of game you can lose hours in just wandering about and never really doing anything. I devoted an entire playthrough (if you want to call it that) to leveling a hunter/gatherer type character, just roaming the countryside hunting animals and selling their meat and pelts. I'd stumble across landmarks and geographic features I had no idea existed, run into NPCs I had never met, and see the world through the eyes of a character who, for once, wasn't destined to save it. The second thing that gives this game seemingly endless replay value is the modding community. There are mods that improve, add, change, and overhaul just about any aspect of the game you can imagine. From epic DLC-sized quest mods like Falskaar and Wyrmstooth, to little details like better footprints in the snow. There are mods that completely overhaul the perk system, and total conversion mods like the Game of Thrones Adaptation mod. The possibilities are nigh endless and the end result is often very very enjoyable. At the time of writing this review, Steam says 207 hours played. That doesn't count the non-steam version of the game I played for at least as long, if not longer. I find myself coming back over and over again, and each time I do, I discover something new to do. If you haven't yet, do yourself a favor and play this game.
game-hours: 410.4
review: Wonderful, wonderful game. Everything it was hyped up to be. With the ability to mod this game (on PC), this game really has so many possiblities and extras that will have you playing over and over again. There really aren't many games that have the type of re-playability that Skyrim has (even if it's not modded), and that's what makes this game incredible. It's arguably one of the top games of all time.

game-hours: 356.2
review: My experience: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is one of my most played and favourite game. I first got Skyrim for the Playstation 3 when it came out in 2011. I was bad at first, (I was new to rpg games), but after a while I got used to how the game works and I was having the time of my life. I only played the dragon born quests and that's all I did, I thought with just that ammount of quests to do, it was brilliant. Next I got it for the Xbox 360, and the same went from there. Once I was introduced to PC gaming back at the end of 2012, I got this game with a weak pc (compared to my current build). Pardon my french, but I ing love Skyrim on pc. Into the review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is a continued franchise from the game Oblivion. This game has a ton of paths you can follow which makes the game even better with sides you can pick depending on what role you pick. For example you can join the college of winterhold which is a college for mages. Keep in mind that you can do the mages quests even if you are a rouge or a warrior, it's just there for the role players I think. ^^ You can fully customise your character to your liking from skills to face, hair etc. You can smith armour, weapons. You can enchant your armour and weapons to have the extra punch for your heath, stamina, magika etc. With enchanting weapons you can get, drain heath, frost damage, fire damage etc. To learn these enchantments you need to find items with these enchantments and destory them by using a arcane enchanter. You also require soul gems to enchant weapons and armour. When I was playing this game like I said before I thought this game was brilliant just by playing the dragon born quests, not even the side quests, but when I started to fully flush out all sides, mains and quests for the dark brotherhood, college of winterhold etc. You should play though the game and do all of the quests. This gives you plenty to do in this game if you do that. From doing this I have a character that has played 80+ hours and 50+ hours. Just shows if you play the game like that, you will have a lot of time capped onto it. This game is famous on pc for the mods. In my opinion even from jumping to console to pc I still thought this game looked kinda dull, but when I looked at the mods that are availible you can totally change this game. I have many mods installed, such as lighting and fx mod, better vampires, focus mod and enhanced blood. The mods that change the way the game looks you should make sure you are running on a up to date system with the hard ware capable of running this game. I have a i7 and a GTX760 and even with these fx and lighting mods this game runs amazing on ultra settings and 60 fps. This game has a huge ammount of content which will just keep you playing for a long time. Story line: As most of you will know, you start the game as a prisoner of the Empire. You are about to be killed and a dragon attacks giving you a second chance to run and live. You end up heading to a city called whiterun and you have to collect a dragon stone for the jarl's wizard. You then get told to kill a dragon near by. You kill it and you absorb the power from it and you find out that you are a dragon born. A person that has the power to permanently kill a dragon by absorbing it's power. DLC: Dawnguard: Dawnguard is a dlc which lets you to chose to either become a vampire hunter or to become a vampire. With the dawnguard dlc, you have a all new power to become a "vampire lord" This lets you turn into a vampire lord and use two spells, drain life or raise the dead to fight for you. Keep in mind that to start this quest, at level 10 a member of the dawnguard will come up to you and ask you if you want to become a vampire hunter. You find a vampire called serana, you take her home and a vampire lord called Harkon gives you a choice. To accept the gift of the vampire lord or to be hunted like all mortals. If you decline you will be on the dawnguards side, if you accept you will be on the vampires side. Dragon born: I do not have much experience with this dlc but I can give you a general idea. This dlc lets you explore a whole new area with new places to explore, a whole new quest line, and more shouts to add to your collection. You meet the first dragon born called miraak. He is much, much more powerful than you with more shouts etc. You're quest is to kill him and end his madness. Hearthfire: This dlc is much more cheaper than dawnguard or dragon born. This completely changes the experience of having a house. You can have children live in your house, they will ask to play games, to keep pets, ask for things and even ask for gold! The biggest part to this dlc is that you can buy land and create your own house with all the availible items you can create. Overall: Overall I think this game is amazing and I reconmmend this game to anyone who wants a game with a lot of content and people who love rpg games. 10/10

review: (Don't mind the gameplay time, i have over 1000h here, but most offline) Pros: +Graphics (there's even a free DLC containing new particles) +Storyline (not only the main story is immersive, the ammount of side quests helps fill in the details) +Longterm (so, the main quest can be finished after some long hours, i finished mine in 50h+-, but doing some sightseeing, but you get lots of stuff to do and see during your journey, that can add up more 200h, or more) +Tamriel Story (so, if you are a fan of The Elder Scrolls series, this is set in a different era than the others titles, so you will know lore you didn't in the others games of the series) Cons: -Some bugs (what would be a open world RPG without some bugs, most are small things, walking over a pot, and it flies way, if it is in a certain position, for example, but not to worry, most of them do not affect gameplay) -Longterm (i know i said this in pros, but it is also a con for some people. Yes, you need to spend some time here, this is not a 1 day game, so, if you like short games, this is not for you) Finally, the game in my opinion is 9/10, a must buy, with or without the DLC's

game-hours: 1664.1
review: One of the most addicting games I have ever played. The total time spent playing this game is greater than the combined play time of every other game in my collection, by a wide margin. Being an Elder Scrolls fan since the days of Morrowind, I can easily admit that Skyrim often feels smaller in scale than the island of Vvardenfell. However, what Skyrim seems to lack in scale, it more than makes up for in fine details. Though I have been playing it almost since Day 1, I still have not explored all that it has to offer. Now, one of the most important requirements for truly enjoying this game is patience. There will be bugs, crashes, etc., but if you have the patience to adapt your playstyle to compensate for these issues (and install the unofficial patches), you will have a relatively problem-free gaming experience that cannot be substituted by any other game. I highly recommend giving this game a try.

game-hours: 28.5
review: If you don't ever play this game , you don't know what you lost :)
game-hours: 15.3
review: By now, most people have somewhere down the line heard of Skyrim, or been a fan of it from the beginning of the Elder Scrolls series. I came in about half-way through it with Oblivion and just barely Morrowland but quickly caught onto the story and the hype which then ensued, I also go roped into been quite a fan of the series. I however feel that the hype was a little bit too high for Skyrim being the fifth installment. Now, I also feel that it fell down in a lot of places and due to the colossal glorified image of what this series has turned out to have, these, for the most part, go un-noticed/not spoken about. A couple of the issues begin in the first five minutes of the game having you tied down from any kind of movement aside from looking around at a quite frankly, boring environment. Why you would be given the ability to do such is a little confusing to me but non the less, you continue on trying to look back and forth between these unknown characters info-dumping names and events that you have no idea of. Now, if you have played the game before and are just restarting, there is no option to allow you to skip these drawn out cutscenes. If you kick off the first 10-15 minutes of your game with a poorly done prisoner thing, being ridiculously scripted, it's going to end badly for the person playing it. This then leads me to your character not even being on the list to be executed, and I'm pretty sure people even in those days didn't act like that, but any who. Character customization comes up quite frankly at a random time during your ''execution'', obvious spoiler to the fact you aren't going to be killed, another poor choice in my personal opinion. Now, unlike most games which at least allow you to change what your character looks like after the initial make, Skyrim does not give you this luxury. Among those issues, we have the excruciatingly long load times far too often, generally after you have spent an agonizingly long time traveling through dull and bland environments. For a game that is going to make you spend most of your time travelling by foot, horse, or horse and cart as a means to ''fast-traveling'', it really lacks in making your surroundings immersive. What you then have to deal with is a compass style pointer which ends up being quite inaccurate and quite frustrating when you find yourself in a dead end path, or in-front of an un-climbable mountain that makes you backtrack for another 5 or so minutes before getting on a path in what seems to be the right direction. Moving onto combat, honestly, it's terrible. Arrows feel way too weak, magic felt weak and sword combat is rough, unpolished and dull, due to the fact it's so unrewarding, you get the occasional execution blurred slow-motion scene and even that feels really drowned. Among that, battling dragons is an utter nightmare, you so much as breathe in the wrong direction of an NPC and you will suddenly find yourself looking like a porcupine from all the cranky trigger happy people shooting you in the face with arrows, or have a club dropped on your head by a giant. Then wolves, don't even get me started. Wolves attack at random, and *All* the time, now unless they are starving, they shouldn't generally attack in the real world, making these just another nuisance along your drawn out travels. Item weight. Now.. I don't know how this was thought to be a good idea, I mean, at first I tried to see it as being a realistic element to the game, but.. really it turned out to be complete . Being stuck far from anywhere you can offload valuable items that you freshly acquired from looting or killing something, suddenly you are walking like you have a couple of fully loaded semi trailers on your back. My argument lies with the fact the game has you running around shouting Fus Ro Dah, throwing fire from your hands, getting your bow out and pewpewing arrows at a thick skinned flying dragon until it's dead, it strayed far away from the realism long ago, making this mechanic just frustrating. Considering you can wield power.. A magic horse whistle would be nice or a horse marker to show where you left your four legged friend and transport. Cause if you loose your horse, chances are it's going to be hell to find it again. Speaking of loosing, it brings me to your inventory. The way it's sorted, I feel is far more optimized for a console rather than PC, finding things can be a right pain going back and forth through the preset groups are and trying to figure out what will be where in the mist of combat. Unless you download the mod SkyUI which makes it much easier to deal with such things. Thank you steam workshop! Finally, silly glitches that still have not being ironed out let alone addressed. Mind you, despite all of which I have complained about, I can still find enjoyment in the game. I enjoy that it has different paths in the main missions, different factions you can join, other side missions that give you rewarding bonuses. When a game gives you different ways to go about things, it gives it so much more depth and it's something that I would love to see more of. It has a diverse array of plants and herbs which you can harvest throughout the lands you traverse giving it a bit more feel and depth to the environment around you it then gives you the ability to craft them into potions and other alchemy things. It has a really nice selection of foods to restore health, and honestly are quite aesthetically pleasing in of itself. Armors are utterly gorgeous and give decent bonuses to different kinds of players, despite the fact that they always cover up the character that if you're anything like me, spent a couple of hours on alone. Storyline is quite in depth, has a good feel and gives you plenty of hours to invest into completion of the game, it's not just a couple of hours and you're done, no, this takes a lot of time and effort and it keeps you entertained and busy enough to want to continue on through main missions. Some of which can be a bit tedious, but others have amazing resonance to them. One of my personal favorites has to be joining the Dark Brotherhood. The game adds to all of this by throwing in a diverse array of enemies which differ from each area you travel through, such as finding camps of hunters, thieves, outlaws, giants, other known and unknown creatures. All in all, I do recommend Skyrim even with it's few failings it makes a good game in whole.
game-hours: 32.7
review: Too much water 11/10
game-hours: 68.9
review: I Banged a dragon. 10/10 Epic Game
game-hours: 59.9
review: Skyrim is almost everything you'd want in an open free-roaming world. There really isn't a correct way of playing the game and it's up to the player in how he want to approach the game. Do you want to be like a Demigod were every enemy encounter is a breeze? Or do you want them all to be challenging? There are a lot of ways of playing this game, and I'd wager for the most fun the player shouldn't be afraid to vary his gameplay style. Imposing your own artificial limitations can go a long way of making the game more enjoyable, such as don't use Fast Travel, don't use the Compass to navigate, don't focus solely on maxing out Enchanting or Smithing first, et cetera. That said, the game is a masterpiece were the sum of its part far outweigh the parts itself, which shows. The voice acting is the best in the series so far, but it doesn't really say much. Voices are still repeated on a regular basis, which some might feel breaks the immersion. The main quest feels empty and boring, as does most of the quests of the guilds. Overall, the feeling of being "special" and treated as such is too obvious. Regardless of what line of quests you want to do, you'll pretty much end up being labeled as SPECIAL early on, and an early non-worthy prize awaits you after a few simple quests. Gone is the struggle of advancing through the ranks of a Guild in order to succeed. Discussing were the elements of the game fails can take all day as Skyrim contains a lot of very different elements, which all feels lacking in one way or another. Yet this doesn't stop the game from feeling like a masterpiece. It's fun, it's immersive, it allows players to customize their gaming experience and offers an extremely high level of freedom. The attention to detail in the world is amazing, and it's a wonderful experience just exploring the world in your own pace. Is Skyrim a GOTY of 2011? Yes, I truly think so. Though is it a 10/10? No, while it's great, it isn't perfect. There's A LOT of faults in the game, though while frustrating or disruptive at times, these doesn't stop you from enjoying the rest of the game.

review: I was incredibly late to this game, i enjoyed the fallout games a lot however Skyrim struck me as a little boring due to its reliance on melee. The fantasy aspect also reminded me a lot of WOW, which i have never been a fan of. I was wrong on both counts. Bethesda have created a masterpiece with Skyrim. It looks fantastic and plays even better. The voice acting is excellent. Involving the player at every junction. The important story driven mission are delivered with seriousness and polish, and the next you could be in town and one of the guards will be really cheeky. The depth of this game is also incredibly comprehensive. It will take you hours to even get started. The map is huge, and the expansion packs add even more. On top of the size of the map the towns and cities have lots of NPCs that you can interact with, some give you information and others give you missions. The leveling system is also a little different but actually makes sense. Instead of getting XP just for finding a location (a la fallout) you now only level up but using or doing the act you want to increase. so if you wanna be a deadly archer you have to use the bow. If you want to get better at talking to merchants and getting a better price for the stuff you buy and sell you have to buy and sell and improve the skill over time. this system is also handy because it means bethesda haven't included a level cap. I could go on and on about this title but i would end up spoiling it, if your looking for a top notch title with so much going on you will never be bored then buy this. An instant classic. 10/10

game-hours: 1664.1
review: One of the most addicting games I have ever played. The total time spent playing this game is greater than the combined play time of every other game in my collection, by a wide margin. Being an Elder Scrolls fan since the days of Morrowind, I can easily admit that Skyrim often feels smaller in scale than the island of Vvardenfell. However, what Skyrim seems to lack in scale, it more than makes up for in fine details. Though I have been playing it almost since Day 1, I still have not explored all that it has to offer. Now, one of the most important requirements for truly enjoying this game is patience. There will be bugs, crashes, etc., but if you have the patience to adapt your playstyle to compensate for these issues (and install the unofficial patches), you will have a relatively problem-free gaming experience that cannot be substituted by any other game. I highly recommend giving this game a try.

game-hours: 247.4
review: An epic game made all the more epic by the fact that it is so easy to mod and so well supported by the modding community. The Elder Scrolls series has a large following and often you will hear people argue over each new TES game comparing it to the last, but for me each TES game stands on its own merits, and Skyrim is no exception. The story is pretty good and there are plenty of side quests, but what makes Skyrim so great even when not modded is its large and open nature. This is a land you can just pick a direction and with no quest in mind and just explore. You will find danger and excitement on your journey ... and loot. Lots and lots of loot. But once you start modding this game, that is when you unlock the true value that is Skyrim. Potentially thousands more hours content (for free) in a game that can be improved ten thousand different ways from graphics, textures and sounds all the way to game mechanics and user interface changes. You can make the game exactly what you need it to be, and play it for so long you may still be playing when the next game in this series comes out.... and sometimes longer than even that. If you are interested in modding the PC version of the game, be sure to check out my guide for beginners:

game-hours: 92.5
review: I was stacking books on a shelf in my house in Whiterun, one of Skyrim's major cities, when I noticed a weapon rack right beside it. I set a sacrificial dagger in one slot, an Orcish mace in the other. They were on display for nobody but me and my computer-controlled housecarl, Lydia, who sat at a table patiently waiting for me to ask her to go questing. The chest upstairs was reserved for excess weapons and armor, the bedside table for smithing ingots and ores, the one next to the Alchemy table for ingredients. I'd meticulously organized my owned virtual property not because I had to, but because tending to the minutia of domestic life is a comforting break from dealing with screaming frost trolls, dragons, a civil war, and job assignments that never seem to go as planned. It's even a sensible thing to do; a seemingly natural component of every day existence in Skyrim, one of the most fully-realized, easily enjoyable, and utterly engrossing role-playing games ever made. Part of what makes it so enjoyable has to do with how legacy Elder Scrolls clutter has been condensed and in some cases eliminated. In Skyrim, there's no more moon-hopping between hilltops with a maxed out Acrobatics skill. That's gone, so is Athletics. The Elder Scrolls V pares down the amount of skills and cuts out attributes like Endurance and Intelligence altogether. There's no time wasted on the character creation screen agonizing over which skills to assign as major. You don't assign major and minor skills at all, but instead pick one of ten races, each with a specific bonus. High Elves can once a day regenerate magicka quickly, Orcs can enter a berserk rage for more effective close-range combat. These abilities are best paired with certain character builds  the High Elf regeneration is useful for a magic user  but don't represent a rigid class choice. Major decisions don't need to be made until you're already out in the world and can try out magic, sneaking and weapon combat, emphasizing first-hand experience over instruction manual study, letting you specialize only when you're ready. It contributes to the thrilling sense of freedom associated with life in Skyrim. Do a quest, kill a dragon, snatch torchbugs from the air, munch on butterfly wings or simply wander while listening to one of the best game soundtracks in recent memory. Despite the enormity of the world and the colossal amount of content contained within, little feels random and useless. Even chewing on a butterfly wing has purpose, as it reveals one of several alchemical parameters later useful in potion making at an alchemy table. Mined ore and scraps of metal from Dwemer ruins can be smelted into ingots and fashioned into armor sets, pelts lifted from slain wildlife can be turned into leather armor sets, and random books plucked from ancient ruins can trigger hidden quest lines that lead to valuable rewards. Skyrim's land mass is absolutely stuffed with content and curiosities, making every step you take, even if it's through what seems like total wilderness, an exciting one, as something unexpected often lies just over the next ridge. Many times the unexpected takes the form of a dragon. Sometimes they're purposefully placed to guard relics, sometimes they swoop over cities and attack at seemingly random times. In the middle of a fight against a camp of bandits a dragon might strike, screaming through the sky and searing foe and friendly alike with frost or flame. Momentarily all on the battlefield unite, directing arrows and magic blasts upward to knock down the creature, creating impromptu moments of camaraderie -- a surprising change from what may have been yet another by-the-numbers bandit camp sweep. Dragons show up often, their presence announced by an ominous flap of broad wings or an otherworldly scream from high above. The scale and startling detail built into each creature's appearance and animations as it circles, stops to attack, circles again and slams to the ground makes encounters thrilling, though their predictable attack patterns lessen the excitement after a few battles. In the long run they're far less irritating than the Oblivion gate equivalent from The Elder Scrolls IV, can be completed in a few minutes, and always offer a useful reward. Killing a dragon yields a soul, which powers Skyrim's new Shout system. These are magical abilities any character can use, you don't have to specialize in spell casting to slow time, throw your voice, change the weather, call in allies, blast out ice and fire, or knock back enemies with a rolling wave of pure force. Even if you favor sword, shield and heavy armor and ignore magic entirely, you'll still be able to take full advantage of these abilities provided you find the proper words  each Shout has three  hidden on Skyrim's high snowy peaks and in the depths of forgotten dungeons, serving as another reason to continue exploring long after you've exhausted the main quest story, joined with the Thieves Guild, fought alongside the Dark Brotherhood, or thrown your support behind one of the factions vying for control of Skyrim. Not only is this land under assault by dragons, long thought to be dead, it's also ripped in two by civil war. You can choose one side or the other, but so much of the allure of Skyrim is how, even outside of the confines of quest lines, the embattled state of the world is evident, and steeped in a rich fictional legacy. Lord of the Rings this is not, but with the release of every Elder Scrolls game, the fiction becomes denser, and the cross-referencing for long-time fans all the more rewarding. Skyrim's residents are all aware of current events. They'll comment on the civil war, some sympathizing with the rebels, others thinking the establishment sold its soul. The peasants complain about the Jarls who control each settlement, the Jarls complain about the rebels or foreign policy, the overprotective College librarian complains when I drop dragon scales all over his floor; many characters feel like whole, distinct personalities instead of vacuous nothings that hand out quests like a downtown greeter hands out flyers for discount jeans. Characters stereotype based on race, they double-cross at even the slightest hint it might be profitable, and they react to your evolving stature within the world. It makes a ridiculous realm, filled with computer-controlled cat people and humanoid reptiles, demon gods and dragons, feel authentic, like a world that existed long before you showed up and will continue to exist long after you leave.

game-hours: 290.5
review: Okay, first off, the bad. One, they got rid of Athletics and Acrobatics (why does everyone hate those skills!?) which means that your wizard runs the same speed as your thief, who runs at the same speed as your warrior (assuming they have the same encumbrance/armor weight). That's a bit silly. Two, you can basically do EVERYTHING. This isn't the elder scrolls where you have to specialize in one thing (epic sneaky thief, tough warrior, powerful wizard, strange ized custom class that you made back in Oblivion with Speechcraft and Hand to Hand). Every character I have, I want them to specialize, but it's too darn easy just to find yourself slipping and doing other things. It's SO difficult to be a wizard when a good mash in the face with a warhammer does it a lot faster. Now the good. Basically, everything. Not as big as Daggerfall or Arena, not as fantasty-ish as Oblivion, not as alien and gritty as Morrowind, but strangely, it's able to hold its own. A sizeable continent that will take you a long while to fully explore. Dragons (finally!) and their shouts are both in here. Zombies and Rats (the mainstay of RPGs) are gone, but replaced with Draugr and Skeevers, which are even more terrifying and not at all oh-I'll-just-hack-my-way-through. With Dawnguard they add nice buffs to vampires, a cool questline, crossbows (finally! But still no spears from Morrowind...) and this really sick looking armor. With Hearthfire, well... if you like to RP your character, get it. If you like combat and stuff, don't. I enjoyed it though. It lets you build a house yourself, adopt children, and occasionally defend your home from bandits and robbers and giants. I haven't gotten the Dragonborn expansion, but it takes place in Morrowind. MORROWIND. Bloody hell, that game is amazing, and now you can go back there in better graphics. It shall be mine soon.... And if the game gets boring (it does after a while (read: about 2 months), but don't worry. Take a week off, and when you come back you somehow love it all over again).... two words. Steam Workshop. Mods. Mods as far as the eye can see. More spells, new armor, hypothermia and sickness (finally! In a game about cold you'd just think SOMEONE would make it...), even new quest lines or completely new areas to explore. Moonpath to Elswyr is a gem that shows how awesome mods can be. Or you can just get one that allows you to go IMA FIRIN' MAH LAZER and blow shizz up. Your choice.

I realize that it helps engage you in the storyline and give you a cursory understanding of the controls and mechanics, however I find it incredibly annoying. review: Elder Scrolls Skyrim is the sequel to the Morrowind amd Oblivion games that takes place in Skyrim area. It is an awesome game that everyone that considers himself a gamer has to play, its a must! I personally have over 100 hours on the game and i really feel that i havent spend much time on it! Graphics/Art: The graphics of Skyrim are very good but not great. But there is a catch! Skyrim is the most Modable game of all! That means you can install any mode you want and literally transform the game into something awesome! If your system can take much you can install high resolution textures and custom water / sky and land elements with glows and blurs that will literally blow your mind! The artwork iself is very good as it presents the medieval ages and has some awesome soundtracks that make the game feel epic! Go buy a surround system and play the game on full volume! Gameplay: The gameplay differes from player to player and it depends on what you like. There are no limitations on what you can do in the game or how to do it! The combat is clearly action style and you need to have skills in order to survive (considering you play the game on hard mode)! By installing mods as i mentioned before in the graphics section you can add features on the gameplay like riding a dragon! Its a game that you will enjoy its gameplay even after 300 game hours! You never get bored of it as there are countless things to do around! Plot: The games plot is awesome as you follow the story of the dragonborn to save the world from the evil dragons! You can chose your own path as you can make decision on what questline you want to follow. Its your choise to kill the dragon or joining the thieves guild! The DLC's also add some awesome extra quests and content like becoming a vampire lord / having a vampire servant and a whole new questline and areas. Skyrim is a game that worth every penny! You will play countless hours and you will be amazed by it! I bought mine Game of the Year edition for 11 euros from steam sales! Keep in mind that the DLC make a big difference on the questline and the content!

review: Epic game! review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Review Say good-bye to real life Pros: +The world is HUGE! Probably one of the, if not the, biggest open world games ever +Graphics are great, even 3 years after its release, and mods make them amazing +There are hundreds of different playstyles to choose from so YOU get to play YOU want +Although the main storyline is a bit short, there are hundreds, if not thousands of side quests, guild quests, and miscellaneous tasks to keep you busy +Over the 2 1/2 years of Steam Workshop integration, the community has put out 20,000+ mods, so as long as there are new mods, the adventure NEVER ends! +One of the few games I've played where I can say that the DLC isn't a ripoff +Every thing in the game is exhilerating, from simply trotting across the countryside on your horse and admiring the beautiful view to being in an intense fight with a massive fire-breathing dragon +The console commands in the base game make for great fun :) (Ex. spawning werewolves to attack a village or becoming a dragon) Cons: -As with games this big, there are quite a lot of bugs and glitches. review: I both recommend and don't recommend Skyrim. I recommend because gameplay is fun (modded), it's kinda fun to fight dragons (modded), and the world is huge (bigger when modded). I don't recommend because the graphics are really ugly without pretty heavily modding the game, and parts are still broken requiring additional mods...basically, the entire game relies almost entirely on mods to be anything you were expecting from The Elder Scrolls. The final reason I don't recommend is because you would have to give Bathesda money for a game that is only any good because unpaid fans of the franchise have made it the game it should have been in the first place.

review: Mod it, love it, play it. A downright beautiful game that edges near reality with mods. If you enjoyed Morrowind or Oblivion you will definitely enjoy Skyrim. Skyrim does cater to the more casual gamer as even on higher difficulties (sans Legendary) it really isn't hard. However this too can be modded. The lore is deep, and spread all throughout the sandbox and its extended areas. Just when you thought you had been to every corner of the map, you will find somewhere new to explore. At a rushed pace you can still spend hundreds of hours completing everything there is to do in the base game and its DLC. Once you are done with that, you can add more with the very active modding community's labors. Rating: 7/7 Recommended price: Under $30.00

The way I play this game won't be like everyone else's and what I enjoy, might not be for others. All in all, try to put yourself in the footsteps of your character and feel that you're in the amazing world of Skyrim.

game-hours: 202.3
review: As we have come to expect from the last ES title "Oblivion" and the more recent Fallout 3 / NV, Bethesda have put together a game of epic proportions, large characters with stories, deep mechanics with no gimmick. It's a sandbox game with a first and third perspective camera, good hand to hand, armed, ranged and magic combat and strong character progression, but the best part is that it's all modable with TES editor. And yet I don't play this game, not nearly as much as Oblivion the last in the series. While the game has fewer sticking points for me than Oblivion I'd highlight the heavy theme as somewhat over played, if the game was more subtle and had more humor to it, I might find myself playing it more. I still recommend this, but not as highly as Oblivion.

game-hours: 19.7

game-hours: 160.8
review: THE best game of this generation. I originally played this on PS3, but switched to PC after 130 hours of play. The vanilla game is fantastic; 1st or 3rd person, open-world with plenty of quests and characters to talk and fight with, dismal-yet-beautiful environments and comfortable fighting mechanics (for both PC and PS3). The story is not the best I've seen in gaming, but Skyrim's strengths are what you can do within the game, and how customisable the game is for content. You can kill enemies and friends alike, marry and live with an NPC, build houses (with DLC), cast magic spells, make your own weapons and armor, mine resources, brew your own potions, explore dungeons, canverns, temples and mountaintops. Plus absorb the souls of dragons. While there are still a few bugs in the game (it's Bethesda, expect them), there is plenty of patches and content created to fix and enhance the game. There are more mods for this game than any other game that I know of, and more are still being made. If you get sick of vanilla Skyrim, try out a mod - it will change the way you play (for better or sometimes worse). Every character you make, every new game you play, will be different. You will always have fun.

If you are a max-min player you can make deadly one hit kill weapons and impenetrable armor (and then set it to hardest difficulty) or literally spend hours decorating the over 8! houses you can own the the game. The mods alone add LITEARLLY hundreds of hours of NON-REPETITIVE PLAY. This is the benchmark that all other RPG's should be set to. Bethesda took their greatest strengths from Fallout and implemented them into ES. Nuff said.

game-hours: 558.9
review: Hands down this is my favorite adventure/RPG I've ever played. Being highly customizable with community mods is what keeps me coming back to this gem. The graphics are stunning and the gameplay is top notch. Just like when purchasing a car, I judge games I play on how they "feel." When I play this game, I can get lost in its world for hours at a time. While the gameworld itself has vast depth, the story itself is lackluster. Bethesda has a habit of making interesting and deep worlds, but shallow characters and storylines. If they could master how to make characters feel real and like your character is PART of an unfolding story, rather than the centerpiece by which the world revolves around, I would probably quit my job and play their games without eating, drinking, and/or defacating. Myself and my couch would become one and together we would rule Tamriel together.
