game-hours: 300.4
review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is an amazing singleplayer RPG game that just has to be in your steam library. The game is so huge and open world that any other RPG will seem pretty small. I played Skyrim on my PS3 about 2000 hours even though I have it on PC. You play as a Dragonborn(Dovahkiin) that is a man with a soul of a dragon. Game's main story is awesome and the best thing is there are so much guilds and faction that you can join(Dark Brotherhood, Companions, College of Winterhold and so on) that will NEVER make the game boring. Also there are 3 DLCs that are just amazing and bring new items, characters, weapons and even new places to the original game. Now, best thing of them all is that there are thousands of mods that just make the game so good that you won't be able to stop playing it. Some mods like Falskaar, Moonpath to Elsweyr even offer you new maps and locations which is just AWESOME. No matter what type of gamer you are you have to play this game, it's just fantastic. RATING 11/10

game-hours: 584.5
review: Skyrim is an open world first person hack and slash. The fifth game in The Elder Scrolls series. THE STORY The plot starts well enough. Dragons are coming back after years of non-existence. You are the Dragonborn. A powerful warrior/mage/thief/spellsword/archer (whatever the hell you want to be) who must fight against the dragon menace. As the Dragonborn you are the only one who can stop it. Its the old 'chosen one' story line again. The main quest line is far too short and basic. At one point the plot looks to be more than it is, but in the end its very disappointing. Luckily Skyrim is huge due to a ton of side quests. A lot of these are story arcs that have interesting sub plots of their own and are not all fetch quests. STARTING YOUR JOURNEY So how do you start? Ironically you're on your way to execution. Once you arrive at Helgen for the chop, you get to choose your race. There are 10 to choose from, ranging from different humans and elves, to an orc, argonian lizard person and a giant . The main racial differences are the level skills start at, the race's 'greater power' and any resistances they have. Your starting greater power is unique to your race. You can use them once a day. Redguard's for example can regen stamina 10x faster. Part of what makes them a good warrior's choice. Race choice doesn't necessarily dictate your play style, however they are all that bit better at something. For example the Redguard's melee oriented skills start at a higher level. Another feature that makes for a great warrior. You could easily choose to make him a mage. Its just that your magic skills start lower than your average elf and your greater power has no use for a mage. MAKING YOUR WAY IN THE WORLD So obviously the game isn't 5 minutes long and you've not actually been executed. You get a clear direction to head in when you start. You're not just dumped on this giant continent without a clue of what to do. Before you can fast travel via your map you'll have to discover locations on foot. Exploring the world is a lot of the fun. On your way to a quest but have happened upon a spooky crypt? Delve inside and loot the place! Or ignore it (coward). The greatest part of Skyrim is choice. Do what you want when you want. Some quests have two different choices. This is normally the choice between being good and being a complete . Once you have enough septims you can buy a horse. These can be killed so take care of them. There are also horse carriages you can pay to ride if the initial lack of fast travel irritates you. I do encourage exploration though. You'll meet many characters on your quests. Characters are where a lot of the flaws come in. Silly behaviours like shouting their life stories at you as you run up the road, or not reacting to a dead body you drag around/dump on their camp fire. Its bad for immersion but it only interfered with gameplay once for me. SKILLS Skills are divided into the warrior, mage and thief categories. Each skill has its own small skill tree. To level up a skill you perform actions relating to that skill. Striking a foe with my war axe levels up the one handed tree, while getting hit in heavy armour levels up that particular tree. When you level up a skill you gain xp towards your character's actual level. That's right, you don't get xp through simply killing (unless by killing you level up an offensive skill), you have to increase your skill levels. Once you get a new character level you gain a perk point. There is no actual cap on character level. There are mostly passive perks on offer, but there is the odd cool ability like decapitation. Smithing, enchanting and alchemy skills allow you to make and improve your own gear and potions. With smithing and enchanting the flaws in the levelling system become apparent. In order to level up smithing I have to craft tons of gear that I'm never going to use that sells for pittance. Having to gather up masses of materials and make all this stuff, sell and repeat may not be frustrating, but its not fun either. Having to use up my soul gems to fuel enchantments on weapons and armour I'm just going to sell/throw in a river? Needless waste. STATS Before choosing your perk you have to choose which stat to increase. Magicka, health and stamina are your choices. This stat choice combined with no respec option (there are two such options for skills) adds to the replay value. My Redguard has next to no magicka to fuel spells. This means I can't just become a powerful mage and choose to abandon my axe. I'd have to roll a new character and concentrate on magicka. This prevents having a single jack of all trades to do all the content with. COMBAT Melee combat consists of fast strikes, power strikes blocking and bashing. Some would say melee combat is too simplistic but I don't think it needs to be complicated to be fun. Archery is another option. Nothing beats the feeling of successfully leading a long distance kill shot. If stealth is more your thing there are skills that give massive damage bonuses for sneaking kills. Successful sneaking requires you to stay quiet and out of sight. The lighter your armour the less noise you make. Daggers make no noise when you swing them. Combine all these factors to become a deadly assassin and dirty thief. Mages have many schools of magic at their disposal. Destruction magic deals damage, conjuration summons pets from Oblivion (basically like separate planes of hell). You can even alter the mental state of your foes if utilising the illusion school of magic. Restoration heals (even my Redguard makes use of this) and alteration protects you. Two spells can be cast/ready at the same time. One for each hand. You could summon an atronach with your left hand and cast stoneflesh with your right. Or you could use flames in both hands to amplify the damage. SLAYING DRAGONS Part of your Dragonborn identity is learning the thu'um. Thu'um's are shouts in the dragon language that produce magical effects. These shouts are usually attacks. Fire and frost breath, knock back (the famous FUS RO DAH!) and even a freaking lightning storm! There are three words to a shout. The more words you learn the more powerful the shout. Learning the word of a shout first requires finding the word wall where it is written (in most cases). After that you need a dragon soul to power it. That means taking down a scaly beast. A little way into the game dragons will spawn here and there. Typically they'll fly around, then land or hover to fire their chosen thu'um. In melee dragons will bite or slap you about with their tail. Before you're geared up to the eyeballs they can be challenging. However at later levels they are too easy. This is where mods come in handy (more on that later). People who find them too easy at earlier levels should increase the difficulty during these encounters. The game's difficulty level can be changed at any point. DLC They're all worth it. Dawnguard and Dragonborn add huge amounts of content. Area's, quests, weapons, powers. I couldn't be without them. Hearthfire gives you awesome homes to display all your loot. Much better than the small houses. MODS Without mods Skyrim is 6/10. The plethora of bugs and annoyances that mods eliminate is massive. With just quality of life and graphical mods this game is 9.5/10. To truly enjoy Skyrim you have to at least mod the awful bugs out, and the great features in. I have high res textures, better models, a map with roads, the unofficial patches which fix literally hundreds of bugs and much more. Then there are all the content mods. New areas with quests, spell crafting, more dragon types etc. 99% of the time when I go to Skyrim Nexus wondering if they have the mod I want, they do! Don't doom yourself to a console level Skyrim experience! In closing, buy it, mod it, love it.

game-hours: 48.3
review: Chances are, If you were interested in Skyrim due to it being a sequal to Oblivion, you either have it already or passed after seeing how different it is. I, myself, played around 400 hours of Oblivion and only really stopped playing it to play Skyrim. Keeping that in mind, here's what I think. I really liked this game for a long time. After a while, though, the "magic" of discovery wore off, and I saw underneath what I realized to be the most shallow and bland game the Elder Scrolls series has to offer. Sure, finding all of those dungeons and Words of Power was a blast, but fighting the enemies while doing so felt more like a chore than anything. Even the well animated Cinematic kills got old after a while. Mods helped a bit with this problem, but overall I would rather the game be more, say, meaty. This was clearly a design descision, and is purely my personal prefrence, but damn did the fun drop off like a rock. Should you play Skyrim? Yeah man, it's $20 for ~150 hours of discovery and self-improvement and you can mod the  out of it pretty easily, but don't expect anything revolutionary out of it, like so many Elder Scrolls fans were.

review: What can I say that hasn't already been said? Purely open world. It means I can go anywhere, do anything, be anybody. I can be stupid rich or dirt poor. I can be a rescuer, errand boy, or dragon hunter. I can invite followers for company only to sacrifice them, or travel alone. I can put buckets on peoples' heads and take everything in their store/house. I can be a wearwolf and rip apart innocent bunnies. I can follow quests or I can murder entire villages - just because. And I can't even beging to describe the awesome creativity people bring to the workshop. Highly recommended game. You won't be disappointed.

review: A game made for exploring. A very large world that will take a ridiculous amount of time to see, especially if you include the DLC. The combat is pretty decent, and the questing is great. One thing you should do in this game is save often! If you don't you will almost certainly regret it when you go on a grand adventure, kill all the things and get all the loot, and then die or get stuck in a glitch. Be a shining hero, or the kind of person people are afraid of the moment they see you. The game has got a pretty good skill tree. I personally enjoy investing in stealthy areas. review: This game is straight out of 2011, but still holds up well to nowadays standards when keeping it Vanilla. All yours to choose. The game starts off with a heavily scripted event, where you're about to get killed, but freed due to a dragon's raid.  that- everyone knows that beaten path already. Anyway, vanilla is good from the quantity of things to do. Only thing that was painful for me was the skill grindfest. Now to the amazing part. You can chunk a ton of mods onto this game and it'll look better than recent releases, depending on how much your rig can handle. 2K textures? All there. 8K Dragons? All good. A ton of ENB shaders? Even better cinematics than the one console players defend. Though, Workshop is poorly done. Better grab only a few mods off there. Best methods are Nexus Mod Manager and Mod Organizer. If you're new to making games awesome, take it slow, or you might flip a table because you installed your ton of mods in the wrong order. Now, go play the beaten path everyone knows,  up the Dawnguard, and kill the Emperor with your cooking skills, and don't forget to get yourself a good enb.

review: I just can't get enough of this game, i'm always want some more. And you know what? You still not satisfied? There's 3 DLC with dragon riding, another Dragonborn, new shouts, vampires, wolverines, crossbows, dirty orphans which can be adopt, your own house which you can buy or build, and also marriage (not a greatest decision in your life, but still) waiting for you. And achievement hunting, of course! Trully 10/10

review: This game has become one of my favorites simply becuase of the almost boundless roaming freely, the DLC's (i have all), the mods, the gameplay, and graphics. It has great creatures roaming the lands, bandits, witches, demons, dragons, trolls, vampires, and werewoles. You can even become a vampire or a werewolf....unfortunately theres no hybrids between the two. Fortunately, though there are guilds you can join with their own quest. Those perks will benefit you very much with whatever weapons you choose/use. Theres even a such thing as "console commands"......in other words cheats. All-in-all, this is an excellent game to have, play, and to own.

review: An epic game made all the more epic by the fact that it is so easy to mod and so well supported by the modding community. The Elder Scrolls series has a large following and often you will hear people argue over each new TES game comparing it to the last, but for me each TES game stands on its own merits, and Skyrim is no exception. The story is pretty good and there are plenty of side quests, but what makes Skyrim so great even when not modded is its large and open nature. This is a land you can just pick a direction and with no quest in mind and just explore. You will find danger and excitement on your journey ... and loot. Lots and lots of loot. But once you start modding this game, that is when you unlock the true value that is Skyrim. Potentially thousands more hours content (for free) in a game that can be improved ten thousand different ways from graphics, textures and sounds all the way to game mechanics and user interface changes. You can make the game exactly what you need it to be, and play it for so long you may still be playing when the next game in this series comes out.... and sometimes longer than even that. If you are interested in modding the PC version of the game, be sure to check out my guide for beginners:

game-hours: 92.5
review: I was stacking books on a shelf in my house in Whiterun, one of Skyrim's major cities, when I noticed a weapon rack right beside it. I set a sacrificial dagger in one slot, an Orcish mace in the other. They were on display for nobody but me and my computer-controlled housecarl, Lydia, who sat at a table patiently waiting for me to ask her to go questing. The chest upstairs was reserved for excess weapons and armor, the bedside table for smithing ingots and ores, the one next to the Alchemy table for ingredients. I'd meticulously organized my owned virtual property not because I had to, but because tending to the minutia of domestic life is a comforting break from dealing with screaming frost trolls, dragons, a civil war, and job assignments that never seem to go as planned. It's even a sensible thing to do; a seemingly natural component of every day existence in Skyrim, one of the most fully-realized, easily enjoyable, and utterly engrossing role-playing games ever made. Part of what makes it so enjoyable has to do with how legacy Elder Scrolls clutter has been condensed and in some cases eliminated. In Skyrim, there's no more moon-hopping between hilltops with a maxed out Acrobatics skill. That's gone, so is Athletics. The Elder Scrolls V pares down the amount of skills and cuts out attributes like Endurance and Intelligence altogether. There's no time wasted on the character creation screen agonizing over which skills to assign as major. You don't assign major and minor skills at all, but instead pick one of ten races, each with a specific bonus. High Elves can once a day regenerate magicka quickly, Orcs can enter a berserk rage for more effective close-range combat. These abilities are best paired with certain character builds  the High Elf regeneration is useful for a magic user  but don't represent a rigid class choice. Major decisions don't need to be made until you're already out in the world and can try out magic, sneaking and weapon combat, emphasizing first-hand experience over instruction manual study, letting you specialize only when you're ready. It contributes to the thrilling sense of freedom associated with life in Skyrim. Do a quest, kill a dragon, snatch torchbugs from the air, munch on butterfly wings or simply wander while listening to one of the best game soundtracks in recent memory. Despite the enormity of the world and the colossal amount of content contained within, little feels random and useless. Even chewing on a butterfly wing has purpose, as it reveals one of several alchemical parameters later useful in potion making at an alchemy table. Mined ore and scraps of metal from Dwemer ruins can be smelted into ingots and fashioned into armor sets, pelts lifted from slain wildlife can be turned into leather armor sets, and random books plucked from ancient ruins can trigger hidden quest lines that lead to valuable rewards. Skyrim's land mass is absolutely stuffed with content and curiosities, making every step you take, even if it's through what seems like total wilderness, an exciting one, as something unexpected often lies just over the next ridge. Many times the unexpected takes the form of a dragon. Sometimes they're purposefully placed to guard relics, sometimes they swoop over cities and attack at seemingly random times. In the middle of a fight against a camp of bandits a dragon might strike, screaming through the sky and searing foe and friendly alike with frost or flame. Momentarily all on the battlefield unite, directing arrows and magic blasts upward to knock down the creature, creating impromptu moments of camaraderie -- a surprising change from what may have been yet another by-the-numbers bandit camp sweep. Dragons show up often, their presence announced by an ominous flap of broad wings or an otherworldly scream from high above. The scale and startling detail built into each creature's appearance and animations as it circles, stops to attack, circles again and slams to the ground makes encounters thrilling, though their predictable attack patterns lessen the excitement after a few battles. In the long run they're far less irritating than the Oblivion gate equivalent from The Elder Scrolls IV, can be completed in a few minutes, and always offer a useful reward. Killing a dragon yields a soul, which powers Skyrim's new Shout system. These are magical abilities any character can use, you don't have to specialize in spell casting to slow time, throw your voice, change the weather, call in allies, blast out ice and fire, or knock back enemies with a rolling wave of pure force. Even if you favor sword, shield and heavy armor and ignore magic entirely, you'll still be able to take full advantage of these abilities provided you find the proper words  each Shout has three  hidden on Skyrim's high snowy peaks and in the depths of forgotten dungeons, serving as another reason to continue exploring long after you've exhausted the main quest story, joined with the Thieves Guild, fought alongside the Dark Brotherhood, or thrown your support behind one of the factions vying for control of Skyrim. Not only is this land under assault by dragons, long thought to be dead, it's also ripped in two by civil war. You can choose one side or the other, but so much of the allure of Skyrim is how, even outside of the confines of quest lines, the embattled state of the world is evident, and steeped in a rich fictional legacy. Lord of the Rings this is not, but with the release of every Elder Scrolls game, the fiction becomes denser, and the cross-referencing for long-time fans all the more rewarding. Skyrim's residents are all aware of current events. They'll comment on the civil war, some sympathizing with the rebels, others thinking the establishment sold its soul. The peasants complain about the Jarls who control each settlement, the Jarls complain about the rebels or foreign policy, the overprotective College librarian complains when I drop dragon scales all over his floor; many characters feel like whole, distinct personalities instead of vacuous nothings that hand out quests like a downtown greeter hands out flyers for discount jeans. Characters stereotype based on race, they double-cross at even the slightest hint it might be profitable, and they react to your evolving stature within the world. It makes a ridiculous realm, filled with computer-controlled cat people and humanoid reptiles, demon gods and dragons, feel authentic, like a world that existed long before you showed up and will continue to exist long after you leave.

game-hours: 190.1
review: One of the best games ever created
game-hours: 26.1
review: My take on Skyrim. Hmmm, difficult to answer but I'll give it a go. From what I've played of Skyrim, it's great technically. The levelling up system works well and there's a real sense of adventure when you travel out to find new places. Finding your first dragon and facing off against it is just plain epic, especially with the Skyrim theme playing in the background. The graphics have greatly improved upon Oblivion and are far more realistic, (you'd expect it would be given the 5 year difference :P) and the landscapes are, quite simply, beautiful. The shadows, lighting and overall ambience in each location really brings you into the experience, without question and on higher systems is truly awesome. Gameplay-wise, it's pretty straightforward. Sword goes thwack, health goes down, guy dies, loot. Repeat. The exploration is cool and the fact that they've included more in the environmental design is cool too (different dungeons, caves and landscapes etc.) Levelling up is pretty easy too, by just putting a point into whatever you've been training. It is a bit on the easy side and very simple though, compared to Oblivion which was, kinda merciless if you didn't put the points into what was best at the time. Getting wrecked by a goblin at level 10 wasn't nice but it certainly was more challenging :P. What I didn't really like (having come from 300-400 hours of Oblivion) was that Skyrim is a very....simple game. There's not a lot of complexity to it and it mostly seems very....bleh. It might've been the way I played it but Skyrim always seems very much catered to a larger audience than Fantasy RPG players. It almost seems like the game can be unneccessarily cruel with certain points put into areas and that some points you can get pretty much destroyed no matter what skillpoints you've been applying to one or two key areas such as full blunt and light armour losing against bandits of the same calibre or bosses that end up stealing your health bar in two blows. But these, again, were probably just results of how I played the game. Anyhow, with what attempt I've just made there as a review, I would recommend that you play Skyrim, just as it is an epic game and worth the time, even just to check it out. Comparitively speaking, Oblivion gives you slightly more adventure as a game, even if a few years old now, but I wouldn't say no to Skyrim. If I had to give it a number I'd say Skyrim was a solid 7 if not 8 at times.

I recommend this game to those who have played the before 'The Elders of Scroll' series and those who like story oriented game.

review: Pros: vast, vast world to explore dungeons and caves are wonderfully differentiated graphics and sound are for the most part incredible to behold Cons: Combat isnt very visceral, and victories and losses feel unearned Menus and interface are terrible While the world is wide open, most quests and dungeons are very linear Bugs abound, especially with physics I won't rant on about this game so heres a summary of it: While Skyrim does almost nothing to address the weaknesses of its predecessors, it expands on the strengths to such an extent that even its most substantial flaws seem microscopic. You may not lose yourself in the unimaginative combat and story, but the world Bethesda has created is so huge and so beautifully realized that you wont care.

game-hours: 82.9

game-hours: 606.8
review: The world of Skyrim is huge...VERY huge. It's one of the biggest action-RPGs I have ever played and one of the best, ranking alongside Zelda: Twilight Princess. You can do practically anything to your heart's content which is something many modern RPGs tend to restrict the player of. The game's focus is not based on trudging through a tale where you get to watch from the sidelines. No, the game puts the focus and emphasis on YOU, the player. The actions and quests you do will greatly, and actually, affect the game progress a lot, mainly because YOU get to decide what you want to become. Want to be a thief and steal from the rich and powerful? You can. Want to be head Arch-Mage of the most powerful college in the realm? You can. Want to become a werewolf? You can. Want to kill everyone in town? YOU CAN...provided they aren't scripted to be invincible (one of the minor flaws in this game). The developers clearly put a lot of effort into making the world of Skyrim believable; from the highest mountaintop to down to the little things such as dungeon traps and lockpicking, you will never run out of things to do. One very major flaw, and this should be obvious to anyone who's played the game, is that with so much content, the game suffers heavily on the framerate side, especially during combat, even on the lowest settings. (I was able to get the Steam version running natively on my Mac using the CrossOver engine and it actually worked!) But don't let a frame hiccup stop you from playing one of the greatest RPGs of all time. Oh, and you get to fight DRAGONS! Who doesn't love fighting dragons? UPDATE: The recent CrossOver version (14.1.02) can now run Skyrim, which means I can play it again, along with all the mods and DLC! :)

game-hours: 278.1
review: A great RPG experience. Improves heavily on the mechanics of Oblivion. Skyrim provides hundreds of hours of gameplay and builds apon its predeceer (TES:Oblivion) Graphical Fidelity is sadly not the greatest in Skyrim but mods and ENBS are available to add to the experience. But the game makes up for this with lush landscapes and mightly mountians to explore. The environments range from Snowy Mountians to the sunny town of riverrun to the towering capital Solitudes Blue Palace. Outdoors environments help build the epic atmosphere of skyrim with wildlife and bandits. But best of all. Dragons. Fighting dragons is the pinnacle experience of the game as they approach from the sky you will have to use shouts. As the dragonborn, you can use these shouts to cast a dragon from the sky to the ground, breath fire and even freeze time. As the dragonborn your primary quest will be to save the world from the almighty dragon Alduin. But not just that, you can pursuit many more quests, you can just the dark brotherhood, become a mage, join the companions and even become a bard! Skyrim is a world so engrossing that its flaws are more than made up for with its impressive open world, immersive character development and amount of incredible content. I recommend this game to Everyone, Skyrim truly is an epic experience!

game-hours: 139.7
review: Play through it once legit, then abuse cheats the rest of the playthroughs.
game-hours: 566.4
review: I got it to about 600 mods over the course of a year. I had to reset to vanilla after an ENB broke. Great experience, whether or not you mod it. I would recommend modding the graphics with 2k textures if you have a high powered machine. I run Skyrim on my laptop, which has 16 GB RAM and Nvidia GTX 860 + 2 GB vRAM. I use the ultra setting, with 2k textures and many mods. It ran smoothly even with 600 mods, until the very end. Gameplay-wise, it is an amazing and immersive game, although the beginning is very boring and not very fun. If you commit to playing, you will love it. The main questline is nice, and has a good story, although it is very bread and butter and doesnt exactly give you a lot of the lore, it is fun to do. There are countless quests for you to do, and many game-changing decisions to be made. Although there is an abundance of quests which put you miles underground fighting zombies and monsters, there is a variety of overworld activity which is fun. If the quests grow boring, just walk around and talk to people, more interesting ones will emerge. As for fast travel, unless you are in an actual hurry or in a quest, I would advise strongly against using it, because it detracts from the gameplay and takes away from the feeling of wilderness. If there are elements of the game that you want, or dont like, or want to change, use mods. Get mods from the workshop or from nexus. But be very careful about what you are doing, take some tutorials, and especially when working with ENBs, make sure to look at the screenshots or videos provided. The customizable and individualistic character creation is what I love the most about this game. I had issues with the hair of my character, so I got a few mods adding hairstyles, and a mod for a barber shop, to help satiate my indecisivity. Again, when in doubt, MODS. Although there are no classes to choose from, you can choose from a variety of races, and master multiple traits and skills. Your character will usually start as a very bland warrior type, but eventually will flesh out to have many diverse skill sets based on how you play. If you do decide to get this game, a few pointers/heads-ups for basic gameplay. 1. Stepping on loose clutter can kill you if you have no armor on or if you are at a low level. 2. Save often, or you will beat your computer to pieces whenever you die. 3. Delete old saves from your save files periodically, to keep the game running smoothely. 4. If the game crashes on start, its a mod conflict. 5. Imperials > Stormcloaks. No matter what people say. 6. Never try to take on a giant. 7. Have fun. Save, kill someone, kill whole cities, and reload the save. Do weird . Its not all quests. 8. If a guard says "I know you." Press tab and run like hell. 9. Talk to everyone. This way you will get more quests. 10. Discover every location. This way you will get more quests. 11. Take the scenic route. This way you will get more quests, more enemy encounters, and discover more places. I'd rate the game 10/10. There are few games that earn my respect as much as this one. I can't wait for TES:VI!
game-hours: 33.1
review: You, Dovahkiin, Dragonborn, are the only person capable of stopping a vast conspiracy (involving dragons) that threatens the entire empire. You face enemies who have never known defeat and strive to destroy you, yet if you blow off the main quest nothing will happen. Along the way you will encounter some horrible AI, buggy graphics, and an awful physics engine. Oh yeah, there's also a civil war in Skyrim (which no one ever sees), a Mages Guild quest line, a band of Furry wolf quest line, a Thieves Guild quest line, an Assassins Guild quest line, and a cluster of pointless quests that are only there to create the illusion that the game has more content than a  main story, but nobody really cares about that. Tl;dr, you're an invulnerable powerhouse that saves the world with you having no say in the matter. You can also eat dragon souls. While there are  that actually think of Skyrim as an RPG, it's much better to compare it with any generic MMORPG like WoW: You are running around in an open world that doesn't react to your actions (except NPCs not respawning). You are doing linear, boring dungeons with trash mobs (having trash lewtz) and boss mobs (dropping phat lewtz). You're doing repetitive quests for people who barely know you, with less story than a generic WoW quest. You have to grind for hours to level alchemy, running around like a  collecting flowers, giant's toes, bees, bee hives, butterflies, torchbugs, human flesh, deer antlers, elven ears, spider eggs, , santorum, and other  just to mix them mindlessly, trying to get crystal meth out of it instead of crap. Because that wasn't enough MMOG in Oblivion, they also added smelting, smithing, and cooking to the game. However, there are two essential differences between Skyrim and an MMORPG: First of all, in Skyrim, you can't run to Solitude showing off with your shiny new armor. While the stupid annoying NPCs comment on everything - absolutely everything, ranging from a quest you finished three in-game months ago up to your high speechcraft level you got from selling all the lewtz you made - they don't give a ing  that you're running around dressed like a ing Daedra. Oh and of course, it has no multiplayer. Secondly, MMORPGs are actually balanced. In Skyrim, on Adept (the standard difficulty level), you will soon one-hit everyone and their mothers. On Master, you will still one-hit almost everyone - but everything else will one-hit YOU. Not to mention you can actually level smithing by crafting at least 100 iron daggers, with materials costing almost nothing, and because the smith sells iron bars and leather, you just have to wait 24 hours for his inventory to reset and craft moar. After you've crafted yourself some fine armor and weapons, there is actually nothing to do in the game any more. Even a stupid Daedra dagger is more powerful than any artifacts you may encounter on your adventures - and why exactly would you want to do boring quests in boring dungeons, if not for phat lewtz? In fact, Skyrim doesn't offer any qualities you could expect from a single-player game - such as a great story, good graphics, complex game design or just lots of cutscenes. Instead, they took the same line as most MMORPGs and failed miserably. Still, 7 million s proved you don't need to make quality - or even a working game - to make money. Skyrim also features automatic movement, so you can keep one foot on your mouse and your other foot on your . Don't tell me what you do with your hands.

game-hours: 3762.1
review: 3000+ hours....what more can I say? Seriously...I've spent too much time in Skyrim. Buy this at your own peril...
game-hours: 376.5
review: 98% of all ratings for this game are positive. If you know you like these kinds of games, what else do you need to know? It's a single player game that was released in 2011, yet still is very popular and has a very active modding community! There's so much I love about this game, I couldn't possibly write it all down here. For just about every feature I don't like, which there aren't all that many of, there's a mod that fixes it. Don't like that your skills are capped at 100? There's a mod for that. I have a character who has an alteration skill of 150. Don't like the animations, or just got tired of them? There are hundreds of mods for that. Can't find armor or weapons that you like? There are thousands of mods for that. Found armor or a weapon that you like, but it's vastly inferior to some other armors you found? Download the creation kit and you can give that armor or weapon you like the same stats as the better armors in like 5 minutes. While this game does live up to its reputation of being buggy, most of the bugs I encounter have something to do with the 40 something mods I have installed to customize my experiance. There are community mods that fix a good deal of the more serious ones, too. While some people may see the modding comunity as the 'easy way out' for the developers to take, to make the community do their work for them, that's just them trying to find an excuse to say something negative about the game. Anyone with any sense at all can see that active modding communities are great for a game's longevity. If it weren't for some of the mods I have, I might not still play Skyrim all that much, and almost definitely wouldn't be reccomending it as highly as I am now. Even without mods, Skryim is still a great game. I'm currently on my 3rd playthrough, and despite the fact that I thought I had run out of things to do on my original playthrough, I've found something new with every one. So all in all, Skyrim gets an 8/10. With all the DLC's, 9/10. Add mods to that, and you got yourself a 10/10 from me!

review: A great RPG experience. Improves heavily on the mechanics of Oblivion. Skyrim provides hundreds of hours of gameplay and builds apon its predeceer (TES:Oblivion) Graphical Fidelity is sadly not the greatest in Skyrim but mods and ENBS are available to add to the experience. But the game makes up for this with lush landscapes and mightly mountians to explore. The environments range from Snowy Mountians to the sunny town of riverrun to the towering capital Solitudes Blue Palace. Outdoors environments help build the epic atmosphere of skyrim with wildlife and bandits. But best of all. Dragons. Fighting dragons is the pinnacle experience of the game as they approach from the sky you will have to use shouts. As the dragonborn, you can use these shouts to cast a dragon from the sky to the ground, breath fire and even freeze time. As the dragonborn your primary quest will be to save the world from the almighty dragon Alduin. But not just that, you can pursuit many more quests, you can just the dark brotherhood, become a mage, join the companions and even become a bard! Skyrim is a world so engrossing that its flaws are more than made up for with its impressive open world, immersive character development and amount of incredible content. I recommend this game to Everyone, Skyrim truly is an epic experience!

review: I'm not going to write a big review for this game, because it's been talked about so much by pretty much everyone already. The amount of playtime you can get from this game is staggering. The atmosphere and immersion is also awesome. Based on that alone, the game is worth it any way you put it. That said, the game has a lot of problems. Combat becomes boring real fast. Most places you visit looks just like everything you've already seen. The amount quests is just insane, and you're going to be really dissapointed eventually as you discover you're never going to finish them all, without ruining the experience along the way. And the road is long. Incredibly long. I don't think I'm even close to finishing this game. The problem is that I don't think I can find the motivation to go on. There are a lot of mods available to offer tweaks and different experiences alltogether, but the base game is what it is. I prefer the newer Fallout games over this one, but even though there are lots of stuff that annoy me about Skyrim, it's an undeniably successful game that deserves being played. It's worth it. I'm really looking forward to the next game from Bethesda.

review: This is a fantastic game! Don't be fooled by my recorded hours on Steam; I've logged more hours than I can count playing this game on the XBOX 360. Bethesda has done a tremendous job creating an entire universe that you are free to explore and interact with in any way you choose, right down to who your character is, what he/she can do, and how he/she looks. There is so much to do all the time, so you can always do something different each time you play. The graphics are terrific, and the environment in Skyrim is absolutely beautiful. Bethesda's attention to detail is exquisite, and the general look of the game shows how much effort they've put into their graphics. Overall, the gameplay is great. The combat controls are very simple, which makes it easy to fight your enemies. Leveling up your character and choosing different skills to hone are also very simple tasks. It's easy to play as a warrior, mage, thief, or a mixture. You can be anything or anyone you want to be in this game. The story lines are good as well. There are all sorts of story lines that you can play through in addition to the main quest, and all of the ones I've played through have been quite enjoyable. On a scale of 1 to 10, I'd give Skyrim a 9.5. When you play it, you see why it's such an acclaimed, well-respected game.

review: The ultimate open-world RPG with many hours of gameplay. It features highly detailed characters and realistic interactions, extensive skill tree and levelling system, carefully crafted quests with good balance between combat skills and wits; the dynamic world features amazing details of nature and the built environment. A 'must buy' if you have enjoyed previous Elder Scrolls titles; and a good buy if you are looking to get started in this series. The new legendary edition looks like a great buy because of the legendary difficulty and the additional option to do mounted combat and master all skills, being unavailable otherwise. However, full appreciation of the game requires computer with fairly good specs and a decent monitor. As per Elder Scrolls games, there are lots of glitches and bugs in the early stages of the game; although most have been fixed since, some still remain. But overall, being a Game of the Year is still an understatement.

game-hours: 107.3
review: Say goodbye to your social life. 10/10
game-hours: 1047.4
review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is one of the bestselling games on Steam, and theres a reason for that. Its a vast world with an immense amount of lore, probably more than any other game. The lore behind Skyrim can be discovered through the Unofficial Elder Scrolls Pages (UESP) or the Skyrim Wiki. But this lore only adds to the already amazing game that Skyrim is, with its amazing combat, quests, and world. Skyrims open world can be accessed almost immediately after a short tutorial. This tutorial is very well done. It quickly sums up the current events in the Province of Skyrim and then throws you straight into the action after you create you create your character. The Character Creation system is amazing with lots of options and ten races to choose from. The only problem here is with the choice of who to follow when entering the Keep. Your choice here can affect the Civil War quest-line by eliminating that character from it depending on which side you choose. And with so little information on the Civil War, it can be confusing and difficult for a first timer to choose. When you complete the tutorial, you have the option to either explore the open World and be free to do as you please, or follow the main quest-line. Skyrim is a vast open world, it would take hundreds of hours to fully explore. There are five default quest-lines with about 10-15 quests each, not to mention the two added in Dragonborn and Dawnguard. While some of these quest-lines may be a bit bland, most are more than worth your time to play through. There are also hundreds of miscellaneous and side quests to enjoy in the world, and hundreds of NPCs to speak with. You can choose whatever path you want, whether that be an Assassin with Heavy Armor, or a Barbarian who dabbles in magic. The perks and skill-trees are vast in Skyrim. There is no set path for your character, you can be whoever you want. That means no classes or character types and such. If you want to play Skyrim mods are virtually required. Mods like Frostfall or Wet and cold add to realism in the game, while other mods like Climates of Tamriel and aMidianBorns Book of Silence make things look a lot better. Quest mods like Moonpath to Elswyre and the unforgettable Falskaar spice up the game by adding new content and entirely new lands to explore. Player Home mods give you a new place to hang out and store your loot. Follower mods give you new companions to accompany you in your travels throughout Skyrim. If you are going to use mods, I recommend going to Skyrims Nexus page and downloading their manager or Mod Organizer. Also, check out Gopher on YouTube for modding tutorials and showcases. Mods add to the already vast world that Skyrim is, they make the world twice as amzing. That said, Skyrim is one of the best games ever created, 9.5/10. Its definitely worth checking out.

review: A long time ago I bought this game, well let me start this off right. A long time ago my son bought this game, I was so impressed with it I bought a copy too. I hadnt played it since then and just a few days ago I picked it back up. RIght away I was drawn into a world of magic and sorcery filled with dragons and odd little creatures and not to meation beings that would sooner rip your arm off and beat you to death with it. I want to start with the storyline here, and dont worry I wont spoil it for you. The story for each and every charactor draws you in, with many side quest quest that are just as fasinating. They are deep and rich, but what really gets you is as you roam you are discovering differnent places where the weather changes and the scenery. Be sure to check out the steam worshop where users whom love this game have added to the detail of the game and made what was great to begin with even better. The grapics are absoultuly amazing, and like I said before the graphics are truly beautiful and amazing. You could even get lost in them, believeing you can just reach right through your screen and jump right into this wonderful world. The open world is so astounding to be in, you feel you can just freeroam forever, talking to NPCs, but look out every action does have a reaction in the game, for instance if you steal or kill certian things and are caught you will be hated sometimes even chased by guards or worse yet even punished by means of death. So beware what you do. One amzing thing I love is doing screenshots and showing them off in the community, you could use the steam screenshot program or the PC hotkey and then if you have any kind of photo software, you can really turn out some amazing artwork from the game to showcase for steam communtiy or up load to your socal network. All in all this game is extremely relaxing and will draw you right into an amazing world created by Bethesda game studios. I highly recommend this game for everyone on planet earth.

review: After 400+ hours on Xbox 360 I can definitely see why and agree, this is a game that defined a generation. Dragons, quests, spells, armor, weapons, skills, Giants, trolls, Giant Spiders and more for hardcore fantasy and Action-RPG fans this game has it all. Completely customizable, you make your character then you do what you want to do. See the outline of a castle on that mountain? You can get there. Want to spend all your time stealing from the rich and giving to the poor ? Go right ahead. Or enter into the world of Vampire Lords and Werewolves. Even become one yourself. Trigger your transformation into a ferocious werewolf and rip entire towns to shreds. Have OCD? This is the game for you. You can now after spending 15 hours gathering loot from random dungeons all across Tamriel organize your many homes into neatly organized boxes and barrels. Have a pathological need to alphabetize your book shelves? You can do that too. This is a huge game. The many engulfing story lines will gladly take away days of your life. Even thought to be "endless" due to the random quest generators. In addition to all this Official content there is a huge and active modding community. This adds even more content. Like I said before it is truly a game that defined a generation.

game-hours: 39.8
review: The latest installment in the Elder Scrolls series if you discount Bethesda's sister company Zenimax's Elder Scrolls Online: Tamriel Unlimited MMO. Yet another amazing open world game with a huge variety of crafting options, skill trees, character customization and extremely immersive questlines. Crafting: Whether you want to be an alchemist giving yourself the extra edge in an encounter with a novice necromancer or to be a blacksmith and create your own set of 'dragon-proof' armour this game has it all. 10/10 **Avoiding spoilers- the Hearthfire and Dawngaurd DLC add even more crafting options, in case you were somehow left asking for that little bit more! Character Customization: With 10 playable races, each with their own unique benefits and skill boosts you will be drawn back to creating another character before you've finished anything with the first. From stealthy Khajiit, to the weapon crazed Orsimer (Orc)...the magical and mystic Altmer, to the animal loving and arrow shooting Boismer (Wood Elf)... the choice is yours. 11/10 **And in case you weren't somehow happy with some of the preset character looks, you have near endless customization of every finite detail. From the tip of your elf's nose to the pointiness of their ears- you can change it! Skill Trees: As with the character customization and every other aspect of the game it can be be adjusted to the last detail by you. Fancy a dual wielding orc who's handy with their spells? you can make it. Want an Argonian who can posion their weapons and make their own armour? yup, you can do it. 10/10 **Even if you want big blonde Nord that prefers picking pockets and hiding in the shadows- the choice is yours! Quest Lines: Well expansive, immersive and endless are some choice words to choose a few! Some quests are better suited to characters with certain skills, others have no restrictions... some quests change how places within the game look and what people say, others might just make you feel good! Follow the main quest line, start on a side quest, join a guild- whatever you want, whever you want with the only restriction being- "Has your character fought enough bandits and bears to know what they're doing? Have they got the right armour to stop that mage turning you inside out?" 11/10 *Want an immersive game that leaves you wanting more? This is for you! Game Environment: Well open-environment and immersive as many reviews will say and dead-to-point. Everything from the wildlife to passers by, a clear night sky to a heavy storm- you'll epxerience it. The Elder Scrolls game's have always had huge areas to explore within realistic environments (by gaming standards, I'm not implying two planets in the nights sky or dog sized rats appear in your local neighbourhood!!) 11/10 **Anything, anywhere, anytime- who knows what will happen next?! With a game this big and expansive, any review can easily be the same! There are a hige amount of pro's to this game and next to no cons (in my opinion). Occassiaonally aplate might fall off a table and vibrate along the floor like it's possessed- it's funny! Excluding meaningless small comments like that, it is FLAWLESS! 11/10 **Every gamer whether serious or just occassional should give this game a go- especially the ultimate edition! The expansions are good value in this edition and all worth a go. Stole bandits loot from a castle, jumped for joy on the road to Windhelm, mauled to death by a Sabertooth Cat. 10/10 Battled a Troll, ran away from giants, only went to the farm for some tomatos.. 10/10 Got rich, built a house, adopted orphans. Brad and Angelina who? 10/10

game-hours: 583.7
review: Skyrim, this game was such an iconic release. With deep lore expanding The Elder Scrolls universe, and many many quests that take the player through the snowy civil war torn world of northern Tamriel. I got to say, I put more then my fair share of hours into it. Yet, sad to say with all that time I never finished the main quest. Here is a list of Pros and Cons as I see them. Pros: - Plenty of story: Skyrim has many many books and notes that you can read to gain insight about the past and hidden lore of Tamriel. From books about the origins of the falmer to the steamy adventures of a maid named Lifts-Her-Tail. There are plenty of entertaining literary works to read. - Combat Choices: There are many weapons to choose from and master, from the mighty Battleaxe to the enchanted pickaxe and staff combo. You can use and master a variety of weapons and skillsets. Though focusing on raising your one handed is an option. - Quests: There are many things to do in Skyrim, you can join the companions and kill monsters for gold, or join the dark brotherhood and kill people for gold. Steal things for gold in the thieves guild, or go to college, for... To learn magics and mastery therein. Almost every character in Skyrim will be able to contribute to your questing in one way of another. - Item: There are many Items to peruse and collect throughout the game, most can be bought from stores but others you have to make yourself or find in the long lost reaches of that one cave off away from the beaten path. - Modability: I don't have to say much about this. The fact the community care so much and releases and continually updates content for this game is amazing. Mods are what keep me playing after 500hours. Cons: - Too much story: People love lore and getting into their favorite games, but, sometimes reading every note, book and letter, can become cumbersome. Reading every skill book for that single point increase is not conducive to killing that skeleton that is keeping you from looting that locked chest in the distance. - Repetitive Combat: Over time holding the Left/Right mouse/trigger can become a chore. Repeatedly tapping the mouse to attack an enemy that you've easily one-shotted a thousand times can get really boring over time, and the vanilla level and difficulty scaling doesn't help. I mean, come on, when I'm whaling on a bandit leader for 3 minutes on legendary, just for 50 gold, a ruby, and some random enchanted weapon I could have made, you're making me question how i'm using my time. - Fetch Quests: OK, I have to say this. Roughly 80% of the quests in this game are a form of fetch quest. Go get the fragment, horn, staff, plans. Go kill that guy, this guy, and Steve. There are so many variants that it gets annoying, at one point the game wants you to fetch 24 of the same thing albeit scattered. You will find yourself using the fast travel system often, but by doing so you will miss some random events. Difficult choice, I know. Overview: Overall This is a very enjoyable game, though I get bothered by some nuances of it's game play mechanics. I constantly find myself coming back and finding some new quest I haven't done, or item I've never used. I've started over at least 20 times, each one a different character. You will definitely get your money out of this game if you like time consuming, repetitive games with deep story, and a vast world to explore.

review: Just like Morrowind and Oblivion, There are still some problems with this game that some people will not like, but it's easy to get past on them given that this game is so beautifully built. Actually at first I was a little disappointed because the game brings the same empty feeling as Oblivion did but as I progressed I realized how great it is and I think the addition of dialog tree helps a lot. The best effort Bethesda did this time is to subtract everything people hate about past elder scroll games, and add everything people like. The combat gameplay in Skyrim is the most satisfying experience I ever had in all the bethesda studio titles I played though it's quite simplistic. The overall difficulty of the game is dragged down compare to Obliviion so I would suggest experienced gamers starting from hard difficulty level. the thing I like the most about this game is religion aspects and cultural perspectives based on races (like they did in Morrowind) which will really immerse you into the game world. Also almost all the levels were handcrafted this time unlike all those "copy and paste" levels in Oblivion. Overall, this game is a huge step forward from the previous title.

review: There is probably not much to add to the massive accretion of Skyrim opinion, but I'll give it a go anyway. I have probably in excess of 200 hours sunk into this game and I still enjoy it. Many of you certainly have two, three, four times that many hours in it. People love it, and those who don't usually love to hate it. My guess is not that many people are completely indifferent to Skyrim unless they just don't play video games at all. It's just another Bethesda game in some ways, but it's the best one they've ever made. There have been mods for other games they've made, but the Skyrim mod community is probably one of the most lively that any game has ever inspired. Even so (and many will disagree), Skyrim's a great game even without mods. I'm intrigued to see what Bethesda will do next. ESO holds no sway over me, but Fallout and Skyrim have me wishing for the next big Bethesda RPG, and they might just keep me occupied until it surfaces.

review: Probably the best open-world RPG out there. Definitely one of my all-time favourite games. The replayability is superb and the modding community is highly active, which makes it easy to play the game the way you want to play it. For me the modding experience has been the greatest aspect of the game. You can easily make the game graphics look like up to date games (as long as you have a decent graphics card). The atmosphere in the game and the way the game feels alive is something that will keep amaze you throughout the game. It really feels like a living world, even though you will stumble upon bad or awkward NPC movements and behaviour (but mods can help fix this). The music and voice acting is as good as it can get. If you like RPGs there are no reasons why you shouldnt own this game already. 10/10.

game-hours: 409.9
review: Skyrim is not a perfect game. Infact it is far from it. Many quests are nothing more than fetch or kill quests, Guild questlines are far less complex and engrossing than before (although the Dark Brotherhood questline is still excellent), multiple skills have been cut out and is far more shallow in terms of storytelling and RPG elements compared to the games before it. Yet despite this, the game is still effortlessly, shamelessly entertaining. The game has a myriad of improvements on its predecessor, Oblivion; The NPCs still level up with your character to an extent, but it is a far more intelligent system than Oblivion (although the game would be far better without levelled NPCs), NPCs no longer look like strange potato people, and NPC writing on a whole is actually pretty decent. As mentioned before, Skyrim is a very shallow RPG compared to the games that preceeded it. Conversations in the game, although being an improvement on Oblivion's keyword based system, aren't a patch on the engrossing and detailed conversations of Fallout: New Vegas and Morrowind. Quests are usually very bland, with only a few standing out as excellent, and in terms of storytelling, Skyrim seems like its written for people with a very short attention span. There are also many inconsistencies with the games own lore, for example, in the lore it states that Khajiit's are banned from entering cities, however in game a Khajiit can waltz in to a city with no opposition. Faction relations are non exisistent, appart from in the Civil War questline. Joining a certain faction has absolutely no consequence, and your able to become the Harbringer of The Companions, The Listener of the Dark Brotherhood, The Arch Mage of The College of Winterhold and the Guild Master of the Thieves Guild, despite the fact that many of these factions with have conflicting ideas. Skyrim's UI is clearly designed for console, and is incredibly difficult to use with a mouse and keyboard, the fact that Bethesda felt it was okay to ship a game for PC without even making a single modification to the UI is downright annoying, and a mistake they definately shouldnt make again. The world of Skyrim is brilliant, the regions are varied and well designed, with each region containing a distinct look, unlike the endless forest of Oblivion. Dungeon design has also improved, instead of being something that resembles a Lego set, Dungeons are varied and interesting and often take you to some stunning locations. Despite all it's flaws, Skyrim is still a great game. However if you go in expecting a deep complex RPG, you will be dissapointed. At times, Skyrim feels like an RPG designed for people who dont play RPGs, and this may very well be the case, It's also worth noting that the modding scene for Skyrim is excellent, with many mods aiming to add more depth to Skyrims system, and one mod in particular replaces the awful UI with an intuitive interface designed for a mouse and keyboard. All in all, Skyrim is a great game, but merely an average RPG.

review: There is so much you can do in Skyrim. You can explore however you want and where ever you want. There are so many possibilities that can happen in this game. Skyrim can have a true sense of immersion. With heartfelt speeches, literary epics and tremendous NPCs, you can feel like you truly are a native of the country. This game does not tell you to do anything, but you decide what to do. Other games tell you to save the world, but Skyrim makes you want to save it. Throughout the game you will find lore and legends that show the tremendous culture and features that went into the creation of the game. In Skyrim you start from fighting dragons and bandits and go on to learning ancient powers, fighting for kings, for honour, harnessing untold energy and even doing the will of the gods. Even after all this, you can find thousands of mods that vary from adding new location, items, quests and NPC, to entirely new ways of playing and immersification. While there are hundreds upon hundreds of quests and people within this game, you will not stop finding individuals and new experiences within the endless amount of adventuring you can partake in.
game-hours: 86.1
review: One of the best RPG games out there. You create your own character, choose a race and try to survive in the world of Skyrim as Dovakiin (Dragonborn). Your arsenal is swords, bows, spells, shouts and your own hands/claws. The unique feature in Skyrim is the shouts. You use various shouts to your advantage that you learn from people or word walls. After learning shouts, you unlock them using Dragon souls. To gain a dragon soul, you slain dragons that appear in the cities or in the wild. The world in Skyrim is vast. There are a lot of places to discover, different people to meet, different factions to join and do a lot of quests. It takes a lot of time to do all quests, which is why this game lets you enjoy many hours of gameplay, unlike most of the game which people complete under 20-40 hours. Although, Skyrim has some bugs, creators still did an outstanding job in making this game. 9.8/10

game-hours: 191.0
review: In the early days of cinema there where a variety of movies that capitalized on low cost special effects, Skyrim borrows a lot from these types of films. By shouting at enemies, and even goats, you make them stumble backwards as if by magic. This isn't revealed to you until you're half way through the game and told by "mysterious shouting from atop a mountain" that you must trek up the mountain and meet these shouters. You're then tasked with saving the world, again, and the most critical choice of the entire game comes after you've actually completed the game. Time travel is involved, and there's plenty of goofy throwbacks to horrible movies in the form of a vampire den full of well-to-do vampire lords who thrive for thousands of years doing things that should have gotten them taken out a millenia ago. To join the thieves guild you simply walk into town with any loot in your inventory. Keeping with tradition, Bethesda has one animator and combat involves clicking until things die and nothing more. Features such as crafting spells where replaced to make room for DLC for your xbox.

game-hours: 583.7
review: Skyrim, this game was such an iconic release. With deep lore expanding The Elder Scrolls universe, and many many quests that take the player through the snowy civil war torn world of northern Tamriel. I got to say, I put more then my fair share of hours into it. Yet, sad to say with all that time I never finished the main quest. Here is a list of Pros and Cons as I see them. Pros: - Plenty of story: Skyrim has many many books and notes that you can read to gain insight about the past and hidden lore of Tamriel. From books about the origins of the falmer to the steamy adventures of a maid named Lifts-Her-Tail. There are plenty of entertaining literary works to read. - Combat Choices: There are many weapons to choose from and master, from the mighty Battleaxe to the enchanted pickaxe and staff combo. You can use and master a variety of weapons and skillsets. Though focusing on raising your one handed is an option. - Quests: There are many things to do in Skyrim, you can join the companions and kill monsters for gold, or join the dark brotherhood and kill people for gold. Steal things for gold in the thieves guild, or go to college, for... To learn magics and mastery therein. Almost every character in Skyrim will be able to contribute to your questing in one way of another. - Item: There are many Items to peruse and collect throughout the game, most can be bought from stores but others you have to make yourself or find in the long lost reaches of that one cave off away from the beaten path. - Modability: I don't have to say much about this. The fact the community care so much and releases and continually updates content for this game is amazing. Mods are what keep me playing after 500hours. Cons: - Too much story: People love lore and getting into their favorite games, but, sometimes reading every note, book and letter, can become cumbersome. Reading every skill book for that single point increase is not conducive to killing that skeleton that is keeping you from looting that locked chest in the distance. - Repetitive Combat: Over time holding the Left/Right mouse/trigger can become a chore. Repeatedly tapping the mouse to attack an enemy that you've easily one-shotted a thousand times can get really boring over time, and the vanilla level and difficulty scaling doesn't help. I mean, come on, when I'm whaling on a bandit leader for 3 minutes on legendary, just for 50 gold, a ruby, and some random enchanted weapon I could have made, you're making me question how i'm using my time. - Fetch Quests: OK, I have to say this. Roughly 80% of the quests in this game are a form of fetch quest. Go get the fragment, horn, staff, plans. Go kill that guy, this guy, and Steve. There are so many variants that it gets annoying, at one point the game wants you to fetch 24 of the same thing albeit scattered. You will find yourself using the fast travel system often, but by doing so you will miss some random events. Difficult choice, I know. Overview: Overall This is a very enjoyable game, though I get bothered by some nuances of it's game play mechanics. I constantly find myself coming back and finding some new quest I haven't done, or item I've never used. I've started over at least 20 times, each one a different character. You will definitely get your money out of this game if you like time consuming, repetitive games with deep story, and a vast world to explore.

review: TES V Skyrim is one of those long lasting experience games that is today, and in days to come, bending, twisting and shaping the genre that we call open world RPG. The depthness and imersiveness factor of it is roughly 90%+ and it can be customized via the mods and other tools. The amount of details put in making the artwork of this game so unique is also by all means immensive. So Get it! Mod it (with skill)! and finally Enjoy it! Cheers :)

game-hours: 56.1
review: I must say, Bethesdsa Softworks has done it again. They've made a truly amazing game, infusing both gripping quests along with their usual twisted linear quests (making you groan about having to go back the way you came, only to find there was an unmarked entrance next to the original entrance). I also must state that I got the Legendary Edition for 13.59 USD when it was on sale about two weeks ago. *sigh*....However I'm going to start with the things I hate first. Cons: 1. The game's long walking periods begin to get tedious - I often find myself spending 30 minutes at a time just walking through the map, trying to find my objective location - The game often gives me a direction along the given map that is untraversable by ordinary means - The game gives me linear paths though minimaps that don't necessarily work - The map is confusing, rarely showing possible paths....just color (indicating weather there, and landmarks. That's it) - I often find myself hunting for paths to traverse around mountains as fast as possible, and that also takes a lot of time 2. The Favorites menu could be much more polished - I find that my favorites gets cluttered very often, even when I ONLY select the items I really use (some spells, weapons, shield - I hope that Bethesda could implement a sorting system in the favorites menu that is similar to the default inventory where you can use your strafe buttons (side movement buttons) to switch between categories, and up down movement keys to select individual items. That would be a massive benefit 3. DLC - I'm not saying I have a complaint with the DLC itself, but I'm saying I have a problem with how it affects the game, even on the regular questline. - For example, The DragonBorn DLC is the only one I have to complain about as of now. The moment you initiate the series of quests in that DLC (the Solstheim Quests), Miraak instantly butts his head into the game, even when you're minding your business in the stock/base storyline. I think that Bethesda could separate the DLC and Base Storyline interactions, because while I was still completing that storyline, Miraak stole a total of 12 Dragon Souls after I killed a dragon.....all by myself....so unfair Miraak WHYYY 4. I encounter small, but annoying bugs very often - Bug 1: The permanent walk glitch: Sometimes after entering new areas, I just randomly start crouchwalking, as if I were overcarrying. I even tried pressing the toggle walk/run button, and everything, and I couldn't do anything but restart my entire game to fix this problem, which I found was annoying - Bug 2: Stuck in map: After using the Whirlwind Sprint shout, I often found myself stuck in walls, or the world, unable to get out. I would be stuck there for a while, and if I tried to fast travel out of there, The game would say "You cannot fast-travel while jumping or falling" or some message like that. I would have to slowly inch my way out, costing time - Bug 3: Coin Eating: Sometimes, If a city guard comes in to arrest me right after I make a purchase, It eats up ALL of the coins I have, and doesn't return them. I've only encountered this glitch once, but it ate up a considerable number of coins (well over 8000) Don't think I hate this game. I actually really love it. So, now I'm going to state everything I love about this game. 1. Combat System - The combat system in this game.....gee. It's just like the god (please do not take offence to my use of god in my review) of combat systems. The hitboxes are pretty great (no errors I've seen yet *cough* *cough* *source*. - This game's dual handed item carry system is great, allowing me to 2 handedly defeat anything in my wake, with a spell in one hand, and Dawnbreaker in the other. Too good. - The weapons are really balanced, with no weapon being completely overpowered to others, each having their own unique affects, advantages, and disadvantages, promoting balanced, even combat gameplay. 2. Smithing/Enchanting - This game has one of the most unique smithing/enchanting systems I've ever seen. The process is tedious and tiring but It really does pay off in the end. - The sheer number of craftable items and individual compatible enchantments is mindboggling, each with very profitable results in the end 3. Questline - This game has quite possible one of the most forgiving, gripping, and amazing questlines yet. The story is fluid, everything is tied together amazingly in the end, and the story is just amazing. That's all I can say without spoiling the game. 4. The detail of each individual character within the game - I honestly believe that Bethesda spent a considerable amount of time to add in all of these npcs and their purposes. - The character customization is amazing, allowing for almost everything on your character to be customized - Even the addition of adoptable children and marriage is very interesting and revolutionary Well, this has been everything that I felt was noteworthy enough to be spoken of. If you notice I'm missing anything that you liked, I guess you should comment? I honestly dont' know. But, If you think I left anything out, It probably means I didn't care about it enough to speak of it. ENCORE BETHESDA!!!! I CANNOT WAIT FOR THE NEXT INSTALLEMTN OF ELDER SCROLLS!!!!! IF YOU HAVE ANY COMMENTS, PLEASE LEAVE THEM IN THE COMMENT SECTION BELOW! CHEERS!!!

game-hours: 892.2
review: This is THE open world adventure game. It doesn't matter whether you bought it on sale or full price - it's worth the buy. Here's the breakdown: You have almost total control of how you character grows. Like previous entries in the series you choose your race, customize your character, and develop based on actions you take. Picking locks grants you more lockpicking levels. Using a greatsword improves two-handed skill. In this way, you truly are whatever you want to be, from death-dealing dual-wielder to summoner to crossbow assassin (crossbows included with Dawnguard DLC). The game promises much with the offering of a massive world map and addtional areas with DLC - it's possible to ride your horse for hours, tackling new dungeons and encountering randomly generated events without ever once repeating an area. Impressive voicework for all NPCs is only somewhat injured by the severely limited list of voice actors, but overall character design and environments are in line with a game so massive in scope (read: passable, not amazing). The story centers on you as something called the Dragonborn, a legendary figure who speaks and Shouts (a form of magic) as the ancient and long dead dragons do. This becomes apparent only after the resurrection of said dragons. While interesting, the story won't pull any heart strings or make you genuinely care about the NPCs, but it works. Even so, the "main" questline can take as much of a back seat to countless side quests as you like - you can delay completing almost any section of it for hundreds of hours of gameplay if you so choose. But, all of this is not what kept me playing for 800+ hours. It's the mods. Dear god, the mods. With the exception of the Sims, I do not believe any other game has the depth, breadth, and scope of mods that this game boasts. Nexus Mods and the community workshop offer remedies for ANY complaint or aspect of the game. Want your women to sport 34DDD's and have 2000 pixel face textures? Done. Want to completely overhaul illusion and destruction magic, or even the way that spells are cast? Easy. Want to add whole questlines, hundreds of new monsters, a new continent, or improve on literally every single aspect there is to the game? Better animations, teleportation, and thousands of new pieces for your wardrobe? Looking for Angelina Jolie? Save some hard drive space - you're going to need it. By the time you finish installing, you'll be taking almost photoreal screenshots and posting them to your friends. I have over 2500 screenshots myself. For a recommendation, check out the Skyrim Nexus and look at the top 10 or 20 mods of all time. Even the top 5 will dramatically change (and extend!) your Skyrim experience. Be SURE to read all of a mod's requirements and installation methods before downloading - some configuring may be required. You'll laugh at your friends who "played" the game on Xbox 360. It's not even the same experience once you've gotten some good mods. Even without mods, the base game should keep you busy for a good 40-50 hours. Marriage and adoption, the ability to transform into a vampire lord and summon guardians of ancient knowledge are available with all DLC installed (which I would HIGHLY recommend). Short story is this - if you like sandbox RPG's, this is it. If you like custom sandbox RPG's, there isn't anything that comes close.

review: Awe-inspiring. So straight off the bat I've never been a big Elder Scrolls fan. Just like there will be lots of others out there who are huge fans, I will admit I have only played Oblivion and Skyrim (And partially Morrowind), however I was overwhelmingly impressed with this game in every single way. When you first step foot into such an open world where everything you do, every child you knock over with your "Fus Ro Dah!", those poor chickens you pitilessly pummelled with your grubby weapons, you can't help but be a little caucious towards playing to make sure that you build the world to something that you'd desire it to be. Taking into account that everything you do has a massive effect, it also makes you enjoy the game more by reading everything, exploring everything, and doing what you can as soon as you can do it. The base game can be a little basic, the storyline is there and you can definitely have fun, however mods turn this game into something completely different. Trust me. I have had many many fun hours playing this game and yet I am nowhere near planning to be done with it, especially with the newly released DLC and the constant output of mods by amazing fans and some developers! Although the game itself is absolutely amazing, mod this game right and you will have endless possibilities and this game truly becomes quite simply a masterpiece of an adventure. 10/10 - Absolute Masterpiece!
