game-hours: 166.2
review: Skyrim is an amazing game. With the updated (not new) engine, character details and animations look stellar. With the HD texture pack, Skyrim proves to be quite the enjoyable experience from start to end. While Tamriel feels really strange so long after the events of Oblivion, and technology between the two games, Skyrim feels like it's own region to provide it's own lore and otherwise interesting details. Unfortunately, Skyrim does show it's console-oriented development with a clunky UI, and some major problems that while can be sorted by INI tweaks such as VSYNC being forced on and physics problems if it's forced off via the INI, it does have a bit of PC-oriented fixes that need to come down the pipe. Steamworks integration makes Skyrim great in that it supports mods pretty much out of the box now, BUT there's no support for Steam Cloud saves, especially as a single playthrough can cost you anywhere between 200 to 400MB depending on how often you save.
game-hours: 77.1
review: Such a BIG game. I was a bit worried when I first started this game because the combat feels floaty at times, but you'll start ignoring it the more you play. There's just so much to do. It took me about 17,5 hours before I encountered my first dragon. For every quest you finish, you'll receive several more, it's unbelievable. I'm not sure I can ever completely finish it. I've done most of the things by now, and I still have about 30-40 misc sidequests open. And don't get me started on the fetch quests; the ones that aren't listed in the quest log. I was actually surprised by the amount of quality quests in this game. All the factions have their own storyline, and other sidequests can take well over an hour to finish. Exploring also just feels right. You're constantly being rewarded with treasures, hidden dungeons, new quests and more. There are several bugs, but nothing game breaking so far. If you have to buy one game this year, let it be this one. It is endless. ENDLESS ! [Rating: 95/100]

game-hours: 339.1
review: Buy it, play it, mod the hell out of it. For the patient and technical ones, a delicious experience with a lot of variation, for those who just want to play, still a really good game. If you're looking for an adventure and spending time exploring, as usual, the Elder Scrolls has just what you need. Although lacking the amazing atmosphere of its most highly regarded predecessor Morrowind, the dazzling sights of Skyrims mountainous northern landcape easily makes up for it. Admittedly, Skyrim does not exactly feel like a different world, like Morrowind did, but rather more like an alternate past, which is a slight pity. Playtime is, well, as long as you make it. Again. mods. Playstyle, I personally basically only play as a cloak and dagger character, as I find stealthing and sneak-attacking practically everyone oh so satisfying. Just remember to quicksave before you try anything too dangerous. Admittedly I could never get into any other playstyles, but seemingly there are those who enjoy other types as well. Graphics, ENB, find one you like, install, if your computer can handle it. Audio, one of the weaker points I would say, but it does what it should, not too fond of the music or the sounds in general. In short, mod it. The game is far from perfect, but it's Bethesda, they only make flawed gems. I pun so hard.

game-hours: 291.1
review: NOTE: This is a review on Vanilla Skyrim, I dont care if there are thousands of mods im reviewing the game as it is unmodded. Pros: Faces are a MASSIVE improvment from Oblivion Mountains and ruins look thousands of times better than Oblivion, especially the mountains. Music when fighting dragons is epic. The music overall is better than Oblivion's Dragon fights are epicness Archery is much more improved, it's alot faster. Pretty good storyline Cons: Coloring sucks balls. The grey atmosphere looks great on mountains but awful on lush forested places. Melee combat system is more like "Press X to not die" which you are basicly just spamming attacks with no strategy. NPCs suck , they're all the same, they all say the same thing to your character about the war. They never evolve to your character. They will treat a level 1 fur armored player the same way they would treat a level 50 dragon slayer savior of Sovngarde player, except for a few comments guards will make about you but other than that they will all treat you the same all the time. I find the dungeons extremley repetitive and boring. Each dungeon basicly looks the same as the last one except duplicated to look bigger. Final Verdict: 7/10, would recommend for 29 dollars but I'm nearly on the verge of not recommending it because the cons i listed really ruin the game.

game-hours: 410.6
review: I have so many hours in this game on PC and console, i have no idea what to write. So here is a Muffin recipe. Muffins Ingredients 1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour 1/3 cup sugar 2 teaspoons baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 1 egg, beaten 3/4 cup milk 1/4 cup cooking oil Directions Preheat oven to 400 degrees F. Grease twelve 2-1/2-inch muffin cups or line with paper bake cups; set aside. In a medium bowl combine flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt. Make a well in center of flour mixture; set aside. In another bowl combine egg, milk, and oil. Add egg mixture all at once to flour mixture. Stir just until moistened (batter should be lumpy). Spoon batter into prepared muffin cups, filling each 2/3 full. If desired, sprinkle Streusel Topping over muffin batter in cups. Bake for 18 to 20 minutes or until golden and a wooden toothpick inserted in centers comes out clean. Cool in muffin cups on a wire rack for 5 minutes. Remove from muffin cups; serve warm. Makes 12 muffins.

game-hours: 762.7
review: True to all Elder Scrolls games, Skyrim takes you from muddled and shady beginnings to become a mighty hero of legend by completing tasks both epic and tirvial alike. Slay dragons, vampires, werevolves, legions of soldiers and bandits, delve into deep dungeons and climb the highest mountains. Collect stuff, store it in random barrels and boxes. Collect more stuff, build a huge rustic mansion with it, then spend a week in game moving all yourt stuff from random barrels and boxes into barrels and boxes in your new house. Find a cook/piggy bank to live with you (they call it marriage for some reason), adopt a dirty kid, and proceed to neglect them both as you go out an slay more dragons and punch a mudcrab. I honestly cringe to think of how much time I waste in this game not even really playing it and just dealing with my collection of...stuff. Most of which I never use. I'm a digital hoarder for no apparent reason considering in the real world I have zero inclination to collect anything whatsoever. So there's that: this game develops latent psychological disorders, but only when you are playing the game. Anyway, this is your typical TES game fare. Combat and levelling is much improved over previous titles, but is still nothing amazing. The leveled loot and creatures system is arguably better than Oblivion's, but still manages to reduce the fun factor in my opinion. Honestly, if everything is roughly the same proportionate strength relative to me throughout the entire process, I never get the sense of making any real progress. Plus, leveled loot just sucks in general. I go through the process of attaining a legendary artifact of the gods at a relatively low level, and so I'm punished for such a feat in that the item is in a diminished state that never improves. Boo to that. There is always plenty of stuff to do, though. The main quest and side "civil war" quests are lacking in the epic department (mostly out of presentation), so the real fun comes from making your own story. As always, characters suffer from what I like to call "Bethesda Face," wherein the emotions conveyed visually hardly match the voice acting, usually to a comical effect because it's like witnessing wax museum characters acting. They try, but it always falls short. Voice acting is decent, but lacks variety (in number of voices, that is). Graphics are equally decent, but can easily be made great by mods. Speaking of, just about anything wrong with the game can be remedied by mods. A lot can be said about Bethesda (mostly negative, in my mind), but if anything they do a great job supporting the modding community. As such, every time they release an unpolished and usually unfinished game, you can be sure eventually the userbase will turn it into something pretty awesome. So, as always, you do a vanilla run just to see what it's all about, then use the community to play a game that is worthwhile and never look back to the retail version. I have a bit of a love/hate (mostly hate) relationship with Bethesda, but TES always keeps me coming back for hundreds of hours of my life because at the very least the lore is fantastic, and the sandbox type approach to the world lets me make my own fun. If that's not an endorsement, I don't know what is. tl;dr: Boo Bethesda. Yay Elder Scrolls with dragons. Huzzah mods. Punch a mudcrab.

game-hours: 414.8
review: "Must be another one of those  RPing games with bad graphics and 5 or less quests." I thought to myself when I downloaded this game. Then I found out its, so far, the BEST RPing game I've ever played! Dragons, Daedrics, Joinable Armies, Hundreds of quests, Great graphics, Great DLCs', The abillity to become a Human, Orc, Khajiit (cat man), Elf, ETC, The possibillities are (almost) Endless! I personaly love being a Kajiit in the Imperial Army (good), but others might like being Stormcloak (rebel) Elves, (and no, not the HL2 rebels) Maybe even a Neutral Orc! What I'm trying to say is, if you play this game, be prepared. It is so fun it can be addicting. Now, it will get boring after a while when you have no quests or when the game glitches to where you cant do a quest (this happened to me on some quests, but most got fixed). But, there are cheats, like godmode (tgm in console) or putting "showracemenu" in the console to change your characters race and name, (sorta like the lady in the theives guild when you download the Dawnguard DLC) but your status will be messed up. I recommend saving before using the showracemenu cheat, to avoid re-doing quests to save your status. I know i've said it before, but prepare yourself, this game IS addicting, like TF2 was before i got this game! The Elder Scrolls : V Skyrim Buy now for $20.00, or $40.00 for all 3 DLCS (Dawnguard, Hearthfire, and Dragonborn)!

game-hours: 80.1
review: Probably the best open-world RPG out there. Definitely one of my all-time favourite games. The replayability is superb and the modding community is highly active, which makes it easy to play the game the way you want to play it. For me the modding experience has been the greatest aspect of the game. You can easily make the game graphics look like up to date games (as long as you have a decent graphics card). The atmosphere in the game and the way the game feels alive is something that will keep amaze you throughout the game. It really feels like a living world, even though you will stumble upon bad or awkward NPC movements and behaviour (but mods can help fix this). The music and voice acting is as good as it can get. If you like RPGs there are no reasons why you shouldnt own this game already. 10/10.

review: This is the game the never, ever ends. I picked this game up thinking I wouldn't like it having never played a previous TES game before. game-hours: 247.4
review: An epic game made all the more epic by the fact that it is so easy to mod and so well supported by the modding community. The Elder Scrolls series has a large following and often you will hear people argue over each new TES game comparing it to the last, but for me each TES game stands on its own merits, and Skyrim is no exception. The story is pretty good and there are plenty of side quests, but what makes Skyrim so great even when not modded is its large and open nature. This is a land you can just pick a direction and with no quest in mind and just explore. You will find danger and excitement on your journey ... and loot. Lots and lots of loot. But once you start modding this game, that is when you unlock the true value that is Skyrim. Potentially thousands more hours content (for free) in a game that can be improved ten thousand different ways from graphics, textures and sounds all the way to game mechanics and user interface changes. You can make the game exactly what you need it to be, and play it for so long you may still be playing when the next game in this series comes out.... and sometimes longer than even that. If you are interested in modding the PC version of the game, be sure to check out my guide for beginners:

game-hours: 92.5
review: I was stacking books on a shelf in my house in Whiterun, one of Skyrim's major cities, when I noticed a weapon rack right beside it. I set a sacrificial dagger in one slot, an Orcish mace in the other. They were on display for nobody but me and my computer-controlled housecarl, Lydia, who sat at a table patiently waiting for me to ask her to go questing. The chest upstairs was reserved for excess weapons and armor, the bedside table for smithing ingots and ores, the one next to the Alchemy table for ingredients. I'd meticulously organized my owned virtual property not because I had to, but because tending to the minutia of domestic life is a comforting break from dealing with screaming frost trolls, dragons, a civil war, and job assignments that never seem to go as planned. It's even a sensible thing to do; a seemingly natural component of every day existence in Skyrim, one of the most fully-realized, easily enjoyable, and utterly engrossing role-playing games ever made. Part of what makes it so enjoyable has to do with how legacy Elder Scrolls clutter has been condensed and in some cases eliminated. In Skyrim, there's no more moon-hopping between hilltops with a maxed out Acrobatics skill. That's gone, so is Athletics. The Elder Scrolls V pares down the amount of skills and cuts out attributes like Endurance and Intelligence altogether. There's no time wasted on the character creation screen agonizing over which skills to assign as major. You don't assign major and minor skills at all, but instead pick one of ten races, each with a specific bonus. High Elves can once a day regenerate magicka quickly, Orcs can enter a berserk rage for more effective close-range combat. These abilities are best paired with certain character builds  the High Elf regeneration is useful for a magic user  but don't represent a rigid class choice. Major decisions don't need to be made until you're already out in the world and can try out magic, sneaking and weapon combat, emphasizing first-hand experience over instruction manual study, letting you specialize only when you're ready. It contributes to the thrilling sense of freedom associated with life in Skyrim. Do a quest, kill a dragon, snatch torchbugs from the air, munch on butterfly wings or simply wander while listening to one of the best game soundtracks in recent memory. Despite the enormity of the world and the colossal amount of content contained within, little feels random and useless. Even chewing on a butterfly wing has purpose, as it reveals one of several alchemical parameters later useful in potion making at an alchemy table. Mined ore and scraps of metal from Dwemer ruins can be smelted into ingots and fashioned into armor sets, pelts lifted from slain wildlife can be turned into leather armor sets, and random books plucked from ancient ruins can trigger hidden quest lines that lead to valuable rewards. Skyrim's land mass is absolutely stuffed with content and curiosities, making every step you take, even if it's through what seems like total wilderness, an exciting one, as something unexpected often lies just over the next ridge. Many times the unexpected takes the form of a dragon. Sometimes they're purposefully placed to guard relics, sometimes they swoop over cities and attack at seemingly random times. In the middle of a fight against a camp of bandits a dragon might strike, screaming through the sky and searing foe and friendly alike with frost or flame. Momentarily all on the battlefield unite, directing arrows and magic blasts upward to knock down the creature, creating impromptu moments of camaraderie -- a surprising change from what may have been yet another by-the-numbers bandit camp sweep. Dragons show up often, their presence announced by an ominous flap of broad wings or an otherworldly scream from high above. The scale and startling detail built into each creature's appearance and animations as it circles, stops to attack, circles again and slams to the ground makes encounters thrilling, though their predictable attack patterns lessen the excitement after a few battles. In the long run they're far less irritating than the Oblivion gate equivalent from The Elder Scrolls IV, can be completed in a few minutes, and always offer a useful reward. Killing a dragon yields a soul, which powers Skyrim's new Shout system. These are magical abilities any character can use, you don't have to specialize in spell casting to slow time, throw your voice, change the weather, call in allies, blast out ice and fire, or knock back enemies with a rolling wave of pure force. Even if you favor sword, shield and heavy armor and ignore magic entirely, you'll still be able to take full advantage of these abilities provided you find the proper words  each Shout has three  hidden on Skyrim's high snowy peaks and in the depths of forgotten dungeons, serving as another reason to continue exploring long after you've exhausted the main quest story, joined with the Thieves Guild, fought alongside the Dark Brotherhood, or thrown your support behind one of the factions vying for control of Skyrim. Not only is this land under assault by dragons, long thought to be dead, it's also ripped in two by civil war. You can choose one side or the other, but so much of the allure of Skyrim is how, even outside of the confines of quest lines, the embattled state of the world is evident, and steeped in a rich fictional legacy. Lord of the Rings this is not, but with the release of every Elder Scrolls game, the fiction becomes denser, and the cross-referencing for long-time fans all the more rewarding. Skyrim's residents are all aware of current events. They'll comment on the civil war, some sympathizing with the rebels, others thinking the establishment sold its soul. The peasants complain about the Jarls who control each settlement, the Jarls complain about the rebels or foreign policy, the overprotective College librarian complains when I drop dragon scales all over his floor; many characters feel like whole, distinct personalities instead of vacuous nothings that hand out quests like a downtown greeter hands out flyers for discount jeans. Characters stereotype based on race, they double-cross at even the slightest hint it might be profitable, and they react to your evolving stature within the world. It makes a ridiculous realm, filled with computer-controlled cat people and humanoid reptiles, demon gods and dragons, feel authentic, like a world that existed long before you showed up and will continue to exist long after you leave.

game-hours: 1993.7
review: The Elder Scrolls Five, Skyrim, is an awesome game. Definitely worth getting, PROS -Over hundreds of hours of gameplay -Good graphics -Plenty of rememberable characters -Lots of quests -Lots of different enemies to fight -Lots of great storylines and lore -Dynamic enemy and loot generation -Difficulty settings -Unlimited save slots -Progression via levelling and perks -Extensive Character customization -Great DLC content -Excellent Modding support -Plenty of role-playing oppurtunities -steam cloud compatability CONS -Its a bethesda game, so it has a lot of bugs -Tends to crash alot, especially on older and/or modded saves -Easy to accidentelly delete a character forever when working with multiple save files -Stupid NPCs (example, trying to mug someone who just ate a dragon's soul after smashing its skull) -Ocasional muse sync issues -Oficial updates have ended -"Save File bloating" -Limited modding capability (without something called Skyrim Script Extender installed) -Slight fps issues on lower-grade computers

game-hours: 410.6
review: I have so many hours in this game on PC and console, i have no idea what to write. So here is a Muffin recipe. Muffins Ingredients 1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour 1/3 cup sugar 2 teaspoons baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 1 egg, beaten 3/4 cup milk 1/4 cup cooking oil Directions Preheat oven to 400 degrees F. Grease twelve 2-1/2-inch muffin cups or line with paper bake cups; set aside. In a medium bowl combine flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt. Make a well in center of flour mixture; set aside. In another bowl combine egg, milk, and oil. Add egg mixture all at once to flour mixture. Stir just until moistened (batter should be lumpy). Spoon batter into prepared muffin cups, filling each 2/3 full. If desired, sprinkle Streusel Topping over muffin batter in cups. Bake for 18 to 20 minutes or until golden and a wooden toothpick inserted in centers comes out clean. Cool in muffin cups on a wire rack for 5 minutes. Remove from muffin cups; serve warm. Makes 12 muffins.

review: I aquired the Mighty Hammer Volendrung and murdered the Chief of an Orc stronghold. I became their new Chief and married the late Chief's daughter. I came home one day and my village was on fire from a Dragon attack. I ran inside and told my wife to come with me. We ran for days until we reached Whiterun where we bought a house and settled in. I told my wife to give me all of our money from our store and to cook me a hot meal. The next morning I set out on a quest across the land - a quest for ultimate power. I came upon Fort Dawnguard on a dark and stormy evening, desperate for shelter and looking to speak with the man in charge. I offered my life and sword for a place in his army of Vampire Hunters and he accepted with gratitude of my bravery and gave me my first quest - to find out what the Vampires are after. I entered a dank dungeon to discover a Vampire entombed, I decided to free it. She led me to her home, Castle Volkihar, where I pledged my eternal allegiance to Vampire Lord Harkon and betrayed my Dawnguard brethren. Lord Harkon gave me a mission - to eliminate all inside of Fort Dawnguard. I did so with haste and I did so with pleasure. When I got to their leader and my former mentor I didn't use my magic, I pierced his flesh with my fangs and drank his life from him slowly. I returned to Castle Volkihar where I then slayed my Master, becoming Vampire Lord Rasputin. I learnt of the ancient power to block out the sun, and so I dipped my Elven arrows into the blood of my Vampire companion, and I shot it into the sky. Complete darkness. I returned to my Orc stronghold swiftly in the night and drained my entire colony of their lives. I came upon my wife in our marital bed and I gently woke her. I bit her neck without a moments hesitation and we fled the colony together, starting our lives anew. I took her to my Castle and they welcomed her into the family with open arms. Only trouble was that my wife used to be my warrior companion...and now I have another. She insisted she come with me to the Depths of Mzinchaleft and I should not have let her...for what await her there I wish I never witnessed. We reached our destination, the heart of the Ruins and were attacked by a Centurian Guardian and two Dwarven Spheres. We retreated to the back corridor as I destroyed the first Sphere with my Hammer, the second one following close. I turn back around and draw my bow to fire at the second Sphere and I let go before I had time to focus... My wife stood in front of my arrow and took it herself, killing her and all the love within my heart. I didn't have time to grieve so I fled the Ruins with haste and returned to my Castle. Filled with despair and hatred for the world, there is not a day that goes by that I do not black out the sun. Every town, every dragon, every animal will feel my rage until there are none left to feel. I have not seen my human form in over 300 days...and I have never returned to Mzinchaleft. ____________________________________________________________ If you haven't heard of Skyrim by 2014 you probably live under a rock. Buy this game, rock dweller. 15/10

review: As the fifth installment of the Elderscrolls series, it is truly everything an adventurer and a roleplayer could hope for. Explore a vast region of a world as detailed as the one we all live in. From the southern most city of RIften, with its birch filled woods and highway travelers. To the barbaric mineraltown of Markarth with its cold winds and viking like people, you will surley find something to be inspired by. The countless hours you will spend to just scratch the surface of this huge world will be filled with friends and foes. Whether its a farmer asking for help with his crops, an ancient vampire haunting a town, a troll attacking a trading camp or a legacy of a dragonborn hero waiting to be fullfilled, everything is there for you to experience. I could go on forever trying to explain how vast this game is, but i took an arrow to my knee and now I just want a belly full of mead.

game-hours: 109.7
review: "As wide as an ocean, as deep as a puddle" pretty much sums up the game. It's a very big game and it gives you a lot of freedom to do what you want. You could wipe out a fort filled with bandits or a city filled with townsfolk. You could hunt down a deer and make a snazzy pair of boots with its hide. You can adopt kids or terrorize the populace as a vampire. Unfortunately, almost every feature is very, very shallow. Combat is generally terrible and any pure melee players are going to be bored to tears with the floaty attacks and unresponsive enemy AI. Marriage and adoption consist of maybe a total of three new lines for your NPC of choice. NPCs don't react to you differently if you wipe out their town and come back a few days later. NPC companions (with the exception of two characters added in the DLCs) rarely do or say anything interesting. I originally played some 150+ hours on the Xbox 360 version before I bought a copy for the PC. The Xbox version of Skyrim is fun, but it can't compare to the PC version with mods. Mods have always been an important part of Bethesda games, and Skyrim is no different. There are thousands of mods under Steam's community workshop and nearly 35k on sites like Nexus Mods. They can add new weapons, armor, quests, and mechanics or improve upon the ones already in the game. Pretty much every problem I have with the base game can be fixed by finding the right mod. Despite its faults, Skyrim is a very enjoyable game. The environments are beautiful, the soundtrack is excellent, and the world as a whole is very detailed. The base game has over 200 hours of content and the (free!) mods only add more bang for your buck. If you haven't played Skyrim yet, you're missing out.

game-hours: 885.2
review: Phenomenal. Absolutely phenomenal. And no, that gameplay logged hours time is not a mistake, or the result of some anomaly (mostly). I had never played an Elder Scrolls game, or even that mythical-era fantasy TYPE of game, unless you count Zelda for the NES when I was 6. That stuff just never appealed to me. Sure, I'm a geek. Okay, a HUGE geek, but never been the medieval times-in', sword-swingin', D&D playin', LARP-in', damsel rescuin', yore-tellin', wizard sleevin', warlock fearin' type of geek. I still don't do any of that stuff, it STILL doesn't really appeal to me. But this game? Oh, this game... My first playthrough I was really enjoying, and about 75% done with the campaign. Then, I googled "Skyrim mods"... I (barely) finished that campaign, which was hard because I got mod-drunk and went CRAZY, with every mod adding a little instability in incompatiblity with each other, as I installed them without "wasting time" reading their descriptions and warnings (pro-tip: MOST big mods recommend they be installed BEFORE you start a campaign). A couple months later, I do it again, on a fresh install, knowing more about mods, but still occasionally crashing, because more and better and bigger mods were STILL coming out that I HAD to try. Now, I'm in my 3rd playthrough, after SEVERAL months off, with all the DLC's, and all the mods that are even BETTER than the DLC's ("Interesting NPCs", "Falskaar", "Moonpath to Elsweyr", ...), and the companions that have been created that have more depth than the whole original cast combined ("Vilja", "Anduniel", "Cerwiden", "Hoth", "Inigo", many from "Interesting NPCs") make this game so much more than a game. It's a damn UNIVERSE. And I'm saying that with NO attachment to the previous games, like The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind, and The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. I bought those games because I like this one, and have logged less than 3 hours *between* them, and THEY are supposed to be phenomenal. I just can't tear myself away from this one. Not yet, anyway. Buy this game. Don't like the whole "lore" type stuff, there are plenty of "lore-breakers" (i.e., having a robot companion from Portal? Yeah, that's a mod). Just buy it, now, quickly, before they...run out? I don't know. Just GET THIS GAME.

game-hours: 27.4
review: People have been asking me to review this one for a very long time, so I finally cracked down and bought a review copy from Nintendo. The game starts like all of the previous games, you are a tiger and you are being sold to the dragons for fur trading, but this game has a big twist! You ARE a dragon! Once you learn about your destiny to slay the other dragons to prove your superiority, you watch as the poor village is drowned in snow, because it's always snowy in Skyrim. You get to change your character's hair color and you can dress up like your favorite video game characters using the in game sprite editor. You can also build your own home using the materials you collect in the overworld. The game gets really tough depending on the time of day, and for example, if it is night time and you have not yet built yourself a home, you will probably not survive. This game introduces new enemies such as the deadly leaf troll, which goes out of it's way to destroy anything you've ever done. Eventually you will reach the bottom of the earth via digging and you will collect raw materials to make your armor with, such as diamonds and dragon bones. One new mechanic is the ability to shout. Because you are part dragon, you learn to speak the language of the dragons and can shout at people. With this new power, you now have the ability to scream your opponents into submission. If you do it in the towns though, the guards will scold you because people don't like to get yelled at. The game is exciting and will suck you into the immersive world with it's creative gameplay. You will never leave your house again. I give this game a solid 5/5!

game-hours: 744.2
review: Quite popular game on the last Dragonborn - hero and just a good guy. The player enters the world of The Elder Scrolls V as usual migrant, who was caught at the border and who was driven in a carriage to execution. Anyone, even a little familiar people with the games of the series, understands that in a few minutes here comes exhilarating moment, associated with the creation of the character. However, one look at the pop-up window in the next moment is enough to understand: role-playing system is not the same. And it's not an interesting test, which has been in past games, and which, of course, is not here. The essence of the complete lack of class, constellations, giving certain allowances. Instead, the player is offered to choose between races already familiar like one most close to him. Graphically TES V significantly outperforms its predecessors. Snow-covered places literally capture hearts of many players in the huge Stone Gem, which is named Skyrim. A stroll through the local ruins, laid roads in mountain ranges, looking in small villages - it is difficult to remain indifferent after all. Music in the game is kept at the proper level, significantly increasing this atmosphere. Personally, I close my eyes to the shortcomings of the game, completely immersed in the atmosphere, so I can put the game 9/10. I hope, Bethesda will again and again delight us with their masterpiece.

review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, the absolute best Elder Scrolls game of the entire series. If you are one of the poor souls who never bothered to go buy this game, you made a huge mistake. At first, I didn't want to buy this game because I thought that it was just another stupid RPG. But Bethesda Game Studios completely shattered my expectations for the game, and heightened them for future Elder Scrolls games. There is always something to do, and you can always do it your way. The way the story is set up allows you to make up your own story. Be a High Elf who's been working as an undercover agent for the Aldmeri Dominion since the third era, who uses the arcane arts to defeat her foes. Or be a Nordic rebel fighting for independence, in a raging civil war in which the Stormcloak rebels are fighting the Empire of Tamriel. Or, be neutral in the war, and be a silent sneaky Khajit who uses the shadows and trickery to outwit his opponents. All of this while exploring dangerous ruins, capturing forts, fighting giant spiders and dragons, and SO MUCH MOREThis game is exciting, expansive, addictive, and you can play it over and over. The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim easily earns a 10/10. Go buy this game, NOW!

review: Well... this game is just amazing. Adventure, action, quests, magic, perfect combination. Actually, you have so much free choice in this game, that I think everyone will love it, because you can basically choose how much every element of this game is important to you. You want to do a lot of sidequests? Go, see bartenders in every city. You want to do some magic? Go to the college of magic. You want to be a bard? Go to a bard school. review: This game seems like the best game ever for a day, week, month, or even a year or two, and then gets boring for a while. Skyrim is kind of like life, sometimes it is fast-paced and so many things are happening, and sometimes its just slow, calm, and quiet, which is what this game is trying to accomplish. This game is not perfect, however. There are bugs, glitches, and the fact that it runs slowly sometimes if you don't have the most up-to-date computer (Which is what my situation happens to be). Some of these bugs can be easily fixed with mods or console commands. This game is great nevertheless, and the fact that so many people are still playing it even when the next game in the series (The Elder Scrolls Online) is out now, shows how great this game is. What makes this game even better is the amount of DLC and mods that the community has made to expand on the game itself. Skyrim is a great way to take a break from life, because its amazing immersion can make you forget completely about your problems happening in the real world. I give Skyrim a 9.25/10

If you are looking for some fun mods, I recommend going to Nexusmods instead of the Steam Workshop, because the mods aren't limited by file size, and can do more complex things than the mods from the Workshop. review: To be honest, I'm not a big fan of this game but I still recommend it because it can be brought to life with the modding community. The vanilla game alone isn't nearly as good as the older titles which I would most recommend if I had the steam versions. The older games, especially Morrowind, had an impressive story, very well written. Skyrim's story was okay, I guess, but I kept getting off track. I especially love all the lore and references linking to the older games. I can go on and on, the game itself is not recommendable, but there are enough parts that I like to recommend this game not only to them casuals, but to Elder Scroll fans out there. With mods like Ultimate Combat, Dragon Combat Overhaul, Civil War Overhaul, Immersive Creatures, Immersive Armors, Immersive Weapons, Character Creation Overhaul with the various add-ons, Pit Fighter, perhaps even Skyrealism...etc...You can brighten up the gameplay a bit more and make it interesting. Personally I like the gameplay altering mods more but I do have a lot of other mods. Again, the game alone isn't too good, but thats why the modding community is here, rather it be the Workshop, Nexus, PlanetElderScrolls, or some other place, they're here to help.

game-hours: 262.6
review: This Game is too good. I mean from the almost endless hours of content to the huge landscape, this game was my favourite game when it came out to now. The story is so interesting about you being the last dragonborn, to the cival war going on between the Imperials and stormcloaks, to guild quests from the Dark Brother hood and theives guild etc, to even the side quests and so on. This story is overall immersive. When you fight for a side in the war, for example taking a fort. You feel as you are actually doing something for it. Even when you assassinate someone for the dark brotherhood you feel the same way. Gameplay is excellent. Combat physics are great. A good example would be the bow, with the skill in the Archery tree you can zoom in when aiming but at the cost of stamina. The fact that everything in this game is balanced is great, not having one type of class being overpowered and another being useless.If you do get bored with the vanilla spells and weapons you can dowload mods right off the steam workshop. Easy and safely The game has so many diffrent choices, from altering the story to changing the way you fight. There are three main classes with many diffrent sub classes. Warrior, Archer, Assassin and Mage. If you have not purchased this game yet and you are reading this just know that these classes are NOT set you can switch if you really wanted to with the recently added "legendary" system. For example lets say you start the game off being a destruction mage and in one point in time you realize its not the style of play you enjoy you can start leveling perks into diffrent skill tree's, maybe into stealth or pickpocketing (my personal favourites). There are a lot of story altering choices you can make. I dont want to go into detail with any of these because they do have spoiler alerts. Skill trees are things which you can put skill points into (which you get everytime you level up) to increase power in a style of play. The names of these trees include destrution, one handed, blocking, conjuration, restoration, stealth, lockpicking etc and thats just a few. And as a plus there are no limits on what you can do and what you cant. For many of you MMO players such as myself, you know that there are armor and weapon restrictions depending on what class you choose. For example casters cant wear heavy armor and cant wield 2 handed battle axes. Thats not a problem in this game, if being a tanky caster is what you want to do, then do it. Also you can enchant the diffrent types of weapons and armor so that its suits you. Another huge part of custimization is races. The are ten races in the game with each being for a diffrent play style. Khajits being the cats are good for stealth because of there bonuses in it and wood elves are good for being a archer or stealth because of there bonuses in those play styles and so on. You also get to change the appearance of your character. Overall custimization and choices are a huge part of this game. The map is huge!!! You get to roam all of skyrim. This including ruins, tombs, dungeons, cities etc. The textures are beautiful. I dowloaded the free HD texture pack and it has really enhanced my game. Im not saying its ugly without it but its better with the texture pack (download it if possible). Everything is great in the landscape, may it be alot of mountains. A couple of downsides to the game -NPC's AI (espicially lydia) -Mountains, Mountains everywhere -Glitchy Overall this game has got to be one of the best games of I've ever played. I highly recommend it to everybody. Such a good game 10/10

game-hours: 241.2
review: A truly great game. My TES journey started with Oblivion and after playing it I was amazed by the sheer amount of greatness. When Skyrim came out, I was blown away by the amount of content and quality at the same time. The graphics are amazing and well optimized for not so powerful computers like mine. The gameplay is engaging and fun at the same time.The story is great and the amount and quality of the side quests as well as the faction quests is overwhelming. The character customization allows for multiple different playthroughs: you can be a silent and cunning argonian assassin, a bash-and-smash orc, a patriotic nord warrior or a bosmer mage, freezing, shocking and burning anyone standing in your way. And that's only a really really small portion of all the elements that'll you discover. Any flaw or feature that exists in Skyrim can be fixed/modified by one of the thousands of mods out there, lots of them being really high quality: starting from unofficial patches, going to combat, immersion and other gameplay enhancements, weapon and armor mods, finishing with DLC-like and size land mods full of content to keep you playing . Even when you finish all the quests, tasks, delve every dungeon, clear out every cave and ruin, defeat every foe possible, you still find something to do. To sum up, Skyrim is the best game I've played so far. After playing 200+ hours, I still feel I haven't even scratched the surface of the whole game. Great story and setting, good gameplay mechanics and an overwhelming amount of content will keep you immersed for thousands of hours. And if you feel you lost interest for it after playing it for some time, try out installing a few to a dozen mods based on your taste, maybe one of those popular overhauls, and try again. Trust me, it'll feel like you're playing a new game

review: Evidence that a good game with a workshop becomes a great game
game-hours: 101.6
review: A good game, but largely overrated. It's better than Oblivion in every conceivable way. However, it's not all good. It really is a pretty dumbed down RPG in the end, as well. A lot of nerds will cite that Morrowind had more skills thna Skyrim and, while it's true, that's not entirely bad. You have to admit, Morrowind did have some useless skills, like Acrobatics. However, when I say dumbed down, I mostly mean that there's almost no consequence to the game. There's no real consequence to taking a side in the civil war, there's no real consequence to becoming a werewolf. The only thing even close to consequence is when vampires attack if you have the Dawnguard DLC. So, in otherwords, for nothing. There's no semblance of risk to anything in the game. This is especially egregious when a good 3rd of all the NPCs in game are unkillable. There's not really any free choice to this RPG to speak of in terms of how you go about playing and questing. It even contradicts the lore in some ways. A great example is the schizophrenic difficulty. It's established that dragons are the harbingers of the end times. Shouldn't they be hard fights? They're honestly push overs. A shield bash followed by attack over and over is an excellent way to kill a dragon. However, the giants? They're insanely hard by comparison. Should a dragon fight a giant, it gets destroyed instantly. Even wimpy  little trolls are tougher than dragons. This really touches again on the lack of any consequence. It really makes me feel like this is a dangerous quest when the actual harbingers of the apocalypse push overs. In the end, it's a fun RPG, but it's not deserving of the idolization it receives. And anyone that made arrow to the knee jokes at any point really needs to be sterilized.

review: Imagine Fallout or New Vegas set in the dark ages, and you have the start of Skyrim. A free roaming game which gives the player control of where they want to go, what they want to do, and how to do it. This game is long. Really long. Longer than the Fallout games. I can't stress that enough. If you had a choice of only buying one game during summer break, this would be your best bet. There is always something to do, or some place to explore. I bought this on sale for $7.50 and it was every penny well spent. It is annoying getting attacked at random times by dragons. Plus there are a few bugs/glitches, but that always comes with free-roaming games. Your partner in the game can get lost sometimes or stuck on objects. Also your partner will block you every time you want to go back through a door. Those problems are small potatoes though. 8.5/10

game-hours: 660.9
review: hmm.. where shall i start... THIS GAME IS F***ING AMAZING!. heres why in my complete review. First off its open world concept. You can chose from a variety of different races, which have various pros for each race. (If you like mods. There are plenty of mods that add new races to chose from: For example, Star wars and final Fantasy to just name a few. after this, you can customize almost everything about your charaacter: body weight, eyes, eys color, nose, etc, basically something similar to what people who have played the Fallout games experience. Next lets mention the story. The story is detailed but very entertaining at the same time. You start as a regular joe captured by imperial forces when all of a sudden, A big Dragon swops in and kills about half of everybody there. So you and a buddy named Ragolf (i think thats his name :P) make an escape and regroup at a town called Riverwood. From there you are free to explore the world however you chose. And With so many side quests, Faction quests, and just exploring the world of skyrim, It can be overwhelmingly exciting and aweing (and even a bit distracting from the main story quest lol) Now that im done explaining that part. lets move on to skills and how you level up in skyrim. Leveling up in skyrim is quite unique compared to other games of its kind. You gain experience from using one of the 18 skills that are divided into three sections, Warrior, Magic, and Theif. You have to use the skills in order to level up. Unfortunatly, you do not gain extra points for immediaty completeing the quest, as compared with the Fallout games. Warrior skills consist of enchanting, smithing, Heavy armor, Block, Two-handed weapons, One handed Weapons, and Archery. Magic skills are divided by what "school of Magic" they represent: Illusion, Conjuration, Destruction, Restoration, and Alteration. Basically in the shortest way possible, I have given you a good explanation at just what these schools of magic are. Illusion spells have to do with fooling other peoples minds. Conjuration brings up dead people and zombies. Destruction lets you deal damage by shooting out lightening, Fire, or Ice from your very hands, Restoration allows you to heal and protect yourself and other people. And alteration allows you to use skills like waterbreating, Stoneflesh, etc. Now that that is out of the way, going back to skills in general, the Last major Skill, Theif, consists of light armor, sneak, lockpicking, pickpocket, speech, and alchemy. :) To note, the only concerns one should have about this game is that there can be a few irratating bugs, such as people who give missions to you wont give you a reward even though you have to go to them to get your reward. :P Also Ive noticed a few graphical problems, but anyone who has a good PC should be fine enough to enjoy this game. To finally sum this up, before i go back to playing more skyrim :), there is a good handful of other miscellaneous things to do besides completing quests, killing dragons and creepy undead nord zombies when your bored out of your mind. Your can go to your local pub and pay a singer to sing songs about skyrim. You can purposely get arrested and escape from jail. You can buy a house and keep all your unwanted crap there, After you buy the furnishings of course. You can get married, have her give you some gold coin and make an instant yummy homecooked meal just for you. You can do what I did and have your Female Housecarl from Dragonsreach stay with you AND be married with your beautiful Nord wife at the same time. lol. :) The List is Endless, Just like skyrim ItsSelf. FUS-DO-RAH!!!

game-hours: 233.5
review: Minecraft is a sandbox styled game created by Markus 'Notch' Persson in which you, well, mine and craft. You gather materials to both construct your house and craft tool and weapons to fight off the creatures of the night. Minecraft has taken an 'always in development' stance and I think it works in its favour. Whenever I see an update I always think 'What crazy things has Notch put in this time?' and start the download with glee. When you start up a 'world' you are thrown into Minecraft's lush and blocky world without any direction. While I do think this encourages exploration a small tutorial would have been a good addition. What you want to do when you start a new world is cut down trees. "But I don't have an Axe you lump of  with arms and legs!" I hear you cry, well fear not! You can cut down trees with the flat of your hands. When you have cut down a few trees you can start crafting! Go into your inventory (accessed by pressing the 'E' key on your keyboard) and grab the logs you got from the trees and put them into your 'crafting menu'. You should see planks on the left of this menu, grab those and put them in your inventory. Now the fun can really begin! Grab the planks and put them in your crafting menu and fill the four spaces to create a 'crafting bench'. Here you will have access to a 3x3 crafting menu instead of the 2x2 you have in your inventory. Now I would tell you more but it would be more fun to let you figure it out on your own! But just remember to find shelter at night, or the monsters will get you! Now the graphics are interesting, as in they're good and bad at the same time. Notch has decided to make Minecraft's visual appearance be that of a blocky and pixely landscape and, strangely, it works in its favour. I always find myself breath-taken whenever the Sun sets across the hills. The controls of Minecraft are very simple, left click to hit things (or harvest them) and right click to place blocks down or use an item's special ability. You can also press the Space Bar to jump and the 'Q' key to throw items on the floor. In conclusion, I believe Minecraft is a very well constructed game and Mojang have a bright future ahead of them. In all, I give this game a 0/10, avoid like the ing plague.

game-hours: 26.6
review: EPIC WIN
game-hours: 499.6
review: Skyrim is an open world RPG that focuses on having amazing world design before anything else. Is this a good thing or a bad thing? Let's find out I played Skyrim as soon as it launched, without mods or any kind of changes to the game and my first impression of the game was positive but after a few hours of gameplay I noticed that the game was a "casual" mess, having 100 sneak will make NPCs completly blind even if you are clearly crouching in front of them, going for mage goes from useless to overpowered, enemies don't seem to level up beyond LV 50 which makes you overpowered as soon as you pass that limit and the maximum armor is 80% which could have been reached with both light armor and heavy armor which made heavy armor useless, the lack of stats in general gave me a bad taste in my mouth as a fan of RPGs such as the Witcher. I still finished the game regardless of the terribly unbalanced skills and underpowering enemies and with finished I mean every single side quest and main quest completed. The main story line is really not worth your time ,the main meat of the game is the open world and the exploration so if you just want to rush through the main story of the game you will be finished in about 5 hours and left disappointed because it's just not very good. The side story lines are very interesting and usually discovered by simply walking around cities, talking with bartenders about the latest rumors or just randomly running into people that seek your aid. There are side story lines for the thief guild, the companions, the dark brotherhood etc. I really loved every single side story quest in this game and I doubt you would hate them. The combat is meh. It's a massive improvement over oblivion or Morrowind but it still lacks the RPG feeling. You can use something in your left hand and something in your right hand and by using left mouse and right mouse you can use whatever you have equipped in that hand but there are never moments in the combat where you will be impressed by the things your character is doing, it's all very generic and what we have all seen before. Example: You play as a two handed weapon warrior all you can do is attack, block and power attack (holding the button to break enemy block) besides that there are no abilities such as a whirling your weapon in a circle to kill all surrounding enemies or throwing your weapon towards the enemy. The Enemy AI is ok but if you are planning on doing a stealth run, well then it's awful. In normal combat situation the enemy AI will use whatever they have the ability to use at the distance they are supposted to use, sadly the AI isn't smart enough to dodge dungeon traps or switch weapons for different situations and archers and mages don't seem to run away even when you just charged their position and are in close combat with them using your sword. If you are the kind of type that wants to sneak in this game well you won't be liking the AI because if your sneak is high enough, the AI will completly ignore you even if you are right in front of them (I mean this quite literally). The friendly AI is garbage because it's the same AI as the enemies but unlike the enemies these guys follow you. Remember when I mentioned how the enemy AI triggers traps? Well the friendly one does that too. So you planned on doing a sneaky mage run and need an AI companion as a tank? Well too bad because there is no such thing as a "taunt" so the enemies will still go for you since you are a bigger threat to them. The personalities in this game are awful, there is no deepth to any character in the game besides Serana in the Dawnguard DLC and it's not your fault for not asking them about their backstories or just not caring about such thing but it's because the game really doesn't give you any options to ask them. There is a mod called "interesting NPCs" on skyrim nexus which tries to fix this issue by adding NPCs that have deepth but I really would have loved more deepth to the currect characters because there are many interesting looking one but thanks to the lack of options you will never know much about them even if you marry them. The world is interesting and beautiful, you will find yourself enjoying wandering around the world and exploring everything there is to offer the only complaint I have when it comes to the world design are the dungeons, they are very repetetive and they did try to give them some varity but all they gave me were deja vus of constantly repeating corridors and rooms. Overall the game is good but if you are planning to buy this game on PC please mod it. You can fix most of the issues I have listed here using mods and even improve things that I havent seen as issue (such as the textures). A must buy on PC and I recommend it to everyone regardless of age or liking, you will like this game and if you don't like it you mod it until you like it.

game-hours: 52.9
review: This game is just simply amazing. The scale of the map, and all the locations you can discover and conquer is just unbelieveable. The graphics, also, are really good too. PLus with all the mods you can get to enhance the graphics, it will leave you breathless. And lets not forget the fact that this whole series is RPG. Build your character from scratch, with a large variety of races, all with their own unique abilities and looks, then choose what you want to be, wether its an archer, a warrior, or a mage, Skyrim provides you with a huge variety of perks to unlock and eventually build your epic dream warrior. The questline in this game is quite fantastic as well. You, a prisoner entering Skyrim at the wrong time, find yourself in the midst of a civil war in Skyrim, along with the fact that the ancient dragons of Tamriel are reawakening. You find out that you are the Dragonborn, the one being spoken and written about throughout Tamriel, who can use the power of the voice to defeat and puish enemies. But mos importantly, you are the only one who can defeat the evil ancient dragon, Alduin, who plans to destroy the world. The enemies, the weapons, the magic, the characters, the locations, the sights, and the sounds and music of Skyrim will 100% pull you in and keep you entertained for months on months, possibly years. (I've been playing since Nov. 11, it's release.) And with all the mods you can get through the Skyrim Workshop or the Skyrim Nexus, they will add even more things to experience in this game, both hilarious and immersive, or even just plain fun. Feel free to take a look at my screenshots for a taste of Skyrim. If I haven't persuaded you yet, I encourage you to look online. Please do yourself a favor, buy this game. Welcome to Tamriel, fellow adventurer.
game-hours: 239.2
review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is by far the defining game of a generation. With top notch combat and relatable characters that anyone could get behind, it cements its place as one of the greatest FPS tacticle shooters of all time. With a campaign that will take you across a land terroised by the south american dragons, and with the looming threat of all out rebellion (a homage to the conflict in Syria according to Bethfesda) it really gets the player immeresed in a flawless adventure that can take up to 8 hours to complete, a new record for the elder scrolls series. After the campaign, spend seconds exploring the map to find hundreds of easter eggs that pay homage to the game that inspired the world, Call Of Duty! I know what your thinking right now, how could this game possably get any cooler? Well with the game winning over 420 awards, bethfesda decided to reward players with the new and improved Legendary Edition! This edition adds over 2 new weapons into the game, and gives players the woodland camo for their crossbow in multiplayer! In addition to all this, it adds the brand new map Solstiem, where you fight The evil Dragonborn Al Qaeda in a all out war for FREEDOM! JUSTICE! AND AMERICA! Don't worry guys, Bethfesda didn't stop there, they promised DLC for the game that would change the face of skyrim forever and they DELIVERED! I know if your like me, you've always wanted to role play as Angelina Joliene and Bradd Pitt but sadly there was no way to do this. Well Bethfesda fixed it, with a whole new adoption DLC, adopt hundreds of street urchins from all over the world like ethiopia. Worried about storing all these kids? Don't worry, Bethfesda has you covered! With the new Hearthstone DLC spend hours mining for stone, waste thousands of gold on lumber and precious resources, then build your own house that you can visit once and then question why you did this in the first place! Still wanting more?? WIth the new Dawnguard DLC indulge in your dark side and help vamp kids earn back their rightful place in skyrim. Go on up to 3 new quests where you earn a woman that constantly follows you and second guesses you every step of the way! Or have a thousand year old man suck you tenderly on the neck, only to find out he infected you with vamparism and that you can never see the light of day again or your just ED. Have fun watching your skin turn flaky and pale while you beat it to the lusty argonian in the basement of your house for all enternity! What am i forgetting? Oh yeah, MODS! Perminetly escape your reality with thousands and thousands of mods made by others who have discovered the joy of euphoria and the comfort of a fedora just like you! Never see the light of Earth again as you waste hundreds of hours of your life trying to escape what you cannot deal with in your reality!  YES! Be warned though, this game will cause you to reach a enlightend state of euphoria. You'll start to see console players as "filthy casuals" and relise that everyone around you is a pleb, never to know the true joys of PC. You will then build a PC completly devoted to skyrim and then you can show it off, you'll be the envy of all your "friends" on Gaia and Reddit! Who knows! Maybe they will even grace you with a tip of the fedora for all your work! To sum it up, this game revolutionises online gaming. With constant updates, new maps, and weapons THE RIDE WILL NEVER END! I'd give it 5 quickscopes out of 5! Don't just take my word for it look at what the pros have to say! 10/10 "Its ok"-IGN DASUDASULOL-PS3Insider Tip of the Fedora/Euphoria"I don't need your phony nine divines!"-PCandFedoraAlliance The Game that Keeps on Giving-Brazzers 5 skulls out of 5"THE RIDE NEVER ENDS"-Mr. Bones "One day ill wake up and just see skyrim....and i'm ok with that"-Some other  that reviewed this

review: It's difficult to ever feel completely satisfied with a play session of Skyrim. There's always one more pressing quest, one more unexplored tract of land, one more skill to increase, one more butterfly to catch. It's a mesmerizing game that draws you into an finely crafted fictional space packed with content that consistently surprises. The changes made since Oblivion are many, and result in a more focused and sensible style of play, where the effects of every decision are easily seen. Featuring the same kind of thrilling freedom of choice The Elder Scrolls series is known for along with beautiful visuals and a stirring soundtrack, playing Skyrim is a rare kind of intensely personal, deeply rewarding experience, and one of the best role-playing games yet produced. I have to say I give this game a solid 10/10.

review: Deep story telling and character progression. This game can keep you hooked for hours just by the sheer amount of exploring at your disposal. The community is active and lots of mods exist, definitely one of the best games out there. The only thing I'd "fault" it for is the lack of deeper relationships with the characters you meet, and I am not talking about marriage but relationships in general. The combat could be better, but you can be just about anything you want. I like the crafting system, you really have to work at it, but it's worth doing. The game immerses you in epic memorable telling, this is easily the best game of The Elder Scrolls series.

game-hours: 817.1
review: The Elder Scrolls: V: Skyrim is an RPG adventure-fantasy video games that was released by Bethesda Game Studios on 11/11/2011. The game features hundreds of hours of customized gameplay, all starting with very extesnive character creation options. The game features several immersive storylines, quests, and choices to define your character's path. You will meet hundreds of interesting, and sometimes relatable, characters who will help in defining your adventure, and you will cross thousands of enemies that will keep you on your toes whether you're creeping through a dungeon or charging across the open moorlands. The main storyline features you, the Dragonborn, an individual with the power to use the Thu'um - the tongue of Dragons. The Dragonborn will be facing powerful dragons throughout his/her adventures in one mission: To defeat Alduin, the God of Destruction, who is prophecized to destory the world. It is up to the Dragonborn to embark on a dangerous mission, but like all stories, there are several chapters that will lead the Dragonborn off of his/her trail and into the war-torn land of the people of Skyrim. With several online mods available to further increase your experience, but with so much already available, Skyrim is a brilliant game that draws you in and threatens to never let go. Inspiring and epic, with a beautiful score and excellent graphics, it will be nearly impossible to not let yourself be indulged in this virtual world of endless possibilities and breathtaking wonders...

review: Skyrim is the firth instalment of the elder scrolls franchies. It followes the same sort of story as the others, as you start out as a prisoner arrested for a crime we don't know. Just as your about to be beheaded, a dragon attacks the town and you are set free. You are then given a choice wether to go with the rebels or the people who tried to kill you. Once free from empire you find out you are the dragon born and you have to go to Whiterun. After this the civil war falls out of the picture as it isn't very important to the whole story. There are many side quest and campaines like an assassi and theif quest and a mage story. Alos there are many little quest that will build up if you let them take over. It is a very long game with lots of interesting people and can be modded so it is stupid. Overall i would defenitly recomend this game as a great game and i can't wait for elder scrolls online.

review: Huang ran a poultry farm. There were ducks of all hues and sizes in his farmwhite ducks, brown ducks, ducks with stripes, and ducks with specks. Every morning, Huang and his two workers, Bill and Jim, would go around the city in a big truck. They supplied ducks and eggs to schools, restaurants, and canteens. One day, Huang set off on his round. At his first stop Huang counted, One, two, three, fourfour ducks for St Peters, and carried them into the school kitchen. Tom, a naughty boy thought, Now for some fun. He opened the truck door and one by one all the ducks came down. Quack! Quack!! they went all the way into the school. Soon the whole school was filled with quacking ducks. Children came out of their classrooms and screamed in joy. Hearing the commotion, Huang came out. Come back! he said quacking sound and all the ducks came back to him.

game-hours: 469.6
review: BEST GAME EVER
game-hours: 213.2
review: Skyrim, is a Medvial set RPG/Action/Adventure/Badass game that focuses around your character also known as the Dragonborn. This game has a long and awesome Main-Questline that brings you all around the Providence of Skyrim. Takes you to the peaks of High Hrothgar to meet the Seclusive Greybeards, and to the dank tunnels of old burial crypts and tombs. In addition to the Main Questline hundreds of hours of side quests including many very large ones (Civil War, Deadric Quests), can keep you occupied for weeks. But thats not all! If you spend hundreds of hours playing the game and have destroyed every monster, explored every cave, there's one more thing you can add to expand the game infinitly. MODS! There are thousands of mods on the steam workshop that can instantly expand your game in ways you couldnt even imagine, this game is not only huge as is with its 3 great DLC's, but can be even more expanded with mods! This is a must buy for any PC Gamer!

review: Quite popular game on the last Dragonborn - hero and just a good guy. The player enters the world of The Elder Scrolls V as usual migrant, who was caught at the border and who was driven in a carriage to execution. Anyone, even a little familiar people with the games of the series, understands that in a few minutes here comes exhilarating moment, associated with the creation of the character. However, one look at the pop-up window in the next moment is enough to understand: role-playing system is not the same. And it's not an interesting test, which has been in past games, and which, of course, is not here. The essence of the complete lack of class, constellations, giving certain allowances. Instead, the player is offered to choose between races already familiar like one most close to him. Graphically TES V significantly outperforms its predecessors. Snow-covered places literally capture hearts of many players in the huge Stone Gem, which is named Skyrim. A stroll through the local ruins, laid roads in mountain ranges, looking in small villages - it is difficult to remain indifferent after all. Music in the game is kept at the proper level, significantly increasing this atmosphere. Personally, I close my eyes to the shortcomings of the game, completely immersed in the atmosphere, so I can put the game 9/10. I hope, Bethesda will again and again delight us with their masterpiece.

game-hours: 817.1
review: The Elder Scrolls: V: Skyrim is an RPG adventure-fantasy video games that was released by Bethesda Game Studios on 11/11/2011. The game features hundreds of hours of customized gameplay, all starting with very extesnive character creation options. The game features several immersive storylines, quests, and choices to define your character's path. You will meet hundreds of interesting, and sometimes relatable, characters who will help in defining your adventure, and you will cross thousands of enemies that will keep you on your toes whether you're creeping through a dungeon or charging across the open moorlands. The main storyline features you, the Dragonborn, an individual with the power to use the Thu'um - the tongue of Dragons. The Dragonborn will be facing powerful dragons throughout his/her adventures in one mission: To defeat Alduin, the God of Destruction, who is prophecized to destory the world. It is up to the Dragonborn to embark on a dangerous mission, but like all stories, there are several chapters that will lead the Dragonborn off of his/her trail and into the war-torn land of the people of Skyrim. With several online mods available to further increase your experience, but with so much already available, Skyrim is a brilliant game that draws you in and threatens to never let go. Inspiring and epic, with a beautiful score and excellent graphics, it will be nearly impossible to not let yourself be indulged in this virtual world of endless possibilities and breathtaking wonders...

review: Huang ran a poultry farm. There were ducks of all hues and sizes in his farmwhite ducks, brown ducks, ducks with stripes, and ducks with specks. Every morning, Huang and his two workers, Bill and Jim, would go around the city in a big truck. They supplied ducks and eggs to schools, restaurants, and canteens. One day, Huang set off on his round. At his first stop Huang counted, One, two, three, fourfour ducks for St Peters, and carried them into the school kitchen. Tom, a naughty boy thought, Now for some fun. He opened the truck door and one by one all the ducks came down. Quack! Quack!! they went all the way into the school. Soon the whole school was filled with quacking ducks. Children came out of their classrooms and screamed in joy. Hearing the commotion, Huang came out. Come back! he said quacking sound and all the ducks came back to him.

review: Got bored with Skyrim today, yes, it is possible, after 100 hours, I had stopped the dragon uprising, slaughtered a castle of vampires, killed an ageless dragonborn, wiped out a dark brotherhood base, collected the seven black books, helped a dead guy finish his book, collected the dragon priest masks, helped the empire crush the stormcloak army, downloaded some mods, made my own house and got it fully furnished, got Wabbajack, and several other artifacts of the like, which I shortly thereof dropped, had not just a dragon working for me, but also had a zombie dragon, and a skeleton horse, and also many other little quests, and made Skyrim a better place. So how to finish with a bang, even through I easily had over fifty more objectives left? Used console commands to make my guy level 80, to face the Ebony Warrior. He was...Odd. His talk of a lack of quests or villains to slay runs parallel to anyone who put WAY to much time into this game, and he wished me to kill him, battle to the death on a mountain-side. After climbing up, and finding that he killed a frost troll with a shout, I decided I was out of my league, and turned on immortailty mode. Not the mode with the super strength though, I wanted to have fun. Although, I also learned that my console "kill" command would just heal him to full health. My zombie dragon and his summoned monsters helped weaken him, but I would not be able to shout for a while, so, with my ebony blade in one hand, and Dawnbreaker in the other, I hacked at him, and hacked at him, and he choped my head off. Due to the immortailty, my guy was alive, but now instead of a head, he had a bloody stump at the end of his neck. I stated searching the ground for my head, hopefully it hadn't rolled very far, and I found it, laying there, helmet and all, bloody gore at it's base matching my hero's neck. It was unfortunate that I couldn't pick it up, because I would have probably thrown it at the Ebony Warrior. I loaded a pre-decapitation save, and climbed the mountain-side, again, and tryed this again, warry of a headless future like so many running chickens. summoning my sidekick after a while, I resorted to my Dwarven crossbow to deal out the damage from afar, only to learn of the Warrior's paralyzing arrows. It is a curious feeling, laying on the ground in a mid-stride postion, incapable of movement, as your sidekick is taught the meaning of pain, and the Ebony Warrior heals himself, and I also learned that his blade had health sapping capabilities, he healed as he tried to kill me. After my shout meter was ready, I called a storm, lightning, rain, wind, the works. You would think being stuck by lightning five times within three minutes would slow a man down, but not this one. Even with a small cloud of electricity circling him. Did I mention he beat my dragon? and he continued to use his shouting, and I was watching as my warrior went tumbling down the side of the mountain, limp as a sloth dropped from twenty thousand feet. As my hero got to his feet, and climbed the mountain, I might as well mention the stuff this guy was saying to me, asking me to hit him harder, and the like, so after the storm wore off, he still wasn't dead, in fact he healed quite a bit, and the scorch marks, arrows and tiny spears, bolts, weapons from the dragon's allies, and that dead troll, we did quite a bit of damage. If I fought this guy in Whiterun where I met him, we might have killed as many people as the game would let us, and also have amassed a small hill of dead guards. Finally, after about twenty or such dwarven bolts in his body, the Ebony Warrior fell, joy was with him as he cried out about his reward. I then proceeded to steal whatever item of value I wanted from his corpse, I was curious as to why he had two hearts (daedra, and human) and I also liberated him of his flawless dimond and items of the liken. I found it raceist when I removed his helmet to find him most likely a former resident of Hammerfall. And I also took the time to shout at his corpse. I saved the game, and quit to desktop. I; had finished my Skyrim experince. Untill the Skywind mod is out.

review: Skyrim is truly a must own game, one that goes down as one of the best of all time. I'm sure though that you probably know this already, and are looking to buy it on your own, and if you don't already own this game, you really should. Welcome to Skyrim, a world were nord fantasy and dragons aboad. Here, magic wizards and sorcerers live, only to be lost in defeat to the returned dragons. Now, all that is the armys of Skyrim, waging war on both eachother and the dragons that have come. You, a prisoner in the crossfire of these wars, is destined to defeat the dragons and restore the Skyrim world. Though in Skyrim, you may choose another path. Like most open world games, your options aren't limited to one path. You can choose from the evil of the world, or the conquering of the world. Here, you can wander steep slopes, vast tundra, large bodies of water, and even slay dragons. All the while, you collect several items and other incredible peripherals known as "shouts". The more you play, the more you just get pulled in. Not to mention the modding community for the game is beyond massive, and the people who do make these mods create THOUSANDS of extra hours of content, and that is trimming it down to just a slim portion. Simply put, Skyrim is one off the best games ever made, EVER. A must own for any gamer, and for the price, it would be a sin not to buy.

review: My prelimenary opinion would be that this game is even more awesome than the ones that came before. game-hours: 152.1
review: Admittedly, I review this game as a non-ES long-time player and aficionado (like most Skyrim players though). The main thing I'm gonna say about Skyrim is that it is certainly a good and completely functional open box RPG. The modding community is so huge and the modders so good that with a pack of top-notch modifications you can limitlessly expand the game (with minor performance issues). I personally find almost every game released in the last 5 years to be unsatisfying for a person like myself, so I can't rate it more than 8/10. Nonetheless, as I've stated above mods can make Skyrim really immersive. You think a feature like the Werewolf transformation is uncomplete and poorly implemented? There's a mod for that. You think being limited to travelling with a mere and dysfunctional follower is somewhat unrealistic for a well renowned hero and Dragonborn? There's a mod for that. You find quite weird being an adventurer and not having a backpack with you all the time? There's a mod for that. You want to introduce new armour and weapons? Be my guest. I might be a little bit obsessed, and over a decade of playing videogames in almost all of my spare time may have increased excessively my aspirations towards videogames, but there isn't really any reason not to mod a game of this sort. You're just missing a bunch of features you will end up looking for later on, or that you didn't know you wanted yet. Besides, why didn't Bethesda add spears? It was real-life Nords favourite weapon!
game-hours: 55.7
review: Completely incompareable to any other RPG game out there. I've never played a finer game in a finer series of games. The amount of time you could spend doing anything is endless. In an open free, vast world, there's plenty of room to do whatever you want, and that's just the regular game! The mod community for Skyrim is unlike any I have other seen, and that just sweetens the experience on top of the already-outstanding official DLC that goes with it. It really did live up to it's potential in the Elder Scrolls series, and even exceeded it. After playing Morrowind and Oblivion, I can say that I have nothing to be upset with. As a former player of Morrowind and Oblivion, I have only just recently gotten Skyrim for PC, and It still doesn't get old. My advice would be that if able, try out a bit of Morrowind, and Oblivion so you can get your taste set in on the Elder Scrolls, or if you want, you can just jump right into Skyrim. The Graphics: 10/10 The Storyline: 10/10 The Choices: 10/10 Recommendation: BUY THIS GAME (NOW)
