review: It's difficult to ever feel completely satisfied with a play session of Skyrim. There's always one more pressing quest, one more unexplored tract of land, one more skill to increase, one more butterfly to catch. It's a mesmerizing game that draws you into an finely crafted fictional space packed with content that consistently surprises. The changes made since Oblivion are many, and result in a more focused and sensible style of play, where the effects of every decision are easily seen. Featuring the same kind of thrilling freedom of choice The Elder Scrolls series is known for along with beautiful visuals and a stirring soundtrack, playing Skyrim is a rare kind of intensely personal, deeply rewarding experience, and one of the best role-playing games yet produced. I have to say I give this game a solid 10/10.

game-hours: 1.9
review: This gaem es bueno(;
game-hours: 21.3
review: Hold on to your helmet, this'll be a long one... Does this game even need an explanation? The subsequent game in the series to 'Oblivion', it is in my opinion a genuine improvement. Aside from the obvious graphical improvement (which can be upped ridiculously further via modding), the middleage-european atmosphere has been abandonned for a more enticing nordic-fantasy one, to which I am enjoying far more greatly, allowing for a far greater variety of situations and sights. In terms of gameplay, movement is better weighted, but the melee combat itself remains largely untouched; as such the 'floatiness' and of swinging remains also. This is not to my preference, as it greatly detracts from the satisfaction you could have felt from strikes. Magic and casting however, is infinitely more diverse and satisfying. While not perfect, casting double handed is both completely, jawdroppingly epic and far more practical. You may level up aspects of your spell tree to your liking, and the freedom that comes with this is dizzying. However, with this freedom comes a major detraction. Oblivion's spellmaking opened up so many clever possibilities with its options to 'design' spells - now you're mostly restricted to what you can buy in shops or s find. Levelling up in terms of other abilities is seamless and effective, as you organically become more proficient in whatever you use most, a far better option than picking your majoring class before you even know what you may be up against. The the enemies are generally what you would expect in all honestly, if not somewhat uninspired. You'll face off against spiders, skeletons, big spiders, skeletons that can shout at you a bit. It's only when you REALLY get into the meat of the world that you find any prominent enemies worth your time. Specifically, the dragons you will battle are absolutely astounding, with your first kill an amazing moment in your 'venture. Visuals are satisfactory. Nothing more. Not reaaaaally BAD, but also not amazing at all. ... Lol jk. with the application of mods this can be quickly remedeed. Oh, we're not talking a HD texture patch, cus Bethesda already gave us that. We're talking complete overhall in all areas. Textures, decals, models, partical effects, lighting, water, everything. The phidelity can reach 'Crysis' levels with a nice enough combination of mods, and while this is technically is not the cause of the game, the modding community is so dedicated and integrated to the scene that it might as well be, and for PC; come on, seriously, modding's a friggin standard. The actuall surroundings of Skyrim are diverse and dynamic, and are far in preference for me to Oblivion (maybe Morrowind?). My only gripe is that a large portion of the main story string seems to occur surrounded by snow, but the fact that there ARE many other seasons to see mostly neutralises this complaint anyway. Sound and music are adequate, but are in comparison less magnificent than the sights you witness in parallel. Not very much to address here. The only notable addition to the soundtrack is the main theme, which is so stupidly epic that it almost... ALMOST makes up for the rest of the score. However, the rest of the score DOES serve its purpose, with some pleasantly mellow tracks that act as peaceful ambiance to your travels. The actual *main* plot is something that I cannot praise, as for an unsual reason its massively hazy in my memory. This was likely due to its briefity and comparitive disengagement from the sheer magnitude of the rest of the game. The final boss is great but not fantastic, but my main complaint for the story line stems from its predicticality. You are TOLD very early on that YOU are the Dragonborn, and as such this detracts from the overall revelation. However, this was in fact likely for the best, as you would in response be unable to perform shouts, kill dragons, etcetera until much later than otherwise allowable. Not as fun to be honest. Skryrim... You forgiven. I have so much to say about this game that I'd go on for much, much longer. But this is getting out of hand. To wrap up, out of the DLC available, 'Dawngaurd' is easily most worth your time. More story driven than 'Dragonborn', it will extend your adventure in a more meaninful, motivational manner. 'Hearthfire' is fairly unneeded and can be replaced by some mods, while 'Dragonborn' is somewhat less polished and briefer. The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is quite frankly a masterpiece, and (debatably) one of the best in the series. You can't go wrong, with literally hundreds of hours of gameplay available even after the main story line is over, picking this up on discount for as little as 4 freaking pounds sterling should be criminal. But I love it. + Ceaseless, seamless character progression + Beautiful, intricate open world + Polished casting system, geniously combinable with melee combat - Somewhat lackluster visuals and sound -- (ironically improvable with mods) 9.5/10 ~ Phenomenal ------------------------ 10/10 ~ MASTERPIECE [with mods] No joke. Absolutely serious. With a delicate combination of mods, Skyrim can literally become perfect. Remove the faults. BAM. Done. EpicSouls (Sam)

review: this is an old game...i know alright, but for testing the new reccomend system on steam, i just review it a little bit for you who probably never played this game before :D alright, this game set 200 years after oblivion at a region called Skyrim, where the land of Nords and the ancient Dragons, Dragons on skyrim already gone for hundreds of years, but in this game unfortunately the dragons come back and search for revenge, that's the main plot of this game. for the gameplay it self....well, if you ever played morrowind or oblivion before, the gameplay of this game kinda the same, noting particularly improve from the combat mechanic, but Bethesda made some improvement into the battle style, like in oblivion you can't really do dual wielding, in this game you can use magic on your left hand and sword on your right hand, or the otherwise, or forget the magic and use shield on it, or if you want to be a badass use different magic on each hand. probably the most improvement that i like from this game is the "realistic" leveling up system, i don't know why most "hardcore" or "old school" gamer don't like this, but i think this is a great idea, like in real world, more often you using something (ex sword) you can get better at it. the environtment really beautiful, everything is really detail you can walking for hours just to admire the environtment on this game one of the drawback from this game probably the storyline, i do agree the storyline in this game really shallow, it's not bad, but not as deep as i expect it, in fact its really shallow, theres no particularly exciting events on the storyline as its go, hell, even the final quest really easy, dissapointing and anti-climax. and another drawback from this game is the guild system, theres so many guild in this game like thief, dark brotherhood, the companion, etc, but theres no real connection beetween them, and theres 2 faction on this game, its the stormcloacks and the imperial, what funny is, if you choose imperial you will not have any negative effect whatsoever, you can still roaming around freely on stormcloacks city, even if you using the imperial armor as well. If you doing that on TES 3 Morrowind the guards will attack you until you died. the vinal verdict is 9/10, its still a really great game, i love all the improvement on this game, i enjoy the combat system, the environtment, the side quest, but if they can improve a little bit on the storyline and storytelling system , and improve the connection beetween guild and faction this game will get 10/10 from me and theres a lot of modder that make mod for this game, and until now the community still active, theres mod for adding more armor, weapon, place even quests, you will get hundreds of additional time to play with these mods

game-hours: 54.4
review: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is an epic open world fantasy RPG that on it's own is average to below average at best. Skyrim is fairly similar to all past Elder Scrolls games. Big difference is they mudded up every menu for controllers and they made everything dual wieldable. Of course the graphics are better and now you're in Skyrim, so different quests, but most remains the same. The main thing that really makes me not reccomend it is how shallow the game and world feel. The world revolves around you and doesn't seem to live on its own. The Gta games are a good example of games that have alive worlds. You always seem like the focus of everybody and all the NPCs are so lifeless. Another thing that really doesn't feel good is the combat. Now the magic combat for the most part feels fine, the melee combat however is quite poor. The animations feel odd, maybe too fast, and weapons never feel like the connect with the target (Unless you get one of those rare finisher moves). The quests in the game are fairly good for the most part, however they never seem rewarding or interesting to finish, you just get some sword or magic cloak that gives you better stats in the end. For the base game I would really only rate this about a 6/10. If I would compare it to anything it would be an ocean about the depth of a kiddy pool. It's big, huge even, but everything you do is kinda meh, or the same. So after all that average or below average nay say on the game why do I reccomend it? Because Bethesda pretty much knows all this, and so does the community. Together they joined forces and created the wonder that is FULL MOD SUPPORT. Seriously, this game is like a PC gamer's modding heaven. Practically everything I've stated above is fixable and changeable with the help of even just a few mods. I will warn you though, modding this game is pretty much just as compelling as making your own freaking game. Bethesda layed the ground work in the base game, now it's your turn to make Skyrim YOUR game. With mods, game gets a 10/10, because it's pretty much everybody's perfect RPG. Only thing that limits you is the amount of time you want to spend modding. The only mod I can say every single person needs to install no matter what is SkyUI, seriously screw that bloody controller optimised UI. It even sucks on controllers.

game-hours: 158.4
review: Ok I am not even sure where to start with this game. If you have played Morrowind or Oblivion, dont bother reading this, you should already own this and all its DLC and if you don't, I have no idea whats wrong with you, so to the review: Graphically this game is absurd. If you have a PC that can support this game at its highest settings, download the HI RES DLC pack (its free on Steam from Bethesda) and pack on some free mods from Steam or Nexus, this game blows anything away you could ever see, and its going on 3 years old by now. Even if you are scared of mods or are not sure how to use them, this game can still look breathtaking. You will have your glitches that happen off and on (if you are familar with this franchise, you know what I am talking about) and sometimes things will go south and may even cause a nice crash to desktop. Just remember the F5 key is your best friend in this game, and set that autosave to everytime you open any menu and a nice 10-15 minute timer so you never really get screwed as bad. When it comes to sound, this game one of the best soundtracks I have ever heard. I absolutely love the opening score, the serene music that plays at times in towns, shops, or even out and about in the world as you are taking in the beautiful environments and that amazing looking moon in the night sky. Voice acting is fantastic, although at times glitchy, and repetitive. There are mods you can get to overhaul the dialogue (especially with the guards) so you dont find yourself hearing the same dopey comment from the guard that you can smite with but a shout. I also wish they went ahead and paid more voice actors for this game as i hear the same damn voice for far too many NPCs. The only exceptions are the really rare or important NPCs, and even then some get repeated. Overall, I can sit with this game up on the menu if I am busy with other things or whatever, and relax to the music going on in the background. Jeremy Soule did an amazing job with this score and I cannot wait to see more from him in the next Elder Scrolls game. Gameplay and Story will be the last thing I touch on in this somewhat lengthy review. If you are still with me, good, this is where it counts for most RPGs. The story is very well written. You are a Dragonborn, one of very few descendants of Dragons themselves, you posses the power to speak as them, using what is called the "Thu'um." You are quested with figuring out what is going on with the sudden rise of the Dragons that have not been seen in centuries, and trying to stem a civil war between the Imperials of Cyrodil, and the Stormcloak Rebellion of Skyrim. One of the best things about this game is you do not even have to really touch the main story to fully enjoy this game. There are hundreds and hundreds of quests between the two major DLCs (Dragonborn and Dawnguard) and the mod community on PC just opens this up even more with Bethesda giving gamers control of their development tool kit. That does not even touch the quests from the base game. I can literally spend about 2-3 minute scrolling thru my quest log of every single quest I have completed in the 150+ hours I have played this, and STILL find more to do! I personally loved the storyline behind the Dark Brotherhood and some fun throwbacks to that guild from Oblivion. (Pay close attention to that Spectral Assassin you can summon!) The expansions brought some amazing stories with the addition of seeing a few more planes of Oblivion (Soul Cairn and Apocrypha) and also becoming a vampire or werewolf, which themselves have their own perks, as well as their own pros and cons. The control scheme is pretty fluid and quite easy to play. I recommend sticking with a mouse and keyboard as the primary control scheme. The controller is an option, but with the added option of the Console Commands for the PC, its best to stick with original PC control scheme. I had no real complaints with the controls except for the quick menu. My god was this a pain in the . You literally would pause the game every single time you changed weapons, spell,shouts, powers, whatever. I FULLY recommend SKYSE and SKY UI. These can be found on Nexus Mod Manager and if you don't know how to do anything with Mods, a great Brit named "Gopher" has a lot of great videos uploaded on how to do a lot with this game and its mods. Google it. The Sky UI overlays a better UI for the player, and doesnt interrupt Skyrims original UI. It DOES require SKYSE to run, but this makes all the world of difference just for the fact that you get gear slots you can assign to specific buttons/keys. I set keys 1-8 for my gear sets and its great using ranged until something gets close and just hitting a 4 and immediately going melee. You can even assign specific shouts or powers to those gear sets. Very well done mod. With all this being said, i cannot recommend this game enough. You can see how many hours I have put into it, and I havent had it for the PC that long. I put in nearly 300 hours on the Xbox 360 and I STILL find new things and have a great time playing this game. If you have a decent PC, built with some of the higher end VGAs and CPUs, this game runs like a dream on the PC compared to ANY OTHER SYSTEM OUT THERE. I can go from starting this game to in it, in less than 2 minutes. On the Xbox 360, this was more like a 5-7 minute ordeal, with far too many lengthly loading screens in between zones(I also experienced many many crashes on the console version at loading screens). Even with some of the negative things I may have mention here, I have to give this game a solid 10/10. You come to expect the glitches, crashes, etc. when it comes to Bethesda games (look at Fallout 3 and NV) so to me it is not worth factoring that too much into the score. I have never had this game crash on me or have any major glitches to the point where it pissed me off and I did not want to play anymore. Buy the Legendary Edition, for the price it is at, it is very much worth it!!

game-hours: 54.5
review: Do not kill the chicken... 10/10
game-hours: 3581.6
review: Well, I have over 2,000 hours into this game, and am still finding new things in it every time I play. It has a lot of content. Overall appearance: 9/10. Bethesda has hands down, the best landscapers in the business. Each generation of their franchise has always been the benchmark for this, and with good reason. The character models on the other hand, could still use some improvement. FaceGen, while innovated when it came out, still has the same bugs it was released with, and these bleed over into any game that uses the technology. Combat mechanics: 6/10. While utilitarian in nature, they mostly get the job done... mostly. While the game gives you that feel of combat with staggering, weapons bouncing off shields and the overall grittiness of it, there are many things left to be desired. Simple things like being able to hotkey a sword and shield, or two swords to a single key. This becomes extremely immersion breaking and annoying when you have to use a spell and then stop, open your inventory and select an item to re equip. There is no excuse for this, save sloppy programming. Quality Control: 2/10. Or... Bugs: 10/10. As usual, Bethesda fails to disappoint with the sheer number of bugs they provide their customers with. While their landscape artists are the best around, their programmers are the worst. One was even quoted as boasting about writing the longest shader script ever. That's like bragging about coming in last at the Special Olympics. So yeah, Bethesda once again outdoes every company in the industry with its award winning bugs. No, they will never be fixed. They never have been fixed, and most of them can be traced clear back to Morrowind. Yup... same bugs, cut and pasted from engine revision to engine revision. They attempted to fix an issue with the dragons with their first patch, which broke them even more. Their solution was to remove their fix and leave them alone. The only bug fixed was their water. It took several attempts, but they finally did get it right. Content: 8/10. There is a lot to do in a TES game. While some people play the main quest and call it good, others will attempt to find everything in the game world. It's worth it, even if most of the quests feel short and relatively unfinished with no full closure. Still, even now while running around, I will find NPCs I never encountered before who have something to do. And then there is the lore. You can spend countless hours reading the books in game, many of which are absolutely awesome. What makes TES games have such staying power is their modding communities. Without them, the games' longevities would be severely shortened. So grab the game. Play it through until you get bored, then hit up some of the modding sites and start perusing. There's something for everyone out there.

game-hours: 16.6
review: This game is addicting. I am picky and I love RPG games that have a midievil feel to them. What really gets me hooked it the ability to mod this. I can not only play the game, but I can build off of it for a truly custom experience to make it look and play how I want it to. It enables me to truly immerse myself in the game how I want to be immersed and enjoy the lore, storyline, and general gameplay. I'm not typically into one-player games, but this has to be my favorite now. The graphics are amazing, the lore is extensive, the gameplay (fighting, weapons, training, skills, skill tree) is easy enough to pick up but gets very complicated in higher levels which really makes you think about what you're doing. The mods are a pleasure, and with the Nexus Mod Manager, easy to implement and manage, even if you have to rebuild your Data install.

review: The Elder Scrolls are back. I renamed them to "The Elder Addiction V" though. Why? Because it instantly draws into you it's world. game-hours: 539.0
review: It's a great game, but some things to note about mods. 1: Don't get your mods from the workshop, just get the nexus mod manager, and download mods from the nexus. 2: If your getting over 80 FPS, Install a texture mod, and an ENB, If it's too much too handle, replace the ENB with a lighting mod. 3: on the topic of lighting, don't get the realistic lighting overhaul, it is an incredibly poorly optimized mod, get ELFX. 4: DON'T FAST TRAVEL! It seems like a pain in the , but it's worth it. 5: avoid mods with a lot of scripts, look up a mod before you use it. 6: avoid changing what mods you use, it causes problems, especially if you ignored tip number 5 when installing it Now your ready to mod the game, and you know more than most idiots who mod already!

review: I have 350 hours in morrowind, 150 in Oblivion, 75 or so in Daggerfall (which I am old enough to have played first as a 17 year old. I played Morrowind modded to hell so long I forgot what vanilla looked like. The story, concept art, silt striders. DLC let us off some gods. Dark elves were awesome..unlike the non dunmer in daggerfall (didn't find andyfall till much later). By the time oblivion came out i couldnt afford a rig so XBOX it was.. I liked oblivion, put in some time and did all the dlc..1000 achievments on xbl. Then Skyrim... Put in close to 150 hours. Thought I loved it. Then realized I was choring my way thru the dlc. The drab gray EVERYTHING on muddy textures..that pop left and right, was depressing me. The game was huge. I havent even touched all the small stuff.. Fast traveled everywhere and leveled stamina and sprinted thru every dungeon with a warrior hacking on easy. Then I built a rig. Just got this 3 days ago and already hit 24 hours. Playing a rogue thief. Running 35 or so graphics mods. WOW. Bethesda should be ashamed...or SHOULD THEY?? I dont have bash, nmm, or any manager. I subscribed to mods thru steam. Didnt touch the load order. Runs almost perfect. (if I alt tab it sometimes crashes a bit later on loading screen exit) Skyrim in color made a huge diff. Now it is alive with sights and sounds. I horse ride everywhere (faster vanilla horses mod). sneak thru dungeons admiring the added skill needed with the lighting overhauls. If you cant see use a torch or magelight.. PC is the way to game. My laptop is under 1500 and runs most everything on max at decent fps. Thru big pic with 360 pad on the 60 is great. Now that skyrim wasn't adding to my winter blues with more winter blues any longer I can enjoy this game for what it is. A commercially made artistic tour de force with unlimited gameplay due to the fact that BETHESDA REALIZES that mod support is essential, as it will always happen. It allows them to add bredth to the game and stay in budget. How many beautiful looking games max out at 25 hours gameplay? They make the best games look pretty good and allow the free help to perfect them. The symbiosis has been essential ever since Abdrew Polis decided that Barenziah wasn't dunmer enough and guards should ride horses up stairways in shacks...

game-hours: 386.1
review: Best game of all time. i rate 8/8
game-hours: 88.3
review: Skyrim is critically acclaimed by many and put down by others, I am torn between these opinions and take a stand in the middle. This game obviously has a lot of work put in, the world is huge, terrain is fairly varied and the list of quests and side-missions is endless, but is it a good game? There are lots of areas where it does not satisfy, visually it is nothing special, many of the quests are just plain boring, dialogue is unnatural and the voice acting is pretty bad. The combat is clunky, stealth is poorly implemented and enemies are stupid. In general it feels rushed and shoddily-made. But there is something about going out and adventuring, finding loot, using spells, taking on dragons and engaging in hand-to-hand or long range combat that is fun and exciting. Now I know from past experience that enjoying Skyrim can be difficult. On my first character I didn't really focus on any particular skill tree and I used a mix of spells, one handed weapons and stealth, I quickly became bored of this because I didn't feel any sense of progression and I wasn't especially good at anything, just an all-rounder. After this save I would have told you that Skyrim was terrible. But more recently I have made a wood elf, focused on archery and sneaking and I'm having a lot of fun. I even find myself using fur armour when I have superior elven armour just because I prefer looking like a hunter than a gaudy warrior. This level of customization and personalisation is something you need to work out for yourself to get the most out of Skyrim but after this you won't be able to help but love it, despite its many flaws and bugs, it's just plain fun. In conclusion, I wouldn't argue that Skyrim was an especially good game, but what it doesn't deliver on quality and story it more than makes up for in entertainment value.

game-hours: 53.9
review: Despite being over 3 years old now, I still find myself coming back to Skyrim even after my longest breaks from it. I originally played it on a PS3, and I completed a good portion of what the game has to offer (Main questline, all side quests, tons of miscellaneous ones as well) and it quickly went on my list of having been one of the best games I have ever played. In fact, having enjoyed it so much, I scavenged enough money to buy the Legendary edition of Skyrim on Steam while it was on sale. I knew I wouldn't get a chance like it until next year's Summer Sale, so I quickly seized the opportunity. The vast amount of content included in this game is essentially unmatched by any game to this date, and even though it is only a "single player" game, it is so immersive that you feel like YOU are actually the warrior delving into a deep dungeon, or the thief in pursuit of his/her next victim to rob. The best part of it is, even when you have finally come close to "finishing" Skyrim by completing the DLC quests and stock quests, there are mods that enhance the game experience to a whole new level making it nearly never ending. The modding community in this title is still going strong from what I am aware of, and some mods can entail hours upon hours of new gameplay. If you have not yet tried Skyrim, I would HIGHLY recommend it. If you are unsure about purchasing it due to fears of no replay value after completing the storyline, fear not. It is an excellent game, arguably one of the best of the generation; capable of giving you several hundred hours of gameplay. Hopefully this will aid in someone's decision to purchase the game, and if so, I wish you luck.

review: My prelimenary opinion would be that this game is even more awesome than the ones that came before. I was a big gamer when it came to Oblivion and I do miss some of the pleasant features of that game in the Skyrim gameplay. Luckely, in my opinion, the conversationwheel was parted with. A big plus for Skyrim is the smithing-feature as are the dragons obviously and the Medieval, Scandinavian, mythological feeling in-game. Regarding to the use of magic, I think it was a great move on the part of the developpers to go with these 'shouts'...very well done. Each factions, race, etc. is now even more diverse than in previous games. A big point of critique is that Bethesda still has a lot men and women in the game talking in the same voice (but of course it is obvious as to why that is so). The vanilla world map could use some improvement, if you are against using mods for this. As a big fan over the series, I think a 9 out of 10 (with Oblivion being 8,5 and Morrowind a 7) is an appropriate mark for The Elder Scrolls V Skyrim.

review: Skyrim is truly a must own game, one that goes down as one of the best of all time. I'm sure though that you probably know this already, and are looking to buy it on your own, and if you don't already own this game, you really should. Welcome to Skyrim, a world were nord fantasy and dragons aboad. Here, magic wizards and sorcerers live, only to be lost in defeat to the returned dragons. Now, all that is the armys of Skyrim, waging war on both eachother and the dragons that have come. You, a prisoner in the crossfire of these wars, is destined to defeat the dragons and restore the Skyrim world. Though in Skyrim, you may choose another path. Like most open world games, your options aren't limited to one path. You can choose from the evil of the world, or the conquering of the world. Here, you can wander steep slopes, vast tundra, large bodies of water, and even slay dragons. All the while, you collect several items and other incredible peripherals known as "shouts". The more you play, the more you just get pulled in. Not to mention the modding community for the game is beyond massive, and the people who do make these mods create THOUSANDS of extra hours of content, and that is trimming it down to just a slim portion. Simply put, Skyrim is one off the best games ever made, EVER. A must own for any gamer, and for the price, it would be a sin not to buy.

game-hours: 115.7
review: Got bored with Skyrim today, yes, it is possible, after 100 hours, I had stopped the dragon uprising, slaughtered a castle of vampires, killed an ageless dragonborn, wiped out a dark brotherhood base, collected the seven black books, helped a dead guy finish his book, collected the dragon priest masks, helped the empire crush the stormcloak army, downloaded some mods, made my own house and got it fully furnished, got Wabbajack, and several other artifacts of the like, which I shortly thereof dropped, had not just a dragon working for me, but also had a zombie dragon, and a skeleton horse, and also many other little quests, and made Skyrim a better place. So how to finish with a bang, even through I easily had over fifty more objectives left? Used console commands to make my guy level 80, to face the Ebony Warrior. He was...Odd. His talk of a lack of quests or villains to slay runs parallel to anyone who put WAY to much time into this game, and he wished me to kill him, battle to the death on a mountain-side. After climbing up, and finding that he killed a frost troll with a shout, I decided I was out of my league, and turned on immortailty mode. Not the mode with the super strength though, I wanted to have fun. Although, I also learned that my console "kill" command would just heal him to full health. My zombie dragon and his summoned monsters helped weaken him, but I would not be able to shout for a while, so, with my ebony blade in one hand, and Dawnbreaker in the other, I hacked at him, and hacked at him, and he choped my head off. Due to the immortailty, my guy was alive, but now instead of a head, he had a bloody stump at the end of his neck. I stated searching the ground for my head, hopefully it hadn't rolled very far, and I found it, laying there, helmet and all, bloody gore at it's base matching my hero's neck. It was unfortunate that I couldn't pick it up, because I would have probably thrown it at the Ebony Warrior. I loaded a pre-decapitation save, and climbed the mountain-side, again, and tryed this again, warry of a headless future like so many running chickens. summoning my sidekick after a while, I resorted to my Dwarven crossbow to deal out the damage from afar, only to learn of the Warrior's paralyzing arrows. It is a curious feeling, laying on the ground in a mid-stride postion, incapable of movement, as your sidekick is taught the meaning of pain, and the Ebony Warrior heals himself, and I also learned that his blade had health sapping capabilities, he healed as he tried to kill me. After my shout meter was ready, I called a storm, lightning, rain, wind, the works. You would think being stuck by lightning five times within three minutes would slow a man down, but not this one. Even with a small cloud of electricity circling him. Did I mention he beat my dragon? and he continued to use his shouting, and I was watching as my warrior went tumbling down the side of the mountain, limp as a sloth dropped from twenty thousand feet. As my hero got to his feet, and climbed the mountain, I might as well mention the stuff this guy was saying to me, asking me to hit him harder, and the like, so after the storm wore off, he still wasn't dead, in fact he healed quite a bit, and the scorch marks, arrows and tiny spears, bolts, weapons from the dragon's allies, and that dead troll, we did quite a bit of damage. If I fought this guy in Whiterun where I met him, we might have killed as many people as the game would let us, and also have amassed a small hill of dead guards. Finally, after about twenty or such dwarven bolts in his body, the Ebony Warrior fell, joy was with him as he cried out about his reward. I then proceeded to steal whatever item of value I wanted from his corpse, I was curious as to why he had two hearts (daedra, and human) and I also liberated him of his flawless dimond and items of the liken. I found it raceist when I removed his helmet to find him most likely a former resident of Hammerfall. And I also took the time to shout at his corpse. I saved the game, and quit to desktop. I; had finished my Skyrim experince. Untill the Skywind mod is out.

game-hours: 298.5
review: Yes. Get it.
game-hours: 2490.7
review: Many old-school Elder Scrolls fans will tell you, no matter how much you say otherwise, that the best game in the Elder Scrolls series was, without a doubt, Morrowind. They will cite long and lengthly arguments using the fact that your choices had real weight and could actually effect your ability to play the game. Skyrim doesn't quite go that far, but what is does do, it does so quite beautifully. First off; there is a civil war brewing in Skyrim as the game opens. The best part of this whole thing is that neither side is completely right and neither side completely wrong; a situation that is very close to how things would work in reality. A quick synopsis (because I do so love Elder Scrolls' Lore): The High Elves and Wood Elves have reformed the Aldmeri Dominion (a group from Nirn's Second Era) after the Oblivion Crisis believing that the Empire had abandoned Summerset Isle during the events taking place in Oblivion. In the two centuries that follow Oblivion, the Empire has begun to crumble due to internal strife and the Empire's inability to police itself. Morrowwind is in disarry due to a slave uprising in Black Marsh (now called Argonia) as well as the erruption of the Red Mounted which destroyed Vvardenfell and a fair portion of Morrowind and Elswyer and Valenwood have both seceded from the Cyrodiilic Empire. The Dominion began planning to make moves against the Empire and, when the Empire refused to their terms, the Dominion attacked them which led to The Great War. In order to end the war, the Empire signed a document called the White Gold Concordat which said that the Empire would give up Talos worship (the Dominion decreed that Talos is a man, not a Divine and his worship is sacrilege) Shortly after which Hammerfell renounced the Empire and severed all ties to Cyrodiil. During the 4 years of war, the Forsworn attacked Markarth and claimed it as their own and had even gon so far as to go through the correct channles to become their own province. One year after the war was over, Ulfric Stormcloak makes the move to reclaim Markarth. In return, Stormcloak asks for free reign to worship Talos; a request the Empire grants him in exchange for cleaning up the mess that is the Forsworn Uprising. However, the Dominion hears of this and quickly moves in.... Ulfric is captured, taken into custody, and stripped of his command. The Empire quickly renegs on the agreement (to placate the Dominion, more than anything), and outrages about half of Skyrim's Nord population; a situation which Ulfric quickly uses as a banner to rally around him those who believe that the Empire is a rapidly crumbling relic has betrayed the Nords with the the signing of White-Gold Concordat. Secondly, as if that is not enough, dragons suddenly begin appearing in Skyrim once again for the first time in over 5,000 years (it's actually 5,450 if you really want to split hairs). Throughout the game, dragons can, will, and usually DO crop up just about anywhere you could possibly imagine a dragon cropping up - just to mess with you sometimes. One of them, as a matter of fact, unwittingly prevents your execution and aids in your escape from the headsman's block as the game opens. ...and this is where YOU come into picture. As you go through talking to NPCs, you start to get a feel of what this whole Stormcloak Rebellion is doing to Skyrim in the eyes of it's citizens. For some, they see it as the death knell for an dying Empire that cannot hold itself together anymore. For others, they condemn the rebellion citing that the only thing keeping the Dominion at bay is the Emipire's unity. Again, nobody's 100% wrong, and npbody's 100% right. While you won't run into epic battlefields during your adventures, you will run into minor scuffles between groups of Stormcloak Rebels and the Imperial Legion which, in my opinion, is much better. I'd rather see the whole rebellion starting out as more of a moral dilemma than to have it relegated to just laying waste to enemy soldiers right out of the gate (if I wanted a game like that I'd play MoH or something similar). Now, there'll be times where you are walking along, minding your own business when suddenly, BAM! A dragon flying overhead sees you and decided come makes your life miserable (and possibly bring it to an abrupt halt in the process). The thing is that nowhere is safe from dragon attacks: you can be attacked as soon as you exit a cave, a ruin, fast travel, or even one of the houses you may own - IN A CITY! This randomness is, to me, the best part of the dragon storyline; which doesn't end when the questline does - they're still flying around out there and will still attack you. I'm not going to sit here and dote on controls or graphics since, with as many mods as are out there for Skyrim right now, you can alter things more to your personal tastes - no matter what they may be. I'm not even going to dote on the game itself since, let's be honest, there is nothing that I can say that probably hasn't already been said at least 10 times over. My bottom line was: is the story engrossing? I found it to be, yes. Are the key players in this story compelling? Again, I found them to be. I'll also confess, I was fanboying hard when I saw that there was going to be DRAGONS in Skyrim. I mean c'mon; it's Elder Scrolls! What more do we need to say?
game-hours: 104.9

review: This game is a masterpiece. The second you start your first adventure you will find yourself spending hours upon hours in the world of Skyrim. With that said, during my play through I rarely came across any and there are bug fix mods out there that can be installed to avoid these problems. game-hours: 75.3
review: Another great game of the Elder Scrools series. Skyrim is much more than just another RPG, it is a deep, packed and customizable roleplaying experience. Whats better than journeying through icy mountains, returning with a pile of loot, bring that pile to your home, then storing it and doing some redecorations to your House while your companion watches your back. And there is plenty to do, the world is simply huge and populated with all kinds of evil, whose goal it is to murder you in your sleep. The game has it's flaws, bugs and glitches are common, but much less than in Oblivion, and some gameplay elements feel a bit stale after a while, but that's why we have a massive modding community, which fixes and expands the world of Skyrim every day. To conclude, Skyrim is a enourmous game, with content that grasps you and after 20+ hours it is still hard to resist to this grasp, especially with a good modpack to iron out the missing stuff. 9/10

game-hours: 321.3
review: Epic!!!
game-hours: 98.1
review: Skyrim. What a weird game. When you first play it, you see the beautiful world, you fight your first dragon and great soundtrack plays while you accomplish your missions. You clear some good-looking dungeons, learn your first shouts, complete some sidequests and eventually visit the top of the world. You're the Chosen One, and you're on your quest to save Skyrim. But after playing more, you start to see problems. One of them is the fact that enemies level up as you do. To me it's a major flaw that completely destroys any feeling of progression. Then you notice that dungeons keep repeating and they all follow a similar pattern: throw in a bunch of Draugrs, hallways, ending room and a quick exit. Dragon fights become a chore after a fifth fight. No matter what you accomplish, the world and quests never change. Stop the Civil War? Nobody cares after 1 minute. Kill the almighty final boss of the game? Absolutely nothing changes. All of this shows how lifeless the entire world of Skyrim is. I enjoyed the game for roughly 50 hours, then I started to notice all of these problems. There were no mods back then, so all of my enjoyment was lost and after that I played the game just for the sake of finishing it and getting achievements. Overall, vanilla Skyrim is good game for 50 hours. After that it becomes boring and repetitive. Install mods to improve your experience.

game-hours: 98.1
review: Skyrim. What a weird game. When you first play it, you see the beautiful world, you fight your first dragon and great soundtrack plays while you accomplish your missions. You clear some good-looking dungeons, learn your first shouts, complete some sidequests and eventually visit the top of the world. You're the Chosen One, and you're on your quest to save Skyrim. But after playing more, you start to see problems. One of them is the fact that enemies level up as you do. To me it's a major flaw that completely destroys any feeling of progression. Then you notice that dungeons keep repeating and they all follow a similar pattern: throw in a bunch of Draugrs, hallways, ending room and a quick exit. Dragon fights become a chore after a fifth fight. No matter what you accomplish, the world and quests never change. Stop the Civil War? Nobody cares after 1 minute. Kill the almighty final boss of the game? Absolutely nothing changes. All of this shows how lifeless the entire world of Skyrim is. I enjoyed the game for roughly 50 hours, then I started to notice all of these problems. There were no mods back then, so all of my enjoyment was lost and after that I played the game just for the sake of finishing it and getting achievements. Overall, vanilla Skyrim is good game for 50 hours. After that it becomes boring and repetitive. Install mods to improve your experience.

game-hours: 84.0
review: Best RPG I have ever played hands down! It's a "Must Get" and well worth the price.
game-hours: 92.3
review: A good RPG with a massive world and loads of quests to do. This would probably be the longest single player campaign-style game I played, because of it's extremely huge number of quests and story. However, it is plague-ridden by performance issues. ===== Pros: ===== A lot of quests -which would take probably at least a hundred hours or two to complete them all. Interesting quests -where you have to do something other than just killing mobs or collecting items and coming back. Wide variety of combat styles -which would suit everyone's preference. Interesting skill tree -a lot of abilities to skill No need for grinding to level up. -There're quests everywhere to help you level and keep you busy. Freedom. -You can do whatever quests you deem important first. Convenient travelling system. -Just need to visit a town once and you can teleport to there for subsequent visits. ===== Cons: ===== Crashes a lot -Game closes without any message when I alt-tab, or try to maximise the game back, very often (crash). -Game closes without any message when I try to save game, sometimes (crash). Long loading time / corrupt loading -Extreme loading screen timing sometimes (5 minutes). -Infinite loading screen or crash at one point. None of my save games or new game could load. I spent an hour trying to fix it and finally resorted to reinstalling the game, but the last save game still couldn't load. But luckily I managed to load the 2nd-last save game, but unluckily I had to waste 10 minutes replaying the part which was lost. Not very well optimized. -I'm forced to play in a lower resolution because it lags in my native resolution (1600x900). Not very smart AIs -AI allies don't follow you exactly. They will wait and have a slow bow-and-arrow fight with remaining enemies and swear to kill them no matter what, as if they killed their families. Therefore if you're planning to just run past a bandit camp, you can't do that if you have a housecarl following you, because they will be stucked there until the camp is all cleared. Bad UI design -Restrictive and inconvenient UI. Very hard to navigate around to find the item you need because they're so poorly organised. -Inconvenient weapons/spell switching. I know there is a "favorite menu" where you can choose the items you want to be on it and pressing Q to open it to access it, but there should be a quick-swap function which you can press just a single key to cycle through combinations of weapons or spells you have saved. Weight limit is very annoying -although I know there is a mod for removing it and I'm using that. A good RPG inventory system will only count weapons in the inventory limit and not miscellenous or potion items. Too many books. -If you're going to tell a story in an RPG, put it in a quest, not in a 10-page book, not to mention that there're probably more than 50 books in Skyrim which would take you longer to read than you read your school textbook. ======== Conclusion ======== An very interesting RPG filled to the brim with quests and story, but also laden with performance issues, inconvenient UI and other small annoying designs. ============== Overall rating: 7.5/10 ==============

game-hours: 237.4
review: Fallout, but better.
game-hours: 201.0
review: Ah, Skyrim, an over rated hack of a game! A complete atrocity to gaming; it's a real statement for the state of our collective intelligence that it was voted Game of the Year in 2011! Still play it, though. Let's list some of the many, many embarrassing flaws that will either have you rolling in laughter at how terribad the game is, or just end up frustrating you: -While I believe this has been patched now, many, MANY NPCs used to spawn with NO TEXTURES. They would be plain white - great for immersion if you believe Skyrim is set in a Russian winter! -This bug is still going strong in the game, and it'll break any sense of reality you have every single damn time. NPCs have a tendency to greet you after they kill you - the most ridiculous time this has happened is when a Forsworn killed me then asked 'who did this?'. -Constant crashes and freezes! This one speaks for itself. -The Unofficial Skyrim Patch contains THOUSANDS of minor fixes. Bethesda apparently missed every single little detail in it! Wow, quality control or what? -The story is bloody awful! 'Big dragon is threat, go kill big dragon'. Points for originality, guys. Now don't tell me it's unique because the 'dragons are coming' back - I can think of plenty of other stories that do the same thing, except better (cough A Song of Ice and Fire cough). -A lifeless world! The dungeons you visit consist of the most generic copy & paste content imaginable. When was the last time you cleared a Dwemer dungeon without also encountering some Falmer? Let's not also overlook the fact that there isn't a single interesting NPC out there, with the exception of maybe a few of the Daedric Princes and M'aiq the Liar... even he's watered down in this, though. -No choice! After having adapted to Fallout New Vegas's excellent writing (in places) and the ability to choose to do whatever I wanted, I couldn't wait to see what choices would be presented to me in Skyrim. Er... about the extent of it was 'Stormcloak or Imperial', both utterly ambiguous factions which I couldn't relate to in the slightest. In fact, I wanted to wipe them both out. -While there's a lot more to cover, I'll end on a nitpick. You're the 'Dovahkiin' - 'Dragonborn'. Except, your not. Your character has nothing to do with dragons except the fact he absorbs dragons souls like the Grim Reaper or something. What the  makes him a Dragon'born'? I rate Skyrim a 0/10. However, in comparison to a lot of titles out there, yeah, I can see why it won Game of the Year 2011. Gaming is pretty ed. You'll enjoy it for the first 10-20 hours (which is undeniably pretty good), but after that you'll fall asleep. Don't worry - mods to the rescue! I've never seen such an extensively modded game. Modders, go enhance a game that's decent to begin with, for crying out loud!
game-hours: 201.0

This one speaks for itself. -The Unofficial Skyrim Patch contains THOUSANDS of minor fixes. Bethesda apparently missed every single little detail in it! Wow, quality control or what? -The story is bloody awful! 'Big dragon is threat, go kill big dragon'. Points for originality, guys. Now don't tell me it's unique because the 'dragons are coming' back - I can think of plenty of other stories that do the same thing, except better (cough A Song of Ice and Fire cough). -A lifeless world! The dungeons you visit consist of the most generic copy & paste content imaginable. When was the last time you cleared a Dwemer dungeon without also encountering some Falmer? Let's not also overlook the fact that there isn't a single interesting NPC out there, with the exception of maybe a few of the Daedric Princes and M'aiq the Liar... even he's watered down in this, though. -No choice! After having adapted to Fallout New Vegas's excellent writing (in places) and the ability to choose to do whatever I wanted, I couldn't wait to see what choices would be presented to me in Skyrim. Er... about the extent of it was 'Stormcloak or Imperial', both utterly ambiguous factions which I couldn't relate to in the slightest. In fact, I wanted to wipe them both out. -While there's a lot more to cover, I'll end on a nitpick. You're the 'Dovahkiin' - 'Dragonborn'. Except, your not. Your character has nothing to do with dragons except the fact he absorbs dragons souls like the Grim Reaper or something. What the  makes him a Dragon'born'? I rate Skyrim a 0/10. However, in comparison to a lot of titles out there, yeah, I can see why it won Game of the Year 2011. Gaming is pretty ed. You'll enjoy it for the first 10-20 hours (which is undeniably pretty good), but after that you'll fall asleep. Don't worry - mods to the rescue! I've never seen such an extensively modded game. Modders, go enhance a game that's decent to begin with, for crying out loud!

review: Skyrim....Hm...It is not as good as I hoped it is. But dont get blinded about that, it is still a really great game. The Game itself is really entertaining. The world is not colorful so often. More like a boring grey, but you have to remember : THIS GAME IS FULL MODABLE. And this is the amazing stuff what Skyrim makes so great. That you can mod as much as you want. You can "design" your own Skyrim. From the little Flowers to the huge Mountains and Dragons. The Fighting System is really cool, so is the Stealth System. It is one of my favourite Elder Scrolls Game besides Morrowind. As an Elder Scrolls fan you should not even think about buying this game. Just do it. No regrets, no doubt about it. 9,5/10

review: This game, eventhough it has a few glitches, is an almost perfect game, I say "almost" because the length of the main story isnt that long, but the amount of side quests and all the things you can become involved in is pretty numerous. The graphics are outstanding, the music is amazin which adds to the "epicness" of the game. You will never play a game made before this that has a more interactive combat system. Because of the creation kit, players can create homes, towns, dungeons, quests, weapons, armor, accesories, alter crafting, even change the overall look of the game world itself. Worth every penny.

game-hours: 198.8
review: What can I say about Skyrim that hasn't already been said? If you own a PC and like video games you need to play Skyrim, it's just that simple. Skyrim (and the previous elder scrolls games) are a large part of video gaming history. They created and perfected multiple genres of gaming that we see in many triple-A titles today. To be honest, if you consider yourself an intelligent gamer, you just don't know games unless you have played one of the Elder Scrolls titles. Skyrim, or its predecessor Oblivion, would be on anyone's list of all-time best games. The storyline is complex and interesting; the world is huge and immersive; the combat is challenging, varied, and fun; and the amount of hours of fun that you can get out of this game is more than worth the full-price. If all of that wasn't enough, on the PC you can dowload literally hundreds of free mods that can completely change how it plays. You want to be a dragon-man? You can! You want to create your own spells? You can! Do yourself a favor and buy this game!
